title: 74-year-old woman with symptomatic monomorphic ventricular tachycardia from the
chief_complaint: Symptomatic wide complex tachycardia.
history: 74-year-old woman with a history of hypertension on antihypertensive medication. She had no history of structural heart disease or tobacco or alcohol use.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: Initial ECG showed monomorphic VT with a right bundle branch block pattern, a Q wave in lead V1, left superior axis deviation, and ventriculoatrial dissociation, suggesting an exit site in the posteromedial papillary muscle region of the left ventricle. Baseline transthoracic echocardiography revealed an LV end-diastolic dimension of 62 mm and an LV ejection fraction of 26%. Cardiac CT showed no significant coronary stenoses or structural heart disease. During endocardial mapping, intracardiac electrograms demonstrated fractionated potentials around the posteromedial papillary muscle with earliest activation (-40 ms), and bipolar voltage mapping showed no scarring (0.5-1.5 mV). Intraprocedural intracardiac echocardiography (ICE) was used for real-time LV visualization, recorded an inaudible steam pop during the first ablation, and confirmed no immediate perforation or tissue defects. Post-procedure, transthoracic echocardiography showed no evidence of mitral regurgitation or tissue defects. At 2-month follow-up, echocardiography showed improved LV ejection fraction to 50% and decreased LV end-diastolic dimension to 52 mm, but identified a 26x9 mm pseudoaneurysm at the base of the LV posteromedial papillary muscle without pericardial effusion.
diagnosis: Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia originating from the posteromedial papillary muscle region of the left ventricle, complicated by tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy.
treatment: Initial attempts included electrical and pharmacological cardioversions, followed by a percutaneous left-sided stellate ganglion block with bupivacaine, all of which were unsuccessful. Definitive treatment was radiofrequency catheter ablation of the posteromedial papillary muscle region using endocardial electroanatomical mapping (CARTO-3 system) and intracardiac echocardiography (ICE) for direct visualization, applying multiple circumferential ablations. The patient was referred to outpatient follow-up.
key_learning_points: Refractory ventricular tachycardia can arise from specific anatomical structures like papillary muscles, requiring precise electroanatomical mapping and ablation.
Tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy is a reversible condition that can improve with successful termination of the underlying arrhythmia.
Intracardiac echocardiography (ICE) is valuable for real-time visualization and safety monitoring during complex catheter ablation procedures.
Complications such as pseudoaneurysm formation can occur post-ablation, even in the absence of immediate signs of perforation, necessitating careful follow-up imaging.
description: 74-year-old woman with symptomatic monomorphic ventricular tachycardia from the posteromedial papillary muscle and tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy, successfully treated with radiofrequency catheter ablation, with subsequent pseudoaneurysm formation at the ablation site.
clinical_text:
A 74-year-old woman presented to the emergency department with symptomatic wide complex tachycardia in the absence of hemodynamic deterioration. On admission, electrocardiography demonstrated monomorphic VT with a right bundle branch block pattern, a Q wave in lead V1, left superior axis deviation, and ventriculoatrial dissociation, suggesting an exit site in the posteromedial papillary muscle region of the left ventricle (Figure 1A). Despite the patient undergoing electrical and pharmacological cardioversions, the VT remained unresponsive. The patient had a history of hypertension with antihypertensive drug use but no history of structural heart disease or tobacco or alcohol use. On the baseline examination, transthoracic echocardiography estimated LV end-diastolic dimension and LV ejection fraction to be 62 mm and 26%, respectively. Cardiac computed tomography (CT) revealed no significant stenotic lesions in the coronary arteries and no structural heart disease (Supplementary Figures 1A,B), indicating tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy.
Following admission to the cardiac intensive care unit, the patient underwent a percutaneous left-sided stellate ganglion block with bupivacaine, a cardiac sympathetic intervention suppressing sympathetic activity for controlling VT. However, the cardiac sympathetic intervention was unsuccessful. Given that the VT remained unresolved and the driving cause of electrical instability was unclear, radiofrequency catheter ablation was decided as the most appropriate treatment strategy. Endocardial electroanatomical mapping of the LV using a CARTO-3 system (Biosense Webster) was performed through both transseptal and retroaortic approaches using a multi-electrode catheter. The procedure was performed using intracardiac echocardiography (ICE) through a transseptal approach and viewing the LV structure in real-time. The ablation catheter was positioned through the retroaortic approach. During endocardial mapping, intracardiac electrograms showed fractionated potentials around the posteromedial papillary muscle with the earliest activation (-40 ms) (Figures 1B-D). Endocardial bipolar voltage mapping revealed no scarring (0.5-1.5 mV), and the activation map was consistent with an exit site in the posteromedial papillary muscle region. Under direct ICE visualization (Figure 2A), endocardial ablation using an irrigated-tip catheter (SmartTouch, Biosense Webster) and 40 W was applied to target the earliest site that showed the initial Q wave in the unipolar signal with 10-15 g of contact force (Figures 2B,C). During the first ablation, the VT was terminated for 30 s with an inaudible steam pop recorded by ICE (Figure 2D and Supplementary Video 1), and a sudden rise in electrical impedance was not noted. After confirming that no evidence of perforation or tissue defects were present in the first ablation site, multiple circumferential ablations were performed in the area surrounding the posteromedial papillary muscle without further steam pops. Repeated programmed electrical stimulation failed to induce VT following the ablation. Before the end of the procedure, the ICE operator confirmed that there was no evidence of procedure-related complications. The transthoracic echocardiography performed the next day showed no evidence of mitral regurgitation or tissue defects in the ablation sites (Figure 3A).
After 2 months of follow-up, the patient remained free of VT. Echocardiography showed improved LV systolic function with LV ejection fraction of 50% and a decreased LV size with LV end-diastolic dimension of 52 mm, but a pseudoaneurysm (26 x 9 mm) that has the ratio of the maximum diameter of the orifice to the maximum internal diameter of the cavity was lesser than 0.50 was identified at the base of the LV posteromedial papillary muscle where a steam pop had occurred without pericardial effusion (Figure 3B and Supplementary Video 2). The patient was asymptomatic; therefore, she was referred to the outpatient clinic for observational follow-up during the following year without anticoagulation or antiplatelet agents; the patient underwent no further interventions. One year later, cardiac CT revealed that the pseudoaneurysm that typically has a neck narrower than the diameter of the aneurysm remained present but showed no signs of a size change or other complications such as thrombus formation (Figure 3C).

title: 56-year-old female with initially resected Stage IA gallbladder carcinoma, compl
chief_complaint: A 56-year-old female presented with persistent upper abdominal and back pain, following a 3-month history of poor appetite, weight loss, and jaundice.
history: The patient is a 56-year-old female. Her medical history prior to the 3 months of constitutional symptoms (poor appetite, weight loss, jaundice) and abdominal pain is not described. She subsequently developed recurrent and metastatic gallbladder adenocarcinoma requiring multiple surgical and systemic treatments.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: Preoperative serum CA19-9 was 731.30 U/mL (normal range, 0-22 U/mL) on November 24, 2015. Postoperative CA19-9 decreased to 110.20 U/mL on March 23, 2016, but increased to 330.50 U/mL by September 23, 2016. On September 1, 2018, CA19-9 was >1000.00 U/ml, then decreased to 40.60 U/ml by November 16, 2018, and normalized by February 20, 2019.
imaging_description: Initial T2-weighted MRI showed gallbladder lesions. Recurrent MRI (Nov 2015) displayed a large mass in the gallbladder area and several soft tissue nodules in the lower segment of the common bile duct. Subsequent upper-abdomen enhanced MRI and chest CT scan (Oct 2017) confirmed new disease progression in the liver and lungs. Enhanced total abdominal CT scan (Sept 2018) revealed a 7.8 x 6.9 cm mass in the original gallbladder area (anastomotic stoma), accompanied by abdominal and retroperitoneal lymph node metastasis. Follow-up CT/MRI (Nov 2018) showed partial response with the mass shrinking to 5.2 x 3.1 cm, impressive reductions in lymph node size and number, and decreased pulmonary metastases with cavity formation. Diagnostic MRI (Feb 2019) showed complete resolution of the mass.
diagnosis: Initially diagnosed with Gallbladder Carcinoma (GBC) at pT1aN0M0, Stage IA. Recurrence was confirmed as moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma.
treatment: Surgical resection of the gallbladder was performed (Feb 2013), followed by no adjuvant therapy. After recurrence, a palliative operation was performed (Dec 2015), including total pancreectomy, splenectomy, subtotal gastrectomy, and partial hepatectomy. She then received three lines of chemotherapy: cisplatin plus S-1, gemcitabine plus capecitabine, and irinotecan plus oxaliplatin. Subsequently, apatinib 500 mg qd was administered (from Sept 2018), with a temporary suspension and dose/schedule adjustment (500 mg/d, 5 days on/2 days off) due to grade 2 hand-foot skin reaction and hypertension. Montmorillonite powder was prescribed for grade 2 diarrhea.
key_learning_points: Gallbladder carcinoma can recur and metastasize even after R0 resection and early-stage diagnosis.
Monitoring of CA19-9 is crucial for assessing disease progression and treatment response in gallbladder carcinoma.
Targeted therapies like apatinib can induce significant responses in advanced, refractory gallbladder carcinoma after failure of multiple chemotherapy regimens.
Management of adverse events, such as hand-foot skin reaction, hypertension, and diarrhea, is essential for maintaining treatment adherence and optimizing outcomes with targeted therapies.
description: 56-year-old female with initially resected Stage IA gallbladder carcinoma, complicated by recurrence and metastasis, achieved a complete response to apatinib after failing multiple chemotherapy regimens.
clinical_text:
In January 2013, a 56-year-old female complained of persistent pain in the upper abdomen and back; this followed a reported 3 months of poor appetite, weight loss, and jaundice. T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the upper abdomen revealed gallbladder lesions. A surgical resection of the gallbladder was conducted on February 28, 2013, after which her jaundice was resolved. Histologically, the lesion was composed of intraductal papillary neoplasms with high-grade intraepithelial neoplasia together with some complex fusion and focal carcinoma. With regards to radical surgery, a margin negative resection status (R0-status) was reached and no positive lymph node was found. Thus, the patient was diagnosed with GBC at pT1aN0M0, Stage IA. No further chemotherapy or radiotherapy was given after surgery. On November 23, 2015, an MRI displayed a large mass occupying the gallbladder area and several soft tissue nodules in the lower segment of the common bile duct. The patient then received a palliative operation on December 17, 2015, including a total pancreectomy, splenectomy, subtotal gastrectomy, and partial hepatectomy. The pathology was confirmed as moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. The preoperative serum CA19-9 was 731.30 U/mL (normal range, 0-22 U/mL) on November 24, 2015 (<PMC6856073_fonc-09-01180-g0001_L_1_1.webp>), and then postoperative level decreased to 110.20 U/mL on March 23, 2016. During the 6-month follow-up period from March 2016 to September 2016, the laboratory tests demonstrated a durable increase in the serum CA19-9 level (330.50 U/mL on September 23, 2016). The patient was then administered three lines of chemotherapy regimens due to disease progression or serious adverse events, which included cisplatin plus S-1, gemcitabine plus capecitabine, and irinotecan plus oxaliplatin in sequence (Table 1). During administration of these chemotherapies, new disease progression in the liver and lungs was first confirmed by an upper-abdomen enhanced MRI and chest CT scan in October 2017.
After seven cycles of the last chemotherapy regimen, the enhanced total abdominal CT scan on September 1, 2018, revealed a 7.8 x 6.9 cm mass located in the original gallbladder area (or the anastomotic stoma), accompanied by abdominal and retroperitoneal lymph node metastasis (Figures 2A1-A4). Meanwhile, the patient's serum CA19-9 level markedly elevated to >1000.00 U/ml. Accordingly, the efficacy was evaluated as systemic progression. After receiving written informed consent, we changed the regimen to apatinib at a dose of 500 mg qd in September 2018. Confirmed partial response (PR) was observed during CT and MRI re-examination within 2 months (November 16, 2018), with impressive reductions in both the numbers and size of the abdominal and retroperitoneal lymph node as well as the mass located in the anastomotic stoma, which shrunk to 5.2 x 3.1 cm (Figures 2B1-B4). Meanwhile, the density of the pulmonary metastases had considerably decreased with cavity formation. The levels of serum 19-9 significantly lowered to 40.60 U/ml. On February 20, 2019, the mass mentioned had reduced and vanished completely according to the diagnostic MRI (Figures 2C1-C4), and this was coupled with a normal level of serum 19-9. The patient experienced some side effects during treatment with apatinib, but no serious adverse events occurred. Anorexia (grade 1), fatigue (grade 1), and diarrhea (grade 2) were observed after 1 week of medication. Montmorillonite powder (3 g tid) was thus prescribed as indicated for the control and symptomatic relief of acute non-specific diarrhea. Hand-foot skin reaction and hypertension occurred after the first week of medication and aggravated to grade 2 after 2 weeks, which led to a 1-week suspension period of apatinib administration. The dose of apatinib was then reduced to 500 mg/d, and a 7-day treatment cycle of 5 days on followed by 2 days off was repeated. Hypertension normalized within 2 weeks following the administration of a combination of amlodipine (5 mg bid) and valsartan (40 mg bid). Meanwhile, the hand-foot skin reaction was also well-controlled after applying a fragrance-free cream that contains urea to keep hands and feet well-moisturized. No proteinuria, occult blood of feces, or decline in leucocyte count occurred. Although the levels of serum CA19-9 were slightly increased, the efficacy of PR was sustained for more than 10 months until the last reexamination (September 19, 2019), and this has since continued (Figures 2D1-D4,E1-E4). By the end of September 23, 2019, the administration of apatinib as single agent for maintenance therapy was continued and the duration of treatment reached almost 1 year with a satisfactory quality of life.

title: 37-year-old female post-AML allogeneic bone marrow transplant presented with a p
chief_complaint: Painless palpable mass in the left breast for 10 days.
history: A 37-year-old female was diagnosed with AML-M6 in April 2004, treated with chemotherapy and an allogeneic bone marrow transplantation in January 2006. At the time of breast mass presentation, she reported no other relevant previous or family histories.
presenting_symptoms: Painless palpable mass in the left breast
exam_findings: A 2.0x1.5 cm mass was palpated in the lower inner quadrant of the left breast.
labs: Complete blood count: WBC 2.9x10^9/l (neutrocytes 53.4%), RBC 1.94x10^12/l (HCT 72.0%), PLT 27x10^9/l. Liver function tests (February 2007): ALT 97 IU/l (normal 0-40), AST 186 IU/l (normal 0-40), Total Bilirubin 90.7 µmol/l (normal 2-25), Direct Bilirubin 40.8 µmol/l (normal 0-8), GGT 1,064 U/l (normal 0-50). Immunoglobulin IgG was 4,240 mg/ml (normal 723-1,685).
imaging_description: Breast ultrasound revealed a solid and hypoechoic mass in the left breast. Chest radiography showed no suspicious lung lesions, and liver ultrasound showed no suspicious liver lesions.
diagnosis: Granulocytic Sarcoma (GS) of the breast; Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD); Fungal pneumonia (cause of death).
treatment: Induction chemotherapy with retinoic acid and consolidation chemotherapy with MA regimen for AML-M6, followed by allogeneic bone marrow transplantation. Lumpectomy for the breast mass. Immunosuppression therapy for GVHD.
key_learning_points: Granulocytic sarcoma (chloroma) can be a manifestation of AML relapse in extramedullary sites, such as the breast, even after bone marrow transplantation.
Initial benign fine-needle aspiration results for a suspicious mass in a patient with a history of malignancy should prompt further pathological evaluation.
Allogeneic bone marrow transplant recipients are at risk for serious complications including graft-versus-host disease and opportunistic infections like fungal pneumonia.
description: 37-year-old female post-AML allogeneic bone marrow transplant presented with a painless breast mass, diagnosed as granulocytic sarcoma, complicated by GVHD and fatal fungal pneumonia.
clinical_text:
A 37-year-old female was diagnosed with AML-M6 by bone marrow aspiration and biopsy in April, 2004. The patient achieved complete remission following inducted chemotherapy with retinoic acid (45 mg/m2, days 1-28). Following a total of 8 cycles of consolidation chemotherapy with the MA regimen, the patient underwent allogeneic bone marrow transplantation in January, 2006.
In November 2006, the patient was admitted to the Department of Oncology (Jinhua Central Hospital, Jinhua, China) due to a painless palpable mass in the left breast that had been present for 10 days. The patient exhibited no other symptoms and had no relevant previous or family histories. A physical examination revealed a mass measuring 2.0x1.5 cm in the lower inner quadrant of the left breast. Ultrasound revealed a solid and hypoechoic mass, and fine-needle aspiration (FNA) identified the mass as a fibroma. No suspicious lesions were located in the patient's lungs by chest radiography or in the liver by ultrasound.
The complete blood count showed a WBC count of 2.9x109/l with 53.4% neutrocytes, a red blood cell count of 1.94x1012/l with 72.0% HCT and a PLT count of 27x109/l. Since the mass was diagnosed as a benign tumor by FNA, the patient underwent a lumpectomy under local infiltration anesthesia, despite having a low PLT count. The tumor was removed in November, 2006, and the pathological results revealed that the structure of the breast, which had been invaded by middle-sized diffuse lymphoid cells and fat tissue, was destroyed (<PMC3861586_OL-07-01-0145-g01_A_1_2.webp>). Immunohistochemical analysis revealed that the markers of MPO and LCA were positive and that those for CD68, CD79a and L26 were negative (<PMC3861586_OL-07-01-0145-g01_B_2_2.webp>). Following confirmation by histopathology, the patient was diagnosed with GS of the breast. The tests for liver function, performed in February, 2007, demonstrated that the levels for alanine aminotranferase, aspartate aminotransferase, total bilirubin, direct bilirubin and r-glutamyltransfarase were 97 IU/l, 186 IU/l, 90.7 mumol/l, 40.8 mumol/l and 1,064 U/l, respectively, with normal reference values of 0-40 IU/l, 0-40 IU/l, 2-25 mumol/l, 0-8 mumol/l and 0-50 U/l, respectively. The level of the immunoglobulin IgG protein subtype was 4,240 mg/ml (normal reference value, 723-1,685 mg/ml). The patient was diagnosed with graft-versus-host-disease (GVHD) and received immunosuppression therapy to protect the liver. However, the effect of the treatment was unsatisfactory and the patient succumbed to fungal pneumonia in June, 2007, without having received systemic chemotherapy or a second bone marrow transplantation. The relapse of the GS in the patient's breasts was not identified prior to mortality.
image_captions: (A) In case 2, mesenchymal tissues were packed into the tumor cells, arranged into a line and the fatty tissue was infiltrated at the edge of the tumor.
(B) Immunohistochemistry stain showing that MPO was markedly positive in the cell plasmid. (Hematoxylin and eosin staining; magnification, x200).

title: 74-year-old female with stress-triggered anginal chest pain, EKG changes, and tr
chief_complaint: A 74-year-old female presented to the Emergency Department with 10/10 midsternal pressure-like chest pain radiating to the left arm and associated with vomiting.
history: The patient has a past medical history of asthma and hypertension. She reported similar, less intense exertional chest pain episodes over the last four months. She had two prior episodes of chest pain (15 and 5 years ago) where coronary angiograms revealed normal coronaries, and she was told she had a 'temporary' disease.
presenting_symptoms: anginal chest pain (10/10 severity, midsternal, pressure-like)
similar prior exertional episodes (less intense, lasting minutes, over 4 months)
pain onset upon hearing about granddaughter's cancer diagnosis
exam_findings: Elderly woman in moderate distress due to pain, blood pressure 146/79 mmHg, other vital signs normal, bilateral basal crackles. Remainder of physical exam was normal.
labs: Complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel were within normal limits. Troponin was initially 2.68 and peaked at 16.08.
imaging_description: Initial EKG showed T wave inversions in leads I and aVL compared to a year prior. A repeat EKG showed dynamic T wave changes with new T wave inversions in all lateral leads. Chest X-ray showed cardiomegaly, central pulmonary vascular prominence, and mild atelectasis over the lung bases. Transthoracic echocardiogram revealed LVEF of 30-35%, moderate apical hypokinesis, moderate mitral regurgitation, and regional wall motion abnormalities (LVEF was 60-69% a year ago). Cardiac catheterization showed normal coronaries with apical ballooning and elevated left ventricular end diastolic pressure (LVEDP). A repeat transthoracic echocardiogram in 4 weeks showed recovery of LVEF.
diagnosis: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (with an initial working diagnosis of NSTEMI)
treatment: Loading doses of dual antiplatelet therapy, heparin drip, aspirin 81 mg, warfarin, ACE inhibitor, beta blocker, and a moderate-intensity statin.
key_learning_points: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy can mimic acute coronary syndrome (NSTEMI) with chest pain, EKG changes (T wave inversions), and troponin elevation.
Cardiac catheterization is crucial for diagnosis, revealing normal coronary arteries and characteristic left ventricular wall motion abnormalities like apical ballooning.
Emotional stressors are common triggers for Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.
Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is characterized by transient left ventricular dysfunction, with recovery of LVEF often seen within weeks.
description: 74-year-old female with stress-triggered anginal chest pain, EKG changes, and troponin elevation, diagnosed with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy after cardiac catheterization showed normal coronaries and apical ballooning.
clinical_text:
A 74- year -old female with a past medical history of asthma and hypertension presented to the Emergency Department with typical anginal chest pain, 10/10 in severity, midsternal, pressure like "someone sitting on my chest", radiating to the left arm, and associated with an episode of vomiting five hours prior to arrival. She also reported several similar prior episodes with exertion that lasted for a few minutes, over the last four months but were less intense. She stated that she started to have the pain upon hearing about her granddaughter's diagnosis of cancer.
Her cardiac history was significant for an episode of similar chest pain approximately fifteen years ago. She had a coronary angiogram done which revealed normal coronaries. She also had episodes of chest pain five years ago and had an abnormal nuclear stress test followed by a coronary angiogram, which showed normal coronaries as well. On both these occasions, the patient was supposedly told she had a "temporary" disease.
On admission, physical examination revealed an elderly woman in moderate distress due to pain with a blood pressure of 146/79 mmHg. Other vital signs were within the normal limit. Physical exam was also remarkable for bilateral basal crackles. Remainder of the physical exam was normal. Electrocardiogram (EKG) initially showed T wave inversions in leads I and aVL (Figure 1) when compared to her EKG a year ago (Figure 2). There were no ST elevations. A repeat EKG showed dynamic T wave changes with new T wave inversions in all the lateral leads (Figure 3). Chest X-ray (CXR) showed cardiomegaly, central pulmonary vascular prominence, and mild atelectasis over the lung bases (Figure 4). Labs including complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel were within normal limits. Troponin initially was 2.68 and peaked at 16.08. At admission, she received loading doses of dual antiplatelet therapy and was placed on a heparin drip for a non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). On risk stratification, she had a total InterTAK diagnostic score of 61 points, which made her have a 58.6% chance of having Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.
A transthoracic echocardiogram revealed a left ventricle ejection fraction (LVEF) of 30-35%, moderate apical hypokinesis, and moderate mitral regurgitation with regional wall motion abnormalities. She was known to have a normal LVEF of 60-69% a year ago.
Cardiac catheterization showed normal coronaries with apical ballooning (Figure 5) and an elevated left ventricular end diastolic pressure (LVEDP). She was treated with aspirin 81 mg, warfarin, ACE inhibitor, beta blocker, and a moderate-intensity statin prior to discharge. A repeat transthoracic echocardiogram in 4 weeks revealed recovery of her left ventricular ejection fraction.

title: A 20-year-old male with a history of schizophrenia presented with treatment-refr
chief_complaint: Hospitalization due to a relapse of psychotic manifestations, including auditory hallucinations, persecutory delusions, disorganized thoughts, and violent behaviors, following discontinuation of antipsychotic medication.
history: A 20-year-old unmarried male diagnosed with schizophrenia at age 17, who previously managed mild psychotic symptoms with paliperidone, experienced a relapse after discontinuing medication without medical consultation. He had no history of mental, genetic, or neurological disorders at his initial diagnosis, nor a family history of similar complaints. Additionally, he developed compulsive hand washing requiring the introduction of fluoxetine prior to the current admission.
exam_findings: Concealed left-side weakness and mild muscle rigidity were exhibited during hospitalization. Other neurological and physical examinations showed negative findings, and the patient maintained a stable gait and independent activities of daily living.
labs: Blood investigations for ceruloplasmin, vitamin D, calcium, magnesium, phosphate, thyroid and parathyroid hormone, and alkaline phosphatase showed no abnormalities. Genetic testing unveiled a deficit in the SLC20SA gene.
imaging_description: Brain computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed calcifications in the bilateral globus pallidus, caudate nucleus, thalami, and subcortical areas, with no evident vessel abnormalities. The calcifications were visualized in coronal, sagittal, and transverse planes on CT, and in the sagittal plane on MRI.
diagnosis: Fahr's disease, confirmed by genetic testing revealing a deficit in the SLC20SA gene.
treatment: Initial treatment for schizophrenia included Paliperidone 3mg/day. Following relapse, various pharmacotherapies were trialed, including Paliperidone, Aripiprazole, Biperiden, Fluoxetine, Risperidone, and Flupentixol Decanoate. During hospitalization, the regimen was adjusted from Aripiprazole to Olanzapine (7.5mg/day), then to Risperidone (1mg/day). The patient was finally stabilized on Risperidone 1.5mg/day, Valproic acid 1500mg/day, and Quetiapine 37.5mg/day.
key_learning_points: Consider organic causes, such as Fahr's disease, for treatment-refractory psychotic symptoms, especially when accompanied by atypical neurological signs or increased susceptibility to medication adverse effects.
Fahr's disease (Idiopathic Basal Ganglia Calcification) can mimic common psychiatric disorders like schizophrenia and necessitates neuroimaging for diagnosis.
Genetic testing is crucial for confirming Fahr's disease, particularly when associated with specific gene deficits like SLC20SA, providing a definitive diagnosis beyond imaging.
description: A 20-year-old male with a history of schizophrenia presented with treatment-refractory psychotic symptoms and medication adverse effects, ultimately diagnosed with Fahr's disease confirmed by neuroimaging showing bilateral basal ganglia calcifications and genetic testing revealing an SLC20SA gene deficit.
clinical_text:
The 20-year-old unmarried male, diagnosed with schizophrenia at 17, was hospitalized due to psychotic manifestations, characterized by auditory hallucinations, persecutory delusions, disorganized thoughts, and violent behaviors with no history of mental, genetic, or neurological disorders. Additionally, the patient had neither family history of similar complaints nor documented history of Parkinsonism, infectious etiologies, or substance abuse at the time of initial diagnosis. The patient maintained modest academic performance during the period spanning from 17 to 19 years while experiencing mild auditory hallucination and paranoid ideation, managed with a regimen of Paliperidone at a dosage of 3mg per day. However, a relapse of psychotic symptoms occurred following the discontinuation of medication without medical consultation, prompting the subsequent adjustments in treatment modalities. Initially, Paliperidone at 3mg daily for one month yielded a suboptimal response, leading to the transition to a combination regimen comprising Aripiprazole at 10mg daily alongside Biperiden at 2mg daily, commenced two months preceding the current admission. Moreover, Fluoxetine at 10mg daily was introduced 1.5 months before the admission, because of compulsive hand washing. Further alterations in pharmacotherapy included the incorporation of Risperidone oral solution at 1mg daily for one month, in conjunction with Flupentixol Decanoate at 20mg administered once biweekly. Upon admission, the patient was receiving Aripiprazole at 10mg daily, Fluoxetine at 10mg daily, Risperidone at 2mg daily, Flupentixol Decanoate at 20mg biweekly, and Biperiden at 2mg daily. Despite the multifaceted pharmacological approach, symptomatic relief remained elusive, with concurrent escalation of aggressive behaviors.
Throughout his hospitalization, the patient exhibited concealed left-side weakness and mild muscle rigidity. He maintained a stable gait and independent activities of daily living. Neurological examinations and physical examinations showed negative findings except for the aforementioned. Brain computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed calcifications in the bilateral globus pallidus, caudate nucleus, thalami, and subcortical areas, with no evident vessel abnormalities ( <PMC11148442_fpsyt-15-1391607-g001_A_1_4.webp><PMC11148442_fpsyt-15-1391607-g001_B_2_4.webp><PMC11148442_fpsyt-15-1391607-g001_C_3_4.webp><PMC11148442_fpsyt-15-1391607-g001_D_4_4.webp> ). Notably, the patient displayed marked aggression and hostility and exhibited pronounced susceptibility to medication-related adverse effects, such as restlessness and Parkinsonism. To optimize therapeutic efficacy while mitigating risks, the medication regimen was transitioned from Aripiprazole (5-10mg/day) to Olanzapine (7.5mg/day; administered for a total of 18 days), and ultimately to Risperidone (1mg/day). The patient's blood investigations including ceruloplasmin, vitamin D, calcium, magnesium, phosphate, thyroid and parathyroid hormone, and alkaline phosphatase showed no abnormalities. Therefore, given the poor response to the patient's psychotic and aggressive behaviors, and high susceptibility to psychotropic adverse effects, with supportive brain CT and MRI findings, a diagnosis of Fahr's disease was considered. The revised diagnosis was further confirmed by genetic testing unveiling a deficit in the SLC20SA gene. Following four weeks of treatment adjustment, the patient was stabilized on a regimen comprising Risperidone 1.5mg/day, Valproic acid 1500mg/day, and Quetiapine 37.5mg/day. Upon discharge from the psychiatric acute ward, the patient had mild psychotic symptoms devoid of disruptive behaviors or violence. His Cognitive Ability Screening Inventory (CASI) score, which might be underestimated because of psychotic symptoms, was 75/100. The component scores of CASI were as follows: Short-term memory: 9/12, Long-term memory: 7/10, Attention: 3/8, Mental manipulation and concentration: 8/10, Orientation: 18/18, Abstract thinking and judgment: 6/12, Language: 8/10, Visual construction and drawing: 10/10, and Fluency: 6/10.
From the patient's perspective, as assessed through the Health, Personality, and Habit Test -A Form Scale, he continued to harbor beliefs that he was being followed, spied on, and subjected to potential harm or attack. He perceived a sense of loss of autonomy, with the conviction that others had control over his body and were privy to his thoughts. Despite recognizing the severity and progressive nature of his mental disorder, he expressed feelings of frustration and sadness regarding his experiences. Acknowledging the necessity for long-term treatment, the patient consented to transfer to a psychiatric chronic ward to facilitate disease management and rehabilitation.
image_captions: Basal ganglia calcification in the brain computed tomography:. Coronal plane.
Sagittal plane.
Transverse plane.

title: A 27-year-old G4P3 with a history of laparoscopic hysteropexy presented at 39+4
chief_complaint: The patient presented to labor ward at 39 + 4 weeks gestation with ruptured membranes and thick meconium.
history: A 27-year-old G4P3 underwent laparoscopic hysteropexy for uterine prolapse, which corrected her point C from +1 cm to -6 cm. She conceived 1 month following the surgery but was a late booker, first seeing her midwife at 18 weeks gestation. All three of her previous children had birth weights on the 10th centile.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: No additional scans were performed during the antenatal period.
diagnosis: Pregnancy at 39 + 4 weeks with ruptured membranes, thick meconium, and a history of laparoscopic hysteropexy for uterine prolapse.
treatment: Emergency caesarean section was performed.
key_learning_points: The importance of thorough antenatal risk assessment and appropriate referral to consultant-led care for patients with a history of uterine surgery like hysteropexy.
Consideration of uterine integrity and potential mode of delivery in pregnant patients with a history of uterine suspension surgery.
The significance of patient compliance with antenatal care and postnatal follow-up, especially in complex obstetric cases.
description: A 27-year-old G4P3 with a history of laparoscopic hysteropexy presented at 39+4 weeks with ruptured membranes and thick meconium, necessitating an emergency caesarean section.
clinical_text:
A 27-year-old para 3 underwent laparoscopic hysteropexy with pre-operative findings of point C + 1 cm; post-operatively, this was corrected to -6 cm. She conceived 1 month following but was a late booker in pregnancy, first seeing her midwife at 18 weeks. Her booking history stated a background of "prolapse surgery" but no referral to consultant led care was made, and she therefore followed a low risk, midwifery led pathway of antenatal care with no additional scans. She presented to labour ward at 39 + 4 with ruptured membranes and was draining thick meconium. She was reviewed by the obstetrician on call who discovered the history of hysteropexy and therefore proceeded to emergency caesarean section.
This was uncomplicated, with a well-formed lower segment and no mesh avulsion. A baby boy was delivered weighing 2795 g (10th centile). All three of her previous children had birth weights on the 10th centile.
Unfortunately, this patient has not attended for a postnatal review.

title: 45yo female with ITP presents with sudden bilateral vision loss due to ocular he
chief_complaint: 3-week history of sudden onset reduced vision in both eyes.
history: A 45-year-old female with a history of idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), diagnosed several years prior with menorrhagia, and diabetes mellitus.
exam_findings: Visual acuity 6/36 OD, 6/60 OS. Anterior segment unremarkable. Fundus examination showed bilateral peripapillary, subhyaloid, and vitreous hemorrhage, more pronounced in the left eye, with no diabetic retinopathy changes. Systemic exam negative for petechiae, bruises, or mucosal bleeding.
labs: Platelet count 120x10^9/L (normal: 150-450x10^9/L); hemoglobin 93 g/L (normal: 120-160 g/L); normal prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time.
imaging_description: Fundus examination revealed bilateral peripapillary, subhyaloid, and vitreous hemorrhage, more pronounced in the left eye, which later showed spontaneous partial resolution.
diagnosis: Bilateral ocular hemorrhage secondary to idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP).
treatment: Oral prednisolone (50 mg daily for 1 week, then tapered over 1 month). Left eye vitrectomy was recommended but not consented to by the patient.
key_learning_points: ITP can present with ocular complications such as vitreous and subhyaloid hemorrhage.
Systemic causes for ocular hemorrhage, especially in the absence of trauma, should be investigated.

Management of ITP-related ocular hemorrhage may involve systemic corticosteroids to improve platelet counts and potentially ophthalmic surgical intervention (vitrectomy) for persistent or vision-threatening hemorrhage.
The importance of multidisciplinary consultation between Ophthalmology and Hematology.
description: 45yo female with ITP presents with sudden bilateral vision loss due to ocular hemorrhages and is treated with corticosteroids.
clinical_text:
A 45-year-old female with underlying ITP and diabetes mellitus presented to the Department of Ophthalmology, Hospital Raja Perempuan Zainab II, complaining of a sudden onset of reduced vision in both eyes, of about 3 weeks in duration. This was associated with floaters in both eyes. There was no history of trauma, intense aerobic exercise, heavy lifting, straining on the toilet, vomiting, coughing, or vigorous sexual activity. She had been diagnosed with ITP several years before, with initial presentation of menorrhagia. Examination revealed visual acuity of 6/36 and 6/60 in the right and left eyes, respectively. Anterior segment findings were unremarkable. Fundus examination showed bilateral peripapillary, subhyaloid and vitreous hemorrhage, which was more pronounced in the left eye (<PMC3908908_imcrj-7-015Fig1_A_1_2.webp><PMC3908908_imcrj-7-015Fig1_B_2_2.webp>). There were no diabetic retinopathy changes noted. Systemic examination did not reveal any petechiae, bruises, or mucosal bleeding.
Hematological evaluation was carried out. The patient's platelet count was 120x109/L (normal: 150-450x109/L); her hemoglobin count was 93 g/L (normal: 120-160 g/L). Coagulation profile (prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time) was normal.
After consultation by a hematologist, she was treated with oral prednisolone, starting dose of 50 mg daily (1 mg/kg/day) for 1 week. Oral prednisolone treatment was then slowly tapered down over the next month. Review at 6 weeks showed spontaneous partial resolving of hemorrhages (<PMC3908908_imcrj-7-015Fig2_A_1_2.webp><PMC3908908_imcrj-7-015Fig2_B_2_2.webp>), and slight improvement of vision (to 6/24 - both eyes). It was recommended to the patient that she undergo left eye vitrectomy (in view of the fact the subhyaloid hemorrhage was just adjacent to the macula), but the patient has not yet consented to the operation.

title: 22-year-old male with 18-month history of right hallux pain successfully treated
chief_complaint: 22-year-old male presented with right hallux pain for 18 months.
history: There was no history of injury, and the patient had no constitutional symptoms such as fever, weight loss, or malaise. He was otherwise fit and well.
exam_findings: The distal phalanx of the right hallux was swollen and tender to palpation, with no obvious erythema or increase in temperature.
labs: Unremarkable blood analysis.
imaging_description: Plain x-rays and a CT scan of the foot revealed a small radiolucency with cortical sclerosis and a nidus formation in the medial side of the distal phalanx of the great toe. Postoperative AP and Lateral x-rays were also obtained.
diagnosis: Osteoid osteoma.
treatment: Operative excision of the nidus and surrounding bone to macroscopically healthy borders was performed through an antero-medial incision with atraumatic elevation of the nail bed and nail. The nail was used as a splint, and the patient was mobilized with a wedge shoe immediately postoperatively.
key_learning_points: Osteoid osteoma is a benign bone tumor classically causing nocturnal pain that is often relieved by NSAIDs.
Typical radiographic features of osteoid osteoma include a small radiolucent nidus with surrounding reactive cortical sclerosis.
Surgical excision of an osteoid osteoma is curative and provides immediate and complete relief of symptoms.
description: 22-year-old male with 18-month history of right hallux pain successfully treated with surgical excision of an osteoid osteoma confirmed by pathology.
clinical_text:
A 22 year old male patient was admitted in our department with right hallux pain for the past 18 months. There was no history of injury. The pain was progressive and worse at night. The pain was initially relieved by NSAIDs but in the last few months only partially and the patient was forced to limit activities due to the pain. There were no constitutional symptoms such as fever, weight loss or malaise.
The distal phalanx of the right hallux was swollen and tender to palpation, with no obvious erythema or increase in temperature (<PMC5676009_TOORTHJ-11-1066_F1_undivided_1_1.webp>). The patient was otherwise fit and well. Blood analysis was unremarkable. Radiographic workup included plain x-rays of the foot and a CT scan and revealed a small radiolucency with cortical sclerosis and a nidus formation in the medial side of the distal phalanx of the great toe (<PMC5676009_TOORTHJ-11-1066_F2_undivided_1_1.webp>).
The patient underwent operative excision of the mass through an antero-medial incision with atraumatic elevation of the nail bed and nail in one layer (<PMC5676009_TOORTHJ-11-1066_F3_undivided_1_1.webp>). Excision of the nidus and surrounding bone to macroscopically healthy borders was performed and histologic samples were sent for analysis (<PMC5676009_TOORTHJ-11-1066_F4_undivided_1_1.webp><PMC5676009_TOORTHJ-11-1066_F5_undivided_1_1.webp> and 5). The skin was closed and the nail was used as a splint to preserve the preoperative hallux shape. Pathology confirmed the diagnosis of osteoid osteoma. The patient was immediately relieved from nocturnal pains and progressively completely relieved from hallux pain. Immediately postoperatively, the patient was mobilized with a wedge shoe. At two years follow up, there were no signs of recurrence or skin and nail problems and the patient was ambulating freely.
image_captions: Xrays of the tumour AP and Lateral.
Postoperative Xray AP.
Postoperative Xray Lateral.

title: 25-year-old female admitted with a complicated choledochal cyst developed post-o
chief_complaint: Admission for a complicated choledochal cyst requiring surgical intervention.
history: History of recurrent cholangitis for which she required repeated biliary stenting.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: Abdominal pus culture reported Acinetobacter baumanii; blood culture reported PDR K. pneumoniae.
imaging_description: Not described in this case.
diagnosis: Complicated choledochal cyst with post-operative biliary leak, complicated by Acinetobacter baumanii abdominal infection and PDR K. pneumoniae bloodstream infection.
treatment: Cyst excision and hepaticojejunostomy; reexploration and peritoneal lavage; meropenem, clindamycin, metronidazole, and fluconazole were given empirically; colistin was later added. Case referred to drug information services for an opinion on appropriate therapy.
key_learning_points: Management of complicated choledochal cysts and potential surgical complications.
Recognition and management of post-operative multi-drug resistant infections.
Importance of culture-directed therapy for severe infections.
Challenges in treating infections caused by extensively drug-resistant bacteria like PDR K. pneumoniae and Acinetobacter baumanii.
Role of drug information services in guiding therapy for complex, refractory infections.
description: 25-year-old female admitted with a complicated choledochal cyst developed post-operative biliary leak and multi-drug resistant infections (Acinetobacter baumanii, PDR K. pneumoniae) refractory to initial therapy.
clinical_text: A female aged 25 years was admitted to the surgical gastroenterology ward with a diagnosis of a complicated choledochal cyst. She had a history of cholangitis for which she required repeated biliary stenting. She underwent cyst excision and hepaticojejunostomy. Postoperatively, she required reexploration and peritoneal lavage for biliary leak and collection. After ordering the cultures, meropenem 1g every eight hours IV was given empirically along with clindamycin, metronidazole, and fluconazole. Cultures of abdominal pus reported Acinetobacter baumanii while blood culture reported PDR K. pneumoniae. Colistin 3 MIU every eight hours was added to the regimen. After six days of adding colistin, as the condition of the patient was worsening, the case was referred to drug information services for an opinion on appropriate therapy.

title: 52-year-old male with IDDM and hypertension presented with bizarre behavior and
chief_complaint: 52-year-old male presented to the ED for evaluation of bizarre behavior and vomiting.
history: A 52-year-old male with a history of insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (IDDM) and hypertension presented after being released from jail, reporting missed insulin doses.
exam_findings: Patient appeared confused but followed commands, alert and oriented to self and place only. Vital signs showed elevated blood pressure (140/72 mm Hg), tachycardia (125 bpm), and tachypnea (28 bpm). Pupils were dilated but reactive to light and accommodation; no facial asymmetry or tongue laceration.
labs: Hyperkalemia, hyperglycemia, elevated creatinine and BUN, elevated alkaline phosphatase, elevated serum lipase, leukocytosis, severe metabolic acidosis, elevated lactic acid, moderate ketones, and anion gap of 27.5.
imaging_description: Bedside EGD revealed diffuse esophageal plaques concerning for candidiasis, ulcerated esophageal necrosis, and a small hiatal hernia. A relook endoscopy after 6 months showed normal esophageal mucosa.
diagnosis: Acute Esophageal Necrosis (AEN) in the setting of Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) and Candida esophagitis.
treatment: Treatment included management for hyperkalemia, DKA protocol (insulin infusions, IV fluids, electrolyte solutions), IV diltiazem and amiodarone for atrial fibrillation, buprenorphine, proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), carafate suspension, and fluconazole.
key_learning_points: Acute esophageal necrosis (AEN) can be a severe and unusual complication of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA).
Immunocompromised states, such as DKA, increase susceptibility to opportunistic infections like Candida esophagitis.
Thorough endoscopic evaluation is crucial in patients with DKA presenting with gastrointestinal symptoms like melena or vomiting.
Social factors, such as incarceration leading to missed medication, can significantly impact chronic disease management and lead to acute decompensation.
description: 52-year-old male with IDDM and hypertension presented with bizarre behavior and vomiting, diagnosed with DKA, atrial fibrillation, and subsequently Acute Esophageal Necrosis with Candida esophagitis.
clinical_text:
A 52-year-old male with a medical history of insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (IDDM) and hypertension was brought to the emergency department (ED) for evaluation of bizarre behavior and vomiting. The patient stated that he was released from jail earlier in the day and that he missed his insulin doses. He denied having fever, chills, dysphagia, odynophagia, acid reflux, chest pain, shortness of breath, palpitations, abdominal pain, melena, hematochezia, recent weight loss, polyuria, polyphagia, polydipsia, or dysuria. In the ED, the patient appeared confused but followed verbal commands. The initial vital signs were notable for elevated blood pressure (140/72 mm Hg), tachycardia (125 beats per minute), and tachypnea (28 breaths per minute). On further examination, the patient was alert and oriented to self and place only. There was no facial asymmetry or tongue laceration, and the pupils were dilated but reactive to light and accommodation. The remainder of the examination was unremarkable.
Triage blood tests were significant for hyperkalemia, hyperglycemia, elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen, elevated alkaline phosphatase, elevated serum lipase, and leukocytosis (Table 1). Arterial blood gas analysis revealed a severe metabolic acidosis and elevated lactic acid. Additional tests revealed moderate ketones with an anion gap of 27.5. An electrocardiogram (EKG) revealed atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular rate but no acute ischemic pattern. The patient was treated for hyperkalemia and admitted to the medical intensive care unit (ICU) for the management of DKA. The heart rhythm converted to sinus rhythm after 10 mg of dose of IV diltiazem and 150 mg of amiodarone. The patient was managed with a DKA protocol comprising insulin infusions, IV fluids, and electrolyte fluid solutions.
The patient's ICU course was complicated by melena and acute blood loss anemia, necessitating a gastroenterology consultation. Bedside esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) revealed diffuse esophageal plaques concerning for candidiasis, ulcerated esophageal necrosis, and a small hiatal hernia (Figure 1). The histopathology of random esophageal biopsies revealed necroinflammatory material and ulcer debris associated with abundant fungal microorganisms, which were morphologically compatible with Candida species. Overall, the findings were consistent with AEN in the setting of DKA and Candida esophagitis. Immunohistochemical staining for cytomegalovirus (CMV) and herpes simplex virus (HSV-1 and HSV-2) was negative. The patient received supportive care with buprenorphine, proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), carafate suspension, fluconazole, IV fluids, and insulin infusion. A relook endoscopy after 6 months showed normal esophageal mucosa (Figure 2).

title: 65yo male with right forearm pain and swelling, diagnosed with metastatic squamo
chief_complaint: A 65-year-old male presented with pain and swelling of the right forearm.
history: A 65-year-old male, no other relevant past medical, social, or family history described.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: Whole body F-18 FDG PET/CT showed multiple foci of abnormal tracer uptake. Increased FDG avidity (SUVmax 9.0) was detected in an irregular, heterogeneously enhancing soft-tissue mass in the right paravertebral region in the upper lobe of the right lung with calcification. Abnormal FDG uptake was also noted in a presacral mass, the bulky left adrenal gland, several dorsal vertebrae, and multiple lesions in the trapezius, right brachioradialis, deltoid, and right external oblique muscles. A peripherally enhancing ring-like lesion in the trapezius also showed increased FDG uptake. Post-treatment PET/CT showed a significant decrease in FDG uptake (SUVmax = 5.1) in the primary tumor and the right brachioradialis muscle lesion.
diagnosis: Primary squamous cell carcinoma of the lung with widespread metastases.
treatment: The patient was treated with 4 cycles of chemotherapy.
key_learning_points: Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma can present with bone/soft tissue lesions in the extremities.
FDG PET/CT is crucial in the workup of suspected metastatic malignancy, especially for identifying the primary site and systemic staging.
Monitoring treatment response in oncology often involves follow-up imaging like PET/CT, with changes in SUVmax indicating response.
Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung can metastasize widely, including to bone, adrenal glands, and muscles.
description: 65yo male with right forearm pain and swelling, diagnosed with metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the lung, treated with chemotherapy.
clinical_text: A 65-year-old male presented with pain and swelling of the right forearm. Fine needle aspiration cytology of the swelling showed metastatic squamous cell carcinoma. The patient underwent a whole body F-18 FDG PET/CT to identify the site of the primary malignancy. Increased FDG avidity (standardized uptake value [SUVmax] 9.0) was detected in an irregular heterogeneously enhancing soft-tissue mass in the right paravertebral region in the upper lobe of the right lung with a focus of calcification within the mass [<PMC3764691_IJNM-28-34-g001_b_2_5.webp><PMC3764691_IJNM-28-34-g001_c_4_5.webp><PMC3764691_IJNM-28-34-g001_d_3_5.webp><PMC3764691_IJNM-28-34-g003_b_2_2.webp>, white arrow]. Abnormal FDG uptake was also noted in a presacral mass [<PMC3764691_IJNM-28-34-g001_c_4_5.webp><PMC3764691_IJNM-28-34-g001_d_3_5.webp><PMC3764691_IJNM-28-34-g001_e_5_5.webp>], the bulky left adrenal gland, several dorsal vertebrae and multiple lesions in the t<PMC3764691_IJNM-28-34-g001_b_2_5.webp><PMC3764691_IJNM-28-34-g001_c_4_5.webp><PMC3764691_IJNM-28-34-g001_d_3_5.webp><PMC3764691_IJNM-28-34-g003_b_2_2.webp>, red arrow], right brachioradialis [Figure 2], deltoid, and right external oblique muscles [Figure 3], suggestive of metastatic involvement. A diagnosis of primary squamous cell carcinoma of the lung was pathologically confirmed. The patient was treated with 4 cycles of chemotherapy, after which significant decrease in FDG uptake (SUVmax = 5.1) was seen in the primary as well as the right brachioradialis muscle lesion (not shown here).
image_captions: Fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) positron emission tomography/computed tomography (PET/CT) Maximum intensity projection (MIP) image (a) showing multiple foci of abnormal tracer uptake.
Transaxial thoracic CT.
Axial CT.

title: A 9-year-old boy presenting with chronic cyanosis, clubbing, and growth restrict
chief_complaint: A nine-year-old boy presented with cyanosis, clubbing, dyspnea, and restricted growth since four years of age.
history: A nine-year-old boy from a rural background presented with restricted growth since four years of age. No other significant past medical history, medications, or allergies are described.
exam_findings: Physical examination revealed central cyanosis and digital clubbing with a resting pulse oximetry (SpO2) of 60% on room air.
labs: Blood investigations showed elevated hemoglobin (15.5 g/L, normal range: 11.5-15 g/L), normal liver enzymes (AST 32 U/L, normal range: 17-59 U/L; ALT 19 U/L, normal range: 21-72 U/L), elevated serum ammonia (77 mumol/L, normal range: 7-30 mumol/L), and slightly deranged coagulation with INR (1.39, normal range: 0.8-1.1) and APTT (30 seconds, normal range: 24.6-29.9 seconds).
imaging_description: Chest X-ray showed mild cardiomegaly with increased pulmonary vascular markings. Electrocardiogram was unremarkable. Echocardiography revealed mild left-sided volume overload and dilated left atrium; contrast echocardiography suggested pulmonary arteriovenous communication. Doppler ultrasound showed a dilated extrahepatic main portal vein with hypoplastic intrahepatic portal venous branches and a large communicating shunt between the IVC and main portal vein. CT angiography confirmed these Doppler findings; hepatic veins were normal.
diagnosis: Type II Abernethy malformation
treatment: Endovascular embolization of the congenital portosystemic shunt (CPSS) was performed using a vascular plug closure device via combined jugular and femoral access.
key_learning_points: Recognize the clinical presentation of chronic hypoxemia and portosystemic shunting in children (cyanosis, clubbing, restricted growth).
Understand the diagnostic workup for congenital portosystemic shunts, including Doppler ultrasound and CT angiography.
Learn about Abernethy malformation (congenital portosystemic shunt) as a rare cause of hypoxemia without primary lung or cardiac disease.
Appreciate endovascular embolization as a treatment option for congenital portosystemic shunts.
description: A 9-year-old boy presenting with chronic cyanosis, clubbing, and growth restriction was diagnosed with Type II Abernethy malformation and successfully treated with endovascular embolization.
clinical_text:
We present a case of a nine-year-old boy from a rural background with a height of 112 cm (<3rd centile) and weighing 19 kg (<3rd centile), who presented with cyanosis, clubbing, dyspnea, and restricted growth since four years of age. Physical examination on admission revealed central cyanosis and digital clubbing with resting pulse oximetry (SpO2) of 60% (normal range > 95%) on room air. Blood investigations showed an elevated hemoglobin level of 15.5 g/L (normal range: 11.5-15 g/L) and a normal liver enzyme profile with aspartate aminotransferase (AST) of 32 U/L (normal range: 17-59 U/L) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) of 19 U/L (normal range: 21-72 U/L). He had an elevated serum ammonia level of 77 mumol/L (normal range: 7-30 mumol/L) but no evidence of hepatic encephalopathy was found. His coagulation profile was slightly deranged with an international normalized ratio (INR) of 1.39 (normal range: 0.8 to 1.1) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT) of 30 seconds (normal range: 24.6-29.9 seconds).
Chest X-ray showed mild cardiomegaly with increased pulmonary vascular markings (Figure 1A). Electrocardiogram (ECG) was unremarkable. Echocardiography revealed features of mild left-sided volume overload and dilated left atrium, after that, a contrast echocardiography was performed with agitated saline, which showed the appearance of micro-bubbles in the left atrium after four cardiac cycles, suggesting pulmonary arteriovenous communication.
Doppler ultrasound showed dilated extrahepatic main PV with hypoplastic intrahepatic portal venous branches arising from the dilated segment and a large communicating shunt between IVC and the main PV (Figure 1B). Computed tomography (CT) angiography confirmed the Doppler findings and a diagnosis of type II Abernethy malformation was made (Figure 1C). Hepatic veins were normal on Doppler and CT angiography. Once the diagnosis was made, the patient was counseled regarding the treatment option.
The patient was taken under general anesthesia for endovascular embolization of CPSS. Both jugular and femoral access were taken. The shunt was cannulated from both sides (jugular and femoral). Multiple catheter angiograms were taken to establish the patency of the intrahepatic portal venous branches (Figure 2A). After documenting the patency of intrahepatic portal venous branches, the decision of shunt closure was taken. Angiogram showed the diameter of the shunt as 12 mm with the length of the shunt being 7 mm. After proper evaluation, the decision was taken to close the shunt with a vascular plug closure device (Cera, LifeTech Scientific Corporation, Shenzhen, China). The device was deployed across the shunt via the femoral route and angiograms were taken from the jugular route, which showed a visualization of the intrahepatic portal branches and immediate closure of the shunt (Figure 2B).

title: A 63-year-old female presented with profound hypotension consistent with anaphyl
chief_complaint: Drop in systolic blood pressure to 65 mmHg 30 minutes after PBV administration.
history: Patient is a 63-year-old lady with a history of mild asthma. She also has a history of allergy/intolerance to ibuprofen, manifesting as wheeze within 2 hours of ingestion on two occasions without other associated features.
exam_findings: Systolic blood pressure dropped to 65 mmHg. There was no cutaneous involvement, laryngeal oedema, or bronchospasm reported.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: Not described in this case.
diagnosis: Anaphylaxis to PBV, confirmed by positive skin prick test.
treatment: Three 3 mg boluses of ephedrine, 200 mg of hydrocortisone, 10 mg of chlorpheniramine, one litre of crystalloid, and 500 mL of colloid administered over 30 minutes.
key_learning_points: Anaphylaxis can present primarily with hypotension, even without typical cutaneous, laryngeal, or bronchospastic features.
Prompt management of anaphylaxis requires a multi-modal approach including vasopressors, corticosteroids, antihistamines, and fluid resuscitation.
Skin prick testing can be effective in identifying the causative agent of a suspected drug allergy following an acute reaction.
description: A 63-year-old female presented with profound hypotension consistent with anaphylaxis 30 minutes after PBV administration, successfully managed with ephedrine, hydrocortisone, chlorpheniramine, and fluids, with subsequent positive skin prick test to PBV.
clinical_text: Thirty min after the administration of PBV a 63-year-old lady showed a drop in her systolic blood pressure to 65 mmHg. There was no cutaneous involvement and no laryngeal oedema or bronchospasm were reported. Sustained improvement was achieved with the administration of three 3 mg boluses of ephedrine, 200 mg of hydrocortisone, 10 mg of chlorpheniramine, one litre of crystalloid and 500 mL of colloid over a period of 30 min. When seen in the DAC 6 weeks later, she showed a 6 mm positive response on SPT with PBV; her response to all other drugs tested was negative. She had a history of mild asthma and allergy/intolerance to ibuprofen (wheeze occurring within 2 h of ingestion on two occasions without any other associated features).

title: Patients experiencing threatened miscarriage or early pregnancy loss, often with
chief_complaint: Patients presented with declining serum hCG levels, indicating threatened miscarriage or early embryonic failure, with some experiencing concurrent minor vaginal bleeds.
history: A significant number of patients had a history of unexplained infertility with recurrent early embryonic failures after ART or multiple previous spontaneous miscarriages. Other patients had tubal factors or previous successful obstetric histories, while some had no prior medical conditions or miscarriage history.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: Declining serum hCG levels (e.g., from 43,271 to 43,185 mIU/mL, or 58,016 to 54,438 mIU/mL), followed by potential recovery of hCG levels.
imaging_description: Not described in this case.
diagnosis: Threatened miscarriage or early pregnancy loss, indicated by declining serum hCG levels.
treatment: Tranexamic acid (1g twice daily) for vaginal bleeds. Off-label adalimumab (40mg single or repeat doses) or certolizumab pegol (200mg single dose) for declining hCG levels as rescue therapy.
key_learning_points: Adalimumab and certolizumab pegol are explored as off-label immunomodulatory treatments for threatened miscarriage or early pregnancy failure, particularly in cases of recurrent loss or ART pregnancies.
Careful monitoring of serial serum hCG levels is critical for diagnosing and managing early pregnancy complications and assessing treatment efficacy.
Underlying factors such as unexplained infertility, tubal factors, or recurrent pregnancy loss can predispose patients to early embryonic failures.
High cesarean section rates can be observed in this patient population, influenced by factors like fetal distress, previous CS, or maternal request, reflecting regional obstetric practices.
description: Patients experiencing threatened miscarriage or early pregnancy loss, often with a history of infertility or recurrent failures, received off-label immunomodulators like adalimumab or certolizumab pegol with varying outcomes.
clinical_text:
Three out of the ten cases were pregnancies following ART. Case No. 3 and 6 were diagnosed with unexplained infertility with at least two episodes of early embryonic failures after ART, while case No. 5 was affected by tubal factors. In case 3, upon the first episode, when hCG declined from 43,271 to 43,185, the patient had concurrent minor vaginal bleeds, indicating a threatened miscarriage. She received 1g tranexamic acid twice daily and a single dose of adalimumab (40mg) for one day and the bleeds stopped. A further decline on Day 55 prompted a second off-label use of adalimumab. Six days after injection, the serum hCG level went back on track (hCG declined from 62,164 on Day 53 to 58,786 on Day 55, then climbed to 120,006 mIU/mL on Day 61). In contrast, case No.6 received only one dose of adalimumab despite having experienced two episodes of early declines of hCG. Case No. 5 had only experienced one episode of hCG early decline and received one single dose of adalimumab on that day. She is now 33wks and is followed up regularly in the antenatal clinic and no stillbirth or any other adverse fetal or maternal outcome has been reported.
Among the seven patients who were conceptualized naturally, case No. 9 and 10 had two and four previous spontaneous miscarriages, respectively. Case No. 2 and 7 had a successful obstetric history before the current pregnancy. Case No. 8 was not complicated with pre-existing maternal medical conditions, nor did she have a previous history of miscarriage. However, she suffered from a long-lasting early decrease of hCG for more than ten days, suggesting an adverse embryonic outcome. A similar case was observed in No. 4, who is now 31wks, after being offered a single dose of certolizumab pegol (200mg) at 7wks when hCG fell from 58,016 to 54,438 mIU/mL the following day.
Eight out of the ten women have delivered so far. The average birth weight was 3377.50g (2780-3850g), which fell into the normal reference range. Despite uneventful pregnancies after the rescue therapy, we identified a disproportionally high cesarean section rate in the study group. Case No. 8 is the only one so far who has delivered vaginally. Case No. 3 and 6 had cesarean for fetal distress in labor, possibly resulted from oligohydramnios (not an absolute indication for cesarean but could lead to increased emergency cesarean delivery in labor). Case No. 2 and 7 had CS (C-sections) indicated for previous CS delivery, a major obstetric indication in China. The other three cases had requested a cesarean delivery (also known as CDMR, cesarean delivery on maternal request) in spite of any obstetric indications. This partly reflects China's high rate of CS in the low obstetric risk population.

title: A 43-year-old female with lung adenocarcinoma presenting with low back pain was
chief_complaint: Persistent low backache since 3 months.
history: 43-year-old female with a known history of adenocarcinoma of the right lung.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: A 99mTc-MDP bone scan showed abnormal, focal increased tracer uptake in the left pelvic cavity, not localizing to any bone, which was persistent on post-void imaging. SPECT-CT imaging localized this uptake to a small focus of calcification in the left pelvic cavity, away from the ureter. Ultrasonography of the pelvis confirmed no ureteric calculus and showed bilateral ureteric jets, ruling out obstruction. A review of recent contrast-enhanced CT revealed a phlebolith in the left iliac vein (CT Hounsfield unit: 338).
diagnosis: Extraosseous 99mTc-MDP uptake due to a phlebolith in the left iliac vein, in a patient with adenocarcinoma of the right lung.
treatment: Not described in this case.
key_learning_points: Extraosseous 99mTc-MDP uptake can occur due to various causes, including phleboliths, and should not be confused with skeletal metastasis.
Multi-modality imaging (e.g., bone scan, SPECT-CT, conventional CT, ultrasound) is crucial for accurate characterization and differentiation of ambiguous findings on nuclear medicine scans.
Specific imaging features like persistent uptake on post-void images and the presence of ureteric jets on ultrasound help rule out urinary tract causes for tracer accumulation.
CT Hounsfield units can aid in the characterization of calcifications identified on imaging.
description: A 43-year-old female with lung adenocarcinoma presenting with low back pain was found to have extraosseous 99mTc-MDP uptake in the pelvis, ultimately identified as a phlebolith in the left iliac vein via multi-modality imaging.
clinical_text: A 43-year-old female patient, known case of adenocarcinoma of right lung was referred for a 99mTc-MDP bone scan with complaint of persistent low backache since 3 months. A whole body 99mTc-MDP bone scan was performed. The scan showed abnormal, focal increased tracer uptake in left pelvic cavity, not localizing to any bone of the skeleton [Figures 1a and b, arrows]. All the bones of the axial and appendicular skeleton showed normal tracer uptake. The uptake was persistent even in post-void imaging done after adequate hydration, giving us a clue that it was not due to tracer hold up in the ureter. On single photon emission computed tomography and computed tomography (SPECT-CT) imaging, the focal tracer uptake localized to a small focus of calcification in the left pelvic cavity away from the ureter [Figure 2, arrow]. An additional ultrasonography of the pelvis confirmed that there was no ureteric calculus [<PMC3628262_IJNM-27-42-g003_undivided_1_1.webp>]. Review of the patient's recent contrast-enhanced computed tomography revealed a phlebolith in left iliac vein (CT Hounsfield unit: 338). Thus, we concluded the extraosseous 99mTc-MDP uptake was due to phlebolith in the left iliac vein.
image_captions: Ultrasonography of the pelvis showing ureteric jets bilaterally (arrows), ruling out obstruction (calculus) in the ureter.

title: 69-year-old male with a non-healing post-auricular scalp lesion after travel to
chief_complaint: Chief complaint of a right post-auricular scalp lesion.
history: A 69-year-old male presented with a non-healing right post-auricular scalp lesion after a recent trip to Belize, where he experienced mosquito bites four weeks prior. He denied systemic symptoms like fever or chills, and no prior history of sebaceous cysts or skin cancers.
exam_findings: Examination revealed a slightly raised 2 cm x 2 cm, soft, tender-to-palpation, non-fluctuant lesion on the hair-bearing scalp with a 1 mm central opening draining scant odorless serous fluid. Binocular microscopy showed no foreign body, purulence, or surrounding erythema.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: Initial examination visually revealed a slightly raised 2 cm x 2 cm, soft, tender, non-fluctuant scalp lesion with a 1 mm central opening draining serous fluid. Intraoperatively, a moving insect-like structure (maggot) was found within the subcutaneous tissue. The excised specimen was identified as a live larva of Dermatobia hominis.
diagnosis: Dermatobia hominis larva (human botfly myiasis)
treatment: Initial treatment with amoxicillin/clavulanic acid and cetirizine for seven days failed. Definitive treatment involved surgical excision of a 1.5 cm x 0.5 cm scalp ellipse containing the furuncle and the D. hominis larva under local anesthetic. The wound was debrided, irrigated, and closed with a non-absorbable monofilament suture.
key_learning_points: Travel history to endemic areas is crucial for diagnosing unusual skin lesions.
Dermatobia hominis myiasis can present as a non-healing, pruritic, painful furuncular lesion with a draining central punctum.
Surgical excision is the definitive treatment for Dermatobia hominis larvae.
AI image recognition tools can assist in the rapid identification of unusual pathogens or parasites.
description: 69-year-old male with a non-healing post-auricular scalp lesion after travel to Belize, diagnosed with Dermatobia hominis myiasis and treated with surgical excision.
clinical_text:
The patient, a 69-year-old male, presented to a general suburban otolaryngology clinic with a chief complaint of a right post-auricular scalp lesion. The patient recalled receiving several mosquito bites to his head, neck, and extremities four weeks prior while on vacation in the rainforests of Belize. He perceived this post-auricular scalp wound as a bite that had failed to heal and said that the area had become more intensely pruritic and mildly painful over the last several days. The wound had started to drain clear fluid, staining his pillow at night, since he returned to the United States. He denied any fever, sweats, chills, diarrhea, nausea, coughing or vomiting. Additionally, he denied a prior history of sebaceous cysts or skin cancers. 
Examination of the scalp revealed a slightly raised 2 cm x 2 cm, soft, tender-to-palpation, non-fluctuant lesion within the hair-bearing scalp, as shown in Figure 1. Centrally, within the lesion, there was a 1 mm well-circumscribed opening that was draining scant odorless serous fluid. Under binocular microscopy, no evidence of a foreign body within the lesion or punctum was observed, nor was there any purulence or surrounding erythema. The differential diagnosis at this juncture included scalp cellulitis/folliculitis, allergic reaction to an insect bite, a foreign body, an evolving scalp abscess or furunculosis, an infected or ruptured sebaceous cyst, or neoplasm. 
The patient was placed on amoxicillin/clavulanic acid 875 mg/125 mg oral tablet twice a day and cetirizine 10 mg oral tablet once a day for seven days. Failing to improve in one week, he was scheduled at an ambulatory surgery center to excise and repair a complex scalp wound under a local anesthetic 10 days after being originally seen. In the operating room, the area was sterilely prepped and infiltrated with local anesthesia, and a 1.5 cm x 0.5 cm ellipse of the scalp, including the furuncle, was incised with a scalpel. Upon dissecting around the scalp ellipse, it was determined that a moving, insect-like structure or maggot was within the subcutaneous tissue, attached to the furuncle, as shown in Figure 2. Careful dissection around the larva was performed, and it was removed in its entirety, alive, with some surrounding scalp tissue. 
The live parasite, as shown in Figure 3, was then photographed intraoperatively using a smartphone and Google Lens AI (Google LLC, Mountain View, United States), which immediately suggested the specimen was likely a larva of Dermatobia hominis. Google Lens is an AI image recognition software based on a neural network (the underlying technology in deep learning and AI), and it is ubiquitously present on mobile phones worldwide. In this case, it was accurate and easily verifiable due to the multitude of provided sources and comparable images. Dozens of similar photographs were presented with this AI-driven search, along with videos of live larvae extracted from their human hosts. Google AI was then used to rapidly gather peer-reviewed case reports of similar surgical extractions and safe curative therapies. The wound was debrided, copiously irrigated, and closed with a 4.0 synthetic, non-absorbable, monofilament suture. Postoperatively, the patient was informed of the suspected identity of the parasite and was reassured that the literature indicated no lasting effects. The larva was sent for pathological examination, which confirmed the identification of D. hominis larva nine days later. The incision healed without complications.

title: A 31-year-old male presenting to a fertility clinic was diagnosed with an inheri
chief_complaint: The patient presented to a fertility clinic for evaluation of infertility.
history: The 31-year-old healthy male presented with his 27-year-old partner who had one previous missed pregnancy at week 6. Genetic analysis revealed that the AZFa partial microdeletion was inherited from his father.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: All tested hormonal and biochemical markers (prolactin, vitamin D, testosterone, T4, TSH) were in normal range. Semen analysis showed normal volume, concentration, and sperm motility, with round cells at 1mil/ml. Morphologically normal spermatozoa were slightly deteriorated at 4%, exhibiting amorphous sperm heads, altered acrosomal distribution, and enlarged necks. Sperm DNA fragmentation was 13% by HaloKit test (within normal fertility range). Karyotype analysis revealed normal 46, XY with slightly decreased levels of constitutive heterochromatin in the long arm of chromosome Y. Initial AZF microdeletion testing showed absence of amplification product for AZFa: sY84. Further detailed analysis confirmed a partial AZFa microdeletion, spanning sY84 and sY1323 markers.
imaging_description: Not described in this case.
diagnosis: Inherited partial AZFa microdeletion spanning sY84 and sY1323 markers, which removes part of the USP9Y gene while leaving the DDX3Y gene intact.
treatment: Not described in this case.
key_learning_points: AZFa deletions can be partial, affecting specific STS markers and genes, and may not always lead to severe spermatogenic failure.
Detailed molecular genetic analysis using multiple STS markers and breakpoint mapping is crucial for precise characterization of Y chromosome microdeletions.
Y chromosome microdeletions, even partial ones, can be inherited, necessitating family screening.
The clinical phenotype of AZFa deletions varies depending on the extent of the deletion and the specific genes involved.
description: A 31-year-old male presenting to a fertility clinic was diagnosed with an inherited partial AZFa microdeletion, affecting part of the USP9Y gene, despite largely normal semen parameters.
clinical_text:
Patient at the time of appointment in fertility clinic was 31 years old, healthy individual. His partner was 27 years old woman with one missed pregnancy at week 6 in anamnesis. All tested hormonal and biochemical markers - prolactin, vitamin D, testosterone, T4 and TSH : were in normal range.
