Given the patient extended treatment with methylprednisolone and cyclosporine, a positive (1,3)-beta-D-glucan and galactomannan test was observed. The presence of spores and mycelium in the sputum suggested possible candida or aspergillus infections, prompting antifungal treatments with caspofungin (50mg, qd) and voriconazole (200mg, qth). Tests for HHV-6, CMV, EBV, and other respiratory viruses were negative. Blood cultures detected Staphylococcus epidermidis, which was considered a contaminant microorganism. Empirical therapy with meropenem (1g, bid) and fosfomycin (4g, q8h) was initiated to prevent bacterial infections.
Following the patient transferred to the intensive care unit, there was an escalation in the medications administered. The patient developed an intensified skin rash marked by redness and desquamation. Blood tests revealed a surge in lgE levels to 4208 kU/L, indicative of a recurrent or persistent of DRESS syndrome. Chest CT exhibited multiple exudations in both lungs, suggestive of interstitial pneumonia (<PMC10799616_IDR-17-153-g0003_undivided_1_1.webp>). Blood gas analysis indicated decreased oxygenation. Beyond potential infections, the manifestations also raised concerns of immune-related lung damage. In response, high doses of methylprednisolone (500mg, 2 days) were administered. Regrettably, the patient's oxygenation progressively declined, blood gas analyses reflected a worsening condition. Unfortunately, the patient passed away.
image_captions: Computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest from different dates. Day 12, Right lung middle lobe and part of the lower lobe of lung atelectasis, both lungs can see calcification and cords; Day 64, Diffuse bilateral ground-glass opacities with mild interstitial changes; Day 75, Diffuse bilateral ground-glass opacities with the thickening of interlobular interval, exudation in both lungs increased significantly compared to previous (Day 64), considering the possibility of interstitial pneumonia; Day 79, Diffuse bilateral ground-glass opacities with the thickening of interlobular interval, multiple bronchiectasis of both lower lungs. The exudation of the upper lobe of the left lung was less than before (Day 75).

title: A 21-year-old female presented with progressive abdominal distension and weight
chief_complaint: 2-month history of abdominal distension, worsening in the last week.
history: A 21-year-old female college student reported menarche at age 14 with irregular menstruation, denying sexual history or dysmenorrhea. She experienced over 10 kg weight loss in two months due to poor appetite, without intentional attempts to lose weight.
exam_findings: On admission, the patient had stable vital signs and whole abdomen distension with muscle tension. A huge, non-tender, clearly demarcated mass encased in a solid sac was palpated in the pelvic cavity, extending to the xiphoid process. Speculum examination of the anus and vulva was normal.
labs: Platelet count: 515 x 10^9/L; Fibrinogen: 6.01 g/L; Prothrombin time: 15.7 s; International standard ratio: 1.40; Prothrombin activity: 64.3%; D-dimer: 2.99 mg/L. Tumor markers were elevated: CEA 17.42 ng/mL, CA-199 28806.09 U/mL, CA-125 138.70 U/mL, HE4 227 pmol/L.
imaging_description: Whole-abdomen CT revealed a large cystic fluid-filled abdominal mass (about 40 x 30 x 34 cm) with separated cavities, slight enhancement of the division and cyst wall, and nodular isodense masses on the right posterior wall. It caused uterine compression with left displacement and right hydronephrosis due to upper ureter dilatation and lower ureter pressure/occlusion. Abdominal ultrasonography showed a large cystic mass in the abdominal pelvis, a gallbladder polyp, and an enlarged spleen. Gynecologic ultrasonography suggested a serous cystadenoma originating from the right ovary, with mild right hydronephrosis and widening of the right upper ureter.
diagnosis: Giant right ovarian serous cystadenoma causing right hydronephrosis.
treatment: An exploratory laparotomy was performed, confirming a large cystic mass in the pelvic cavity.
key_learning_points: Recognizing a giant abdominal mass originating from the adnexa as a cause of abdominal distension and systemic symptoms.
Interpreting elevated tumor markers (CA-125, CA-199, CEA, HE4) in the context of a suspected ovarian mass.
Understanding the mechanical complications of a large pelvic mass, such as hydronephrosis due to ureteral compression.
Appreciating the complementary roles of multi-modal imaging (CT, ultrasonography) in characterizing large abdominal masses.
description: A 21-year-old female presented with progressive abdominal distension and weight loss due to a giant right ovarian serous cystadenoma causing right hydronephrosis.
clinical_text:
The patient was a 21-year-old female college student with height and weight on admission of 183 cm and 100 kg, respectively. She was admitted to our hospital on April 22, 2023, with a complaint of "abdominal distension for 2 months that had aggravated since 1 week." The patient self-reported menarche at the age of 14 with an irregular menstruation cycle of 5-6/20-40 days, no menstruation on April 20, 2023, and no dysmenorrhea. She denied any sexual history. Since February 2023, the patient experienced abdominal distension, nausea, poor appetite, constipation, and discomfort; frequency of urination was normal. The patient's appetite significantly decreased as her abdomen expanded, leading to a reduced food intake; however, she did not exhibit any attempts to intentionally lose weight. In 2 months, she experienced weight loss of >10 kg.
Physical examination on admission revealed stable vital signs, whole abdomen distension, muscle tension, and no obvious tenderness rebound pain. Speculum examination of the anus and vulva revealed no abnormality. A huge mass was observed in the pelvic cavity; its upper margin of the mass was in contact with the xiphoid process; the mass had a clear boundary and was encased in a solid sac; no tenderness was observed.
Routine blood exam on admission revealed the following: platelet count, 515 x 109/L; fibrinogen concentration, 6.01 g/L; prothrombin time, 15.7 s; international standard ratio, 1.40; prothrombin activity, 64.3%; D-dimer level, 2.99 mg/L; serum carcinoembryonic antigen, 17.42 ng/mL; carbohydrate antigen-199, 28806.09U/mL; carbohydrate antigen-125, 138.70 U/mL; human epididymal protein 4, 227 pmol/L.
Whole-abdomen computed tomography (CT) revealed abdominal distention, the presence of a large cystic fluid-filled mass in the abdomen, measuring about 40 x 30 x 34 cm, separated cystic cavity visible inside; slight enhancement of the division and cyst wall was observed, but no enhancement was observed in the internal fluid shadow at each stage, and no significant localized thickening was observed in the division ( Figure 1 ). The lower posterior wall was about 2 cm in diameter, with nodular and heterogenous, isodense masses on the right posterior wall. No enhancement was observed at any stage. Uterine compression with left displacement, and no obvious abnormal shadow and compression of the abdominal aorta and adjacent intestinal cavity were observed. Dilatation and hydrops of the right renal calyces and the right upper ureter were observed. No abnormal shadow was found in the left renal parenchyma, and no water was found in the left kidney. No effusion was observed in the abdomen and pelvis, and no significantly enlarged lymph nodes were observed retroperitoneally. Right upper ureter occlusion, right hydronephrosis, and pressure on the right lower ureter were observed. The diagnosis of large cystic mass in the abdomen and pelvic cavity was established. The possibility of a cystic tumor originating in the right adnexa and serous cystadenoma was considered.
Abdominal color ultrasonography showed the presence of a large cystic mass in the abdominal pelvis and a polyp in the gallbladder. The spleen was enlarged ( Figure 2 ). Color ultrasonography of the urinary system showed mild hydronephrosis of the right kidney and widening of the upper segment of the right ureter, with obstruction of the middle and lower segments, not due to the compression by the large huge mass. No obvious abnormalities were found in the left kidney, left ureter, and bladder.
Gynecologic color ultrasonography suggested the presence of a serous cystadenoma originating from the right ovary. Electronic gastroscopy showed chronic gastritis esophagitis, and electronic colonoscopy showed no abnormality.
After the preoperative examinations, an exploratory laparotomy was performed on April 26, 2023. Intraoperative exploration showed the presence of a large cystic mass in the pelvic cavity; the upper boundary of the mass was close to the xiphoid process, and it was tightly adhered to the anterior peritoneum, lateral peritoneum, and greater omentum. Because the tumor completely occupied the dorsal cavity of the abdomen, its source could not be identified. First, about 14,000 mL of liquid was aspirated from the clear capsule. Then, on exploring the pelvic cavity, it was found that the mass originated from the right ovary; the right fallopian tube was attached to the mass, the uterus was anteriorly positioned and enlarged, and the appearance of the left adnexa was normal. During the operation, 300 mL of the flushed ascites solution was reserved for examination. Peritoneal hyperemia was detected; proliferative nodules and follicular cysts were observed in the omentum; no obvious abnormalities were observed in the appearance of the liver, stomach, diaphragmatic surface, and appendix; the spleen was slightly enlarged; and pelvic lymph node enlargement was not detected. The right adnexa, measuring about 40 x 35 x 15 cm (after aspiration of 14,000 mL of intracapsular fluid), was completely removed. Tumor growth was observed on the surface. Left and right peritoneal tissues and lesion-like tissues of the omentum were retained for examination ( Figure 3 ). The family was informed of the intraoperative situation, and the right appendage was removed first. Intraoperative frozen sections showed the presence of a borderline myxoid tumor (right ovary). Bilateral peritoneal tissue showed hyperplasia of local mesothelial cells. No tumor cells were found in the frozen section of the retinal tissue. Intraoperative diagnosis of "borderline mucinous tumor of the right ovary" was made. Due to the patient's young age, her family expressed a desire to preserve her fertility following discussions with the patient. Consequently, during the operation, a recommendation was made for right adnexectomy, greater omentectomy, and peritoneal biopsy. In the follow-up examination in August, CT scans revealed resolution of the mass, and tumor markers returned to normal.
Histological examination of the mass specimen obtained during surgery showed that the capsule wall was lined with a single columnar epithelium and showed intracellular mucous with epithelial hyperplasia in some areas; cribriform, labyrinth like and papillary structures, were observed, with increased cell layers, disordered polarity, obvious atypia, and visible mitotic figures ( Figure 4 ). Pathological examination of the paraffin section of the right ovary showed mucinous cystadenocarcinoma of the swelling and infiltrating type. No cancer tissue involvement was observed in the right fallopian tube, bilateral peritoneal tissue, and greater omentum. Pathological examination of the ascites showed no malignant tumor cells. The ascites cells showed no abnormal mitotic changes. The postoperative diagnosis was right ovarian mucinous cystadenocarcinoma of IC2 stage(T1c1N0M0).

title: A 45-day-old male neonate presented with jitteriness, poor weight gain, and tach
chief_complaint: The patient presented with jitteriness, difficulty in sleeping, and poor weight gain despite a voracious appetite.
history: The patient was a 45-day-old male neonate. His mother reported sleeping with eyes open and having about 10 bowel movements a day. No other past medical history, medications, allergies, or family/social history were reported.
exam_findings: The patient was thin, alert, irritable, and moderately dehydrated. His weight was 3920 g (a weight gain of 17 g/day since birth). His pulse rate was 182/min. He had a staring look and mild proptosis. The thyroid gland was diffusely enlarged.
labs: Thyroid function tests showed a T4 level of >24.9 mg/dL (normal 7-13.5) and an undetectable TSH level (normal 0.45-5.5 mIU/mL). Thyroid stimulating immunoglobulin index was 6.2 (normal <1.9).
imaging_description: Not described in this case.
diagnosis: Neonatal hyperthyroidism
treatment: The patient was started on PTU 7.5 mg/kg/day and propranolol 2 mg/kg/day. He also received Lugol's solution (1 drop q8h on the first day of treatment). Antithyroid treatment was discontinued at age nine months.
key_learning_points: Recognize the clinical manifestations of neonatal hyperthyroidism, including nonspecific symptoms like poor weight gain and irritability, alongside specific signs like tachycardia, proptosis, and goiter.
Interpret thyroid function tests in neonates consistent with hyperthyroidism: elevated T4, suppressed/undetectable TSH, and elevated thyroid stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI).

Understand the acute management of neonatal hyperthyroidism, which includes antithyroid medications (PTU), beta-blockers (propranolol) for symptom control, and iodine (Lugol's solution) in cases of high risk for thyroid storm or congestive heart failure.
description: A 45-day-old male neonate presented with jitteriness, poor weight gain, and tachycardia, leading to a diagnosis of neonatal hyperthyroidism.
clinical_text:
The patient was 45 days old when referred to our center. His mother reported that he had jitteriness, difficulty in sleeping and poor weight gain despite a voracious appetite. She also noted that he had been sleeping with eyes open and having about 10 bowel movements a day. On examination he was thin, alert and irritable, moderately dehydrated. His weight was 3920 g (a weight gain of 17 g/day since birth). His pulse rate was 182/min. He had a staring look and mild proptosis. The thyroid gland was diffusely enlarged. Examination of other systems did notreveal any noteworthy findings. 
Thyroid function tests at presentation showed a T4 level of >24.9 mg/dL (normal 7-13.5) and an undetectable TSH level (normal 0.45-5.5 mIU/mL). Thyroid stimulating immunoglobulin index was 6.2 (normal <1.9). The diagnosis of neonatal hyperthyroidism was made and the patient was started on PTU 7.5 mg/kg/day and propranolol 2 mg/kg/day. He also received Lugol's solution (1 drop q8h on the first day of treatment) because of high risk for congestive heart failure. A gradual but steady improvement was noted in the subsequent days. After discharge, antithyroid treatment was monitored by frequent clinical and biochemical assessments and was discontinued at age nine months.

title: 20yo male with a 7-year history of an enlarging left neck lump, dysphagia, and s
chief_complaint: A 20-year-old male presented with a 7-year history of a slowly enlarging lump on the left side of his neck.
history: The patient had a 7-year history of a slowly enlarging neck lump associated with multiple swellings of the scalp, trunk, and left forearm. He recently developed dysphagia, obstructive sleep apnea, and hoarseness. There was no significant past medical or family history.
presenting_symptoms: slowly enlarging lump of the left side of his neck
multiple swellings of the scalp, trunk, and left forearm
tongue deviation to the left side
exam_findings: The patient looked comfortable at rest with no speech abnormality, abnormal facial appearance, or dyskinesia. Multiple swellings were noted on his scalp, trunk, and left arm. Neck examination revealed a solitary symmetrical oval swelling of the left carotid triangle, approximately 15 cm x 8 cm, with normal overlying skin, nontender, firm, well defined, and with limited cephalocaudal mobility. No pulsation, fluctuation, or transillumination was present, and the trachea was shifted to the right. No cervical lymphadenopathy or abnormal sounds on auscultation were detected. Cranial nerve examination showed tongue deviation to the left, consistent with left hypoglossal nerve involvement. Indirect laryngoscopy failed to reveal vocal cord mobility due to mass effect.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: Cervical MRI with contrast showed a large prevertebral retroesophageal mass lesion (13.7 cm x 6.4 cm x 4.1 cm) displaying isointense signal on T1 and bright signal on T2 WIs with heterogeneous contrast uptake, indenting the esophagus and posterior airway. MRI of the brain showed multiple meningiomas with bilateral acoustic schwannomas, consistent with neurofibromatosis type II.
diagnosis: Schwannoma (confirmed by histopathology) associated with Neurofibromatosis Type II.
treatment: Preoperative tracheostomy and wide local excision of the schwannoma via a transcervical approach were performed. Nerve-preserving surgical excision was successful. The tracheostomy tube was removed one week post-operatively after assuring airway patency.
key_learning_points: Large neck masses can cause significant airway compression requiring preoperative tracheostomy.
Schwannomas can be associated with neurofibromatosis type II, which presents with multiple meningiomas and bilateral acoustic schwannomas.
Careful surgical planning and technique are crucial for nerve preservation in complex neck dissections.
Histopathological examination, revealing Antoni A and B areas with Verocay bodies, is diagnostic for schwannoma.
Comprehensive imaging, including MRI of the neck and brain, is essential for diagnosis and surgical planning in extensive lesions.
description: 20yo male with a 7-year history of an enlarging left neck lump, dysphagia, and sleep apnea, diagnosed with a schwannoma associated with neurofibromatosis type II, treated with surgical excision and tracheostomy.
clinical_text:
A 20-year-old male student presented to our surgery at Suez Canal University Hospital, referred by his neurosurgeon, with a 7-year history of slowly enlarging lump of the left side of his neck. This swelling was associated with multiple swellings of the scalp, trunk, and left forearm. The patient had a recent history of dysphagia and obstructive sleep apnea along with hoarseness of his voice. However, he had no hearing or neurological problems. There was no significant past or family history.
On physical examination, the patient looked comfortable at rest with no speech abnormality. There were no obvious abnormal facial appearance and no evidence of any kind of dyskinesia. The patient had multiple swellings of his scalp, trunk, and left arm [Figure 1].
Neck examination revealed a solitary symmetrical oval swelling of the left carotid triangle measuring approximately 15 cm x 8 cm with normal skin overlying and no visible scars [<PMC8407632_AMS-11-144-g002_undivided_1_1.webp>]. The swelling was nontender, firm, well defined, with limited cephalocaudal mobility. There was no pulsation, no fluctuation, and negative transillumination. Trachea was shifted to the right side. No cervical lymphadenopathy was detected, and no abnormal sounds were heard on auscultation.
Cranial nerve examination showed no abnormalities other than tongue deviation to the left side, which is consistent with left hypoglossal nerve involvement [<PMC8407632_AMS-11-144-g003_undivided_1_1.webp>]. Indirect laryngoscopy failed to reveal the mobility of both vocal cords, due to the mass effect of the swelling obscuring the view.
Cervical MRI with contrast [Figure 4] highlighted a large prevertebral retroesophageal mass lesion measuring 13.7 cm x 6.4 cm x 4.1 cm in maximum craniocaudal, transverse, and anteroposterior dimensions, respectively, and displaying isointense signal on T1 and bright signal on T2 WIs with heterogeneous contrast uptake. It was seen indenting the esophagus and the posterior airway column. In addition, MRI of the brain [Figure 5] showed multiple meningiomas with bilateral acoustic schwannomas; findings were consistent with neurofibromatosis type II.
The clinical findings and imaging observations were discussed at a multidisciplinary team meeting in the same week. The plan was to perform a preoperative tracheostomy and wide local excision of the schwannoma via a transcervical approach. Under general anaesthesia, supine position, and 30  head up, a subplatysmal flap was raised. Marginal mandibular, hypoglossal, and lingual nerves were identified and preserved. An ovoid well-circumscribed mass, with smooth yellow/tan outer surface showing prominent vascular arborization, was identified medial to the carotid sheath [Figure 6]. The mass was seen compressing the left hypoglossal nerve. Successful nerve preserving surgical excision was performed.
The specimen was sent for histopathological examination. Microscopic pictures [<PMC8407632_AMS-11-144-g007_E_2_2.webp><PMC8407632_AMS-11-144-g007_H_1_2.webp>] revealed a biphasic tumour formed of compact hypercellular (Antoni A) areas, with nuclear palisading around the fibrillary process (Verocay bodies), and myxoid hypocellular (Antoni B) areas. These findings confirmed the diagnosis of schwannoma. No immunohistochemical stains were used.
On subsequent follow-up appointments, the patient was recovering very well, with no evidence of neurological affection including Horner's syndrome. The tracheostomy tube was removed 1 week later after assuring the patency of the patient's airway. The patient has been regularly reviewed for 1 year with no signs of recurrence.
image_captions: H and E-stained sections from the mass. Sections showing biphasic tumour formed of Antoni A areas (black arrows), with Verocay bodies (blue arrows), and Antoni B areas (white arrow).
H and E-stained sections from the mass. Sections showing biphasic tumour formed of Antoni A areas (black arrows), with Verocay bodies (blue arrows), and Antoni B areas (white arrow).

title: 28-year-old woman with primary amenorrhea diagnosed with Mullerian agenesis (MRK
chief_complaint: A 28-year-old woman presented for further evaluation of primary amenorrhea and a shapeless pelvic mass.
history: The patient is a 28-year-old married woman with primary amenorrhea. Her secondary sexual characteristics (larche and pubarche) began around the age of 13. There is no history of amenorrhea in her family.
exam_findings: Physical examination showed pubic and axillary hair (Tanner Stage III) and breast development (Tanner Stage IV). Vaginal examination revealed a blind vagina, and the uterus was not obvious by physical examination.
labs: Hormonal serum profile showed normal FSH (2.5 mIU/ml), LH (3.5 mIU/ml), serum creatinine (0.6 mg/dl), and prolactin (9.45 ng/ml). Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) was below the normal range (1.5 ng/ml). A positive buccal smear was also normal.
imaging_description: Ultrasound examination revealed bilateral renal agenesis with a 95 mm x 72 mm ectopic pancake-shaped kidney on the left side of the pelvic cavity, as well as the complete absence of the uterus, cervix, and upper part of the vagina. Ovaries were normal in size with follicles between 10 and 14 mm. Pelvic MR imaging confirmed uterovaginal atresia with normal ovaries. The ectopic pancake-shaped kidney showed no evidence of hydronephrosis. MR angiography identified the middle sacral artery as the principal blood supply to the ectopic pelvic kidney.
diagnosis: Mullerian Agenesis (MRKH syndrome) with associated bilateral renal agenesis and an ectopic pelvic kidney.
treatment: Not described in this case.
key_learning_points: Mullerian agenesis (MRKH syndrome) should be considered in young women presenting with primary amenorrhea and is often associated with renal anomalies.
Pelvic MRI is essential for detailed anatomical evaluation of uterovaginal agenesis and associated pelvic organ malformations.
Ectopic kidneys can exhibit anomalous vascular supply, such as the median sacral artery, which should be assessed, ideally with MRA, if surgery is contemplated.
description: 28-year-old woman with primary amenorrhea diagnosed with Mullerian agenesis (MRKH syndrome) and associated bilateral renal agenesis with an ectopic pelvic kidney.
clinical_text:
A 28-year-old married woman with a primary amenorrhea was referred to our medical imaging department for further evaluation of a shapeless pelvic mass, and to investigate the possibility of having functional ovaries and uterus. Initial gynecological studies such as height, weight, body mass index, and secondary sexual characteristics were performed by a gynecologist. Secondary sexual characteristics of the patient indicated the presence of pubic and axillary hair (Tanner Stage III), her breast examination showed Tanner Stage IV, and the vaginal examination showed a blind vagina. The uterus was not obvious by physical examination. Larche and pubarche, in this case, started at around the age of 13 years with no history of amenorrhea in her family. The laboratory tests, including the hormonal serum profile, showed the normal range of follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) (2.5 mIU/ml), luteinizing hormone (3.5 mIU/ml), serum creatinine (0.6 mg/dl), and prolactin (9.45 ng/ml). However, the concentration of anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) was below the normal range (1.5 ng/ml). Moreover, a positive buccal smear, (for determination of gender by observing Barr bodies in the exfoliative cells of both men and women), was also normal. A bilateral renal agenesis with a 95 mm x 72 mm ectopic pancake-shaped kidney on the left side of the pelvic cavity was seen in the ultrasound examination. In addition, the complete absence of the uterus, the cervix, and the upper part of the vagina was also identified during the ultrasound procedure. The size of the ovaries was normal with the echo pattern of follicles between 10 and 14 mm in diameter.
The patient also underwent a pelvic magnetic resonance (MR) imaging at 1.5T (Magnetom Avanto Siemens Medical Solution, Erlangen, Germany). The conventional MR images consisted of: a sagittal T2-weighted turbo spin-echo (TSE) (turbo spin-echo), 3 mm thickness, a small field of view (sFOV), 4500/120 ms (repetition time/echo time), with 320 x 320 matrix sagittal T2W, fat saturation, the (3 mm thickness sFOV, 3500/120 ms), T2W coronal oblique images (3 mm thickness sFOV, 4000/120 ms), and T1W TSE with fat saturation axial oblique (3 mm, sFOV, 400/25 ms) with 256 x 256 MATRIX. After intravenous administration of gadobutrol 0.1 mmol/kg body weight (Gadovist, Bayer Pharma, Germany), the contrast-enhanced T1W and TSE images were obtained in axial, coronal, and sagittal planes. MR images confirmed ultrasound findings, including the uterovaginal atresia with normal ovaries in shape and size [<PMC6543865_ABR-8-35-g001_undivided_1_1.webp><PMC6543865_ABR-8-35-g002_undivided_1_1.webp> and 2]. The coronal section revealed an ectopic pancake-shaped kidney with no evidence of hydronephrosis [<PMC6543865_ABR-8-35-g003_undivided_1_1.webp>]. An interesting feature in this patient was the existence of the middle sacral artery in the blood supply of the pelvic kidney. An MR angiogram (time of flight technique) showed that the middle sacral artery was the principal artery that supplied the ectopic pelvic kidney [<PMC6543865_ABR-8-35-g004_undivided_1_1.webp>].
image_captions: Axial T2-weighted magnetic resonance image of the pelvis shows a complete absence of the uterus, the cervix and the vagina, with normal ovarian signal intensity. The white arrow shows the left ovary.
Sagittal T2-weighted with fat saturation and T1-weighted with contrast show uterovaginal atresia.
Coronal section magnetic resonance imaging of the pelvis (proton density with fat saturation) shows a left side pancake-shaped kidney. The white arrow shows the ectopic kidney.

title: A 45-day old foal presented with left forelimb lameness and septic coffin joint
chief_complaint: Left forelimb lameness with heat and swelling localized to the coffin joint.
history: The patient was a 45-day old foal that arrived from a Rhodococcus-endemic farm.
presenting_symptoms: swelling localized to the coffin joint
exam_findings: Heat and swelling localized to the coffin joint of the left forelimb.
labs: Synovial fluid analysis of the coffin joint showed a total nucleated cell count of 600,000/µL with identified gram-positive bacteria; synovial fluid culture was negative.
imaging_description: Distal limb radiographs showed no bony abnormalities. Thoracic films revealed focal pulmonary radiopacities consistent with abscessation.
diagnosis: Presumed Rhodococcus equi infection causing septic coffin joint and pulmonary abscessation.
treatment: The patient received initial broad-spectrum antimicrobial therapy with gentamicin and potassium penicillin, then switched to gentamicin and azithromycin. The coffin joint was lavaged and treated with intra-articular amikacin on days 1, 2, and 7 of hospitalization.
key_learning_points: Rhodococcus equi is an important cause of septic arthritis and pulmonary abscesses in foals, particularly those from endemic areas.
Diagnosis of R. equi infection can be presumptive, relying on clinical signs, imaging, and synovial fluid analysis, even if cultures are negative.
Effective treatment for septic arthritis typically involves a multi-modal approach with systemic antimicrobials, intra-articular antimicrobials, and joint lavage.
description: A 45-day old foal presented with left forelimb lameness and septic coffin joint due to presumed Rhodococcus equi infection, managed with systemic and intra-articular antimicrobials and joint lavage.
clinical_text:
The 10 remaining cases presented with lameness, and accompanying swelling and heat of various joints. Lameness scores on admission ranged from 3/5 to 5/5, with a median lameness score of 4/5. Joints involved included the tarsocrural joint (3 cases), stifle joint (3 cases), coxofemoral joint (2 cases), radiocarpal joint (1 case), cubital joint (1 case), glenohumeral joint (1 case) and coffin joint (1 case). Additionally, there were four cases of osteomyelitis/physitis including femoral osteomyelitis with abscessation (1 case), scapular osteomyelitis (2 cases), and distal tibial physitis (1 case).
In 90% (9/10) of cases, radiographs of the affected limb were taken on admission, though only 4 of 9 cases had detectable radiographic osseous lesions. One case was euthanized on admission due to a grave prognosis associated with a large bony abscess involving the right distal femur and medial condyle. Of the remaining nine cases that were admitted, all were started on a combination of antimicrobials including a macrolide plus rifampin and/or ceftiofur. The most common combination was azithromycin and rifampin, which was immediately initiated in 3/11 cases (27%) based on a high index of suspicion of R. equi. Culture samples were submitted from a variety of tissues; R. equi organisms were positively identified in bone (2/2), synovial fluid (2/8), abscess fluid/material (3/4), trans-tracheal washes (2/2), feces (1/1) and lung tissue (1/1 at necropsy). Synovial fluid samples were typically cultured in aerobic and anaerobic blood culture vials.
Of nine patients that underwent surgical procedures, six had joint lavages performed either through large gauge needles or arthrotomies. The following antimicrobials were instilled intra-articularly: imipenem (3/6), amikacin (5/6), ticarcillin/clavulanic acid (3/6), and erythromycin (1/6). The three patients without joint involvement underwent anesthesia for drainage and debridement of bone abscesses. In eight of the nine patients, euthanasia was elected due to clinical progression of lameness and radiographic progression of lysis and osteoarthritic changes. The mean duration of hospitalization prior to euthanasia was 10.5 days. The ninth patient was found deceased in the stall due to complications from pneumonia.
The only patient discharged alive presented with a left forelimb lameness with heat and swelling localized to the coffin joint. The 45-day old foal arrived from a Rhodococcus-endemic farm. Distal limb radiographs did not reveal any bony abnormalities, but thoracic films showed focal pulmonary radiopacities consistent with abscessation. Based on pulmonary lesions and a coffin joint synovial fluid total nucleated cell count of 600 thousand/muL with gram-positive bacteria identified, a diagnosis of R. equi was presumed, but not able to be confirmed on synovial fluid culture. The foal was treated with gentamicin and potassium penicillin broad-spectrum antimicrobial therapy for the first 24 h of admission, then switched to gentamicin and azithromycin for the remainder of the hospitalization. In addition, the joint was lavaged, and amikacin was infused intra-articularly on days 1, 2, and 7 of hospitalization. Serial synovial fluid arthrocenteses improved over the course of a 15-day hospital stay, and the foal was discharged on day 15 and lost to follow up.

title: A 62-year-old male with a recurrent full-thickness stage III macular hole compli
chief_complaint: A 62-year-old male was referred for a macular hole in his left eye.
history: A 62-year-old Caucasian male with no explicit past medical history or medications mentioned, though surgical clearance issues delayed his initial surgery, and he was lost to follow-up for 5 months due to ankle surgery.
exam_findings: Initial BCVA was CF at 6 ft OS. On exam, a full-thickness stage III macular hole was noted along with a stellate pattern pigment nasal to the fovea. The hole appeared closed clinically 1 day post-operatively after the first surgery. On return after 5 months, BCVA was unchanged at CF OS. Before brolucizumab, baseline BCVA was 20/200 OS. At 2 weeks post-brolucizumab, BCVA was 20/400, and at 4 weeks, BCVA returned to 20/200 OS.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: OCT confirmed an irregular PED, showed slight improvement in macular edema after initial bevacizumab, later showed an increase in macular edema, and subsequently showed improved IRF and decreased average pericentral macular thickness by 15-17 microns after brolucizumab. Fluorescein angiogram revealed lacy hyperfluorescence with late leakage, and later showed occult CNV with active leakage. Indocyanine green angiogram showed possible hotspot and polyp, and later occult CNV with active leakage.
diagnosis: Full-thickness stage III macular hole in the left eye, complicated by classic CNV and later occult CNV with active leakage.
treatment: Initial treatment included bevacizumab intravitreal injection, followed by vitrectomy, membrane stripping, and C3F8 gas tamponade. After reopening, repeat surgery with silicone oil tamponade was performed. Following a second reopening, monthly aflibercept intravitreal injections were given, and after non-response, the patient was switched to brolucizumab.
key_learning_points: Macular holes can be associated with choroidal neovascularization (CNV), which is a rare but significant complication.
Recurrence of macular holes after vitrectomy and gas/oil tamponade is possible, requiring repeat surgical or medical intervention.
Complex retinal conditions may necessitate a multi-modal treatment approach, including anti-VEGF injections and multiple surgical procedures.
Non-response to one anti-VEGF agent may warrant switching to another, as demonstrated by the transition from aflibercept to brolucizumab.
description: A 62-year-old male with a recurrent full-thickness stage III macular hole complicated by classic and occult CNV, requiring multiple surgical interventions and a switch in anti-VEGF therapy from aflibercept to brolucizumab due to persistent edema.
clinical_text: A 62-year-old Caucasian male was referred for a macular hole in his phakic left eye. Initial BCVA was CF at 6 ft OS. On exam, a full-thickness stage III macular hole was noted along with a stellate pattern pigment nasal to the fovea associated with an irregular PED confirmed on OCT. Lacy hyperfluorescence with late leakage was found on fluorescein angiogram, and possible hotspot and polyp were found on indocyanine green angiogram (not shown). This is consistent with classic CNV, a rare association with a macular hole. The patient was treated with bevacizumab intravitreal injection, and macular edema slightly improved on OCT. The patient then underwent vitrectomy, membrane stripping, and placement of C3F8 gas tamponade. This was delayed by 1 month after initial consultation as the patient was not able to be cleared for surgery. The hole appeared closed on clinical exam 1 day post-operatively. Four weeks post-operatively, the macular hole reopened, and the patient underwent repeat surgery with placement of silicone oil tamponade the following week. After the second surgery, the hole was closed but once again reopened after 4 weeks. Fluorescein and indocyanine green angiograms showed occult CNV with active leakage. The patient was started on monthly aflibercept intravitreal injections and completed 3 treatments before being lost to follow-up for 5 months due to ankle surgery. On return, BCVA was unchanged at CF OS, and OCT showed an increase in macular edema. The patient was restarted on monthly aflibercept injections. However, after 5 treatments with aflibercept, OCT showed increased edema, and the patient was started on brolucizumab (<PMC7231770_IMCRJ-13-145-g0003_A_1_2.webp>). Baseline BCVA was 20/200 OS. At 2 weeks post-injection, BCVA was 20/400 and average pericentral macular thickness (APT) decreased by 17 microns. At 4 weeks post-injection, BCVA returned to 20/200 OS. OCT showed improved IRF, and the APT decreased by 15 microns from the pre-brolucizumab baseline (<PMC7231770_IMCRJ-13-145-g0003_B_2_2.webp>, Table 1).

title: A 60-year-old man presented with persistent headaches, fatigue, and hearing loss
chief_complaint: A 60-year-old man presented to the ED for persistent headaches, generalized weakness, fatigue, hyponatremia, weight loss, and a recent hearing deficit.
history: The patient is a 60-year-old retired communications technician with no significant past medical history. His only medications were oxycodone and acetaminophen. He denied alcohol abuse, illicit drug use, or recent sick contacts, but reported recent travel to southern California and Vancouver Island.
exam_findings: The patient appeared fatigued and had tachycardia (HR 127 bpm). Bilateral decreased hearing was noted due to cerumen, which did not improve after removal. Neurological exam revealed subtle hearing loss and lethargy, but otherwise intact cranial nerves, motor function, and reflexes.
labs: WBC 13 800/L with neutrophil predominance; Hemoglobin 12.4 gm/dL; Sodium 127 mmol/L; Potassium 3.3 mmol/L; Chloride 91 mmol/L. HIV antibody was negative. Lumbar puncture revealed elevated opening pressure 27 cmH2O, CSF WBC 59 (38% neutrophils, 42% lymphocytes, 20% monocytes), CSF glucose 40 mg/dL, and CSF protein 2.9 g/L. Cryptococcal antigen titer was strongly positive (> 1:1 024).
imaging_description: Initial and outpatient CT scans of the head showed sinusitis. Chest X-ray and head CT angiogram were unremarkable.
diagnosis: Cryptococcal meningitis caused by *Cryptococcus gattii*.
treatment: The patient was immediately given amphotericin B and flucytosine in doses for an immunocompetent host and admitted to the hospital.
key_learning_points: Persistent neurological symptoms despite antibiotic treatment for sinusitis warrant further investigation, especially in travelers.
Fungal infections like cryptococcosis, particularly *C. gattii*, can cause meningitis in immunocompetent hosts.
Lumbar puncture with CSF analysis and cryptococcal antigen testing is crucial for diagnosing fungal meningitis.
Hyponatremia can be a presenting feature of CNS infections such as meningitis.
Environmental exposure, including travel to endemic areas (e.g., Vancouver Island, California), is a risk factor for *C. gattii*.
description: A 60-year-old man presented with persistent headaches, fatigue, and hearing loss, eventually diagnosed with *Cryptococcus gattii* meningitis after initial misdiagnosis of sinusitis.
clinical_text:
A 60-year-old man from southern British Columbia presented ambulatory, in the spring of 2011, to a Vancouver area ED for further evaluation of intermittent headaches, generalized weakness, fatigue, hyponatremia, weight loss, and a recent hearing deficit. The headache and malaise symptoms had been present for two months and started when the patient and his wife vacationed in southern California. While golfing there, he experienced a thunderclap headache associated with fever, nausea and vomiting. The patient sought care at an urgent care facility and was immediately referred to the ED of a nearby academic hospital where he had a CT scan of the head, was diagnosed with sinusitis, and discharged with a prescription for clarithromycin. When his symptoms failed to improve, he returned home to British Columbia, was evaluated at another ED, and given an oxycodone prescription for symptomatic relief. The patient was then followed up with his primary care clinician who ordered an outpatient CT scan of the head which showed sinusitis. Despite completing a second course of antibiotics- moxifloxacin, the patient continued to experience headache, malaise and fatigue. A finding of hyponatremia and worsening symptoms prompted a referral to the ED by his family physician.
The patient, a retired communications technician with no significant past medical history and whose only medications included oxycodone and acetaminophen, denied alcohol abuse, illicit drugs use, any known sick contacts, or other recent travel. He gave no history of trauma, change in vision, chest pain, cough, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, night sweats, focal weakness, paresthesias, incontinence, rash, or joint pain but admitted to a recent 10 pound weight loss, debilitating fatigue, intermittent low grade fever and, of most concern to him, gradual hearing loss which he attributed to wax build-up.
His triage vital signs were temperature 37oC (98.6oF), heart rate 127 beats/min, respiratory rate 17 breaths/min, blood pressure 118/57 mmHg, and room air oxygen saturation 98%. The patient was well-developed but appeared fatigued. The external auditory canals were full of cerumen with bilateral decreased hearing which did not improve after wax removal. His neck was supple without lymphadenopathy. The oral cavity and pharynx showed normal mucosa and good dental hygiene. Cardiovascular examination revealed tachycardia without a murmur. Respirations were unlabored and both lungs were clear to auscultation. The abdomen was soft and non-tender with no hepatosplenomegaly. The skin was warm, dry, and without a rash. Aside from subtle hearing loss and lethargy, neurological examination revealed intact cranial nerves, motor function (normal tone coordination and muscle strength against resistance), and symmetrical deep tendon reflexes.
Laboratory examination revealed that the patient had WBC of 13 800/L with a neutrophil predominance and a hemoglobin level of 12.4 gm/dL. A chemistry panel was significant for adescreased sodium of 127 mmol/L, potassium 3.3 mmol/L, and chloride 91 mmol/L. Urinalysis, TSH and liver functions tests were normal. HIV antibody was negative. Chest X-ray and head CT angiogram were unremarkable. A lumbar puncture revealed an elevated opening pressure of 27 cmH2O with colorless cerebral spinal fluid (CSF) containing 59 WBC (38% neutrophils, 42% lymphocytes, 20% monocytes), 6 RBC, a low glucose of 40 mg/dL, and elevated protein level of 2.9 g/L. A cryptococcal antigen titer was strongly positive (> 1:1 024).
The patient was immediately given amphotericin B and flucytosine in doses for the immunocompetent host and admitted to the hospital. Several days later, Cryptococcal species were identified as C. gattii. Upon further questioning, the patient recalled that he had visited Vancouver Island seven months earlier. After two months of hospitalization, the patient was eventually discharged neurologically intact except for a continued mild bilateral hearing deficit.

title: Patient underwent surgery for prosthesis placement under general anesthesia in a
chief_complaint: Not described in this case.
history: Not described in this case.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: Not described in this case.
diagnosis: A clinical situation that would benefit from receiving a prosthesis (specific diagnosis not stated).
treatment: Prosthetic implantation via surgery performed in a beach chair position under general anesthesia.
key_learning_points: Consideration of prosthetic implantation as a treatment option.
Understanding surgical positioning (beach chair position).
Awareness of general anesthesia use in surgery.
description: Patient underwent surgery for prosthesis placement under general anesthesia in a beach chair position due to their clinical situation.
clinical_text:
Considering his overall clinical situation, we evaluated that the patient would have been better off receiving a prosthesis.
Surgery was performed in a beach chair position and took place under general anesthesia.

title: A 46-year-old man presenting with refractory seizure-like episodes, ultimately d
chief_complaint: A 46-year-old man presented with new-onset seizure-like episodes.
history: A 46-year-old man with no other reported past medical history presented with progressive seizure-like episodes for 13 months. He was previously treated unsuccessfully with increasing doses of levetiracetam and eslicarbazepine.
presenting_symptoms: Seizure-like episodes (predominantly nighttime, early morning hours)
Episodes of bizarre behavior (grunting, blowing, sitting up, rocking movements)
Inadequate reaction even with partial responsiveness
Progression in seizure frequency (up to 4-5 per month) and duration (up to 3 hours)
Raising right hand and throwing legs on the bed
Kicking feet from side to side and flexing right leg
Making loud noises, tossing head up and down
Object agnosia (calling an apple a hat)
exam_findings: During seizure-like episodes, the patient exhibited unresponsiveness to verbal stimuli and inadequate reaction even if partially responsive. No other general physical examination findings were described.
labs: Blood tests, including blood glucose level, were normal when no clinical symptoms were present. Cerebrospinal fluid examination and antibodies against paraneoplastic and autoimmune encephalitis were evaluated (results not specified as abnormal). Interictal EEG showed intermittent slow activity above the left temporal region, but no interictal epileptiform discharges. Routine morning blood tests during a symptomatic period showed a blood glucose level of 0.5 mmol/l (9 mg/dL).
imaging_description: MRI showed no described abnormalities. Interictal scalp EEG showed intermittent slow activity above the left temporal region. Video-EEG monitoring captured two typical seizure episodes, characterized by specific motor and behavioral automatisms.
diagnosis: Pancreatic insulinoma, histologically confirmed as pT1, N0, M0, G2.
treatment: Initially treated with antiseizure medications (levetiracetam, then eslicarbazepine), which were ineffective. Definitive treatment was surgical removal of the insulinoma. Post-surgery, antiseizure medication was withdrawn.
key_learning_points: Hypoglycemia can present with seizure-like episodes and complex behavioral automatisms, mimicking epilepsy.
Insulinoma should be considered in the differential diagnosis of new-onset, refractory seizures, especially those with atypical features or prominent nocturnal occurrence.
Accurate diagnosis often relies on measuring blood glucose during symptomatic periods, as interictal levels may be normal.
description: A 46-year-old man presenting with refractory seizure-like episodes, ultimately diagnosed with a pancreatic insulinoma after severe hypoglycemia was identified.
clinical_text:
We present a case report of a 46-year-old man who started to experience seizure-like episodes. These episodes were predominantly linked to nighttime, lasting tens of minutes.
At first, the seizures appeared in the early morning hours and were described as episodes of bizarre behavior, including grunting, blowing, sitting up, or rocking movements. The patient was mainly unresponsive to verbal stimuli. An inadequate reaction was present if partial responsiveness was perceived. Both seizure frequency and severity progressed over time. The frequency increased to 4 to 5 seizures per month and the duration to 3 h. The timeline of disease development is summarized in Figure 1.
Antiseizure medication (ASM, levetiracetam) was introduced with a temporary effect. However, increasing doses and a second drug (eslicarbazepine) influenced neither seizure frequency nor severity. The patient underwent a comprehensive evaluation (blood test, cerebrospinal fluid examination, the examination of antibodies against paraneoplastic and autoimmune encephalitis, MRI, and scalp EEG); blood tests, including blood glucose level, were normal. The blood glucose level was measured when no clinical symptoms were present. Interictal EEG showed intermittent slow activity above the left temporal region, but no interictal epileptiform discharges were current.
Two typical episodes were captured during video EEG monitoring (<PMC11002118_fneur-15-1371055-g002_A_1_2.webp><PMC11002118_fneur-15-1371055-g002_B_2_2.webp>). Subsequently, routine morning blood tests showed a blood glucose level of 0.5 mmol/l (9 mg/dL), which led to the establishment of a correct diagnosis of insulinoma.
Thirteen months after the first symptoms, the patient underwent surgical removal of the insulinoma. Histological diagnosis confirmed pancreatic insulinoma pT1, N0, M0, and G2. After surgery, the patient was seizure-free, and antiseizure medication was withdrawn.
image_captions: Clinical manifestation of insulinoma in our patient - seizures captured during video EEG. (A) Seizure 1 - Video-EEG: The seizure starts with rocking movements (0:12). At 0:32, the patient raises his right hand, throws his legs on the bed, and straightens his shirt sleeve. Rocking motions are repeated (0:54). After the nurse arrives, he says he wants to sleep. He counts aloud at the nurse's request but only to 2. Then he rocks again, sits up, and grabs the bed rails (1:24). He crosses his arms (2:54) and grunts. At the end of the seizure, he raises his head and hyperventilates (3:32).

Clinical manifestation of insulinoma in our patient - seizures captured during video EEG. (B) Seizure 2 - Video-EEG: The seizure again begins with rocking movements. The patient raises his right hand and lifts his legs (0:33). He then kicks his feet from side to side and flexes his right leg (0:43). He rocks again (0:51), sits down, and makes loud noises, tossing his head up and down. He does not recognize the apple and says it is a hat (1:30). At 1:49. He rocks violently, squeals, flails his hands, and stops responding. The seizure ends with arm-stretching (2:10) and tense body posture (2:28).

title: This report details a comparative analysis of demographic, clinical, laboratory,
chief_complaint: Patients typically present with respiratory symptoms, varying in severity and onset based on the specific eosinophilic pneumonia syndrome, from acute severe respiratory distress to milder, chronic symptoms.
history: Relevant patient history details for a specific individual, such as PMH, medications (except for mention of an instigating drug for CEP), allergies, or social/family history, are not described in this comparative review of eosinophilic pneumonia syndromes.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: For CEP, initial peripheral blood eosinophilia was common (77% of patients, average 1490/µL). For AEP, initial neutrophilic leukocytosis was typical with no elevated eosinophil fraction, though 20.7% later had counts >500 cells/µL (average 1390 cells/µL). BAL fluid eosinophil fraction >25% was observed significantly more in AEP (95.6%) than CEP (80%).
imaging_description: Peripheral segmental/patchy bilateral infiltrates were more common in CEP (49% vs 30.4% in AEP). Reticular/interstitial findings were more common in AEP (26.7% vs 14.7% in CEP). Diffuse ground-glass opacities (11%) and an ARDS presentation (4.4%) were exclusively found in AEP. Pleural effusion with parenchymal lesions was rare in both (2.2% AEP, 3.3% CEP). Wandering infiltrates were present in similar rates in both groups.
diagnosis: Acute Eosinophilic Pneumonia (AEP) and Chronic Eosinophilic Pneumonia (CEP).
treatment: For CEP, 35% of patients were treated with cessation of the instigating drug, while 65% received steroids. For AEP, 82% of patients were treated with steroids. The cure rate was high for both (AEP 96.6%, CEP 90.1%), but recurrence was significantly higher in CEP (6.5% with steroids) than in AEP (3.7%).
key_learning_points: AEP typically affects younger individuals (20-40 years old) with an acute, severe presentation including hypoxemic respiratory failure, whereas CEP may have a trend toward male predominance with milder, chronic respiratory symptoms.

Initial laboratory findings differ: CEP commonly presents with peripheral blood eosinophilia, while AEP often shows neutrophilic leukocytosis, though both can have elevated eosinophil fractions in BAL fluid.

Radiographic patterns help differentiate: AEP is associated with reticular/interstitial findings, diffuse ground-glass opacities, and ARDS presentation, while CEP is more linked to peripheral segmental/patchy bilateral infiltrates.
Both syndromes respond well to treatment, often steroids, but CEP has a significantly higher recurrence rate, and some CEP cases may resolve with cessation of an instigating drug alone.
description: This report details a comparative analysis of demographic, clinical, laboratory, imaging, and treatment characteristics between Acute and Chronic Eosinophilic Pneumonia syndromes.
clinical_text:
AEP has been reported to occur twice as often in men than in women and in CEP the ratio between men and women is reported to be equal. However, we did not observe these trends in our review. On the contrary, there was a trend toward male predominance among the patients with CEP and cases of AEP were equally distributed between men and women. As previously reported, AEP patients tend to be younger (20-40 years old), which is consistent with our findings.
AEP is a severe and dramatic syndrome. This explains the early detection (average of 9.8 days after the onset of symptoms). In comparison, the mean time to diagnosis of CEP is 4.14 months. It has been reported that most patients with AEP are diagnosed within the first week, but the longer time to diagnosis of CEP emphasizes the difficulty in diagnosing this syndrome in an outpatient setting. The severity of AEP is evidenced by the fact that 21% of patients had acute hypoxemic respiratory failure and 19.8% required mechanical ventilation. None of the patients with CEP had respiratory failure and 97% had only mild respiratory symptoms. Our results are consistent with those of Philit et al, who reported that 63% of patients had respiratory failure.
After analyzing the radiographic findings, there was some degree of overlap between the 2 syndromes; however, we were unable to find a common pattern. Peripheral segmental/patchy bilateral infiltrates were more commonly seen in patients with CEP than in those with AEP (49% vs 30.4%), and this result was close to statistical significance (P = .06). These infiltrates have been previously described as being prototypical of CEP. In addition to peripheral segmental/patchy bilateral infiltrates, reticular/interstitial findings have been described significantly more often in cases of AEP than in cases of CEP (26.7% vs 14.7%; P <.025). Pleural effusion with parenchymal lesions was rarely found in either group (2.2% of AEP cases and 3.3% of CEP cases). Diffuse ground-glass opacities and an ARDS presentation were exclusively found in the AEP group (11% and 4.4%, respectively). Wandering infiltrates in both lungs is a unique finding of EP and was present in similar rates in both groups.
Our data showed that peripheral blood eosinophilia was common in the initial presentation of CEP (77% of patients) with an average absolute eosinophil count of 1490/muL. In contrast, patients with AEP generally presented with an initial neutrophilic leukocytosis with no elevated fraction of eosinophils. As the disease progresses, the eosinophil count increases. In this study, only 20.7% of patients with AEP had eosinophil counts >500 cells/muL and the average among those with initial peripheral blood eosinophilia was 1390 cells/muL.
The diagnostic criterion of an eosinophil fraction >25% in the BAL fluid was observed in both syndromes, but significantly more in AEP group (95.6% of cases in the AEP group and 80% of cases in the CEP group). No case report could define EP without the presence of either peripheral blood eosinophilia or an elevated eosinophil fraction in the BAL fluid.
There are no guidelines for treating these EP syndromes with steroids. The cure rate for both AEP and CEP was very high: 96.6% in the AEP group and 90.1% in the CEP group. In this study, the recurrence rate was significantly higher in the CEP group, which is similar to what has been previously described. In the AEP group, recurrence was rare and the rate was lower than that anticipated based on previous descriptions of a small series of cases. Upon analyzing the use of steroid treatment, we found that 35% of CEP patients were treated only with cessation of the instigating drug, and the associated recurrence rate was only 3.3%. The patients with CEP who were treated with steroids (65%) had a higher recurrence rate (6.5%) and this difference was statistically significant. In the AEP group, the recurrence rate was much lower (3.7%) and most of the patients were treated with steroids (82%). There was no recurrence among AEP patients who were not treated with steroids. One possible explanation for this finding is that the patients with AEP who were not treated with steroids had a milder disease course.
Upon comparing patients treated with steroids in both groups, there was a significantly higher recurrence rate in the CEP group. It is logical to assume that the severity of the initial clinical presentation led to earlier steroid treatment, but the higher recurrence rate among patients with CEP treated with steroids may be due to premature discontinuation of steroid treatment. The optimal duration of steroid treatment for EP is unknown, but the more common approach is to slowly taper steroids over 2 to 3 months. Although steroid treatment resulted in a very high cure rate and a low recurrence rate in CEP cases, our data analysis revealed that cessation of the implicated drug resulted in no further need for steroid treatment. Steroid-sparing treatment with omalizumab may also be used in patients with recurrent disease if IgE levels are elevated; omalizumab has been recommended as a second-line treatment in patients with recurrence who did not improve with steroid treatment. Because most case reports did not report data regarding IgE levels and because the correlation between IgE levels and eosinophil counts has not been examined in a large series, we cannot currently support the use of treatments based on IgE levels.
Due to the rarity of this syndrome, very few cases reports have been published during the past few decades, thus restricting the statistical power of this analysis. In addition, the heterogeneity of the published case reports decreases the quality of this data analysis.

title: 51-year-old woman presented with severe dengue complicated by distributive shock
chief_complaint: A 51-year-old woman presented with 5 days of fever and shivers, associated with epigastric pain, emesis, diarrhea, and an episode of hematemesis.
history: Her medical history included hypertension and dyslipidemia, for which she was taking enalapril, hydrochlorothiazide, atorvastatin, and ASA. She was from a rural area of Santander, Colombia.
exam_findings: Key physical examination findings included hemodynamic instability, tachycardia, hypotension requiring vasopressors, delayed capillary refill time, dehydration, petechiae on the skin of the extremities, bilateral basal rales, and painful hepatomegaly (4 cm).
labs: Blood count showed pancytopenia with severe thrombocytopenia (7000 cc/mm3). Liver function tests revealed transaminase elevation (50x normal), LDH > 1000, normal bilirubins and alkaline phosphatase, and prolonged PTT without PT alteration. Serological testing confirmed positive anti-DENV-1 IgM by ELISA. Further workup showed consumed complement fraction C3, normal C4, and negative cultures, malaria, Chagas, Hepatitis A, B, C, CMV, HIV, Leptospira, TMAs, inherited thrombophilia, ANAs, anti-dsDNA, and ANCAs.
imaging_description: The chest X-ray and abdominal ultrasound showed evidence of leakage with free fluid in the abdomen and pleural effusion, and hepatomegaly. Echocardiography reported bubbles in the right cavities without evidence of shunt. Doppler ultrasonography of portal and mesenteric veins and CT with portal venous phase showed an image compatible with acute complete non-cirrhotic thrombosis in the proximal portion of the portal vein. Control Doppler ultrasonography 8 weeks later was completely normal.
diagnosis: Severe dengue with secondary coagulopathy and acute complete non-cirrhotic thrombosis in the proximal portion of the portal vein.
treatment: The patient required close monitoring in the intensive care unit with vasopressors for 11 days. She received methylprednisolone and prednisone 1 mg/kg for suspected ITP, anticoagulation with LMWH (started when platelets reached >70,000 cells/mm3), and piperacillin tazobactam (4.5 g IV q.i.d.) for 7 days. Steroid and anticoagulation therapy were discontinued after 3 months.
key_learning_points: Severe dengue can present with atypical and life-threatening complications such as acute portal vein thrombosis and profound coagulopathy.

A thorough differential diagnosis is crucial in patients presenting with acute hemorrhagic fever syndrome and thrombotic events, requiring extensive workup for infectious, autoimmune, and thrombophilic causes.

Management of severe dengue complications often involves intensive care, hemodynamic support, and tailored treatments like anticoagulation, carefully balanced against coagulopathy and thrombocytopenia.
description: 51-year-old woman presented with severe dengue complicated by distributive shock, profound coagulopathy, and acute portal vein thrombosis, requiring intensive care and targeted treatments.
clinical_text:
In October 2019, a 51-year-old woman from a rural area of Santander, Colombia, was admitted to our unit with a story of fever and shivers for the past 5 days associated with epigastric pain, emesis, diarrhea, and an episode of hematemesis. Previous medical history included hypertension and dyslipidemia, and she was taking enalapril, hydrochlorothiazide, atorvastatin, and ASA.
Examination revealed hemodynamic instability, tachycardia, hypotension requiring vasopressors, delayed capillary refill time, and dehydration. Petechiae were identified on the skin of the extremities. Cardiopulmonary auscultation documented bilateral basal rales and palpation of the abdomen, painful hepatomegaly (4 cm).
Her blood count showed pancytopenia with severe thrombocytopenia (7000 cc/mm3). Liver function tests revealed transaminase elevation (50 times above its normal value), LDH> 1000, normal bilirubins, and normal alkaline phosphatase suggesting hepatocellular injury with an ischemic component; the PTT was prolonged without PT alteration (See Table 1). The chest X-ray and abdominal ultrasound showed evidence of leakage with free fluid in the abdomen and pleural effusion, and hepatomegaly was also noted. The presence of bubbles in the right cavities without evidence of shunt was reported by echocardiography, as a consequence, a Doppler ultrasonography of portal and mesenteric veins were performed as well as CT with portal venous phase, showing an image compatible with acute complete non-cirrhotic thrombosis in the proximal portion of the portal vein (see Fig. 1). She was serologically confirmed positive for anti-DENV-1 IgM by ELISA.
The patient required close monitoring in the intensive care unit with vasopressors for 11 days due to distributive shock. A presumptive diagnosis of severe dengue with secondary coagulopathy and thrombotic complications was made.
She received methylprednisolone and prednisone 1 mg/kg as maintenance for suspected ITP, and anticoagulation with LMWH was started when platelets reached >70,000 cells/mm3. She was treated with piperacillin tazobactam (4.5 g IV q.i.d.) for 7 days starting at the 6th day of thedisease.
The patient was further evaluated for additional causes of acute hemorrhagic fever syndrome with thrombotic events associated as well as prothrombotic systemic states (See Table 2). Cultures of the blood, urine, and stool yielded normal results. Malaria and Chagas tests in blood smear were negative. Hepatitis A, B, and C virus infections were ruled out serologically as well as CMV, HIV, and Leptospira infections. Screening for TMAs and inherited thrombophilia did not reveal any abnormality. She was screened for antiphospholipid syndrome, protein C and S deficiency, factor V Leiden, hyperhomocysteinemia, and ATIII deficiency. There was no evidence of hemolytic anemia, blood smear did not show abnormal cells, and ADAMTS 13 levels were normal. Complement fraction C3 was consumed and C4 was normal. ANAs, anti-dsDNA, and ANCAs were also negative. She was not tested for COVID-19 given that the first case reported in our country occurred in March 2020.
She underwent a control 8 weeks later, and Doppler ultrasonography of portal and mesenteric veins as well as laboratory initial alterations were completely normal. Steroid and anticoagulation therapy was discontinued after 3 months.

title: A 7-year-old boy initially diagnosed with an upper airway tract infection return
chief_complaint: A 7-year-old boy presented to the emergency department with high fever and ear pain.
history: His medical history was unremarkable. No relevant medications, allergies, social, or family history were described in the case report.
exam_findings: Initial neurological and full-system examination indicated no pathology. Otoscopic examination was not performed at admission. Subsequent neurological examination showed no signs of any pathology. Ophthalmologic evaluation confirmed binocular horizontal diplopia (worse for distant objects) and concomitant strabismus with esotropia to the right side due to right abducens palsy. Later otoscopic examination showed bulging of the right tympanic membrane without retroauricular or mastoid tenderness. Audiogram showed mild conductive hearing loss.
labs: Initial routine blood tests showed leukocytosis with neutrophilia and elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) levels. Middle ear fluid aspirate culture grew no pathogen. Postoperative laboratory tests showed no abnormality in white blood cell count and CRP level.
imaging_description: Cranial MRI showed complete opacification and high signal in the mastoid air cells, middle ear, and petrous apex on T2 scans on the right side. Temporal CT showed complete opacification in the mastoid air cells and middle ear, and erosion in the petrous apex indicative of petrous apicitis on the right side. Follow-up CT scans showed improvement of the right mastoiditis and edema at the apex.
diagnosis: Gradenigo's syndrome, characterized by right acute mastoiditis with petrositis, right orbitofacial pain, and right abducens palsy.
treatment: Initially oral amoxicillin was prescribed for a presumed upper airway tract infection. Upon re-presentation, the patient was hospitalized and received intravenous ceftriaxone (50 mg/kg/day for 2 days). A right myringotomy was performed and a ventilation tube was inserted. Intravenous cefoperazone + sulbactam sodium (3 x 800 mg/day) and vancomycin (4 x 240 mg/day) were administered for 2 weeks, followed by oral amoxicillin/clavulanate therapy. Monthly ophthalmologic follow-up was recommended.
key_learning_points: Gradenigo's syndrome is a rare but serious complication of otitis media, characterized by the triad of otorrhea (or ear infection signs), ipsilateral facial pain, and abducens nerve palsy.
A high index of suspicion is required to diagnose Gradenigo's syndrome in children with persistent ear symptoms and new neurological deficits, as initial presentations may be misleading.
Advanced imaging (MRI and CT) is crucial for confirming petrous apicitis and mastoiditis, which are hallmarks of Gradenigo's syndrome.
Management involves aggressive intravenous antibiotic therapy and often surgical intervention, such as myringotomy and ventilation tube insertion, to drain the middle ear and mastoid.
description: A 7-year-old boy initially diagnosed with an upper airway tract infection returned with persistent fever, headache, diplopia, and orbitofacial pain, leading to the diagnosis of Gradenigo's syndrome.
clinical_text: A 7-year-old boy was admitted to the pediatric emergency department because of high fever and ear pain. His medical history was unremarkable. Otoscopic examination was not performed at admission. A neurological and full-system examination indicated no pathology. Routine laboratory blood tests indicated leukocytosis with neutrophilia and elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) levels. The patient was subsequently diagnosed with upper airway tract infection and discharged with a prescription of oral amoxicillin. Twelve days later, the patient was referred to the pediatric emergency department with persistent fever, headache, right diplopia due to abducens nerve palsy, and right orbitofacial pain. Subsequent neurological examination showed no signs of any pathology. Ophthalmologic evaluation confirmed the presence of binocular horizontal diplopia, which was worse for distant objects, as well as concomitant strabismus with esotropia to the right side secondary to right abducens palsy. The patient was diagnosed with meningitis; he was hospitalized, and ceftriaxone (50 mg/kg/day per day) was given for 2 days. A cranial magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was performed, which showed complete opacification and high signal in the mastoid air cells, middle ear, and petrous apex on T2 scans on the right side (Figure 1). Subsequently, the ear, nose, and throat department was consulted. Otoscopic examination showed bulging of the right tympanic membrane without any tenderness in the retroauricular area and mastoid. Temporal computed tomography (CT) was performed, which showed complete opacification in the mastoid air cells and middle ear. In addition, the CT images showed erosion in the petrous apex indicative of petrous apicitis on the right side (Figure 2). Concomitant right acute mastoiditis with petrositis, right orbitofacial pain, and right abducens palsy was indicative of Gradenigo's syndrome. Audiogram showed mild conductive hearing loss. A right myringotomy was performed and a ventilation tube was inserted with intravenous administration of cefoperazone + sulbactam sodium (3 x 800 mg/day) and vancomycin (4 x 240 mg/day) for 2 weeks, which was followed by oral amoxicillin/clavulanate therapy. Middle ear fluid aspirate culture grew no pathogen. On postoperative day 2, the patient's fever, pain, and abducens nerve palsy improved dramatically. On postoperative day 4, he had no pain or symptom of abducens palsy, but the right diplopia for distant targets persisted. Simultaneously, laboratory tests showed no abnormality in white blood cell count and CRP level. On postoperative day 7, his diplopia resolved completely and the tympanic membrane showed improvement. Follow-up CT scans performed after the intravenous therapy showed improvement of the right mastoiditis and edema at the apex (Figure 3). At 2 weeks postoperatively, the patient was discharged with further recommendations for monthly ophthalmologic follow-up. It has been 2 months since the disease and there was no problem in follow-up. Informed consent was obtained from the parents for the use and publication of his data.

title: A 42-year-old nulligravida with 3 years of primary infertility and recurrent emb
chief_complaint: The patient presented with primary infertility of 3 years duration.
history: A 42-year-old Caucasian nulligravida with primary infertility for three years. She had undergone five previous IVF cycles, none resulting in embryo transfer due to genetic abnormalities identified during pre-implantation genetic screening. She is a nonsmoker in excellent health, and her previous ovarian stimulation responses were consistently adequate.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: Serum AMH: 0.97 ng/ml; Patient and partner G-band karyotypes: normal; Patient and partner carrier screening: no mutations/deletions; Semen analysis: unremarkable; Sperm DNA fragmentation index: 9%.
imaging_description: Transvaginal ultrasound was used for ovarian guidance during injections and later confirmed normal-appearing ovaries post-IVF and a single intrauterine pregnancy with fetal heart activity (153/min) at six weeks' gestation.
diagnosis: Primary infertility due to recurrent embryonic aneuploidy, successfully treated with novel ovarian rejuvenation therapies and IVF.
treatment: The patient underwent five prior IVF cycles with unsuccessful embryo transfer. She then received two rounds of experimental ovarian treatments: first, autologous PRP injection, followed by a GnRH-antagonist IVF cycle. Second, intraovarian injection of isolated platelet-derived growth factors (Neokine), followed by a second GnRH-antagonist IVF cycle with adjusted gonadotropin doses, which yielded one euploid blastocyst. This blastocyst was subsequently thawed, transferred, and resulted in a successful pregnancy, culminating in an uncomplicated c-section delivery at 39 weeks.
key_learning_points: Recurrent embryonic aneuploidy poses a significant challenge in IVF, even in patients with adequate ovarian reserve.
Experimental ovarian rejuvenation techniques, such as intraovarian PRP and platelet-derived growth factor injections, are being explored for complex infertility cases with recurrent aneuploidy.
Comprehensive chromosomal screening (PGT-A) and single euploid blastocyst transfer can lead to a healthy live birth after multiple prior IVF failures.
description: A 42-year-old nulligravida with 3 years of primary infertility and recurrent embryonic aneuploidy achieved a healthy live birth following novel ovarian treatments and a single euploid blastocyst transfer.
clinical_text:
This 42- year old Caucasian nulligravida (BMI =20 m/kg2) with primary infertility of 3 years duration attended with her partner. Although the couple had undergone five IVF cycles at two different facilities, none of the 20 embryos generated during treatment were transferred due to genetic abnormalities identified during pre-implantation genetic screening (Table 1). Review of previous clinical records showed consistent, adequate responses to numerous gonadotropin stimulation regimes; no cycles were cancelled (or converted to intrauterine insemination (IUI)) because of poor follicular recruitment. Serum anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) here was 0.97 ng/ml, consistent with ovarian reserve appropriate for chronological age. Both partners were nonsmokers in excellent health. Standard G-band karyotypes and Recombine  carrier screening panel (Reprogenetics; Livingston NJ USA) identified no mutations or deletions for either partner. Semen analysis was unremarkable and sperm chromatin analysis returned a DNA fragmentation index of 9%.
Prior to embarking on her next (sixth) IVF cycle, at this center the patient received autologous PRP injection to both ovaries under ultrasound guidance at this center. Three months later, controlled ovarian hyperstimulation with 150 IU/d recombinant follicle-stimulating hormone (rec-FSH) + 150 IU/d human menopausal gonadotropin (hMG) commenced incorporating a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) -antagonist (9), selected after review of prior cycle data. While six eggs were retrieved and five advanced to the blastocyst stage, unfortunately all were aneuploid, and therefore embryo transfer was not performed. The following month, after transvaginal ultrasound exam confirmed normal appearing ovaries andreturn of menses post-IVF, a second bilateral intraovarian injection was performed:this time with isolated platelet-derived growth factors prepared as an enriched, cell-free substrate (Neokine ; Chicago USA) using a technique similar to previously reported methods.
A three, month interval elapsed before commencing her final IVF; for this cycle a GnRH-antagonist was again utilized but gonadotropin doses were adjusted (Table 1). Uniquely, this treatment action resulted in one euploid blastocyst which was cryopreserved on day of trophectoderm (TE) biopsy. Genetic assessments at our clinic and at the outside facilities were uniformly from blastocyst TE biopsy, which provided material for whole genome amplification and DNA tagmentation and PCR of adapter sequences. Next, comprehensive chromosomal screening was carried out by dual-indexed sequencing of pooled libraries on the MiSeq  platform (Illumina; San Diego USA).
Nine days after blastocyst thaw and transfer, the patient's serum human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) was 250 mIU/ml and transvaginal ultrasound at six weeks' gestation confirmed a single intrauterine pregnancy with fetal heart at 153/min. The patient underwent uncomplicated c-section delivery at 39 weeks' gestation had a healthy male infant (3459 g). Mother and child continue to do well at home. Written informed consent for treatment and unrestricted permission to publish/present these data in a non-identifiable manner were obtained by the patient.

title: A 47-year-old female presenting with fatigue was diagnosed with severe endometri
chief_complaint: Fatigue.
history: She had no significant medical or surgical history. Her menstrual cycle was regular and not painful, and she had never seen a gynaecologist. She was gravida 2 para 0.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: CA 125 was 44 U/mL (<30), CA 19.9 was 29 U/mL (<30), and CEA was < 0.5 ug/L (up to 4.6). Urea was 5.5 mmol/L (2.5-7.0), Creatinine was 72 mmol/L (45-85), and eGFR was 86 (>59). Urine cytology showed red blood cells but was negative for high-grade urothelial carcinoma.
imaging_description: A pelvic ultrasound scan revealed an enlarged, adenomyotic uterus (84 x 67 x 88 mm, volume 260 cc) with normal ovaries. An ultrasound scan of the upper renal tract noted significant right hydronephrosis (renal pelvis anterior-posterior diameter of 42 mm) with parenchymal thinning. A CT urogram confirmed significant right hydronephrosis with marked thinning of the renal parenchyma, minimal contrast uptake by the affected kidney on delayed imaging, no renal, ureteric or bladder calculi, and a dilated right ureter identified at the pelvic brim with surrounding soft tissue density. MAG 3 scintigraphy showed the right kidney was nonfunctional.
