treatment: Diagnostic laparoscopy and ovarian drilling were performed, during which a 2 cm yellowish nodular solid and hardened formation was observed in the right ovary and surgically removed without rupture. Tubal patency test confirmed bilateral permeability. Postoperatively, the patient was followed with serial serum testosterone levels and transvaginal ultrasound, and was later proposed for in vitro fertilization treatment, including high-dose gonadotropin therapy, despite which she had no ovarian response.
key_learning_points: Ovarian steroid cell tumor NOS is a rare cause of ovarian mass, which may be discovered during infertility workup.
Detailed histopathological and immunohistochemical studies are essential for the definitive diagnosis of rare ovarian tumors.
Fertility treatment post-ovarian tumor resection, especially with prior ovarian drilling, can be challenging due to impaired ovarian response.
description: A 30-year-old nulligravida presented with primary infertility, leading to the discovery and surgical removal of an ovarian steroid cell tumor NOS, followed by unsuccessful IVF attempts.
clinical_text:
A 30-year-old nulligravida presented herself in our institution because of the inability to conceive for four years. She was healthy, with no history of previous surgeries. Menarche had occurred at age 14. She had used oral contraceptives for nine years, having stopped taking them four years ago, followed by regular menses. No one in her family had history of infertility or any type of gynecologic cancer.
General examination and body mass index were normal. Analytically she had normal blood count and hormonal assay [FSH, LH, TSH, free T4, testosterone, and dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA)]. A transvaginal ultrasonography was performed revealing a normed uterus and ovaries slightly enlarged and polycystic with a small echogenic mass in the right ovary of 15 millimeters. The hysterosalpingography was normal.
Her husband was healthy and had no relevant past medical history and his semen analysis was normal.
She was proposed for a diagnostic laparoscopy and ovarian drilling. In the surgery, both ovaries were polycystic and a yellowish nodular solid and hardened formation of about two centimeters, vascular and friable to touch, was observed in the right ovary. That mass was removed, without rupture, and removed in an endoscopic bag. Tubal patency test confirmed bilateral permeability.
The removed mass was sent to histological examination. Macroscopically, it was a yellow-colored tumor measuring two centimeters in greatest diameter, with a smooth and well-limited surface. Microscopically, the ovarian parenchyma was almost entirely occupied by a tumor lesion, represented by large polyhedral cells with small nuclei and vacuolated eosinophilic cytoplasm, without mitosis and nuclear atypia. Hemorrhage and necrotic areas were absent (Figure 1). Immunohistochemical study revealed diffuse marking for calretinin, vimentin, and melan-A (Figure 2). These features were consistent with ovarian steroid cell tumor NOS.
In the postoperative period, the woman is followed up with serial measurements of serum testosterone levels and transvaginal ultrasound. At 24 months, she had no evidence of recurrence and began follow-up in reproductive medicine consultation. She was proposed to in vitro fertilization treatment, but despite gonadotropin therapy (in high doses, 300U) for ovarian stimulation, she had no response. At 36 months postoperatively, she is still not pregnant and no evidence of recurrence too.

title: A 43-year-old male presented with gum bleeding and bilateral visual loss and was
chief_complaint: A 43-year-old male presented with a 3-month history of gum pain and bleeding and 6-week history of bilateral visual loss.
history: The patient had no significant past medical or family history of bleeding disorders, eye disease, or diabetes mellitus. He denied smoking or alcohol use. He was recently diagnosed with mild, untreated hypertension.
exam_findings: Mildly pale appearance, BP 140/90 mmHg, pulse rate 136 bpm, RR 22 cycles/min. Ocular findings included bilateral hyperpigmented infraorbital skin lesions, VA of hand motion OU, sluggish pupils, diffuse retinal hemorrhages, IOP 12 mmHg OU, and central visual field defects (worse in LE).
labs: Reduced Na+, bicarbonate, and alkaline phosphatase; elevated creatinine. Elevated PT and PTTK with INR 1.42 (normal 0.9-1.3). Serum protein electrophoresis showed a large monoclonal IgG Lambda peak (75.1 g/dL) in the beta-region. Elevated beta 2-microglobulin (7.1 mg/dL, normal 1.16-2.52 mg/dL) with normal LDH. Bone marrow examination showed reduced hematopoiesis, increased lymphocytes (61%), and 2% plasma cells, positive for CD138, CD56, CD20, and negative for CD38.
imaging_description: Optical coherence tomography revealed retinal hemorrhage, oedema, detachment, and diffuse photoreceptor damage.
diagnosis: Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma complicated by hyperviscosity retinopathy.
treatment: Four cycles of manual exchange blood transfusion (EBT), tablet allopurinol 100 mg/day, tablet chlorambucil 8 mg daily, tablet prednisolone 20 mg bid, liberal oral fluids, gutt Zaditen Ophtha every 8 hours OU, and tablet Diamox 250 mg every 12 hours.
key_learning_points: Unexplained bleeding and progressive visual loss can be symptoms of hyperviscosity syndrome, a medical emergency.
Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma is a cause of hyperviscosity syndrome, often presenting with symptoms related to impaired blood flow and coagulopathy.

Diagnosis involves detecting monoclonal gammopathy (e.g., IgG Lambda) via serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation, and confirming the underlying malignancy with bone marrow examination and immunocytochemistry.
Management of hyperviscosity syndrome requires urgent reduction of blood viscosity (e.g., plasmapheresis or EBT) and treatment of the underlying hematologic malignancy.
description: A 43-year-old male presented with gum bleeding and bilateral visual loss and was diagnosed with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma complicated by hyperviscosity retinopathy.
clinical_text:
A 43-year-old Nigerian male presented with history of pain and bleeding from the gums for three months and bilateral visual loss of six weeks duration. The bleeding was heavy and in clots with associated generalized body weakness and increased exercise intolerance. There was neither history of trauma, tooth extraction, nor treatment with medications known to encourage bleeding such as warfarin or heparin. The patient had neither family history of bleeding disorder nor past history of haemoptysis, epistaxis, haematuria, melaena stool, and easy bruising. The visual loss was sudden, progressive, and essentially painless, with the left eye (LE) being first affected followed by the right eye (RE) about a month after. The patient denied any history of eye disease or diabetes mellitus in self or family. He neither smoked cigarettes nor imbibed alcohol. He was found to have mild hypertension elsewhere shortly before presentation but had not been placed on any antihypertensive drug. The general examination revealed a middle-aged man, mildly pale, and essentially in stable general clinical state. The respiratory rate was 22 cycles/min, pulse rate was 136 beats/min, and BP was 140/90 mmHg. The essential ocular findings were bilateral hyperpigmented infraorbital skin lesions, visual acuities (VA) of hand motion in both eyes, round and sluggish pupils, and diffuse and extensive retinal haemorrhages obliterating the retinal details. The intraocular pressure was 12 mmHg in both eyes. There were central visual field defects, worse in the LE (Figure 1).
The optical coherence tomography revealed retinal haemorrhage, oedema, detachment, and diffuse photoreceptors damage (Figure 2).
The results of initial blood investigations showed reduced Na+, bicarbonate, and alkaline phosphatase and elevated creatinine (Table 1).
The coagulation studies showed elevated PT and PTTK results with INR = 1.42 (0.9-1.3). The serum protein electrophoresis revealed a large monoclonal peak (75.1 g/dL) in the beta-region which was shown to be IgG Lambda by serum and urine immunofixations. beta 2-microglobulin was elevated -7.1 (1.16-2.52 mg/dL) with normal lactate dehydrogenase. The bone marrow examination showed a cellular marrow with reduced megakaryopoiesis, myelopoiesis, and erythropoiesis and increased lymphocytes (61%) with plasma cells constituting only 2% of nucleated cells in the marrow. Immunocytochemical studies at a reference laboratory showed positivity for CD138, CD56, and CD 20 with negativity for CD 38 suggestive of lymphoplasmacytic differentiation, while eyes findings including bilateral blindness and retinal features mimicking central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) are suggestive of hyperviscosity retinopathy. Therefore, a diagnosis of lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma complicated by hyperviscosity retinopathy was made.
In the absence of an aphaeresis machine the patient was given four cycles of manual EBT to address the hyperviscosity as well as tablet allopurinol 100 mg/day, tablet chlorambucil 8 mg daily (0.1 mg/kg/day), tablet prednisolone 20 mg bd, and liberal fluids orally. Additionally, eye medications including gutt Zaditen Ophtha (Ketotifen Fumarate) every 8 hours in both eyes and tablet Diamox (acetazolamide) 250 mg every 12 hours were administered.
Following treatment, the patient's general condition improved with less body weakness and improved vision. The gum bleeding and pain also subsided. The VA initially improved to 6/18 (both eyes) about a month into the treatment and stabilized at 6/12 (RE), 6/36 (LE) five months into treatment without any improvement with pin hole test. Nevertheless, the near vision improved from N36 to N8 (RE) but remained N36 (LE) with +1.50 DS presbyopic correction. There was no improvement in distance vision following refraction. The IOP stabilized between 12 and 10 mmHg.

title: 47-year-old male presented with hematuria and a left kidney mass, diagnosed as O
chief_complaint: The patient was admitted to hospital one week after a physical examination identified a left kidney tumor, presenting with hematuria.
history: The patient reported no lumbago, anorexia, fatigue, emaciation, or other systemic symptoms. Clinical laboratory test reports were generally normal prior to admission.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: Clinical laboratory test report was generally normal.
imaging_description: Urinary system ultrasound showed echoes of 3.1cm*2.6cm*2.2cm in the upper left renal collecting system with unclear boundary and visible peripheral blood flow. Lower abdominal CT plain scan + enhancement revealed a circular, slightly low-density shadow in the left kidney, about 4.6cm*3.7cm, with progressive uneven enhancement consistent with a malignant tumor.
diagnosis: Oxyphilic Papillary Renal Cell Carcinoma (OPRCC) of the left kidney, pathological stage pT3aNxMx.
treatment: Laparoscopic radical resection of left renal cancer, followed by adjuvant pembrolizumab 200mg intravenous drip once every three weeks.
key_learning_points: Hematuria is a common presenting symptom for renal malignancy.
The combination of ultrasound and CT imaging is crucial for the characterization and initial staging of renal tumors.

Pathological examination including immunohistochemistry is essential for the definitive diagnosis, subtyping (e.g., OPRCC), and accurate pathological staging of renal cell carcinoma, guiding subsequent treatment and prognosis.
description: 47-year-old male presented with hematuria and a left kidney mass, diagnosed as Oxyphilic Papillary Renal Cell Carcinoma (OPRCC) pT3aNxMx, successfully treated with laparoscopic radical nephrectomy and adjuvant pembrolizumab.
clinical_text:
A 47-year-old male patient was admitted to hospital one week after physical examination for a left kidney tumor. The patient presented with hematuria, accompanied by blood clot, occasional dysuria and urinary tract irritation without obvious inducement or reason one week before, and no lumbago, anorexia, fatigue, emaciation and other systemic symptoms.
1.Color ultrasound of urinary system was conducted on September 2, 2023 in our hospital before admission: echoes of 3.1cm*2.6cm*2.2cm were found in the upper left renal collecting system, the boundary was not clear, and blood flow was visible around the periphery.
2. Lower abdominal Computed Tomography (CT) plain scan + enhancement (conducted on September 6, 2023): Malignant tumor of left kidney (description: circular and slightly low-density shadow in left kidney, progressive uneven enhancement was observed on enhanced scan, about 4.6cm*3.7cm in size), clinical Laboratory test report was generally normal.
The patient was considered to have renal tumor with hematuria. The preliminary diagnosis was left renal malignancy (cT3aNxMx). The clinical stage was set as stage III renal cancer, and the surgical protocol was set as laparoscopic radical resection of left renal cancer.
Pathological diagnosis after operation: (left kidney) combined with immunohistochemistry was consistent with OPRCC. The tumor volume was 3.8cmx3cmx3cm. The tumor invaded the renal pelvis but did not invade the capsule of the kidney. Pathological stage (refer to AJ0C 8th Edition):pT3aNxMx. Immunohistochemical results: Vimentin (+), E - 0 adherin (+), PAX - 8 (+), RCC (+), P504S (+), CD10 (+), EMA (+), CAIX (+) a few, CD117 (-), CK7 (-), TFE3 part (-), 34betaE12 (-), FH (+), SDHB(+),Ki-67(10%+).
Pathological stage (refer to AJCC 8th Edition): pT3aNxMx
After surgery, the patient received pabolizumab 200mg (once every three weeks) intravenous drip.
Regular follow-up for 15 months., no signs of tumor recurrence and metastasis (Figure 1).

title: A 23-year-old female diagnosed with apical periodontitis on tooth 36 underwent e
chief_complaint: The patient suffered from apical periodontitis on tooth 36 after root canal treatment, leading to a hopeless prognosis.
history: A 23-year-old, healthy female patient with a history of periodontitis developed apical periodontitis following root canal treatment on tooth 36.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: Initial radiographs were used with a calibration ball for planning. Baseline bone crest in mesial and distal directions was documented. At 10 weeks post-implantation, a slight loss in bone height adjacent to the implant (mesial and distal) was observed, with no excess cement. Nine years after implant placement, remineralisation and new bone formation at the peri-implant interface, indicating stable biological conditions, were noted.
diagnosis: Apical periodontitis on tooth 36 with a hopeless prognosis, in a patient with a history of periodontitis.
treatment: Extraction of tooth 36, followed by delayed implantation with a one-piece implant (FairOne; diameter 5.0 mm, length 10 mm). A metal-supported ceramic crown was fabricated and placed, initially with provisional cementation (eugenol-free temporary cement) and later with permanent cementation (dual-curing dimethacrylate composite, PANAVIA F) using a custom analog to reduce excess cement.
key_learning_points: Management of tooth with hopeless prognosis post-endodontic treatment, involving extraction and implant placement.
Technique and considerations for delayed placement of a one-piece dental implant and subsequent prosthetic restoration.
Importance of precise impression techniques, laboratory procedures, and cementation protocols for implant crowns.
Long-term biological stability and bone remodeling around dental implants, as evidenced by nine-year follow-up imaging.
Strategies to minimize excess cement during implant crown cementation using custom analogs.
description: A 23-year-old female diagnosed with apical periodontitis on tooth 36 underwent extraction and delayed one-piece implant placement with subsequent ceramic crown restoration and nine-year follow-up.
clinical_text: For single crown restorations, the following case is aimed at illustrating the prosthetic procedure. A 23-year-old, healthy female patient diagnosed with periodontitis suffered from apical periodontitis after root canal treatment on tooth 36. Due to a hopeless prognosis, a decision was made to extract the tooth and to use delayed implantation with a one-piece implant. The clinical situation after atraumatic extraction showed no signs of inflammation and sufficient quantity of soft tissue (Figure 4(a)). Assessment of the correct position and dimensions for the planned reconstruction was realized using a radiograph with calibration ball. After implantation with a one-piece implant (FairOne ; diameter: 5.0 mm and length: 10 mm), it was ensured that no interference in the static or dynamic occlusion is occurring during healing. Minimal adjustments can be performed by means of the preparable head. In order to achieve accurate transmission for the prosthetic restoration, the geometric design should be preserved. This provides the possibility for direct impressions or digital scanning with high-detail reproduction and precision. In the posterior region, no provisional restoration was necessary during the healing phase, since there is no additional surgery for uncovering of the implant and no abutment dis-/reconnection shaping of the emergence profile occurred early during the initial healing phase on the continuous rough surface (Figure 4(b)). Additionally, the baseline of the bone crest in the mesial and distal direction is documented (Figure 4(g)). The impression could be performed using a double-mix technique with a polyether (Impregum , 3M, Landsberg am Lech, Germany) (Figure 4(c)). Within the laboratory process, a master cast in conjunction with an implant analog and gingival mask was used adjusting the prosthetic restoration and ensuring that the emergence profile of the crown is optimally contoured (Figure 4(d)). In cases were the clinical situation causes interference with the crown design, a transfer coping joined with pattern resin is fabricated. This could enable the surgeon to realize defined adjustments for the prosthetic head prior to the crown fitting and cementation process (Figure 4(e)). CAD/CAM processing is possible with the use of a digital implant model analog (CAM-Analog, FairImplant GmbH, Bonningstedt, Germany). The final restoration was placed using a metal-supported ceramic crown (Figure 4(f)). Provisional cementation for up to four weeks securing the final fitting of the contact situation in the approximal area and adjustment of the occlusal situation as well as the color of the crown was conducted with eugenol-free temporary cement (TempBondNE , Kerr GmbH, Bioggio, Switzerland). The permanent cementation was usually conducted using a dual-curing dimethacrylate composite with a custom analog for precementation to significantly reduce excess cement (PANAVIA F , Kuraray Noritake, Tokyo, Japan). Implant placement should ideally by controlled by periapical radiographs that were taken by the use of a long-cone paralleling technique. After 10 weeks of implant treatment, a slight loss in bone height adjacent to the implant in the mesial and distal direction could be observed but no excess of cement is evident (Figure 4(h)). The patient reported no complications during the procedure and the healing period. Nine years after implant placement, remineralisation and formation of new bone at the peri-implant interface can be observed presenting stable biological conditions (Figure 4(i)).

title: 13-year-old boy with mild intellectual disability and dysmorphic features diagno
chief_complaint: 13-year-old boy admitted for mild intellectual disability and dysmorphic features.
history: The patient is a 13-year-old boy, the only child of non-consanguineous, healthy Paraguayan parents. He was born at term by elective caesarean section with a birth weight of 4060g and had a delay in psychomotor development (sat at 8 months, walked at 18 months). He moved to Italy at 12 years old.
exam_findings: Neurological examination demonstrated mild clumsiness without obvious focal signs. Physical examination revealed a weight of 42.8 Kg (50-75th percentile), height of 161 cm (75-90th percentile), head circumference of 52 cm (3rd-10th percentile), facial dysmorphisms (hypertelorism, wide and flat nose), pectus excavatum, and chest asymmetry.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: Ultrasound imaging demonstrated the absence of pectoralis major and minor muscles on the right side and no additional anomalies of the kidney, urinary tract, or heart. Standing X-ray films of the full-length spine showed thoracolumbar scoliosis, without vertebral abnormalities. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed cerebellar vermis hypoplasia. Neurophysiological studies including electroencephalogram (EEG) and brainstem auditory evoked potentials (BAEP) resulted normal.
diagnosis: Poland Syndrome (MIM 173800), mild intellectual disability, cerebellar vermis hypoplasia, and thoracolumbar scoliosis.
treatment: Not described in this case.
key_learning_points: Poland Syndrome is characterized by unilateral absence of pectoralis muscles and can be associated with various other anomalies, including skeletal deformities and central nervous system defects.
Cerebellar vermis hypoplasia can be a neurological finding in patients with Poland Syndrome, potentially contributing to developmental delay and intellectual disability.
A comprehensive multi-system evaluation, including advanced imaging, is important in children presenting with dysmorphic features and unexplained developmental delays.
description: 13-year-old boy with mild intellectual disability and dysmorphic features diagnosed with Poland Syndrome, associated with cerebellar vermis hypoplasia and scoliosis.
clinical_text:
The patient, a 13-year-old boy, is the only child of non-consanguineous, healthy Paraguayan parents. The child was born at term by elective caesarean section after an uneventful pregnancy. Birth weight was 4060 g and no perinatal diseases were reported. Data on the patient's history as a child are not available because he lived in Paraguay with his grandparents, however delay in psychomotor development was reported (he was able to sit without support at 8 months and to walk at 18 months). At 12 years, he moved to Italy to join his mother and at 13 years he was admitted to our hospital because of mild intellectual disability and dysmorphic features.
the
Neurological examination demonstrated mild clumsiness without obvious focal signs. On physical examination, his weight was 42.8 Kg (50-75th percentile), height 161 cm (75-90th percentile), and head circumference 52 cm (3rd-10th percentile). He showed facial dysmorphisms (hypertelorism, wide and flat nose), pectus excavatum and chest asymmetry. The absence of pectoralis major and minor muscles on the right side was demonstrated by ultrasound imaging and the diagnosis of Poland Syndrome (PS) (MIM 173800) was made. Standing X-ray films of  full-length spine showed thoracolumbar scoliosis, without vertebral abnormalities (Figure 1A). No additional anomalies of the kidney, urinary tract, or heart were detected by ultrasound examination. Ophthalmologic evaluation demonstrated intermittent exotropia, bilateral myopia, and normal fundus oculi. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed cerebellar vermis hypoplasia (Figure 1B, C). Neurophysiological studies including electroencephalogram (EEG) and brainstem auditory evoked potentials (BAEP) resulted normal.
Cognitive impairment was revealed by psychometric evaluation (<5th centile at Raven's Progressive Matrices P.M.38).

title: 17-year-old Caucasian boy presented at age 15 with intention tremor, palpitation
chief_complaint: The patient presented with intention tremor, palpitations, and marked anxiety at age 15.
history: This 17-year-old Caucasian boy presented with symptoms two years prior to his current age. He was medicated with propranolol and hydroxyzine, which led to partial improvement of his symptoms. No other past medical history, allergies, or social/family history is described.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: Not described in this case.
diagnosis: Not described in this case snippet.
treatment: Propranolol and hydroxyzine were prescribed, leading to partial improvement of symptoms, followed by referral to a hospital pediatric appointment.
key_learning_points: Recognition of common presenting symptoms like tremor, palpitations, and anxiety in adolescents.
Initial pharmacologic management for symptoms such as tremor, palpitations, and anxiety.
Importance of specialist referral for persistent or partially improved symptoms in pediatric patients.
description: 17-year-old Caucasian boy presented at age 15 with intention tremor, palpitations, and marked anxiety, for which he received propranolol and hydroxyzine with partial improvement.
clinical_text: The patient is a 17-year-old Caucasian boy that presented with intention tremor, palpitations, and marked anxiety at age 15. He was medicated with propranolol and hydroxyzine with partial improvement of symptoms and was referred to a hospital pediatric appointment.

title: A ten-month-old male infant with Popliteal Pterygium Syndrome presented with a 9
specialty: Orthopedic Surgery, Pediatric Surgery, Plastic Surgery
chief_complaint: A male child presented at ten months of age with an abnormally flexed left knee and inability to extend it, which was observed at birth.
history: The patient was a male child, the first child of healthy parents, delivered at term via elective cesarean section without complications. There was no family history of similar conditions. Prior to presenting at ten months of age, multiple traditional massages and physiotherapies were attempted without satisfactory results.
exam_findings: An abnormally flexed left knee with a 90-degree rigid flexion contracture, left popliteal pterygium running from the buttock to the calcaneus, bilateral undescended testis, syndactyly of the left foot, and a sacral dimple.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: A plain radiograph showed no abnormality. An angiographic CT scan revealed no vascular disturbances and showed normal anatomical location and shape of the left popliteal artery. Intraoperatively, a short sciatic nerve was encountered.
diagnosis: Popliteal Pterygium Syndrome (presenting with left popliteal pterygium, severe knee flexion contracture, bilateral undescended testis, and syndactyly of the left foot).
treatment: Initial conservative management included multiple traditional massages and physiotherapies, which were unsuccessful. Surgical intervention involved multiple Z-plasties through a posterior approach, excision of a fibrotic band, and a fascicular shifting procedure to extend the sciatic nerve by approximately 7 cm using an 8-cm fascicular segment.
key_learning_points: Popliteal Pterygium Syndrome is a rare congenital condition characterized by a constellation of anomalies including skin webs across joints, joint contractures, and other malformations.
Surgical management of severe knee flexion contractures due to popliteal pterygium may require extensive soft tissue release, including Z-plasties for skin and excision of fibrotic bands.

Fascicular nerve shifting is a specialized technique that can be utilized to extend a shortened nerve, such as the sciatic nerve, in cases of severe joint contractures where nerve lengthening is critical for functional improvement.
Thorough preoperative assessment, including vascular imaging like CT angiography, is crucial to rule out vascular compromise and plan complex surgical interventions for severe congenital deformities.
description: A ten-month-old male infant with Popliteal Pterygium Syndrome presented with a 90-degree rigid left knee-flexion contracture, bilateral undescended testis, and syndactyly, successfully treated surgically with Z-plasties and a fascicular nerve shifting procedure.
clinical_text:
This case report describes a male child delivered at term via elective cesarean section without any complication. Both his parents were healthy and came to the obstetrician regularly for antenatal monitoring. The patient was the family's first child with no history of his relatives suffering from the same condition. From physical examination, an abnormally flexed left knee was observed at birth along with bilateral undescended testis and syndactyly of the left foot. The left popliteus pterygium runs from the buttock to the calcaneus, with an associated knee flexion contracture. The patient could not extend his knee as the popliteal pterygium caused a 90  rigid knee-flexion contracture (<PMC10051030_ORR-15-47-g0001_undivided_1_1.webp>). The parents opted for multiple traditional massages, and physiotherapies were performed without satisfactory results. The patient was initially encountered in our outpatient department at ten months of age. The delayed treatment was due to administrative problems including health insurance and the referral process. 
Surgical intervention was planned after an angiographic CT scan revealed that there were no vascular disturbances (<PMC10051030_ORR-15-47-g0002_undivided_1_1.webp>). We thoroughly informed the patient's parents that although fascicular shifting is a relatively new technique to be implemented especially in human and its failure rate is considered common, the realistic goal from releasing the contracture is to enable brace utilization daily. To these, the parents gave their full informed consent. 
Multiple Z-plasties through a posterior approach along with excision of the fibrotic band were performed. After meticulous dissection, a tight sciatic nerve was encountered (<PMC10051030_ORR-15-47-g0002_undivided_1_1.webp>). Fascicular shifting procedure was performed to extend the sciatic nerve for approximately 7 cm. The sciatic trunk was exposed at the popliteal level, and an 8-cm fascicular segment was excised from the distal stump and sutured to the proximal stump using 10/0 non-absorbable thread under an operating microscope (Zeiss) (Figure 3). The chosen length of fascicular segment was unlike previous reports in other centers which excised a much shorter segment.
image_captions: Preoperative marking and plain radiograph. Note the presence of sacral dimple prior to surgery but no abnormality seen from x-ray.

Comparison of the right and left CT-Scan of the lower extremities, showing normal anatomical location and shape of the left popliteal artery (left image). Intra operative short sciatic nerve (right image).

title: 30yo woman with refractory occipital neuralgia presented with sudden severe pain
chief_complaint: Sudden onset of severe unilateral pain, spasms, and myoclonus in the right upper nuchal, occipital, and parietal regions.
history: A 30-year-old woman with a 5-year history of refractory occipital neuralgia, who had failed medical therapy (pregabalin, duloxetine) and received only temporary relief from rhizotomies and nerve blocks. She underwent microvascular decompression for trigeminal neuralgia 6 years prior, complicated by successfully managed cerebral venous sinus thrombosis and mastoiditis.
presenting_symptoms: Severe unilateral pain (stabbing, sharp, lancinating, paroxysmal)
Pain originating in right upper nuchal region, spreading to occipital and parietal regions
Spasms in right trapezius, scalene, and supraspinatus muscles
Myoclonus in right trapezius, scalene, and supraspinatus muscles
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: A skull radiography showed occipital nerve stimulator (ONS) lead migration. Subsequent imaging after surgery confirmed correctly repositioned lead and internal pulse generator (IPG) placement.
diagnosis: Occipital nerve stimulator (ONS) lead migration complicated by extensive fibrosis, causing intractable pain, muscle spasms, and myoclonus.
treatment: Surgical lead repositioning was performed, which involved thorough dissection and release of fibrotic tissue, removal of the original ONS lead and IPG, and re-implantation of the system. Post-operative IPG settings are being optimized for pain control.
key_learning_points: Occipital nerve stimulator (ONS) lead migration is a potential complication of neuromodulation therapy.
Extensive fibrosis can cause ONS lead migration by producing constriction points and tension on the lead.
Clinical manifestations of ONS lead migration include new or worsening pain, muscle spasms, and myoclonus in the affected region.
Surgical intervention is required to address ONS lead migration, involving dissection of fibrotic tissue and lead repositioning or replacement.
The importance of proper stress relief loop creation during ONS implantation to minimize tension and prevent migration.
description: 30yo woman with refractory occipital neuralgia presented with sudden severe pain, spasms, and myoclonus due to ONS lead migration caused by fibrosis.
clinical_text:
A 30-year-old woman with a 5-year history of refractory occipital neuralgia, who had been under ONS therapy for 2 months, presented with a sudden onset of severe unilateral pain, originating in the right upper nuchal region and spreading to the occipital and parietal regions. The pain was described as stabbing, sharp, lancinating, and occurred in paroxysms. The patient also described spasms and myoclonus that occurred in the right trapezius, scalene, and supraspinatus muscles, a new symptomatic component that had not accompanied her typical occipital neuralgia pain before.
The patient had a history of microvascular decompression surgery 6 years before as a treatment for trigeminal neuralgia, with full remission of symptoms. She developed cerebral venous sinus thrombosis and mastoiditis as immediate postoperative complications, but they were appropriately and successfully managed.
Due to the failure of medical therapy for occipital neuralgia (pregabalin and duloxetine), the patient had been submitted to three percutaneous radiofrequency rhizotomies (1, 3, and 4 years ago) which provided immediate symptomatic relief and yielded significant pain control, but for a limited time. She had also received two occipital nerve blocks through local anesthesia, but with poor effect in long-term pain management.
The pain had become progressively more severe, more frequent and associated with nausea. As a result of the unresponsiveness to less invasive procedures, the patient underwent ONS 2 months ago.
ONS was employed through surgery. The patient was placed in prone position under anesthesia. A right paramedian incision was performed in the level of C1 vertebra and a pathway was carefully dissected over the muscle fascia, toward the mastoid region. Once the correct position was asserted through fluoroscopy, a lead containing 16 electrode contacts was inserted and anchored over the muscle fascia. The IPG was placed in the infraclavicular region, in a subcutaneous pocket, and connected to the lead extension, which was inserted through subcutaneous tunneling. A stress relief loop was produced with the lead cable extension in the subcutaneous pocket, alongside the IPG, forming a circular coil to minimize tension on the lead [<PMC8168692_SNI-12-189-g001_undivided_1_1.webp>]. The technique provided adequate pain management after optimization of the IPG settings.
Two months after ONS were implemented, the patient suddenly started with the symptoms and manifestations described. When the ONS system was turned off, the spasms and myoclonus ceased. A skull radiography showed lead migration [Figure 2].
The patient underwent surgery for lead repositioning. During surgery, extensive fibrosis was identified throughout the lead extension loop, which was deemed as cause for the lead migration. The fibrosis produced numerous points of constriction along the stress relief loop, which provided tension over the lead during head-and-neck movement and caused its migration.
We conducted thorough dissection of the fibrotic tissue, releasing the stress relief loop, and removing the IPG from the infraclavicular subcutaneous pocket [<PMC8168692_SNI-12-189-g003_undivided_1_1.webp>]. A low cervical incision was made over the dislocated lead position guided by fluoroscopy and new tunneling was performed due to important fibrosis in the subcutaneous that restrained the lead from being removed. The lead and cables were then removed through the infraclavicular incision. The lead was repositioned through the former occipital incision and the system was reinserted as described previously [<PMC8168692_SNI-12-189-g004_undivided_1_1.webp>].
After lead repositioning, the patient did not experience any muscle spasms or myoclonus. The pain intensity significantly decreased and the IPG settings are still being managed to optimize pain control.
image_captions: Lead and internal pulse generator correctly located after surgery for occipital nerve stimulation.
Repositioned lead after surgery.

title: 69yo post-menopausal woman with severe hirsutism and elevated testosterone due t
chief_complaint: Several months of increasing terminal hair growth on her face, torso, and arms, requiring shaving.
history: The patient is a 69-year-old post-menopausal woman with a significant past medical history including Crohn's disease status-post total colectomy and ileostomy, complicated by multiple abdominal surgeries, fistula formation, and a large parastomal hernia. She also has chronic renal insufficiency, renal stones, polymyalgia rheumatica, restless leg syndrome, asthma, arthritis, osteoporosis, and depression. Her obstetrical history includes six pregnancies with one vaginal delivery, one tubal ectopic pregnancy, and four 2nd trimester spontaneous abortions. Her current medications include albuterol, fluticasone, benzonatate, lactobacillus, calcium carbonate, cholecalciferol, cyanocobalamin, fenofibrate, omeprazole, zolpidem, citalopram, gabapentin, hydrocodone, pramipexole, furosemide, and zoledronic acid. Family history is non-contributory.
presenting_symptoms: Increasing terminal hair growth on face, torso, and arms (hirsutism)
exam_findings: The patient's height was 63 in, weight 157 lb (BMI 27.9 kg/m2), and blood pressure 122/81 mmHg. Skin examination confirmed extensive hirsutism of the face, neck, and chin, and significant frontotemporal balding. She was a cheerful, elderly white female with an evident shaven beard and hairline recession. There was no clitoromegaly.
labs: Initial serum total testosterone: 160 ng/dL (normal 5-32 ng/dL); later 100.6 ng/dL (normal 2.9-40.8 ng/dL). ACTH level: normal. DHEA-S level: below assay detection. Serum creatinine: 1.3-1.6 mg/dL. FSH: 112.1 mIU/mL (normal 25.8-134.8 mIU/mL). LH: 62.4 mIU/mL (normal 7.7-58.5 mIU/mL). Estradiol: 9 pg/mL (normal 0-47 pg/mL). Hemoglobin A1c: 5.9% (normal <6.0%). Cholesterol: 142 mg/dL. HDL: 51 mg/dL. Triglycerides: 101 mg/dL. Calculated LDL: 71 mg/dL.
imaging_description: Initial transvaginal pelvic ultrasound showed two simple cysts (11 x 12 x 8 mm and 11 mm) and a 6 x 6 x 7 mm hypoechoic structure in the right adnexa; the left ovary was not visualized. A follow-up transvaginal pelvic ultrasound demonstrated a normal right ovary (17 x 5 mm) and a 13 x 9 mm left paratubal cyst; the left ovary was again not seen. MRI of the pelvis did not demonstrate any adnexal masses. Adrenal MRI was unremarkable.
diagnosis: Severe hyperandrogenism with a suspected ovarian source, likely due to an occult ovarian lesion or stromal hyperthecosis, given elevated testosterone, suppressed DHEA-S, and negative adrenal imaging.
treatment: Possible surgical exploration and oophorectomy were considered but deemed infeasible due to multiple prior abdominal surgeries and a massive parastomal hernia. Medical management with a GnRH agonist (leuprolide) was recommended to assess gonadotropin-responsiveness of testosterone production, but the patient did not initiate treatment due to a slight decrease in testosterone and insurance coverage issues.
key_learning_points: Persistent hyperandrogenism in a post-menopausal woman despite normal imaging suggests an occult ovarian source, such as stromal hyperthecosis or a hilus cell tumor.
Complex past surgical history and comorbidities can significantly impact treatment options for conditions requiring surgical intervention.
GnRH agonists can be used to differentiate gonadotropin-dependent vs. independent ovarian testosterone production.
Thorough evaluation of hyperandrogenism requires careful interpretation of multiple endocrine tests and imaging, considering both adrenal and ovarian etiologies.
Challenges in localizing an ovarian source of hyperandrogenism are common, especially with small lesions or diffuse processes.
description: 69yo post-menopausal woman with severe hirsutism and elevated testosterone due to a suspected ovarian source, presenting a diagnostic and therapeutic challenge given extensive surgical history and imaging limitations.
clinical_text:
A 69 year-old post-menopausal woman presented to her primary care physician with several months of increasing terminal hair growth on her face, torso, and arms, requiring shaving. There was also recession of the hairline, but no clitoromegaly. An initial endocrine evaluation demonstrated a markedly elevated serum total testosterone of 160 ng/dL (normal 5-32 ng/dL). ACTH level was normal, and the DHEA-S level was below assay detection. Initial transvaginal pelvic ultrasound demonstrated two simple cysts measuring 11 x 12 x 8 mm and 11 mm, and a 6 x 6 x 7 mm hypoechoic structure in the right adnexa; the left ovary was not visualized. A follow-up transvaginal pelvic ultrasound demonstrated a normal right ovary measuring 17 x 5 mm and a 13 x 9 mm left paratubal cyst; the left ovary was again not seen. An MRI of the pelvis did not demonstrate any adnexal masses, and an adrenal MRI was unremarkable as well.
Her past obstetrical history was notable for six pregnancies, one vaginal delivery, one tubal ectopic pregnancy, and four 2nd trimester spontaneous abortions. Her past medical history included Crohn's disease status-post total colectomy and ileostomy. Her condition was complicated further by fistula formation through an appendectomy scar, stoma relocation, hernia repair, and development of a secondary large parastomal hernia. These operations resulted in scarring of the inside of her entire abdomen and replacement of her left lower quadrant by the large parastomal hernia. She also had chronic renal insufficiency with the serum creatinine elevated to 1.3-1.6 mg/dL. Other less significant factors in her medical history were renal stones status-post surgical removal, polymyalgia rheumatica, restless leg syndrome, asthma, arthritis, and osteoporosis, and depression.
On physical examination, the patient's height was 63 in and weight was 157 lb (body mass index, 27.9 kg/m2). Her blood pressure was 122/81 mmHg. Skin examination confirmed the presence of extensive hirsutism of the face, neck and chin, and significant frontotemporal balding.
Her medications at initial evaluation included an albuterol inhaler, fluticasone, benzonatate, lactobacillus, calcium carbonate, cholecalciferol, cyanocobalamin, fenofibrate, omeprazole, zolpidem, citalopram, gabapentin, hydrocodone, pramipexole, furosemide, and zoledronic acid, none of which are known to have androgenic side effects.
Her family history was non-contributory.
Given the low levels of DHEA-S and normal adrenal imaging, an adrenal source for the testosterone was thought to be unlikely, and an ovarian source was suspected. The patient was referred to a gynecologic oncologist for possible surgical exploration and oophorectomy; however, she was deemed to be a poor operative candidate due to her multiple prior abdominal surgeries and massive lower left quadrant parastomal hernia. The patient was then referred to the reproductive endocrinology clinic for possible medical management.
Physical examination confirmed a cheerful, elderly white female with an evident shaven beard, and hairline recession. Laboratory testing demonstrated: testosterone 100.6 ng/dL (normal 2.9-40.8 ng/dL), FSH 112.1 mIU/mL (normal 25.8-134.8 mIU/mL), LH 62.4 mIU/mL (normal 7.7-58.5 mIU/mL), and estradiol 9 pg/mL (normal 0-47 pg/mL). Her hemoglobin A1c at this time was 5.9% (normal <6.0%). Lipid levels several months prior to presentation were: cholesterol 142 mg/dL (normal <200 mg/dL), HDL 51 mg/dL (normal >40 mg/dL), triglycerides 101 mg/dL (normal <150 mg/dL), and a calculated LDL 71 mg/dL (normal <129 mg/dL). A recommendation was given to start a GnRH agonist (leuprolide) to determine whether her testosterone production was gonadotropin-responsive. However, the patient did not start the GnRH agonist at that time for two reasons. First, the testosterone level had decreased somewhat on its own, though it was still quite elevated (160 ng/dL to 100 ng/dL). Second, the patient's health insurance, Medicare, would not cover the off-label use of the medication, and the patient could not afford an out-of-pocket cost of ~ $1000/month for the intramuscular depot injection of leuprolide.
Over the next two years, the patient had a progression of her symptoms, including continued scalp hair loss requiring a wig, increased body and facial hair requiring daily shaving, increased body odor and libido, and a deepening of the voice. Several high-resolution transvaginal ultrasounds over these two years continued to demonstrate a grossly normal right ovary (1.7 cm x 0.5 cm) The left ovary was visualized on the most recent ultrasound, and was also grossly normal (1.7 cm x 0.5 cm). Total testosterone levels remained elevated up to 151 ng/dL (normal 8-60 ng/dL). Because the patient continued to be a high risk surgical candidate with no clear surgical target, the patient was referred back to the reproductive endocrinology clinic to reconsider medical management.
At the time of that appointment, her testosterone had increased to 187.4 ng/dL (normal 2.9-40.8 ng/dL) and free testosterone was 1.3 pg/mL (normal 0.14-1.72 pg/mL). The patient was started on 20 U (1 mg) of daily subcutaneous injection of leuprolide (~$300/month), which her husband helped her administer at home. Two weeks later, testosterone levels had normalized to 23.9 ng/dL, confirming gonadotropin-responsive testosterone secretion, most likely of ovarian etiology.
Unfortunately, two months after starting leuprolide, the patient reported significant "hot flashes", difficulty sleeping, and feeling anxious and depressed. On laboratory evaluation, the total and free testosterone levels were suppressed to below assay range <2.5 ng/dL (normal 2.9-40.8 ng/dL) and <0.43 pg/mL (normal 0.14-1.72 pg/mL), respectively. The patient was advised to use half of an estradiol/norethindrone acetate patch twice weekly to relieve symptoms. However, her depressive symptoms and fatigue persisted even in the presence of add-back therapy, and given the high cost of the medication not covered by Medicare, the patient decided against pursuing further attempts at increasing progestin add-back therapy and discontinued the leuprolide one month later (three months after starting injections). At follow-up 2 weeks after discontinuing leuprolide, the patient's testosterone had increased slightly to 6.5 ng/dL (normal 2.9-40.8 ng/dL).
Her lipid levels at this time were as follows: cholesterol 149 mg/dL (normal 100-199 mg/dL), HDL 39 mg/dL (normal 40-80 mg/dL), triglycerides 280 mg/dL (normal 35-150 mg/dL), and a calculated LDL 54 mg/dL (normal 50-129 mg/dL). The patient's hemoglobin A1c level was 6.4% (normal <6.0%); with the aim of lowering her glucose levels and potentially ameliorating the hirsutism, she was subsequently started on metformin. At the last check-in, six months after discontinuing leuprolide therapy, her testosterone level increased to 85.24 ng/dL (normal 14-76 ng/dL), and she reported still having to shave her chin, but not as frequently as in the past. She reported being generally in good spirits, although low on energy secondary to having been recently hospitalized for medical complications unrelated to the elevated testosterone.

Recognizing Wilcoxon's signed rank test as a non-parametric alternative for paired data.
Interpreting p-values (<= 0.05) to determine statistical significance in research findings.

description: This text exclusively details the statistical methods used in a study, without providing any patient clinical information, symptoms, diagnosis, or treatment.
clinical_text: Comparative statistics were performed between T0 and T5. Paired samples test was used to test the difference in FMBS, FMPS, and PPD. Wilcoxon's signed rank was used to calculate the significance of the patient related outcomes (VAS and OPCS). P values <= 0.05 were considered to be statistically significant. SPSS (SPSS for windows, version 11, SPSS inc, Chicago, IL, USA) statistical software was utilized.

title: 10-year-old male with probable autoimmune encephalitis and refractory seizures,
chief_complaint: A 10-year-old male presented with acute onset of poor communication, fatigue, lethargy, drowsiness, and generalized convulsions, following a resolved fever.
history: This 10-year-old male, weighing 35 kg, had a previously healthy medical history and normal psychomotor development. He was in grade 5 with good academic performance. No other relevant medical, social, or family history was described.
presenting_symptoms: Generalized convulsions (with eye rotation, purple coloration, loss of consciousness)
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: CSF showed 0 cells/mm3 with normal protein and glucose. Microbiological tests for herpes simplex virus, Japanese encephalitis virus, and bacteria cultures were negative. CSF anti-NMDAR autoantibody test was negative. Blood antinuclear antibody test was negative. Cancer screening (CT chest, abdominal ultrasound) was normal.
imaging_description: Initial brain MRI results were normal. A second brain MRI did not show any abnormalities. CT chest scan was normal. Abdominal ultrasound was normal.
diagnosis: Probable autoimmune encephalitis with negative anti-NMDAR antibodies.
treatment: Acyclovir was started then discontinued. Methylprednisolone 20 mg/kg/day was given for 5 days. Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) 2 g/kg was administered for 5 days, followed by maintenance IVIG 0.4 mg/kg weekly for 5 consecutive weeks. Antiepileptic drugs included oxcarbazepine (initial 600 mg/day, increased to 1050 mg/day), topiramate (initial 100 mg/day, increased to 200 mg/day), levetiracetam 500 mg/day, and prednisone 1 mg/kg daily for 6 weeks. Haloperidol 1 mg at night was also added. Outpatient treatment continued with oxcarbazepine, topiramate, levetiracetam, and haloperidol.
key_learning_points: Autoimmune encephalitis can present with acute neurological symptoms and refractory seizures, even with negative NMDAR antibodies.
A comprehensive diagnostic workup for encephalitis includes CSF analysis, neuroimaging, and specific antibody tests, even when initial findings are non-diagnostic.
Management often involves a combination of immunomodulatory therapies (steroids, IVIG) and multiple antiepileptic drugs for seizure control.
Patients with severe autoimmune encephalitis can achieve significant cognitive recovery, but may require long-term management and face risk of relapse.
Consider other autoimmune causes or atypical presentations of known autoimmune encephalitides when initial antibody panels are negative.
description: 10-year-old male with probable autoimmune encephalitis and refractory seizures, showing significant improvement with immunomodulatory and antiepileptic therapies despite negative NMDAR antibodies.
clinical_text:
A 10-year-old male patient, weighing 35 kg, with a previously healthy medical history and normal psychomotor development, was in grade 5, with good academic performance. The disease progression was documented in 2 separate periods.
The first period was characterized by the acute onset of fever (39.5 C) associated with an unknown infection for 3 days that resolved on its own, with no specific treatment. One day after the fever stopped, symptoms of poor communication, fatigue, lethargy, and drowsiness appeared. The onset of convulsions was marked by the rotation of the eyes in the direction of head motion, sometimes to the left and sometimes to the right, which developed into generalized convulsions, accompanied by a purple coloration, and the loss of consciousness. Each episode lasted 1 to 2 minutes, with urinary incontinence and lethargy after each episode.
The patient was admitted to the hospital with an early diagnosis of suspected herpes encephalitis, and acyclovir treatment was started. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) showed 0 cells/mm3, and protein and glucose levels were within the normal range. Microbiological tests for herpes simplex virus, Japanese encephalitis virus, and bacteria cultures were performed and were negative. An anti-NMDAR autoantibody test performed on CSF was negative. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) results were normal. The antinuclear antibody test of the blood was negative. The patient was diagnosed with probable autoimmune encephalitis with negative anti-NMDAR antibodies. Acyclovir was discontinued after 3 days. Methylprednisolone 20 mg/kg/day was started in the second week of disease and last for 5 days. Oxcarbazepine was started at 600 mg/day. The following week, the patient was treated with 2 g/kg intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) for 5 days, and antiepileptic drugs (600 mg/day oxcarbazepine and 100 mg/day topiramate) and 1 mg/kg prednisone were taken daily for 6 weeks. Electroencephalography (EEG) results showed local onset paroxysmal activity in the left hemisphere with inhibited background activity (Figures 1 and 2). Many types of localized seizures were observed, accompanied by confusion, loss of time orientation, amnesia, insomnia, symptoms of hyperactivity disorder, irritability, and abnormal movement disorder included twisted mouth, no autonomic dysfunction, speech dysfunction. Maintenance IVIG therapy, at 0.4 mg/kg each week was administered for 5 consecutive weeks, and the doses of oxcarbazepine and topiramate were gradually increased to 1050 and 200 mg/day, respectively, and 1 mg haloperidol at night and 500 mg/day levetiracetam were added. Convulsions ceased after 14 days, stopped a few days, then relapsed with a frequency of 3 to 4 attacks/week. At sixth to ninth week, cancer screening tests, including computed tomography (CT) chest scan, were normal. Normal abdominal ultrasound. The patient showed improvement in cognitive-behavioral disorder symptoms and memory recovery but remained hyperactive and easily agitated. After 2 months of inpatient treatment, the patient was discharged from the hospital and continued outpatient treatment with antiepileptic drugs, including oxcarbazepine, topiramate, levetiracetam, and haloperidol.
At thirrd month, re-examination, and re-assessment, the patient continued to experience 1 to 2 seizure episodes/month, returned to school, played chess, and performed math. The patient scored 125 points (high IQ) on the Raven's Progressive Matrices intelligence quotient (IQ) test; 7/9 on the hyperactivity and 4/9 on the attention reduction scales of the Vanderbilt ADHD Diagnostic Rating Scale; and 2/8 on the impulsivity, and displayed significantly reduced behavioral disturbances. The second brain MRI did not show any abnormalities. The symptoms, laboratory data, and treatment modalities for this period lasted for 19 weeks and are presented in Table 1.
Five months after the disease onset, the recurrence of multiple seizures was observed, and the patient presented to the Children's Hospital 2. The results of CSF analysis showed 8 white blood cells/mm3 and normal protein and glucose levels. CSF and blood were examined using indirect immunofluorescence to detect 5 antibodies known to cause autoimmune encephalitis, including those against NMDAR, leucine-rich glioma-inactivated 1 (LGI1), contactin-associated protein-like 2 (CASPR2), gamma-aminobutyric acid B receptor (GABABR), and AMPAR (Figure 3). The result was positive for the AMPAR antibody. The brain MRI was normal. EEG showed generalized paroxysmal epileptic activity in the left temporal lobe with abnormal slow-wave background activity. Cancer screening tests, including a computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest and an ultrasound of the abdomen, were normal. The patient was diagnosed with anti-AMPAR encephalitis. Autoimmune-induced local epilepsy was treated with 30 mg/kg/day methylprednisolone for 5 days, and the antiepileptic drug treatment was adjusted (increase oxcarbazepine to 1800 mg/day, reduced levetiracetam to 3000 mg/day, and maintained topiramate at 300 mg/day). The patient responded with a significant reduction in seizure frequency, experiencing occasional short seizures lasting for a few seconds, with no purpleness and improved behavioral disturbances. Test Raven IQ again showed high IQ (110 points). This progression lasted from weeks 20 to 30 (Table 1).

title: A girl diagnosed with MPS I due to Q70X and Delta349 mutations presented with fr
chief_complaint: Frequent diarrhea or loose stools, often accompanied by vomiting.
history: A girl, diagnosed enzymatically for MPS I (McKusick's OMIM 25280) at 3 years and 9 months, was investigated until 5 years and 4 months. Genetic analysis revealed a Q70X truncation and an in-frame Delta349 deletion in the alpha-L-iduronidase gene. Her family members had no documented chronic diarrhea or intestinal infections.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: Enzymatic diagnosis for MPS I. Genetic analysis showed a Q70X truncation and an in-frame Delta349 deletion in the alpha-L-iduronidase gene. Stool microbiological analyses detected bacterial, viral, or fungal infections using various media and biochemical/immunological assays. Identification methods included specific detection of non-enteropathogenic E. coli, Enterococcus faecalis, other Enterobacteriaceae, and enteropathogenic E. coli strains based on O antigens (groups A, B, C).
imaging_description: Not described in this case.
diagnosis: Mucopolysaccharidosis type I (MPS I, Hurler syndrome, Scheie syndrome) with alpha-L-iduronidase gene mutations Q70X and Delta349. Etiology of recurrent diarrhea was investigated through microbiological stool analyses for bacterial, viral, and fungal infections.
treatment: The patient was never treated with antibiotics before stool collection; no other treatments are mentioned in this report.
key_learning_points: Mucopolysaccharidosis type I (MPS I) is a lysosomal storage disorder that can present with significant gastrointestinal manifestations such as recurrent diarrhea and vomiting.

Genetic analysis, including identification of specific mutations like Q70X and Delta349 in the alpha-L-iduronidase gene, is crucial for confirming MPS I diagnosis and understanding its molecular basis.

In patients with chronic or recurrent gastrointestinal symptoms, especially those with underlying genetic conditions, detailed microbiological investigation of stool for bacterial, viral, and fungal pathogens is essential for diagnosis and management.
description: A girl diagnosed with MPS I due to Q70X and Delta349 mutations presented with frequent diarrhea and vomiting, prompting detailed microbiological stool investigations.
clinical_text:
A girl, diagnosed enzymatically for MPS I (McKusick's OMIM (MPS I, Hurler syndrome, Scheie syndrome): 25280) at the age of 3 years and 9 months, was investigated until the age of 5 years and 4 months. Genetic analysis (performed by us) indicated that one allele of the alpha-L-iduronidase gene contains a mutation causing a common Q70X truncation in the enzyme amino acid sequence. Further studies (performed at Consorzio Genetica Moleculare Umana, Monza, Italy, supervised by Prof. Andrea Biondi and coordinated by Genzyme Co.) confirmed the presence of this allele and indicated that the second mutation is an in frame deletion of three base pairs (codon 349), resulting in the loss of aspartic acid residue (Delta349). The investigated MPS I patient suffered, between other symptoms characteristic for this disease, from frequent diarrhea or loose stools, often accompanied by vomiting. No obvious contacts with persons suffering from intestinal infections, including family members (who also had no documented chronic or often diarrhea), were noticed shortly before or during these episodes. During the most severe episodes of diarrhea, detailed microbiological analyses of stools were performed. The patient was never treated with antibiotics before stool collection, thus, results of microbiological assays were not affected by such a treatment. Bacterial, viral or fungal infections were detected in all these analyses (Table 1).
Isolation and preliminary analyses for identification and characterization of bacteria, viruses and fungi were performed using S-F selenium, blood agar, CNA, McConkey, SS, XLD, Sabouraud, Kligler and Singer, and BHI media (purchased from Becton Dickinson, Biomed or Bimex). Detailed analyses were performed using biochemical assay kits ID GN 32 (BioMerieux), EN-COCCUStest (Lachema) and ATB ID 32 C (BioMerieux), and immunological tests (kits purchased from Immunomed and BioMarieux). The microbiological assays were performed according to the semi-quantitative method, described previously. Non-enteropathogenic strains of Escherichia coli, strains of Enterococcus faecalis and small amounts of other bacteria belonging to Enterobacteriaceae were considered as normal aerobic bacterial flora. Identification of enteropathogenic E. coli strains was performed using a specific latex-immunological assay (purchased from Biomex). In this assay, 10 randomly chosen E. coli colonies (classified on the basis of microbiological and biochemical tests described above) were streak onto nutrient agar plates, and following 18 h incubation at 35 C bacteria were tested immunologically using the Biomex kit. The O antigens (characteristic for enteropathogenic E. coli strains but not for other strains of this bacterium), were detectable in this assay, and corresponding strains, bearing particular antigens, were divided into following groups: group A (antigens O26, O55, O111, O127 and O142), group B (antigens O86, O119, O124, O125, O126 and O128) and group C (antigens O18, O25, O44 and O114).

title: 43-year-old male presented with a 4-year history of retained glass foreign bodie
specialty: Ophthalmology (Oculoplastics) and Otolaryngology (Head and Neck Surgery)
chief_complaint: A 43-year-old man presented with a foreign body in his left orbit.
history: He had a four-year history of a deep wound on the left side of his nose following a car accident, which was sutured without initial imaging and healed well. Five months prior to presentation, an ulcer appeared on the right nasal root and gradually worsened to form a sinus tract, leading to initial detection and partial removal of a foreign body at a district hospital.
presenting_symptoms: ulcer on the right nasal root
exam_findings: Two wounds longitudinally located on both sides of the nose were observed. Best-corrected visual acuity was 20/20. Eyeball position and movement were normal.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: Initial CT of the paranasal sinuses showed a 25 mm x 5 mm strip of dense shadow transversely running through the nasal bone. Postoperative CT from the district hospital showed the glass foreign body broke into two pieces: a larger piece in the left orbit and the rest in the nasal cavity. MRI detected two foreign bodies in the soft tissues behind the nasal bone and in the left orbit. A 3D model based on CT data depicted the orbital foreign body as triangular, piercing 20 mm posteriorly into the left orbit, with its back located on the inferior medial angle. Postoperative CT at our hospital demonstrated complete removal of the intranasal and intraorbital foreign bodies.
diagnosis: Retained glass foreign bodies in the left orbit and nasal cavity following a car accident.
treatment: At the district hospital, a partial removal of an intranasal foreign body (2mm x 2mm glass) was performed. At the current hospital, surgical removal of the intraorbital foreign body was performed via an infraciliary incision of the lower lid, followed by exploration and removal of the firmly embedded intranasal foreign body behind the nasal bone.
key_learning_points: The importance of comprehensive initial imaging in trauma cases to detect and localize foreign bodies, especially in complex anatomical regions.
Retained foreign bodies can manifest with delayed symptoms, such as ulcers and sinus tracts, several years after the initial injury.
3D modeling based on CT data can be invaluable for precise surgical planning and localization of foreign bodies prior to complex removals.
Meticulous surgical technique is crucial for the complete removal of embedded or broken foreign bodies, particularly in delicate areas like the orbit, to prevent further complications.
description: 43-year-old male presented with a 4-year history of retained glass foreign bodies in the left orbit and nasal cavity following a car accident, manifesting as a nasal ulcer and sinus tract, successfully treated by surgical removal guided by 3D modeling.
clinical_text:
A 43-year-old man presented with an FB in his left orbit. He had a four-year history of a deep wound on the left side of his nose following a car accident. Although the patient underwent emergency trauma suturing, no imaging was performed, and no foreign objects were detected at that time. The wound healed well. About five months ago, an ulcer appeared on the right nasal root and gradually worsened to form a sinus tract. Computed tomography (CT) of the paranasal sinuses was performed at a district hospital, which showed a strip of dense shadow transversely running through the nasal bone, measuring 25 mm x 5 mm [Fig. 1a]. At the district hospital, the patient underwent the removal of intranasal FB, but only a part of the object that measuring 2 mm x 2 mm was taken out. The FB was glass. Postoperative CT showed that the glass FB broke into two pieces: the larger one pierced into the left orbit close to the eye and the rest remained in the nasal cavity [Fig. 1b]. The patient was referred to our hospital.
Examination revealed two wounds longitudinally located on both sides of the nose. The best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) was 20/20. Eyeball position and movement were normal. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) detected the two FBs in the soft tissues behind the nasal bone and in the left orbit.
Three-dimensional (3D) model preparation: Based on the patient's CT data, a 3D model was made at a scale of 1:1 that accurately recreated the shape and position of the FB in the left orbit [<PMC10155551_IJO-71-300-g002_a_1_2.webp>]. On the 3D model, the orbital FB was triangular; its tip pierced posteriorly into the left orbit about 20 mm, and its back was located on the inferior medial angle of the orbit.
Surgical procedure: We performed an infraciliary incision of the lower lid and dissected the site under the orbicularis oculi to the infraorbital rim to expose the orbit septum. Then, the orbital septum was opened, and the intraorbital FB was carefully removed [<PMC10155551_IJO-71-300-g002_b_2_2.webp>]. After the sutures were removed from the right wound of the nose, the deeper part was explored, and a hard FB was found embedded firmly behind the nasal bone. The surrounding tissues of the nasal FB were fully separated, and the FB was carefully removed [<PMC10155551_IJO-71-300-g003_a_1_2.webp>]. Postoperative CT demonstrated complete removal of the intranasal and intraorbital FBs [<PMC10155551_IJO-71-300-g003_b_2_2.webp>].
image_captions: (a) Three-dimensional printing model representing the foreign body in the orbit.
(b) Computed tomography after operation at our hospital showing that the foreign bodies were completely removed.

title: 87-year-old woman with progressive dyspnoea and decreased exercise tolerance dia
chief_complaint: An 87-year-old woman presented with progressive dyspnoea and decreased exercise tolerance following a fall.
history: Past medical history includes hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, impaired glucose tolerance, and iron deficiency anaemia due to haemorrhoidal bleeding.
exam_findings: Regular pulse of 110 bpm, supine blood pressure 120/50 mmHg, harsh grade III holosystolic murmur at the apex, clinical and radiological signs of congestive cardiac failure.
labs: Elevated serum troponin T level (163 ng/L).
imaging_description: ECG showed sinus tachycardia with 2mm ST elevation in V2-V4 and left anterior fascicular block. Transthoracic echocardiography revealed apical hypokinesis, an apical muscular VSD (1.6 cm), moderate pulmonary hypertension (PASP 42 mmHg), normal LV wall thickness, no atrial dilatation, normal LV function (EF 65%), and a left-to-right shunt (Qp/Qs 1:1.8). Myocardial perfusion scan showed a small apical nontransmural infarct with peri-infarctional ischaemia. Intraprocedural TEE confirmed good VSD device placement with reduced shunting, and left ventriculography showed small residual flow.
diagnosis: Acute apical myocardial infarction complicated by ventricular septal defect.
treatment: Initially, anticoagulation and diagnostic coronary angiography were deferred, and the patient was deemed unsuitable for cardiac surgery. Eighteen months later, a percutaneous closure of the VSD was performed using a 16 mm Amplatzer muscular VSD occlude device.
key_learning_points: Post-myocardial infarction ventricular septal defect (VSD) is a serious complication requiring careful management.
Percutaneous VSD closure is a viable option for high-risk surgical candidates, with potential benefits of delayed intervention to optimize defect edges.
Complexities in managing elderly, multimorbid patients with post-MI VSD necessitate individualized treatment strategies.
description: 87-year-old woman with progressive dyspnoea and decreased exercise tolerance diagnosed with an acute apical myocardial infarction complicated by ventricular septal defect, successfully treated with delayed percutaneous VSD closure.
clinical_text:
An 87-year-old woman presented to a tertiary referral hospital with progressive dyspnoea and decreased exercise tolerance following a fall. She denied chest pain, palpitations, or syncope. She had a past history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and impaired glucose tolerance.
Physical examination revealed a regular pulse of 110 beats per minute. Her supine blood pressure was 120/50 mmHg and there was a harsh grade III holosystolic murmur heard best at the apex. She had clinical and radiological signs of congestive cardiac failure.
The 12-lead electrocardiograph (ECG) revealed sinus tachycardia (110 beats per minute), with 2 mm ST elevation in the anteroseptal leads (V 2-V 4) and a left anterior fascicular block. Serum troponin T level at admission was elevated (163 ng/L).
Transthoracic echocardiography (Figures 1 and 2) revealed apical hypokinesis and an apical muscular ventricular septal defect (VSD) measuring approximately 1.6 cm in diameter. She had features of moderate pulmonary hypertension, with an estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure of 42 mmHg. Left ventricular wall thickness was within normal limits and there was no atrial dilatation. Left ventricular function was within normal limits with an estimated ejection fraction of 65%. She had a left to right shunt with Q p/Q s ratio of 1 : 1.8.
Technetium (99mTc) sestamibi myocardial perfusion scanning revealed a small apical nontransmural infarct, with small area of peri-infarctional ischaemia. She was diagnosed as having an acute apical myocardial infarction complicated by ventricular septal defect.
In view of her age, iron deficiency anaemia due to haemorrhoidal bleeding, and the absence of ongoing angina, it was decided that she should not be anticoagulated or referred for diagnostic coronary angiography. She was also considered unsuitable for cardiac surgery.
Following discharge from hospital, patient complained of lethargy and breathlessness and developed a recurrence of cardiac failure. In view of her age and comorbidities as well as a reluctance to undergo open repair, the decision was made to perform percutaneous closure of the VSD. This was performed in delayed fashion 18 months after the patient's initial presentation, the rationale being that this would allow the edges of the defect to fibrose to optimise the landing zone and to let the patient stabilise from her recent hospital admissions.
A 16 mm Amplatzer muscular VSD occlude device was deployed (Figures 3 and 4), with transesophageal echocardiography confirming good placement of the device with reduction in the degree of shunting. Left ventriculography demonstrated a small residual flow around the apical side of the device but this appeared to reduce with time. It was felt that device sizing was appropriate and this residual shunting was related to the irregular shape of the postinfarction defect and is likely to lessen with time as the disks become endothelialised.
The patient subsequently made a successful postprocedural recovery and is clinically well to date.

title: A patient diagnosed with Myoclonus-Dystonia receives genetic counseling regardin
chief_complaint: The patient presented for genetic counseling to understand the risk of her asymptomatic preschool-aged and teenage daughters inheriting her recently diagnosed condition.
history: The patient, a mother of a preschool-aged and a teenage daughter, has been diagnosed with Myoclonus-Dystonia and is presumed to have inherited the pathogenic variant maternally, as her counseling discusses imprinting of her maternal allele.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: A figure (genetics pearl) depicting and summarizing the genetic counseling provided, detailing inheritance risks for myoclonus-dystonia, is referenced but not available.
diagnosis: Myoclonus-Dystonia, associated with a pathogenic SGCE variant.
treatment: Genetic counseling was provided regarding the complex inheritance patterns and risk of phenotype expression for myoclonus-dystonia, with a recommendation against predictive genetic testing for minors when it will not change medical management.
key_learning_points: Predictive genetic testing in asymptomatic minors is generally not recommended if it does not change medical management.
Myoclonus-dystonia typically presents in childhood, with most patients developing symptoms before the age of 20.
Maternal transmission of the pathogenic SGCE variant leads to a significantly reduced risk of phenotype expression (5% chance) due to imprinting of the maternal allele.
Paternal transmission of the pathogenic SGCE variant results in a 50% risk of inheritance and expected symptomatic expression due to the absence of paternal imprinting.
Genetic risk calculations must account for imprinting patterns, which can significantly alter penetrance based on the transmitting parent's sex.
description: A patient diagnosed with Myoclonus-Dystonia receives genetic counseling regarding the complex, sex-specific inheritance risks for her offspring and grandchildren due to SGCE imprinting.
clinical_text: Following diagnosis, she inquired about the risk of her asymptomatic preschool-aged and teenage daughters. She was counseled that patients under the age of 18 generally should not undergo predictive genetic testing when it will not change medical management, but that typically myoclonus-dystonia presents in childhood with most patients developing symptoms before the age of 20. There was a 1 in 2 chance that she passed the pathogenic variant to each daughter, but due to imprinting (silencing) of her maternal allele 95% of the time, there is only a 5% (1 in 20) chance that the pathogenic allele will be expressed if it was inherited. Thus, each daughter's individual risk of expressing the phenotype is 1 in 2 multiplied by 1 in 20, or 1 in 40 (2.5% chance). If the patient has a son, he will have the same risk of inheriting and expressing the phenotype as her daughters. Since her daughters will also imprint their SGCE allele when they have children, provided they inherited the pathogenic variant, the risk of passing on and expressing the phenotype for each of the patient's grandchildren is also 1 in 40 (2.5%). However, if the patient has a grandson with the pathogenic variant, his risk of passing on the variant to each of his children, her great-grandchildren, would be 1 in 2 (50%), and those who inherit the variant would be expected to be symptomatic because there is no paternal imprinting, and the paternal copy of the gene would be expressed. <PMC10453946_tohm-13-1-783-g2_undivided_1_1.webp> depicts and summarizes the counseling provided above as a concise genetics pearl for reference in the clinic. Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for the publication of this manuscript.

title: A 47-year-old HIV-positive female presented with cough, chest pain, and bilatera
chief_complaint: Five-day history of cough, chest pain, and asymptomatic bilateral swelling of the cheek.
history: A 47-year-old female with a 19-year history of HIV seropositivity.
exam_findings: Patient was afebrile with normal vital signs, mild bibasilar crackles, bilateral parotid enlargement, and a palpable left superior cervical lymph node (3 cm).
labs: CD4 count of 551 K/mm and HIV-1 RNA load of 16784 copies/ml.
imaging_description: Chest X-ray showed an abnormal contour along the right cardiomediastinal border. Contrast-enhanced chest CT revealed a 7.1 x 2.7 x 8.8 cm lobulated, low-attenuation mass with heterogeneous enhancement in the anterior mediastinum, consisting of non-enhancing cystic areas (14 HU) separated by enhancing septations (43 HU), with no evidence of invasion. Neck CT showed bilateral parotid enlargement with innumerable cystic areas.
diagnosis: Multilocular thymic cyst (MTC) with follicular hyperplasia (histologically confirmed) and benign lymphoepithelial cysts of the parotid gland (clinically diagnosed).
treatment: Thymectomy was performed for the mediastinal mass. Biopsy of parotid lesions was deferred due to known association with HIV.
key_learning_points: Recognize the association of multilocular thymic cysts and benign lymphoepithelial cysts of the parotid gland with HIV infection.
Understand the characteristic imaging features of multilocular thymic cysts on CT, including cystic and enhancing septal components.
Appreciate the role of surgical pathology in confirming the diagnosis of mediastinal masses, even in the context of known HIV.
description: A 47-year-old HIV-positive female presented with cough, chest pain, and bilateral cheek swelling, ultimately diagnosed with a multilocular thymic cyst and benign lymphoepithelial cysts of the parotid glands.
clinical_text: A 47-year-old female who has been seropositive for HIV for 19 years, presented with a five-day history of cough, chest pain, and asymptomatic bilateral swelling of the cheek. On physical examination, patient was afebrile, and vital signs were within normal limits. There were mild bibasilar crackles in the lungs, bilateral parotid enlargement, and a palpable left superior cervical lymph node approximately 3 centimeters in size. Laboratory evaluation revealed CD4 count of 551 K/mm, and HIV-1 RNA load of 16784 copies/ ml.
