On the next session, the ultimate setting of the RetroMTA was confirmed, and the remaining coronal space of the root canal was reserved for post placement. The access cavity was sealed for a relatively longer period of time using 3mm of light curable glass ionomer (Fuji II LC, GC, Tokyo, Japan) and 1mm of composite resin (3M ESPE, St. Paul, MN, USA) to evaluate the treatment result. After 3 months, radiographic examination revealed substantial bone formation in the periapical lesion, and clinical examination of the patient revealed no signs or symptoms. In order to maintain the coronal seal during the orthodontic treatment, the MTA apical plug was backfilled using gutta-percha (Meta (Dentsply, Tulsa, OK, USA) with warm vertical compaction technique (Fig. 5). Biomed, Seoul, Korea) and AH26 sealer.
The access cavity was restored with composite resin. Upon periapical radio-graphic evaluation after 6 months, complete bone formation was observed in the periradicular area (Fig. 6a). At the one-year follow-up, the patient was asymptomatic, and the periapical radiograph showed bone healing and no evidence of recurrence of the periapical lesion (Fig. 6b).

title: A 36-year-old male with paranoid schizophrenia developed a severe necrotic ulcer
chief_complaint: One month after initiating fortnightly fluphenazine injections, the patient complained of dull pain over the injection site, which subsequently increased in severity with high-level discomfort in movement.
history: A 36-year-old married male farmer with a 3-year history of paranoid schizophrenia, partially controlled with oral risperidone and trihexyphenidyl. Due to poor compliance with oral medications, fluphenazine 25 mg intramuscular long-acting injection was initiated fortnightly.
presenting_symptoms: Increased pain severity at injection site
exam_findings: Initially, mild swelling was noticed over the injection site. On later examination, a 4-cm x 4-cm deep-seated necrotic ulceration was observed at the injection site, along with two other lumps over previous injection sites.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: Not described in this case.
diagnosis: Necrotic ulceration at fluphenazine intramuscular long-acting injection site, a severe complication of antipsychotic therapy.
treatment: Initially, a brief course of analgesics (diclofenac 50 mg two times per day for 5 days) was prescribed. Subsequently, fluphenazine was stopped, and the patient underwent wound debridement with wide excision of margins by a general surgeon, followed by a course of prophylactic intravenous antibiotics (cephazolin 2 g for 5 days).
key_learning_points: The importance of proper injection technique for long-acting intramuscular depot medications to prevent local complications.
Prompt recognition and management of injection site complications, including rare but severe adverse effects like necrotic ulceration.
Considering medication non-compliance as a factor in managing chronic psychiatric conditions and choosing appropriate drug delivery methods.
The necessity of interdisciplinary collaboration (e.g., Psychiatry and General Surgery) in managing complex drug-related complications.
description: A 36-year-old male with paranoid schizophrenia developed a severe necrotic ulceration at the fluphenazine intramuscular long-acting injection site, requiring surgical debridement and excision.
clinical_text: The patient was a 36-year-old married male, a farmer by occupation. He had been suffering from paranoid schizophrenia for the past 3 years, with partial improvement of psychotic symptoms while treated with oral medication: tablets risperidone 6 mg/day and trihexyphenidyl 4 mg/day. The patient was found to have poor compliance. Hence, fluphenazine (25 mg), intramuscular long-acting (LA) injection, was initiated fortnightly along with existing oral medications, as previous multiple attempts to improve adherence failed. The patient used to come for follow-ups every month on an outpatient basis. He used to receive the depot injection from a psychiatric nurse near his place. On follow-up after 1 month, the patient complained of dull pain over the injection site. On local physical examination, mild swelling was noticed and this was managed by a brief course of analgesics: diclofenac 50 mg two times per day for 5 days. On the second follow-up, the pain increased in severity with high-level discomfort in movement. The injection site was examined by the resident. A 4-cm x 4-cm deep-seated necrotic ulceration (Figure 1), along with two other lumps over the previous injection sites, was noticed. In view of the above complication, a further dose of fluphenazine was stopped and the patient was immediately referred to general surgery consultation for evaluation and management. Wound debridement along with wide excision of margins was done by the surgeon and a course of prophylactic antibiotics (cephazolin 2 g intravenous for 5 days) was given. It took another 2 months for the wound to heal.

title: 19-year-old male presented with chronic left facial swelling diagnosed as an int
chief_complaint: 19-year-old male presented with cosmetic disfigurement of the face due to a slowly growing swelling on the left side since childhood.
history: The patient had a chronic facial swelling that began in childhood and was slowly growing. He had previously consulted a physician and undergone an ultrasonography examination, but no conservative treatment had been initiated before this presentation.
presenting_symptoms: swelling in the left side of the face
slowly growing in size since childhood
exam_findings: Gross facial asymmetry was detected with a diffuse palpable firm soft tissue swelling in the left middle and lower third of the face. The skin over the swelling was normal in color, and no other abnormalities were observed.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: USG identified multiple venous channels with prominent arc-like calcifications, reporting the lesion as a venous malformation with calcifications. Panoramic radiograph showed multiple calcifications (phleboliths) overlapping the left maxillary tuberosity and mandibular ramus region. CT angiography revealed an approximately 5 x 25 x 60 mm (AP x TR x SI) sized, well-defined, heterogeneously enhancing soft tissue density lesion in the superficial and intramuscular planes along the left masseter muscle, reaching the skin laterally, overlying the left ramus of the mandible medially, and causing lateral displacement of the superficial lobe of the parotid gland postero-laterally. Multiple vessels traversed the lesion with chunky areas of calcifications, suggestive of an intramuscular hemangioma.
diagnosis: Intramuscular cavernous hemangioma, confirmed by histopathological examination.
treatment: The patient underwent surgical excision of the lesion via a direct cheek incision. Extracapsular dissection was performed, and 2% Methylene blue dye was used intraoperatively to identify and ensure complete excision of the stained lesion and 14 phleboliths. Postoperative follow-up at one month showed satisfactory recovery, and the patient is under periodic review.
key_learning_points: Chronic, slowly growing facial swellings originating in childhood warrant thorough imaging including USG, panoramic radiograph, and CT angiography.
Phleboliths are a common imaging finding in venous malformations and hemangiomas.
Methylene blue dye can be a valuable intraoperative tool to delineate vascular lesions during surgical excision and confirm complete removal.
Histopathological examination is essential for definitive diagnosis of soft tissue masses like intramuscular cavernous hemangioma.
description: 19-year-old male presented with chronic left facial swelling diagnosed as an intramuscular cavernous hemangioma with phleboliths, successfully treated with surgical excision aided by methylene blue dye.
clinical_text: A 19-year-old male patient reported with a chief complaint of cosmetic disfigurement of face due to swelling in the left side of the face which had been slowly growing in size since childhood. On extra-oral clinical examination [<PMC11057590_NJMS-15-160-g001_undivided_1_1.webp>], gross facial asymmetry was detected with a diffuse palpable firm soft tissue swelling in the left middle and lower third of face. The skin over the swelling was normal in color, and no other abnormalities were observed. The patient had previously consulted a physician, and he reported with the ultrasonography (USG) report. The USG examination reported the lesion to be venous malformation with calcifications [<PMC11057590_NJMS-15-160-g002_undivided_1_1.webp>]. Patient had not undergone any conservative treatment before. Further investigation was advised which included panoramic radiograph and computed tomography (CT) angiography. In panoramic radiograph, there was evidence of multiple calcifications overlapping the areas of left maxillary tuberosity and mandibular ramus region suggestive of phleboliths [<PMC11057590_NJMS-15-160-g003_undivided_1_1.webp>]. IN CT angiography, there was a evidence of approximately 5 x 25 x 60 mm (AP x TR x SI) sized well-defined heterogeneously enhancing soft tissue density lesion seen in the superficial and intramuscular planes along the left masseter muscle. Laterally, the lesion was reaching up to the skin. Medially, the lesion was overlying the left ramus of mandible. Postero-laterally, the lesion is causing lateral displacement of the superficial lobe of the parotid gland. On contrast, multiple vessels are seen traversing through it with multiple chunky areas of calcifications [<PMC11057590_NJMS-15-160-g004_a_1_2.webp><PMC11057590_NJMS-15-160-g004_b_2_2.webp>]. The features were suggestive of IMH. The patient underwent surgery, direct cheek incision was made on the site of the lesion 10-12 mm behind the Zuker's point, and extracapsular dissection was done until the superior portion of masseter muscle [<PMC11057590_NJMS-15-160-g005_a_1_2.webp><PMC11057590_NJMS-15-160-g005_b_2_2.webp>] was identified. 2% Methylene blue dye was injected to identify the lesion. Once the lesion was stained, the stained part was excised. Total 14 phleboliths were identified and removed [<PMC11057590_NJMS-15-160-g006_undivided_1_1.webp>]. Again 2% methylene blue dye was injected over the lesion to check for residual lesion, and no residual lesion was detected. Closure was done in layers. The excised specimen was sent for histopathological examination. Gross specimen showed soft tissue mass of 3 x 3 cm in size, brownish to reddish in color, firm in consistency and 14 phleboliths. The pathological examination confirmed the intra muscular cavernous hemangioma [Figure 7]. One-month postoperative follow-up showed satisfactory recovery, and presently patient is under periodic review [<PMC11057590_NJMS-15-160-g008_undivided_1_1.webp>].
image_captions: Multiple venous channels with prominent arc-like calcifications were identified in USG.
Panoramic radiograph showing phleboliths in left maxillary tuberosity and ramus region.
Axial section of CECT showing soft tissue swelling with hyperdense areas.

title: 62-year-old female with persistent phantosmia for 4 months due to a retained sur
chief_complaint: A 62-year-old female presented with persistent phantosmia for 4 months.
history: The patient had no known comorbidities or systemic illnesses. She underwent right external Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) 18 months prior and left external DCR 12 months prior, with the DCR tube removed 6 months after the surgery. Her vision was 20/20 and she was pseudophakic bilaterally.
presenting_symptoms: Foul smell from nose (noted by patient and family)
exam_findings: Vision 20/20 bilaterally, pseudophakic bilaterally. Nasal speculum examination revealed a foreign body or suspected mass in the right-sided nasal cavity above the middle turbinate. Subsequent examination found a foul-smelling, 6.3 cm long gauze piece stuck in the right nasal cavity, surrounded by granulation tissue and blood, causing pain and bleeding.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: Paranasal sinus X-ray was clear.
diagnosis: Retained surgical gauze piece (gossypiboma) in the right nasal cavity causing phantosmia.
treatment: Initial treatment with steam inhalation was unsuccessful. The patient was advised to instill liquid paraffin for 2 days. The retained gauze piece was then removed under local anesthesia (4% xylocaine with adrenaline-soaked gauze) using Tilley's nasal pack forceps. Hemostasis was achieved with pressure. She was discharged with systemic antibiotics and analgesics.
key_learning_points: Persistent phantosmia can be a symptom of a retained foreign body in the nasal cavity.
Retained surgical foreign bodies, or gossypibomas, are a serious, preventable surgical complication that can occur even years after the initial surgery.
A thorough nasal examination, even after 'clear' imaging, is crucial for persistent or unusual nasal symptoms following prior surgical procedures.
Early patient reporting of unusual symptoms post-surgery should prompt a comprehensive investigation.
description: 62-year-old female with persistent phantosmia for 4 months due to a retained surgical gauze piece in the right nasal cavity following DCR surgery.
clinical_text:
A 62-year-old, married female, resident of, Karachi with no known comorbid presented with complaint of phantosmia, persistent for the last 4 months. She was given a history of right external DCR with intubation 18 months back and left external DCR 12 months back in another hospital. DCR tube was removed 6 months after the surgery. She had no significant history of any systemic illness. Her vision was 20/20 and was pseudophakic bilaterally.
The patient started to feel a foul smell often after her DCR surgery. She reported this phenomenon to her primary surgeon. She was reassured that the surgery went well and was referred to an otolaryngologist. An otolaryngologist examined her in an outpatient department (OPD) and was advised for steam inhalation. Four months back, her complaint of phantosmia became persistent, not relieved by any medication or steam inhalation. Her family members also noticed a foul smell coming from the patient's nose. She visited our hospital. She was advised for a paranasal sinus X-ray. Her X-ray was clear and was referred for nasal examination. Her nose was examined with help of a nasal speculum by an otolaryngologist in an OPD. It revealed a foreign body or suspected mass in her right-sided nasal cavity above the middle turbinate. The next day patient was examined in an operation theater for further evaluation. It was discovered that the foul-smelling foreign body was a gauze piece. Her otolaryngologist tried to pull it but it was stuck up in her nose causing pain and bleeding. She was then advised to instill liquid paraffin for 2 days to soften the gauze piece. The patient was then followed after 2 days in an operation theater. Four percent xylocaine with adrenaline-soaked gauze piece was placed in her nasal cavity for 5 min and removed. The retained gauze piece was then pulled out with a Tilley's nasal pack forceps [<PMC10062087_OJO-16-145-g001_undivided_1_1.webp>]. It was about 6.3 cm long surrounded by granulation tissue and blood [<PMC10062087_OJO-16-145-g002_undivided_1_1.webp>]. There was slight bleeding and hemostasis was achieved by applying pressure. The patient was discharged on the same day with systemic antibiotics and analgesics. After 1 week follow-up, there was no foul smell or any discharge from the nasal cavity.

title: 22-year-old female presented with acute subdural hemorrhage requiring craniotomy
chief_complaint: Headache followed by loss of consciousness.
history: Past medical history was unremarkable. The patient had no history of antiplatelet or anticoagulant medications, previous bleeding problems, illicit drug use, or alcohol abuse.
exam_findings: Patient was drowsy, disoriented, and inconsistently answered questions and followed commands. Pupils were anisocoric (2 mm right, 4 mm left) and equally reactive to light. She had brisk corneal reflex, no facial asymmetry, intact gross hearing, and withdrew to pain on all extremities. Vital signs: BP 110/70, CR 64, RR 19, T 36.6, SpO2 98% at room air.
labs: Capillary blood glucose was 146 mg/dL. Baseline blood counts, coagulation tests, and inflammatory markers were within normal limits. Patient tested positive for COVID-19 by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction.
imaging_description: Non-contrast computerized tomography scan revealed an acute subdural hemorrhage, left cerebral convexity (1.9 cm maximal thickness), with compression of adjacent cortical sulci and left lateral ventricle, with rightward subfalcine herniation (1.2 cm). Computerized tomography angiography revealed no aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation.
diagnosis: Acute subdural hemorrhage of the left cerebral convexity with rightward subfalcine herniation.
treatment: Left frontotemporoparietal craniotomy with evacuation of subdural hematoma was performed. Medical decompression was started after surgery. The patient completed 14 days of quarantine in the hospital due to COVID-19.
key_learning_points: Acute subdural hemorrhage requires urgent diagnosis and neurosurgical intervention for optimal outcomes.
Neurological examination findings, such as anisocoria and altered mental status, are critical in evaluating intracranial pathology.
Incidental findings or co-existing conditions, like COVID-19, can impact patient management and hospital course even if unrelated to the primary presentation.
description: 22-year-old female presented with acute subdural hemorrhage requiring craniotomy, complicated by an incidental positive COVID-19 test.
clinical_text:
In late March 2021, a 22-year-old female, Filipino, was brought to the emergency room due to headache followed by loss of consciousness. The patient was apparently well until 1 day prior to admission, when she allegedly complained of headache, uncharacterized. No associated trauma, no cough, no vomiting, nausea, fever, diarrhea, body malaise,or weakness of the extremities. Patient self-medicated with Paracetamol tablet. Then 1 h prior to consult, patient sent a text message to her brother asking for help due to her headache. However, her brother found her unconscious, lying on the bed, hence she was immediately brought to the emergency room.
Past medical history of the patient was unremarkable. No history of taking antiplatelet or anticoagulant medications, and no previous bleeding problems. No illicit drug use and no alcohol abuse.
Patient's vital signs: BP 110/70, CR 64, RR 19, T 36.6, and SpO2 98% at room air, with capillary blood glucose of 146 mg/dL. Patient was drowsy, disoriented, and inconsistently answered questions and followed commands appropriately. Pupils were anisocoric, 2 mm on the right and 4 mm on the left, equally reactive to light. Primary gaze was at midline. Patient had brisk corneal reflex, no facial asymmetry, with intact gross hearing, and withdrew to pain on all extremities.
Immediate non-contrast computerized tomography scan (Figure 1) revealed an acute subdural hemorrhage, left cerebral convexity (1.9 cm maximal thickness), with compression of the adjacent cortical sulci and left lateral ventricle, with rightward subfalcine herniation (1.2 cm). Computerized tomography angiography revealed no aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation.
Ideally, patient should have been screened for coagulation factors deficiency, but such tests were not readily available. Baseline blood counts, coagulation tests, and inflammatory markers were within normal (Table 1).
The patient was referred to neurosurgery service, and a left frontotemporoparietal craniotomy with evacuation of subdural hematoma was done. Decompressive hemicraniectomy was not done because brain parenchyma was not edematous on inspection post-evacuation of hematoma. No identifiable source of bleeding and no noted cerebral vessel malformation. Medical decompression was started after surgery. Postoperatively, patient became fully awake, oriented, followed command, answered appropriately without motor or sensory deficit. Patient's reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction tested positive for COVID-19, but chest X-ray was unremarkable, and she had no respiratory symptoms. Hence, the patient completed 14 days of quarantine in the hospital and was discharged without neurologic deficits.

title: A 21-month-old girl presented with global developmental delay, significant growt
chief_complaint: The patient presented with delayed developmental milestones and mild dysmorphic features.
history: The patient was born at 37 weeks gestation with mild intrauterine growth restriction, normal metabolic and neonatal hearing screening. Her family history was unremarkable for congenital anomalies, intellectual disability, recurrent pregnancy loss, or infertility. She exhibited significant postnatal growth restriction and global developmental delay, with head holding at 6 months, sitting at 10 months, and walking with support at 21 months.
exam_findings: Mild dysmorphic features including flat facial profile, dolicocephaly, hypertelorism, short philtrum, flat nasal bridge, posteriorly rotated and low set ears, and short fifth fingers bilaterally. At 21 months, she exhibited significant growth restriction with weight 7.6 kg (approximately, -3SD), height 76 cm (approximately, -2SD), and head circumference 43.2 cm (approximately, -3SD).
labs: Normal metabolic and neonatal hearing screening at birth. Developmental Screening Test (DST) showed DQ score of 58 and MI score of 55.
imaging_description: Not described in this case.
diagnosis: Not provided in this text excerpt.
treatment: Not described in this case.
key_learning_points: Recognition and accurate description of dysmorphic features in pediatric patients.
Interpretation of developmental milestones and screening test scores (DQ, MI) to identify global developmental delay.
Assessment of growth parameters (weight, height, head circumference) and their deviation from standard deviations in a pediatric patient.
description: A 21-month-old girl presented with global developmental delay, significant growth restriction, and multiple mild dysmorphic features.
clinical_text:
The patient was born to a healthy unrelated 25-year-old mother and a 27-year-old father without family history of multiple congenital anomalies, intellectual disability, recurrent pregnancy loss, or infertility. The girl was born by natural delivery at 37 weeks of gestation. Her birth weight was 2.520 kg (approximately, -2SD), length 48 cm (approximately, -1SD), and head circumference 33.5 cm (approximately, -1SD). At birth, her metabolic and neonatal hearing screening were all normal.
Her develop milestones were delayed. Head holding was acquired at 6 months of age, she started to sit up at 10 months and walked with support at 21 months. At age of 21 months, her weight was 7.6 kg (approximately, -3SD), her height was 76 cm (approximately, -2SD), and her head circumference was 43.2 cm (approximately, -3SD). She presented with mild dysmorphic features including flat facial profile, dolicocephaly, hypertelorism, short philtrum, flat nasal bridge and posteriorly rotated and low set ears. She also had a short fifth finger on both hand (<PMC4886423_13039_2016_251_Fig1_HTML_a_1_4.webp><PMC4886423_13039_2016_251_Fig1_HTML_b_2_4.webp><PMC4886423_13039_2016_251_Fig1_HTML_c_3_4.webp><PMC4886423_13039_2016_251_Fig1_HTML_d_4_4.webp>). Developmental Screening Test (DST) showed that the DQ and MI scores was 58 and 55, respectively.

title: A 58-year-old man developed hypovolemic shock, acute renal failure, and a persis
chief_complaint: Complications following esophagectomy, including hypovolemic shock, acute renal failure, and subsequent anastomotic leakage.
history: A 58-year-old man with submucosa-invasive esophageal cancer who underwent a thoraco-laparoscopic esophagectomy with cervical esophagogastrostomy. No other significant past medical history, medications, or allergies are described.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: A radiocontrast study revealed leakage from the esophagojejunostomy. Endoscopy revealed a 1.2-cm dehiscence of the anastomosis located 18 cm from the incisors, with injected radiocontrast discharging to cervical drainage. Follow-up endoscopy revealed a persistent fistula at the anastomosis site, which subsequently showed complete closure on a later repeated examination.
diagnosis: Anastomotic dehiscence and fistula formation following esophagectomy for submucosa-invasive esophageal cancer.
treatment: Thoraco-laparoscopic esophagectomy with cervical esophagogastrostomy was performed. Postoperatively, continuous renal-replacement therapy was initiated for acute renal failure. An anti-migration esophageal stent was endoscopically placed to manage the anastomotic leak, and a nasojejunal tube was inserted for feeding. The stent was removed after 7 weeks once the fistula had completely closed.
key_learning_points: Post-esophagectomy anastomotic leaks are serious complications that can lead to systemic issues like hypovolemic shock and acute renal failure.
Endoscopic stent placement can be an effective treatment for anastomotic leaks and fistulas following esophagectomy.
Careful follow-up with repeated endoscopic examinations is essential to monitor healing and guide management, including stent removal.
description: A 58-year-old man developed hypovolemic shock, acute renal failure, and a persistent anastomotic leak with fistula formation after esophagectomy, which was successfully managed with endoscopic stent placement and supportive care.
clinical_text: A 58-year-old man received a thoraco-laparoscopic esophagectomy with a cervical esophagogastrostomy due to submucosa-invasive esophageal cancer. Hypovolemic shock and acute renal failure occurred 2 days after the surgery, and continuous renal-replacement therapy followed. Three weeks after the surgery, a radiocontrast study revealed leakage from the esophagojejunostomy, and endoscopy revealed a 1.2-cm dehiscence of the anastomosis that was located 18 cm from the incisors (<PMC3572311_gnl-7-112-g003_A_1_2.webp>). The radiocontrast that was injected into the working channel of the endoscope was discharged to the cervical drainage. We applied an anti-migration stent with 0.5-cm-wide, uncovered proximal flange and silk threads (CHOOSTENT  esophageal ST, 2.2x12.0 cm; M. I. Tech Co., Ltd.). However, the attempt to perform a fixation to an earlobe failed because the threads were broken during the insertion. A nasojejunal tube (ENBD-7-LIGUORY, 7 Fr, 250 cm; Cook Medical Inc., Winston-Salem, NC, USA) was inserted through the scope for feeding. The stent did not migrate, but a follow-up endoscopy revealed that a fistula was present at the anastomosis site 4 weeks after the insertion of the stent. Repeated endoscopic examination revealed the complete closure of the fistula 7 weeks after the insertion, and the stent was removed (<PMC3572311_gnl-7-112-g003_B_2_2.webp>). The patient remained stable over a 1-year follow-up period.

title: A 48-year-old woman with recalcitrant vaginal itching and discharge was diagnose
chief_complaint: A 48-year-old woman reported vaginal itching and discharge of 5 months' duration.
history: Her medical history included mild gastritis treated with omeprazole and irregular uterine bleeding managed with hormone replacement therapy. She was in a monogamous relationship but reported abstinence for several months due to severe vaginal symptoms.
exam_findings: Vaginal erythema with a white liquid vaginal discharge was observed on physical examination.
labs: Vaginal discharge grew P. lilacinus in pure culture. Serum protein electrophoresis (IgG, IgA, IgM), C3, C4, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, complete blood count, CD4, and CD8 counts were all within normal limits. Results for HIV antibodies were negative. An anergy panel was reactive. A repeat vaginal fungal culture and KOH preparation performed 6 months post-treatment were negative.
imaging_description: Not described in this case.
diagnosis: Vaginal infection due to P. lilacinus.
treatment: Initially treated empirically with fluconazole, topical clotrimazole, ticoconazole ointment, and intravaginal boric acid gel without success. Subsequently treated with itraconazole 200 mg orally twice a day for 3 weeks, leading to symptom resolution.
key_learning_points: Persistent or recalcitrant vaginitis warrants investigation for unusual pathogens beyond common Candida species.
Fungal culture is crucial for definitive diagnosis and guiding treatment in cases of atypical or treatment-resistant vaginal infections.
P. lilacinus is a rare cause of human infections, including vaginitis, often requiring specific antifungal agents like itraconazole.
The management of rare fungal infections often requires collaboration with specialized mycology laboratories for identification and susceptibility testing.
description: A 48-year-old woman with recalcitrant vaginal itching and discharge was diagnosed with P. lilacinus vaginitis after multiple failed empirical treatments, successfully resolving with itraconazole.
clinical_text:
A 48-year-old woman reported vaginal itching and discharge of 5 months' duration. Her symptoms had been recalcitrant to several courses of therapy for a presumptive diagnosis of candidal vaginitis. She had been treated initially with fluconazole, then sequentially with topical clotrimazole, ticoconazole ointment, and intravaginal boric acid gel. Her medical history was notable for mild gastritis (treated with omeprazole) and irregular uterine bleeding, controlled with hormone replacement therapy (a transdermal estrogen/progesterone combination). The patient was in a monogamous relationship with her husband but reported abstinence for several months because of the severity of her vaginal symptoms.
On physical examination, vaginal erythema with a white liquid vaginal discharge was observed. Although a potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation was not obtained at baseline, the discharge grew P. lilacinus in pure culture.
The patient was treated empirically with itraconazole, 200 mg orally twice a day for 3 weeks. At the end of therapy, she reported complete resolution of her vaginal discharge and a significant decrease in her vaginal pruritus. A repeat vaginal culture was not obtained at her first follow-up appointment after completion of itraconazole therapy because the vaginal vault contained a large amount of blood. At an appointment 6 months later, she remained free of vaginal discharge; a vaginal fungal culture and KOH preparation performed at that time were negative.
The results of laboratory studies, including serum protein electrophoresis (with immunoglobulin [Ig] G, IgA, IgM) C3, C4, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, a complete blood count, CD4 cell count, and CD8 cell count were all within normal limits. Results of a test for antibodies to HIV were negative. An anergy panel (with Candida and Trichophytin used as controls) was reactive. A purified protein derivative was not placed because the patient had a history of a positive test result.
The patient's isolate was forwarded to the Fungus Testing Laboratory, Department of Pathology, University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio, Texas, for confirmation of the identity and antifungal susceptibility testing, and accessioned into the stock collection as UTHSC 01-872. The isolate was initially subcultured onto potato flakes agar (PFA, prepared in house), which was prepared in-house, at 25 C, 30 C, 35 C, and 40 C (ambient air with alternating daylight and darkness). The isolate was subsequently plated onto carnation leaf agar (CLA [prepared in-house]) and malt agar (Remel, Lenexa, KS) at 25 C. Temperature studies were repeated after initial observations.
The case isolate was evaluated for susceptibility to antifungal agents by using the National Committee for Clinical Laboratory Standards broth macrodilution method M38-P. Briefly, the case isolate and the P. variotii control organism, UTHSC 90-450, were grown on PFA for 7 to 10 days at 25 C to induce conidial formation. The mature PFA isolate and control slants were overlaid with sterile distilled water, and suspensions were made by gently scraping the colonies with the tip of a Pasteur pipette. Heavy hyphal fragments were allowed to settle, and the upper, homogeneous conidial suspensions were removed. Conidia were counted with a hemacytometer, and the inoculum was standardized to 1.0 x 105 CFU/mL. Conidial suspensions were further diluted 1:10 in medium for a final inoculum concentration of 1.0 x 104 CFU/mL. Final drug concentrations were 0.03-16 mug/mL for amphotericin B (Bristol-Myers Squibb, Princeton, NJ), ketoconazole (Janssen Pharmaceutica, Titusville, NJ) and clotrimazole (Schering-Plough, Kenilworth, NJ), 0.125-64 mug/mL for 5-flucytosine (Roche Laboratories, Nutley, NJ), fluconazole, voriconazole (Pfizer, Inc, New York, NY), and terconazole (Ortho-McNeil Pharmaceuticals, Inc., Raritan, NJ), and 0.015-8 mug/mL for itraconazole (Janssen Pharmaceutica) and posaconazole (Schering-Plough).

title: This text provides an overview of the increasing incidence, distinct characteris
chief_complaint: Not described in this case.
history: Not described in this case.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: Not described in this case.
diagnosis: Acute Myelogenous Leukemia (AML) in the elderly population.
treatment: Intensive chemotherapy is not suitable for AML patients over 80 years old. Common regimens like low-dose cytarabine and best supportive care alone do not significantly prolong survival times. Treatment is evolving towards targeted therapies, including humanized anti-CD33 monoclonal antibodies, tyrosine kinase inhibitors, 5-azacytidine, 5-aza-2'-deoxycytidine, proteasome inhibitors, anti-angiogenic drugs, FLT3 inhibitors, anti-apoptotic inhibitors, and demethylating agents such as decitabine.
key_learning_points: The incidence of Acute Myelogenous Leukemia (AML) is significantly higher in the elderly population, being approximately 20 times greater in individuals aged 80-85+ years compared to younger patients.

AML in elderly patients presents with distinct biological characteristics, including a high incidence of cytogenetic abnormalities, therapy-related leukemia, prior hematological disease association, multidrug resistance gene expression, and is often accompanied by high comorbidity and poor tolerance to chemotherapy.

Conventional intensive chemotherapy is generally not suitable for AML patients over 80 years old, and regimens like low-dose cytarabine or best supportive care do not significantly prolong survival, resulting in a mean survival time of approximately 3 months for this age group.
Treatment strategies for elderly patients with AML are evolving from traditional chemotherapy-only approaches to targeted therapies due to the poor outcomes and unique challenges in this population.
description: This text provides an overview of the increasing incidence, distinct characteristics, treatment challenges, and evolving therapeutic strategies for Acute Myelogenous Leukemia (AML) in the elderly population.
clinical_text: The incidence of acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) in the elderly population is increasing due to the aging of the general population. Statistics from U.S. National Cancer Institute demonstrated that the incidence of AML is 23/100,000 in the age range of 80-84 years, while 21.2/100,000 over the age of 85, which is ~20 times greater than the incidence in younger patients. The biological characteristics, clinical manifestations and treatment response of AML in elderly individuals differs from that in young patients. The major characteristics of AML in elderly patients include: i) high incidence of cytogenetic abnormalities; ii) high incidence of therapy-related leukemia; iii) association with a prior hematological disease; iv) often accompanied by multidrug resistance gene expression; v) high incidence of comorbidity and poor tolerance to chemotherapy. All of these features contribute to low remission and short survival times. There are no standard treatment regimens for AML in elderly patients. Intensive chemotherapy is not suitable for the treatment of AML in patients over 80 years old. Common regimens such as low-dose cytarabine chemotherapy and the best supportive care alone do not prolong survival times significantly in elderly patients. The mean survival time of patients with AML over 80 years old is ~3 months. Therefore, the treatment regimens for elderly patients with AML has evolved from chemotherapy only to targeted therapies. The new drugs under investigation include: humanized anti-CD33 monoclonal antibodies, tyrosine kinase inhibitors, 5-azacytidine, 5-aza-2'-deoxycytidine, proteasome inhibitors, anti-angiogenic drugs, FLT3 inhibitors and anti-apoptotic inhibitors. Among them, decitabine is a demethylating agent.

title: 39-year-old male with relapsed and transformed Follicular Lymphoma to DLBCL, ref
chief_complaint: Pain in the back and lower extremities developed during a relapse of lymphoma.
history: A 39-year-old Chinese male was diagnosed with Follicular Lymphoma (FL) grade 3b, stage III, high-risk FLIPI, in January 2020. The disease subsequently relapsed, transformed into Diffuse Large B-cell Lymphoma (DLBCL), GCB subtype, and showed TP53 and other gene mutations.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: Initial FL: BCL6 (+), MUM1 (+), Ki-67 (80%+), CD20 (+), Pax5 (+), BCL2 (+), CD10 (+), CyclinD1 (-), sparsely positive for CD3, CD5, CD15, CD30, CD68, C-MYC. EBER negative. Transformed DLBCL: Bcl-6 (90%+), MUM1 (90%+), Ki-67 (80%+), Bcl-2 (90%+), c-myc (60%+), CD10 (+), CD19(+), CD20 (-). FISH: negative MYC rearrangement, positive BCL2 rearrangement. NGS: TP53 mutations always present, along with KMT2D, MS4A1, CD83, DUSP2, EZH2, FOXO1, HIST1H1C, HIST1H1E, NFKBIA, SGK1, SOCS1, STAT3, and TBL1XR1 mutations.
imaging_description: Initial PET-CT showed multiple lymphadenopathies on both sides of the mediastinum with high FDG uptake. After 3 R-CHOP cycles, PET-CT showed complete metabolic remission (CMR). Early relapse indicated an enlarged lymph node with high uptake in the right pelvic cavity (SUVmax 7, Deauville 5). After BR, PET-CT showed disease progression with soft tissue mass enlargement in bilateral inguinal and right paravascular iliac arteries. After GB, PET-CT revealed a bulky mass (84 mm) from the right psoas major muscle to the right pelvic wall (SUVmax 42.1) and a soft tissue mass in the right groin (SUVmax 21.2). Before ASCT and CAR T-cell infusion, PET-CT demonstrated progressive disease (PD) with a novel intraperitoneal tumor mass and remaining masses. Post-ASCT and CAR T-cell therapy, PET-CT showed CMR at +1 month and sustained CMR at +3 months.
diagnosis: Transformed Diffuse Large B-cell Lymphoma (DLBCL), GCB subtype, with a history of relapsed Follicular Lymphoma (FL) grade 3b, stage III.
treatment: Initial: 6 cycles of R-CHOP (rituximab, cyclophosphamide, pirarubicin, vincristine, prednisone) + 1 cycle maintenance R (rituximab). First relapse: 1 cycle of BR (rituximab, bendamustine). Progression after BR: 2 cycles of GB (obinutuzumab, bendamustine). Salvage chemotherapy: 1 cycle of DHAP (dexamethasone, cisplatin, cytarabine) with ibrutinib, followed by 1 cycle of ICE (ifosfamide, carboplatin, etoposide) as a bridging regimen. Ultimately, CD19 CAR T-cell infusion following ASCT with BEAM conditioning (carmustine, etoposide).
key_learning_points: Follicular lymphoma can transform into more aggressive lymphomas like DLBCL, often associated with disease progression and therapeutic resistance.

Refractory and relapsed lymphomas require aggressive multi-modality treatment approaches, including salvage chemotherapy, autologous stem cell transplant (ASCT), and novel cellular therapies like CAR T-cells.

Molecular profiling, including NGS and FISH, is crucial for identifying high-risk genetic features such as TP53 mutations and BCL2 rearrangements, which influence prognosis and guide therapeutic strategies in aggressive lymphomas.
description: 39-year-old male with relapsed and transformed Follicular Lymphoma to DLBCL, refractory to multiple lines of immunochemotherapy, achieving remission with ASCT followed by CAR T-cell therapy.
clinical_text:
A 39-year-old Chinese male was diagnosed with FL (grade 3b, stage III, group A, FLIPI was 3, high risk and FLIPI-2 was 2, intermediate risk) in January 2020. Immunohistochemical results for lymphoma cells of left cervical lymph nodes were as follows: BCL6 (+), MUM1 (+), Ki-67 (80%+), CD20 (+), Pax5 (+), BCL2 (+), CD10 (+), CyclinD1 (-), and sparsely positive for CD3, CD5, CD15, CD30, CD68, and C-MYC. EBER by in situ hybridization test was negative in the lymphoma cells. Multiple lymphadenopathies on both sides of the mediastinum with high uptake of 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) were revealed by positron emission tomography (PET-CT). The patient obtained CMR by PET-CT evaluation after 3 cycles of R-CHOP (rituximab 375 mg/m2 day 0, cyclophosphamide 750 mg/m2 day 1, pirarubicin 50 mg/m2 day 1, vincristine 1.4 mg/m2 day 1, and prednisone 100 mg day 1-5). After receiving additional 3 cycles of R-CHOP and 1 cycle of maintenance R therapy, PET-CT indicated an enlarged lymph node with high uptake in the right pelvic cavity (SUVmax was 7, Deauville was 5), and the original disease relapsed early. As the patient had no symptoms at the time, he refused further biopsy and treatment.
In March 2021, the patient complained of pain in the back and lower extremities, and further core needle aspiration biopsy of the right inguinal lymph node revealed grade 2 FL. The patient received 1 cycle of BR (rituximab 375 mg/m2 day 0 and bendamustine 90 mg/m2 day 1,2). Although pain relief and thrombosis occurred in his right lower limb, the disease progressed with further enlargement of the soft tissue mass in the bilateral inguinal and right paravascular iliac arteries. Subsequently, 2 cycles of GB ( ortuzumab 1000 mg day 1, 8, 15 for the first cycle and day 1 for the second cycle, bendamustine 90 mg/m2 day 1, 2 for each cycle) were administered. Unfortunately, the disease showed no response to treatment with salvage immunochemotherapy. Then, PET-CT scans showed a bulky mass (a maximum diameter of 84 mm) from the right psoas major muscle to the right pelvic wall with increased FDG uptake (SUVmax was 42.1) and a soft tissue mass in the right groin with increased FDG uptake (SUVmax was 21.2) ( Figure 1A ). The third pathological investigation of the right paravascular iliac lesion indicated that the lymphoma had transformed into DLBCL (GCB subtype) that was negative for CD20 and positive for Bcl-6 (90%+), MUM1 (90%+), Ki-67 (80%+), Bcl-2 (90%+), c-myc (60%+), CD10 (+), and CD19(+) ( Figure 1B ). A negative rearrangement of MYC and a positive rearrangement of BCL2 were demonstrated by fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH). Next-generation sequencing (NGS) of the paraffin-embedded lymphoma tissues was performed using the Illumina high-throughput sequencing platform technology. The results showed that TP53 mutations were always present in 3 pathological specimens from different sites ( Table 1 ). Moreover, there were more than 10 kinds of gene mutations, including TP53, KMT2D, MS4A1, CD83, DUSP2, EZH2, FOXO1, HIST1H1C, HIST1H1E, NFKBIA, SGK1, SOCS1, STAT3, and TBL1XR1.
The patient received CD19 CAR T-cell infusion following ASCT therapy. Auto hematopoietic stem cells were collected after 1 cycle of DHAP (dexamethasone 40 mg day 1-4, cisplatin 100 mg/m2 day 1, cytarabine 2 g/m2 q12h day 2) with the BTK inhibitor ibrutinib (560 mg/day) administered continuously as salvage chemotherapy. One month later, autolymphocyte apheresis was performed to manufacture CAR T cells. During the production of CD19 CAR T cells, 1 cycle of ICE (ifosfamide 5000 mg/m2 day 2, carboplatin 737 mg day 2, etoposide 100 mg/m2 day 1-3) was administered as a bridging regimen. PET-CT evaluation before ASCT and CAR T-cell infusion indicated PD with a novel intraperitoneal tumor mass near the posterior abdominal wall and other remaining masses ( <PMC10739420_fimmu-14-1307242-g002_A_1_3.webp> ). The patient underwent BEAM conditioning (carmustine 300 mg/m2 day -7, etoposide 200 mg/m2 day -6~-3, cytarabine 200 mg/m2 q12h day -6~-3, and melphalan 140 mg/m2 day -2) and ASCT following CD19 CAR T-cell infusion. On May 28, 2022 (day 01), and May 29, 2022 (day 02), a total of 3.8 x 106/kg CD34+ stem cells were infused. The patient received an infusion of CD19 CAR T cells (relmacabtagene autoleucel, relma-cel, JWCAR029, 2.7 ml containing 108 CAR T cells) on June 1, 2022 (day 3). Platelets were 35x109/L, implanted on June 18, 2022 (day 20); neutrophils were 1.52x109/L implanted on June 19, 2022 (day 21); lymphocytes were 1.6x109/L on July 7, 2022 (day 39). CD4 was 374/ul, IgG 5.57g/L, IgA 0.25g/L, IgM 0.12g/L on July 7, 2022 (day 39).
On the 4th day after ASCT (the 1st day after CAR T-cell infusion), the patient's oral mucosa showed pseudomembranes and ulcers, and he had diarrhea 3-5 times a day but was able to eat and swallow liquid diet. Therefore, a diagnosis of mucositis grade 2 was made, which lasted for 6 days and gradually recovered. Additionally, on the 2nd day after CAR T-cell infusion, the patient developed a fever with a temperature of approximately 38.5 C and was not effectively treated with nonsteroidal antipyretic analgesic drugs and antibiotics. Repeated bacterial blood cultures were negative. On the 4th day after CAR T-cell infusion, the patient's blood pressure was 88/49 mmHg (the IL-6 level was 659.7 pg/ml) and was not effectively treated with rapid fluid replenishment. The patient was diagnosed with CRS grade 2 and treated with one dose of 8 mg/kg tocilizumab. His blood pressure gradually returned to normal within a few hours, and his temperature gradually returned to normal within 2 days. There was no ICANS after CAR T-cell infusion.
Surprisingly, PET-CT examination demonstrated CMR in the +1 month after CD19 CAR T-cell infusion following ASCT ( <PMC10739420_fimmu-14-1307242-g002_B_2_3.webp> ). At the last follow-up, the patient received ibrutinib as maintenance therapy and remained in CMR ( <PMC10739420_fimmu-14-1307242-g002_C_3_3.webp> ). Importantly, the circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) results indicated that the mutations of TP53, KMT2D, MS4A1, SOCS1 and HIST1H1C were persistently negative after CD19 CAR T-cell infusion following ASCT ( Table 2 ). The timeline of treatment is shown in  Figure 3 .
image_captions: PET-CT evaluation before and after ASCT and CAR T-cell infusion. (A): PET-CT examination demonstrated PD before ASCT and CAR T-cell infusion.
PET-CT evaluation before and after ASCT and CAR T-cell infusion. (B): PET-CT examination demonstrated CMR in the +1 month after ASCT and CAR T-cell therapy.

PET-CT evaluation before and after ASCT and CAR T-cell infusion. (C): PET-CT examination demonstrated sustained CMR in the +3 month after ASCT and CAR T-cell therapy. The thick arrows represent the positive lesions; thin arrows represent the original comparable lesion locations.

title: 8-year-old girl with a rapidly growing conjunctival mass diagnosed as embryonal
chief_complaint: 5-day history of a rapidly growing conjunctival mass of the right eye.
history: An 8-year-old Caucasian girl presented with no relevant past medical history, medications, allergies, or social/family history described in the report.
presenting_symptoms: Rapidly growing conjunctival mass of the right eye
exam_findings: Uncorrected visual acuity 6/15 bilaterally, normal intraocular pressures and pupillary examination. Right eye showed -1 abduction deficit, fullness of the upper eyelid with 3-mm blepharoptosis, but no proptosis, erythema or tenderness. Eversion revealed a large 30-mm x 10-mm x 4-mm multilobulated, vascularised, and papillomatous lesion in the superior conjunctival fornix and bulbar conjunctiva. Remainder of anterior and posterior segment examination was unremarkable for both eyes.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: Systemic staging imaging including CT chest, MRI brain, orbits, spine, and PET scan was performed and revealed stage 1, group 2 disease with no evidence of metastatic disease.
diagnosis: Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, stage 1, group 2 disease.
treatment: Subtotal excision of the lesion followed by systemic chemotherapy with vincristine, actinomycin, and cyclophosphamide as per protocol ARST0331.
key_learning_points: Rhabdomyosarcoma can present as a rapidly growing ocular mass in children, requiring urgent evaluation.
Diagnosis of rhabdomyosarcoma relies on histopathological examination with immunohistochemistry (desmin, MyoD1, myogenin) and genetic testing (FOX01 rearrangement) for subtyping.
Ocular rhabdomyosarcoma requires comprehensive staging imaging and a multidisciplinary approach for management, often involving surgery and chemotherapy.
description: 8-year-old girl with a rapidly growing conjunctival mass diagnosed as embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, successfully treated with subtotal excision and chemotherapy.
clinical_text:
We present a case of an 8-year-old Caucasian girl referred to the Pediatric Ophthalmology Clinic for a 5-day history of a rapidly growing conjunctival mass of the right eye (OD). On initial presentation, the uncorrected visual acuity was 6/15 bilaterally with normal intraocular pressures and pupillary examination. On motility assessment, there was a -1 abduction deficit of the affected eye (OD) with no significant proptosis noted using an exophthalmometer. However, the OD revealed fullness of the upper eyelid with approximately 3-mm blepharoptosis without eyelid erythema or tenderness (shown in <PMC10978040_cop-2024-0015-0001-536382_F01_undivided_1_1.webp>). On eyelid eversion, there was a large 30-mm x 10-mm x 4-mm multilobulated, vascularised, and papillomatous lesion arising within the superior conjunctival fornix and some parts of the bulbar conjunctiva (shown in <PMC10978040_cop-2024-0015-0001-536382_F01_undivided_1_1.webp>, 2). The remainder of the anterior and posterior segment examination was unremarkable. The left eye (OS) was also examined to be normal. The differential diagnoses based on the clinical findings included pyogenic granuloma, papilloma, lymphoma, and rhabdomyosarcoma.
An urgent subtotal excision of the lesion was performed in the theatre, and histopathological assessment was conducted. This demonstrated an infiltrate of mitotically active spindled cells positive for desmin, myoD1, and myogenin, therefore highly suggestive of rhabdomyosarcoma (shown in <PMC10978040_cop-2024-0015-0001-536382_F03_left_1_3.webp><PMC10978040_cop-2024-0015-0001-536382_F03_middle_2_3.webp><PMC10978040_cop-2024-0015-0001-536382_F03_right_3_3.webp>). The fluorescent in situ hybridisation assay demonstrated no rearrangement of the FOX01 gene consistent with the embryonal variant of rhabdomyosarcoma.
Following the diagnosis, a systemic staging process was conducted including CT chest, MRI brain, orbits, and spine in addition to a PET scan. This revealed stage 1, group 2 disease with no evidence of metastatic disease. The patient was treated with vincristine, actinomycin, cyclophosphamide, as per protocol ARST0331. Six months post treatment, the patient remains tumour-free with no ocular complications.
image_captions: Demonstrating an infiltrate of mitotically active spindled cells positive for desmin.
MyoD1.
Myogenin , highly suggestive of rhabdomyosarcoma.

title: 28yo male presents with severe DKA, acute pancreatitis, and multi-organ failure
chief_complaint: 28-year-old male found unresponsive on the floor of his home, following a one-week prodrome of fatigue and polydipsia.
history: The patient is a 28-year-old male with no past medical history and no prior medications. His demographic data included non-Hispanic/Caucasian ethnicity/race, BMI of 22, and he was not vaccinated against COVID-19.
exam_findings: Unresponsive, initial temperature 30.0 C rising to 39.0 C within 24 hours, admission blood pressure 70/40 mmHg, profound encephalopathy, emesis, petechial rash, new junctional cardiac rhythm, diffuse ST-segment elevation on ECG, left ventricular ejection fraction of 15% with global hypokinesis on TTE.
labs: Initial: pH < 6.78, bicarbonate <5 mEq/L, creatinine 3.69 mg/dL, blood glucose 1,959 mg/dL, lactate 4.8 mmol/L. Inflammatory markers: CRP 232 mg/L, ferritin 15,000 mug/L, procalcitonin 22 mug/L. Infectious: SARS-CoV-2 PCR positive (Ct 36.1), nucleocapsid IgG positive, blood cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus and Serratia marcescens. Cardiac: Troponin I peaked at 50 mug/L. Endocrine: Hemoglobin A1c > 14%, positive GAD-65, Zinc transporter 8, and islet cell antigen152 antibodies.
imaging_description: A computed tomography (CT) scan revealed diffuse cerebral edema without herniation or hemorrhage, and edematous pancreatitis.
diagnosis: Severe diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), acute pancreatitis, Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Adults (MIS-A), Staphylococcus aureus and Serratia marcescens bacteremia, and new-onset Type 1 diabetes.
treatment: Emergent intubation, volume and metabolic resuscitation, rapid escalation of vasopressor support, dobutamine, percutaneous LVAD placement, continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT), veno-arterial extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (VA-ECMO), antibiotics, fluids, electrolytes, insulin, methylprednisolone 1 gram IV for 3 days, IVIG 2 g/kg over 2 days, anakinra 100 mg twice daily then daily, Remdesivir 100 mg IV daily for 4 days, prednisone taper, and intermittent hemodialysis.
key_learning_points: New-onset Type 1 diabetes can present as severe diabetic ketoacidosis complicated by profound multi-organ dysfunction, including pancreatitis and encephalopathy, especially in young adults.

Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Adults (MIS-A) is a severe post-infectious complication of SARS-CoV-2, capable of causing critical illness, shock, and cardiac dysfunction, often co-existing with other acute conditions like DKA and sepsis.

A comprehensive approach is crucial for patients with severe DKA and multi-organ failure, including evaluation for underlying triggers such as infection, assessment for MIS-A, and workup for autoimmune diabetes.
description: 28yo male presents with severe DKA, acute pancreatitis, and multi-organ failure requiring critical care support, ultimately diagnosed with MIS-A following SARS-CoV-2 infection and new-onset Type 1 diabetes.
clinical_text:
In March 2022, a 28-year-old male with no past medical history was found unresponsive on the floor of his home, last seen 15 h prior, following a one-week prodrome of fatigue and polydipsia. His demographic data included non-Hispanic/Caucasian ethnicity/race, BMI of 22, not vaccinated against COVID-19, and no prior medications. On admission, his temperature was 30.0 C, but within 24 h it had risen to 39.0 C. His admission blood pressure was 70/40 mmHg, and he was emergently intubated for airway protection secondary to profound encephalopathy. His initial laboratory findings included pH < 6.78 (7.35-7.45), bicarbonate <5 mEq/L (22-29 mmol/L), creatinine 3.69 mg/dL, blood glucose 1,959 mg/dL (70-199 mg/dL), and lactate 4.8 mmol/L (0.5-2.0 mmol/L). His inflammatory markers were elevated with a CRP of 232 mg/L, ferritin of 15,000 mug/L, and a procalcitonin of 22 mug/L (<0.26 mug/L). A computed tomography (CT) scan revealed diffuse cerebral edema without herniation or hemorrhage, and edematous pancreatitis. A SARS-CoV-2 PCR was positive with a cycle threshold of 36.1, and a nucleocapsid IgG was also positive. The differential diagnosis for his syndrome considered by treating clinicians included sepsis, COVID-19, diabetic ketoacidosis, overdose, toxin exposure, pancreatitis, and myocardial infarction.
The patient underwent volume and metabolic resuscitation to treat severe diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) and acute pancreatitis, but nonetheless developed progressive shock requiring rapid escalation of vasopressor support. On hospital day 1, he developed emesis, a petechial rash, and a new junctional cardiac rhythm. ECG revealed diffuse ST-segment elevation. His troponin I peaked at 50 mug/L. A TTE showed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 15% with global hypokinesis. On hospital day 2, dobutamine was started, a percutaneous LVAD was placed, and continuous renal replacement therapy was initiated. Blood cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus and Serratia marcescens. On hospital day 3, veno-arterial extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (VA-ECMO) was initiated.
While on admission the patient was hypothermic, he met clinical and laboratory criteria for MIS-A on hospital day 1 based on the presence of fever, severe cardiac illness, encephalopathy, shock, elevated CRP, ferritin, procalcitonin, and positive SARS-CoV-2 IgG. In addition to antibiotics, fluids, electrolytes and insulin, the patient was treated with methylprednisolone 1 gram IV for 3 days, IVIG 2 g/kg over 2 days, and anakinra 100 mg twice daily for 2 days, then daily for 3 days, and clinically improved. COVID-19 was treated with Remdesivir 100 mg IV daily for 4 days. VA-ECMO and the LVAD was removed on day 8, he was extubated on day 12, and vasopressor and inotropic support was discontinued on day 13. He required ongoing renal replacement therapy for volume removal and was discharged to a skilled nursing facility on hospital day 23 on a prednisone taper and intermittent hemodialysis. His hemoglobin A1c was greater than 14% and testing for islet cell autoantibodies revealed positive GAD-65, Zinc transporter 8, and islet cell antigen152 antibodies, consistent with a new diagnosis of Type 1 diabetes.

title: 25-year-old female with a 5-year history of facial redness and excessive sweatin
chief_complaint: Redness and excessive sweating over the nose for more than 5 years.
history: A 25-year-old female presented with redness and excessive sweating over the nose for more than 5 years. She has a positive family history of increased centrofacial sweating, affecting her mother and two sisters, though they had no visible lesions. There was no history of exacerbation with sunlight.
exam_findings: Physical examination of the nose revealed dark erythematous multiple papules that disappear on diascopy.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: Figure 2 depicts dark erythematous multiple papules on the nose that disappear on diascopy.
diagnosis: Not explicitly stated in this case report.
treatment: The patient was initially treated with topical clindamycin and systemic doxycycline for 2 months, without improvement. Cryotherapy, isotretinoin, topical indomethacin, tacrolimus, and botulinum toxin A were considered but not pursued due to limited availability or moderate effectiveness. The patient was ultimately reassured regarding the benign nature of the disease.
key_learning_points: Understanding the role of family history in centrofacial sweating.
The utility of diascopy in evaluating dermatological lesions to differentiate vascular from non-vascular pathologies.
Factors influencing treatment decisions, including local availability, cost, and perceived efficacy of treatment options.
The importance of patient reassurance for benign conditions, especially when effective or readily available treatments are limited.
description: 25-year-old female with a 5-year history of facial redness and excessive sweating, presenting with papules that disappear on diascopy, managed with reassurance due to the benign nature of the condition.
clinical_text:
The second patient is a 25-year-old female who presented with redness and excessive sweating over the nose for more than 5 years. Physical examination of the nose revealed dark erythematous multiple papules that disappear on diascopy (Figure 2). This patient has a positive family history of increased centrofacial sweating (2 sisters and mother) but no visible lesions on the family members. No history of exacerbation with sunlight. The patient was treated with topical clindamycin and systemic doxycycline for 2 months but has not improved.
After discussing the potential side effects of the few treatment options available in our setup (cryotherapy and isotretinoin), and since even those options were only moderately effective and considering the lack of the relatively safe topical treatment options in our setting (topical indomethacin, tacrolimus, and botulinum toxin A), both patients were reassured considering the benign nature of the disease.

title: 33-year-old female patients with a history of FGM presented with a discomfort va
chief_complaint: Patients presented with a discomfort mass in the vagina.
history: The mean age of patients was 33 years. The average age for female genital mutilation (FGM) was 7.33 years, and the average age for the start of cyst growth was 18.05 years. A significant majority (85.7%) had FGM type II, with 66.7% of these patients being married.
exam_findings: A palpable mass with a mean size of 5.62+-1.77 was identified.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: Not described in this case.
diagnosis: Clitoral cyst, with most cases identified as epidermal cysts on pathology.
treatment: Not described in this case.
key_learning_points: Female genital mutilation (FGM) can lead to the formation of clitoral cysts.
Clitoral cysts often present as a discomfort mass in the vagina.
Epidermal cysts are a common pathological finding in patients with FGM-related clitoral cysts.
description: 33-year-old female patients with a history of FGM presented with a discomfort vaginal mass, diagnosed as clitoral epidermal cysts.
clinical_text: Findings: the mean age of the patients was 33.00+-14.89. Mean values for BMI, gravida, parity, live births, and abortion were as follows; 27.05+-2. 55, 3.24+-4.23, 3.19+-4.18, 3.14+-4.21, and .05+-.22, respectively. The mean size was found as 5.62+-1.77. While the average FGM date (age) was found to be 7.33+-1.77 years old, the average start date of cyst growth (age) was found as 18.05+-8.18 years old (Table 3). The female genital mutilation type of 18 (85.7%) of the patients was type II. However, all patients were diagnosed with a clitoral cyst. The most common type of complaint was discomfort mass in the vagina. The pathology type of most patients was an epidermal cyst. 66.7% of female genital mutilation type II patients were married (Table 4).

title: Patient recovering from a prosthetic joint infection and metabolic acidosis afte
specialty: Infectious Disease, Orthopedic Surgery, Critical Care Medicine
chief_complaint: Not described in this case. The patient was recovering from a prosthetic joint infection and metabolic acidosis.
history: After 19 days of ICU treatment, the patient was discharged to a regular ward. No other relevant past medical, social, or family history is provided, beyond a hospitalization for another illness 6 months later.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: An external laboratory report showed isolated, massive oxoprolinuria of 2965 mg g (creatinine).
imaging_description: Not described in this case.
diagnosis: Prosthetic Joint Infection (PJI) and metabolic acidosis.
treatment: Initial treatment involved 19 days of ICU care. Antibiotic treatment was switched to oral moxifloxacin 400 mg d and rifampicin 600 mg d, which was given for a further 7 weeks, totaling 12 weeks of antibiotic treatment.
key_learning_points: Massive oxoprolinuria can be an important and sometimes isolated lab finding in complex clinical scenarios.
Prosthetic joint infections (PJI) often require prolonged, multi-drug antibiotic regimens for successful treatment.
Monitoring for complete recovery and absence of relapse is crucial after treatment for severe infections and metabolic disturbances.
description: Patient recovering from a prosthetic joint infection and metabolic acidosis after prolonged ICU treatment, complicated by massive oxoprolinuria, receiving extended oral antibiotic therapy.
clinical_text: After discharge to the regular ward following 19 d of ICU treatment, we received the external laboratory report. It showed an isolated, massive oxoprolinuria of 2965 mg g (creatinine) (reference  mg g (creatinine)). The antibiotic treatment was switched to an oral treatment on moxifloxacin 400 mg d and rifampicin 600 mg d, and it was given for a further 7 weeks (12 weeks antibiotic treatment in total). The patient showed a complete recovery from the metabolic acidosis and no signs of relapse of the PJI during a hospitalisation for another illness 6 months later.

title: A 32-year-old woman on hemodialysis with chronic glomerulonephritis presented wi
chief_complaint: Sudden onset of nausea and rigor with fever during hemodialysis.
history: A 32-year-old woman with chronic kidney disease secondary to chronic glomerulonephritis had been on stable maintenance hemodialysis for 9 months via a right internal jugular tunnelled catheter placed 8 months prior. She had refused arteriovenous fistula creation due to being waitlisted for kidney transplantation and had a history of hypertension.
exam_findings: Physical examination revealed no signs of hyperaemia, tenderness, or drainage from the catheter exit site or subcutaneous tunnel. Auscultation of her chest and abdominal examination were normal, with no obvious non-catheter-related infection sources.
labs: Absolute neutrophil count 8.5 x 10^9 cells/L with increased neutrophil/lymphocyte ratio, hemoglobin 10.6 g/dL, C-reactive protein 6.6 mg/L. Blood cultures from the catheter lumen and peripheral vein revealed Acinetobacter baumannii, sensitive to ceftazidime, cefoperazone/sulbactam, ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, piperacillin/tazobactam, ticarcillin/clavulanate, meropenem, imipenem, and sulfamethoxazole.
imaging_description: Echocardiography, chest computed tomography, and abdominal ultrasonography were performed; however, no source of infection was revealed.
diagnosis: Acinetobacter baumannii Catheter-Related Bloodstream Infection (CRBSI).
treatment: Empirical oral cefuroxime axetil (500 mg/day) was initiated. After blood culture results and a positive skin test for ceftazidime and cefoperazone/sulbactam, intravenous levofloxacin (500 mg every other day), tailored to residual renal function, was chosen. Antibiotic lock therapy with a levofloxacin (2 mg/mL) and urokinase (5,000 U/mL) mixture was prescribed daily after an initial levofloxacin-heparin mixture produced turbidity. Intravenous antibiotic treatment and antibiotic lock therapy were administered for 14 days.
key_learning_points: Diagnosis and management of catheter-related bloodstream infections (CRBSI) in hemodialysis patients.
Importance of blood cultures from both catheter and peripheral sites for CRBSI diagnosis.
Tailoring antibiotic therapy based on culture sensitivities, patient allergies, and renal function.
Addressing drug incompatibility issues in antibiotic lock therapy (e.g., levofloxacin and heparin).
Strategies for catheter salvage in CRBSI through antibiotic lock therapy.
description: A 32-year-old woman on hemodialysis with chronic glomerulonephritis presented with fever and rigor during dialysis, diagnosed with Acinetobacter baumannii catheter-related bloodstream infection, successfully treated with tailored intravenous antibiotics and antibiotic lock therapy.
clinical_text:
A 32-year-old woman with chronic kidney disease secondary to chronic glomerulonephritis had been on stable maintenance HD for approximately 9 months. The vascular access was a tunnelled catheter placed 8 months prior via the right internal jugular vein. The patient had refused arteriovenous fistula creation because she had been waitlisted for kidney transplantation. She had a history of hypertension and glomerular nephritis. In July 2020, after 2 h of HD, she developed nausea and rigor, with a temperature of 38.4 C. Her blood pressure decreased from 140/89 to 112/65 mmHg and her heart rate was 90 beats/min (regular). Two sets of specimens were obtained for blood culture from the catheter lumen and peripheral vein.
The patient was then admitted to the hospital for further observation. Physical examination revealed no signs of hyperaemia, tenderness, drainage from the exit site, or subcutaneous tunnel of the catheter. Auscultation of her chest and abdominal examination were normal. No obvious causes of non-catheter-related infection were observed. A complete blood count at the time of admission revealed a slightly increased absolute neutrophil count (8.5 x 109 cells/L) with a dramatic increase in the neutrophil/lymphocyte ratio. Her haemoglobin level was 10.6 g/dL and her C-reactive protein was 6.6 mg/L. Echocardiography, chest computed tomography, and abdominal ultrasonography were performed; however, no source of infection was revealed. Therefore, empirical treatment with oral cefuroxime axetil (500 mg/day) was initiated for presumed CRBSI.
On the patient's third day of hospitalisation, blood cultures from the catheter lumen and peripheral vein revealed Acinetobacter baumannii, with sensitivity to ceftazidime, cefoperazone/sulbactam, ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, piperacillin/tazobactam, ticarcillin/clavulanate, meropenem, imipenem, and sulfamethoxazole. However, she developed a positive reaction in the skin test for ceftazidime and cefoperazone/sulbactam. Therefore, we chose 500 mg of intravenous levofloxacin (quinolone) to be administered every other day, which was tailored to the residual renal function. Antibiotic lock therapy was used to salvage the catheter. The levofloxacin (2 mg/mL) and heparin (1,000 U/mL) mixture produced turbidity. Therefore, we prescribed an antimicrobial lock of levofloxacin (2 mg/mL) and urokinase (5,000 U/mL) once daily.
The patient's symptoms resolved after the initiation of appropriate antibiotics. Subsequent blood cultures obtained 3 days after treatment initiation was negative; thus, the catheter was salvaged. The effects of treatment on the routine laboratory parameters are shown in Table 1. Intravenous antibiotic treatment and antibiotic lock therapy were administered for 14 days, without any allergic reactions. The patient did not develop a recurrence of infection over the next 9 months, after which she underwent successful kidney transplantation (<PMC10105553_j_med-2023-0699-fig001_undivided_1_1.webp>). Additionally, we verified the physical compatibility of levofloxacin and urokinase by visual inspection, turbidimetric measurements, and particle count.

title: 72-year-old female with severe, symptomatic Kellgren-Lawrence grade IV right kne
chief_complaint: A 72-year-old female presented with progressively worsening right knee pain for over 15 years.
history: A 72-year-old female with a BMI of 33.8 had severe tricompartmental osteoarthritis of the right knee, classified as Kellgren-Lawrence grade IV radiographically, causing symptomatic pain for over 15 years.
exam_findings: On clinical examination, she had a varus knee with a mild fixed flexion deformity. Her range of movement was limited to 90 degrees flexion, and she was tender on palpation around the medial joint line.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: Radiographic imaging revealed severe tricompartmental osteoarthritis of the knee, classified as Kellgren-Lawrence grade IV.
diagnosis: Severe tricompartmental osteoarthritis of the right knee, Kellgren-Lawrence grade IV.
treatment: The patient underwent right total knee replacement surgery using a navigated Columbus total knee replacement (B. Braun) prosthesis. Preoperative and 12-month postoperative questionnaires were administered for assessment.
key_learning_points: Understand the clinical presentation and progression of advanced knee osteoarthritis.
Learn about the Kellgren-Lawrence grading system for radiographic osteoarthritis severity.
Identify the indications for total knee replacement in severe osteoarthritis.
description: 72-year-old female with severe, symptomatic Kellgren-Lawrence grade IV right knee osteoarthritis undergoing total knee replacement.
clinical_text:
The Nottinghamshire Research Ethics Committee gave ethical approval for this patient to receive a metal artefact reduction MRI scan as part of a wider study (REC ref number 10/H0408/115). The patient (female, aged 72, BMI 33.8) awaiting right total knee replacement surgery was recruited after taking informed consent as part of the pilot study. The patient had severe tricompartmental osteoarthritis of the knee with radiographic (Kellegren-Lawrence grade IV) and symptomatic OA prior to the joint replacement surgery (Figure 1). The patient had suffered from progressively worsening symptoms of pain in the right knee for over 15 years. She described pain on standing and on movement as well as disturbance of her normal sleep pattern. On clinical examination she had a varus knee with a mild fixed flexion deformity. Her range of movement was limited to 90  flexion and she was tender on palpation around the medial joint line.
Preoperative questionnaires were administered within 2 weeks of the total joint replacement and were repeated 12 months after the operation. The questionnaires included assessment of pain severity, pain catastrophizing, knee function, anxiety, depression, and a measure of the neuropathic pain-like symptoms. The questionnaires included are outlined in Table 1. A navigated Columbus total knee replacement (B. Braun) prosthesis was used as the implant in the case (Figure 2).

title: A 9-year-old boy with alpha thalassemia presented with chronic fever, cytopenias
chief_complaint: Intermittent fever for 2 months.
history: A 9-year-old boy born with alpha thalassemia (-SEA/alphaalpha) received five red blood cell transfusions from birth to 2018. He was BCG vaccinated at birth, has no recent travel history, and his parents reported no family hereditary diseases (besides thalassemia), no TB history nor TB exposure.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: WBC: 2.6 x 10^9/L (initial), then 1.5 x 10^9/L; Neutrophils: 1.15 x 10^9/L (initial), then 0.51 x 10^9/L; Hemoglobin: 74 g/L (initial), then 64 g/L, then 90 g/L (post-transfusion); Platelets: 211 x 10^9/L (initial), then 201 x 10^9/L; EB DNA: Negative; IGRAs: Positive; PPD: Positive; Serum ferritin: 3,603.35 ng/ml (elevated), then 9612.81 ng/ml (further elevated); Bone marrow smear: Positive for acid-fast staining; Bone marrow qPCR for TB: Positive; Gene sequencing: InhA gene mutation (-15C > T) causing isoniazid resistance; Bone marrow biopsy: Active hyperplasia with occasional hemophagocytic histiocytes; Sputum and CSF smear/TB-DNA: Negative.
imaging_description: Ultrasound scan revealed bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy and an enlarged spleen. Lung computed tomography (CT) showed calcification of the right hilum and mediastinal lymph nodes, without lung infiltration or tuberculous foci.
diagnosis: Isoniazid-resistant disseminated tuberculosis originating from bone marrow with suspected secondary hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis.
treatment: 2U red blood cell infusion, empirical amoxicillin and antifebrile, anti-TB regimen (isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, ethambutol), and methylprednisolone 1 mg/kg q12h.
key_learning_points: Disseminated tuberculosis can present with chronic fever, cytopenias, and extrapulmonary manifestations, requiring thorough investigation.
Persistent fever, cytopenias, and markedly elevated serum ferritin in the setting of severe infection should prompt evaluation for Hemophagocytic Lymphohistiocytosis (HLH).
Drug susceptibility testing is critical in tuberculosis management, as demonstrated by the identification of isoniazid resistance leading to treatment challenges.
description: A 9-year-old boy with alpha thalassemia presented with chronic fever, cytopenias, and lymphadenopathy, diagnosed with isoniazid-resistant disseminated tuberculosis and suspected secondary hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis.
clinical_text:
A 9-year-old boy with intermittent fever for 2 months was transferred to our hospital on November 3, 2021. He was born with alpha thalassemia (-SEA/alphaalpha), and from his birth to 2018, he had received five red blood cell transfusions. He has been Bacilli Calmette-Guerin (BCG) vaccinated at birth under the national vaccination program. He has no recent travel history, and his parents reported no family hereditary diseases, besides thalassemia, no TB history nor TB exposure.
The patient started to develop intermittent fever in August 2021, with the highest body temperature of 38.0 C and night sweats. There were no respiratory symptoms or weight loss. He was admitted to a local children hospital shortly after his fever had persisted for 5 days. His routine blood test on admission showed white blood cell (WBC) 2.6 x 109/L, neutrophils (Neu) 1.15 x 109/L, hemoglobin (Hb) 74 g/L, and platelets (PLT) 211 x 109/L. Ultrasound scan revealed bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy and an enlarged spleen.
In 3 days, his hemoglobin level dropped to 64 g/L, and he was given 2U red blood cell infusion. Repeated blood test on the following day showed decreased level of WBC to 1.5 x 109/L and Neu of 0.51 x 109/L with an elevated Hb level of 90 g/L and an unremarkable change of PLT 201 x 109/L. Viral markers for Epstein-Barr virus (EB DNA) was negative. In addition, subsequent blood interferon-gamma release assays (IGRAs) and skin purified protein derivative (PPD) tests were positive. Lung computed tomography (CT) showed calcification of the right hilum and mediastinal lymph nodes. In the absence of lung infiltration and tuberculous foci, latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI) was suspected. A bone marrow aspiration smear performed the following day showed active bone marrow hyperplasia, significantly decreased neutrophil level, and generally normal morphology. The patient had persistent daily fever between 37.4 C and 38.8 C accompanied with dry cough, fatigue, and loss of appetite. He was empirically administered with amoxicillin 0.25 g three times a day for 3 days and antifebrile for a week. But his fever remained unsolved during the treatment, fluctuating in the same range as before. Pathological findings from his cervical lymph node biopsy showed no caseous necrosis and no acid-fast mycobacteria. The persistent low WBC in peripheral blood had raised concern. To look into possible causes of the persistent fever, a second bone marrow puncture was performed. Bone marrow smear was positive for acid-fast staining (Figure 1). Disseminated TB infection was suspected. But further sputum and cerebrospinal fluid smear were negative for both acid-fast staining and TB-DNA (CapitalBio Technology, China). Thus, pulmonary TB and tuberculous meningitis were ruled out. The bone marrow was presumed as the tuberculous origin. Anti-TB regimen composing isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol was initiated from the diagnosis. His temperature resumed to normal range 4 days later. His appetite also improved.
But a week later, he had fever again with the highest measure of 40.0 C. Serum ferritin was observed to have elevated to 3,603.35 ng/ml (reference: < 300 ng/ml). Methylprednisolone 1 mg/kg q12 h was administered as anti-inflammatory therapy, but his fever did not go away. A repeated bone marrow aspiration was performed the following day to investigate the causes for the unresolved fever, elevated serum ferritin, and decreased WBC.
