The peritoneal cavity was entered and entire abdomen explored. A firm, irregular brownish-yellow mass measuring 19 cm x 10 cm was found. This had almost completely replaced the right kidney. tumor had infiltrated the Gerota's fascia and was adherent to the inferior surface of the liver. The right renal vein and adjacent IVC wall were infiltrated. There was perihilar and para-aortic lymphadenopathy. However, there was no palpable liver metastasis.
 The colon and duodenum were free.
 Initial renal pedicle control was not possible. Thus, the tumor was mobilized inferiorly and laterally. The superior pole of the tumour was separated from the inferior hepatic surface with careful blunt dissection. The distorted renal vessels were carefully dissected, and divided in between Satinsky vascular clamps. Partial longitudinal resection of the tumor-infiltrated IVC wall was done. This was accompanied by transient hypotension which was controlled by the preinformed anaesthetists.
The ureter was then ligated and divided far beyond the level of tumour involvement. The tumour, the adrenal gland, regional lymph nodes, and resected wall of IVC were removed in one block.
The renal fossa and inferior hepatic surface were packed as the latter continued to ooze despite efforts at meticulous hemostasis. The pack was removed forty-eight hours postoperatively by the bed side.
 Patient had hypovolemic shock with acute renal failure twelve hours after-surgery. This was successfully managed in conjunction with nephrologists.
 She also had right facial palsy and bilateral pitting pedal edema up to midleg. She was discharged to the clinic ten days later.
The gross pathological examination revealed a greyish-brown nodular kidney with the adrenal measuring 18.5 cm x 12 cm x 11 cm and weighing 813 g. The pelvic region showed the stump of the ureter, two ligated blood vessels measuring 1.5 cm and 1.7 cm long, respectively, with external diameter of 0.4 cm (Figure 2).
 Microscopically, the specimen showed renal tissue with large sheets of neoplastic epithelial cells separated by delicate vascular septae. These cells exhibited clear to eosinophilic cytoplasm, moderately pleomorphic round to avoid vesicular nuclei with prominent nucleoli, and two mitotic figures per high-power field. There were extensive areas of hemorrhage and necrosis along with foci of dystrophic calcification. Tumour cells were seen in the pelvis of the kidney and in a vascular channel. These are in keeping with right clear cell RCC with vascular invasion; Fuhrman's grade 3.
The woman has been regular at clinic followup. She no longer has flank pain, and pedal edema had resolved.
Postoperative ultrasound demonstrated absent right kidney, normal left kidney, no para-aortic lymphadenopathy and no ascites.

title: A 4-year-old boy presented with motor developmental delay, reeling gait, and mus
chief_complaint: Investigation of symptoms suggestive of Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) and genetic counseling for future pregnancy planning.
history: A 4-year-old boy, the first child of healthy parents, with no relevant family or medical history. Parents sought genetic understanding for the patient's symptoms and assistance with future pregnancy prevention via PGD.
exam_findings: Gowers' sign on rising from floor, fatigue, muscle weakness, and calf pseudohypertrophy were observed. Muscle power assessment by MRC scale showed a slight reduction in muscle tone. An electromyograph showed fasciculation potential at resting state and a pathological interference phase when the medial femoris muscle contracted vigorously; low amplitude, short-duration motor unit potentials (MUPs) were also found in the medial head of the gastrocnemius and the medial femoris muscle. Nerve conduction velocity was normal.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: Not described in this case.
diagnosis: Speculated Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD)
treatment: Not described in this case. Parents sought future Preimplantation Genetic Diagnosis (PGD) for recurrence prevention.
key_learning_points: Clinical features suggestive of Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) include motor developmental delay, reeling gait, Gowers' sign, and calf pseudohypertrophy.
Electromyography (EMG) can reveal myogenic injury in DMD, characterized by fasciculation potentials, pathological interference phases, and low amplitude, short-duration motor unit potentials (MUPs).
Genetic counseling and preimplantation genetic diagnosis (PGD) are important considerations for families with genetic disorders to prevent recurrence in future offspring.
description: A 4-year-old boy presented with motor developmental delay, reeling gait, and muscle weakness, with findings suggestive of Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) on examination and electromyography.
clinical_text:
A 4-year-old boy being speculated as having DMD was investigated in this study. The patient is the first child of healthy parents, and there was no heredity and medical history within his family. The patient's parents were eager to understand the underlying genetic factors behind the patient's symptoms and be assisted in future pregnancy to prevent the recurrence of the same mutation in the new offspring by PGD. The patient complained of reeling gait, delay in motor development, Gowers' sign on rising from floor, and having difficulties climbing stairs, which are suggestive of DMD clinical phenotypes.
Upon general physical examination, fatigue, muscle weakness, and calf pseudohypertrophy were observed in the patient (Figure 1A). An electromyograph showed that the fasciculation potential could be seen at the resting state and appeared as a pathological interference phase when the medial femoris muscle contracted vigorously; low amplitude coupled with short-duration motor unit potentials (MUPs) was also found in the medial head of the gastrocnemius and the medial femoris muscle. The patient's nerve conduction velocity was found to be normal. These findings reflect myogenic injury in the patient. Interestingly, muscle power assessment, as determined by the Medical Research Council's scale (MRC scale) of muscle power, showed a slight reduction in muscle tone.

title: 28-year-old brain-dead female donor with recurrent low-grade astrocytoma from wh
chief_complaint: A brain-dead 28-year-old female with recurrent low-grade astrocytoma was evaluated for organ procurement.
history: The patient was a 28-year-old brain-dead, heart-beating female with a history of recurrent non-operable, large, low-grade astrocytoma. She had no evidence of sepsis or other co-morbidities.
presenting_symptoms: No specific symptoms described, as the patient was brain-dead for organ donation purposes.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: Hematological and biochemical investigations were within the normal range. Urinalysis revealed occasional pus cells; serum creatinine was 0.9 mg% and serum bilirubin was 0.6 mg%.
imaging_description: Abdominal ultrasonography showed both kidneys were normal in size, maintained echotexture, and had preserved cortico-medullary differentiation. There was no evidence of lymphadenopathy, ascites, or liver metastasis.
diagnosis: Brain-dead, heart-beating donor with recurrent non-operable, large, low-grade astrocytoma.
treatment: Organ procurement involved midline laparotomy and thoracotomy, dissection of infra-renal and supraceliac aorta, in situ perfusion with histidine-tryptophan-ketoglutarate solution, blood and fluid exsanguination, and abdominal organ cooling with ice-slush. Recipients received induction with rabbit-anti-thymocyte globulin (1.5 mg/kg) and methylprednisolone (500 mg IV for 3 days post-operatively). Maintenance immunosuppression included prednisolone (30 mg/day tapered to 10 mg/day), mycophenolate mofetil (2 g/day), and tacrolimus (0.08 mg/kg body weight/day). Prophylaxis was given for CMV (ganciclovir 1g TID x 3 months), fungal infections (fluconazole 100 mg QD x 6 months), and PCP (trimethoprim/sulfamethaxazole 160/800 mg QD x 9 months).
key_learning_points: Considerations for organ procurement from deceased donors with a history of low-grade brain tumors, including counseling recipients on potential cancer transmission risks.
Standard induction and maintenance immunosuppression protocols following renal transplantation.
Routine prophylactic regimens for opportunistic infections (CMV, fungal, PCP) in renal transplant recipients.
description: 28-year-old brain-dead female donor with recurrent low-grade astrocytoma from whom kidneys were procured and transplanted into two recipients.
clinical_text:
Both kidneys were procured from a brain-dead, heart-beating 28-year-old female harboring recurrent non-operable, large, low-grade astrocytoma in a city 250 km away from our center. She had no evidence of sepsis and other co-morbidity. Her hematological and biochemical investigations were within the normal range. Urinalysis revealed occasional pus cells and the serum creatinine was 0.9 mg% and serum biluribin was 0.6 mg%. Ultrasonography of the abdomen revealed that both kidney were normal in size, maintained echotexture and had preserved cortico-medullary differentiation. There was no evidence of lymphadenopathy, ascites and liver metastasis.
A standard technique of in situ perfusion during organ procurement was used. Briefly, midline laparotomy and thoracotomy was performed. The infra-renal and supraceliac aorta were dissected. In situ perfusion was performed with histidine-tryptophan-ketoglutarate solution, blood and fluid were exsanguinated in the chest. Abdominal organs were cooled by ice-slush at the time of in situ perfusion and then procured. Both the recipients agreed upon accepting the organ at the first instance when they were counseled regarding the availability of a deceased donor harboring brain tumor and possible risk of cancer transmission, and transplantation was carried out on 24 November 2013.
Both recipients received induction with rabbit-anti-thymocyte globulin (r-ATG) (1.5 mg/kg) and methylprednisolone (MP) 500 mg intravenously. MP was continued for 3 days post-operatively. Maintenance of immunosuppression consisted of prednisolone (30 mg/day tapered to 10 mg/day at 3 months post-transplant and continued thereafter), mycophenolate mofetil (2 g/day) and tacrolimus (0.08 mg/kg body weight/day). Both recipients also received prophylaxis against cytomegalovirus infection (gancyclovir 1 g thrice a day x 3 months), fungal infections (fluconazole 100 mg once a day x 6 months) and Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia (trimethoprim/sulfamethaxazole [160/800 mg] once a day x 9 months).

title: 76-year-old female presenting with chronic and acute GI symptoms, ultimately dia
chief_complaint: Three-month history of nausea, vomiting, and occasional diarrhea.
history: A 76-year-old female with a past medical history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, and gastroesophageal reflux disease.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: EGD showed a small hiatal hernia and atrophic gastritis. Initial CT scan revealed significant colonic wall thickening and pericolonic inflammatory stranding of the entire colon with sparing of the cecum, concerning for pancolitis with mild ascites. Colonoscopy revealed pancolonic diffuse mucosal vascular congestion, pronounced in the rectosigmoid, with decreased mucosal vascular pattern; biopsies showed architectural distortion and Paneth cell metaplasia of chronic colitis. CTA showed slightly improved diffuse pancolitis, patent abdominal aorta and proximal mesenteric vasculature, and tortuous vascular lesions in the IMA territory with early filling veins concerning for AVMs. MRA displayed multiple focal aneurysmal vessels in the left colonic mesentery in an IMA distribution, with mild improvement in colitis. Mesenteric arteriogram demonstrated three AVMs, each supplied by branches of the IMA (left colic, superior rectal, and sigmoid arteries).
diagnosis: Inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) territory arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) causing recurrent colonic bleeding and colitis.
treatment: Supportive care and steroid therapy were initially provided. Lovenox was administered for bilateral lower extremity DVTs. Ultimately, selective coil embolization and Onyx liquid embolic instillation of three AVMs in the left colic, superior rectal, and sigmoid arteries were performed.
key_learning_points: Recurrent gastrointestinal bleeding and colitis warrant thorough investigation beyond common etiologies like inflammatory bowel disease or ischemic colitis.
Advanced imaging modalities such as CTA, MRA, and conventional angiography are crucial for diagnosing vascular malformations as a cause of colonic bleeding.
Mesenteric arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) can present with varied symptoms, including chronic and acute gastrointestinal bleeding, and may require interventional radiologic embolization.
Paneth cell metaplasia in biopsy can be seen in chronic colitis, and may not exclude vascular causes when clinical suspicion persists.
description: 76-year-old female presenting with chronic and acute GI symptoms, ultimately diagnosed with inferior mesenteric artery AVMs causing recurrent colitis and bleeding, successfully treated with embolization.
clinical_text:
Our patient is a 76-year-old female with a past medical history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, and gastroesophageal reflux disease, initially presenting to the emergency department (ED) with a three-month history of nausea, vomiting, and occasional diarrhea. She was evaluated by gastroenterology, and an outpatient EGD was performed showing a small hiatal hernia and atrophic gastritis. Within the next few weeks, she presented to ED with acute onset abdominal pain and worsening diarrhea which now appeared to be bloody. A CT scan of abdomen and pelvis was requested for the clinical diagnosis of ischemic colitis. Significant colonic wall thickening and pericolonic inflammatory stranding of the entire colon with sparing of the cecum, concerning for pancolitis with mild ascites, were noted on the initial CT scan (Figures 1(a) and 1(b)). The gastroenterology team was mostly concerned for noninfectious colitis, namely, ulcerative colitis or ischemic colitis, and boarded her for colonoscopy. Due to the patient's overall condition, comorbidities, and improvement of acute symptoms with supportive care, a colonoscopy was performed three days after admission when she was deemed stable. The results revealed pancolonic diffuse mucosal vascular congestion, pronounced in the rectosigmoid region, with a decreased mucosal vascular pattern. Random biopsies were performed which histopathologically revealed architectural distortion and paneth cell metaplasia, as seen in chronic colitis, without evidence of active colitis, granulomas, crypt abscesses, or dysplasia. The following day, a CTA of the abdomen and pelvis was obtained to evaluate for the possibility of an underlying vascular etiology. CTA showed that diffuse pancolitis slightly improved compared to the prior CT exam four days prior with a normal caliber patent abdominal aorta and proximal mesenteric vasculature. The CTA also displayed tortuous vascular lesions in the IMA territory with early filling veins concerning for AVMs (Figures 2(a)-2(d)). Given the rarity of AVM-induced ischemic colitis, patency of proximal mesenteric vessels, biopsy results suggesting chronic colitis, and overall clinical improvement with supportive therapy and steroids, the clinical suspicion favored ulcerative colitis. Given this presumed diagnosis, steroid therapy was continued and the patient was discharged in stable condition with recommendation for a follow-up in two weeks. At the time of follow-up, the patient had no abdominal symptoms and reported complete improvement.
Approximately one month later, the patient presented to the emergency department with bilateral lower extremity edema and fatigue. Work-up for the edema revealed bilateral lower extremity DVTs, and the patient was placed on Lovenox. Shortly after, the patient developed several episodes of hematochezia and abdominal pain which prompted MRA of the abdomen, further strengthening the concern for AVMs. The MRA exhibited an inferior mesenteric artery distribution of multiple focal aneurysmal vessels in the left colonic mesentery (Figures 3(a) and 3(b)). Additionally, MRA displayed mild improvement in the patient's previously noted colitis.
At this point, interventional radiology was consulted for a mesenteric angiogram. Arteriogram demonstrated a total of 3 AVMs, each individually supplied by branches of the IMA (Figures 4(a)-4(d)). The left colic artery was divided into two distal omental branches, which were coil embolized prior to Onyx liquid embolic instillation of the left colic artery (Figure 5(a)). The superior rectal artery was divided into two distal branches; both of which supplied the largest of the three AVMs, which was embolized with Onyx injection into the superior rectal artery proximal to both of the aforementioned branches (Figure 5(b)). The sigmoid artery, similar to the left colic, had two distal omental branches that were coil embolized before Onyx liquid embolic instillation (Figure 5(c)). There was an enlarged marginal vein draining into the middle colic vein with increased flow due to the AVMs. Subsequent SMA arteriogram displayed adequate flow to the left colon, sigmoid colon, and superior rectum from collaterals supplied by the marginal artery.
During postprocedural follow-up, the patient denied any abdominal pain, melena, or hematochezia. The patient demonstrated stability for over 1 year and was without any recurrence of abdominal symptoms.

title: A 54-year-old male presented with advanced HER2-negative gastric adenocarcinoma
chief_complaint: A 54-year-old male presented with black stool, chest tightness, and fatigue of more than one month's duration.
history: Relevant past medical history, medications, allergies, social history, and family history are not described in this case report.
exam_findings: Physical examination revealed anemia and stomach upset.
labs: Hemoglobin 39g/L. Tumor markers CA-125 and CA-199 showed an initial increase followed by a gradual decrease.
imaging_description: Emergency abdominal CT showed findings suspicious for gastric antrum cancer. Gastroscopy revealed an enormous, ulcerated, friable, easily bleeding ulcer extending from the gastric antrum to the corner of the stomach, with irregular upwelling, and inability to pass the pylorus. Abdominal CT from other hospitals showed advanced gastric malignant tumor with multiple distant lymph node metastases. Initial PET/CT showed diffuse abnormal thickening of the gastric antrum with increased metabolism and extraneous invasion, along with multiple hypermetabolic enlarged lymph nodes around the pylorus, mesenteric root, and retroperitoneum. Subsequent PET/CT scans showed partial response (PR) with significant reduction in size and metabolism of the gastric cancer and lymph node lesions.
diagnosis: HER2-negative gastric adenocarcinoma, advanced stage T4N3M1 (Stage IV) with multiple distant lymph node metastases.
treatment: Exploratory laparotomy was performed, followed by palliative gastrojejunostomy and postoperative symptomatic and supportive treatments. Subsequently, the patient received a SOX regimen palliative chemotherapy combined with PD-1 antibody immunotherapy (Nivolumab, 200 mg, q2w) and synchronous irradiation of the gastric lesion (3Gy/8fx).
key_learning_points: Advanced gastric adenocarcinoma often presents with non-specific symptoms like black stool, chest tightness, and fatigue, necessitating comprehensive investigation.

HER2-negative gastric adenocarcinoma, especially in advanced stages with distant metastases, may benefit from multidisciplinary palliative treatment involving chemotherapy, immunotherapy (PD-1 inhibitors), and radiation therapy.
Imaging modalities like PET/CT are crucial for initial staging, assessing tumor response (e.g., partial response by RECIST criteria), and monitoring tumor activity during systemic treatment.
description: A 54-year-old male presented with advanced HER2-negative gastric adenocarcinoma (T4N3M1) treated with palliative gastrojejunostomy, SOX chemotherapy, Nivolumab, and radiation, achieving partial response.
clinical_text:
A 54-year-old male patient received emergency treatment in our hospital for black stool, chest tightness and fatigue that started more than one month earlier. He was initially diagnosed with gastrointestinal bleeding and severe anemia due to hemoglobin 39g/L. Next, emergency abdominal CT showed that the gastric antrum cancer should be considered first, recommending the patient to be transferred to the Department of Gastroenterology for follow-up treatment. Then, gastroscopy results showed that the gastroscope smoothly passed through esophagus, the dentate line of cardia was clear, the gastric fundus was smooth, and the mucosa was normal. However, his gastric mucosa was congested, and an enormous ulcer spread from the gastric antrum to the corner of the stomach with irregular upwelling around, ulcerated surface, brittle texture, easy bleeding (biopsy site), and gastroscope could not pass through pylorus in the gastric antrum (Figure 1). Meanwhile, he also underwent gastroscopy biopsy that revealed HER2-negative gastric adenocarcinoma (<PMC6757230_OTT-12-7691-g0002_A_1_3.webp><PMC6757230_OTT-12-7691-g0002_B_2_3.webp><PMC6757230_OTT-12-7691-g0002_C_3_3.webp>). Additionally, abdominal computed tomography (CT) examination in other hospitals showed advanced gastric malignant tumor with multiple distant lymph node metastases, with staging of T4N3M1. Due to severe anemia caused by hemorrhage, the patient received exploratory laparotomy. Unfortunately, the tumor lesion was found to have invaded so widely that lost the opportunity of radical treatment during operation, which was the same as imaging results. Finally, surgeons had to operate gastrojejunostomy for the sake of his life quality, and he was discharged from our hospital with only postoperative symptomatic and supportive treatments.
Physical examination showed anemia with stomach upset, which was consistent with laboratory findings. Follow-up positron emission tomography/computed tomography (PET/CT) depicted that diffuse abnormal thickening of the gastric antrum accompanied by increased metabolism was considered as gastric malignant tumor with extraneous invasion; multiple hypermetabolic enlarged lymph nodes around the pylorus of the gastric antrum, mesenteric root and retroperitoneum were regarded as metastasis, which were divided into IV stages of T4N3M1 (Figure 3A). After a multi-disciplinary consultation, we formulated a treatment plan: SOX regimen palliative chemotherapy combined with PD-1 antibody immunotherapy (Nivolumab, 200 mg, q2w), and synchronous irradiation of gastric lesion (3Gy/8fx) to alleviate local symptoms. The specific treatment schedule was shown in Supplementary figure 1.
Two weeks after the injection of Nivolumab, the patient returned to our hospital, reporting that he felt slightly itchy on his thighs, but the symptoms of gastric discomfort were better than before. He insisted on continuing treatment, and after two courses of treatment, the patient volunteered for a PET/CT. The PET/CT revealed a partial response (PR, about a 60% decrease in the total diameters of target lesions compared with the first PET/CT results) of the gastric cancer and lymph node, the morphology of the lesion and metabolism was obviously reduced, but tumor activity remained (Figure 3B), which was in accordance with the RECIST guideline (version 1.1). Combination therapy continued. After four doses of Nivolumab, the patient complained of obvious fever, with the highest temperature of 38 degree Celsius. The condition improved after two days, and the rest had no obvious discomfort. PET/CT scan was performed again after four more doses of Nivolumab. PET/CT examination suggested that PR (the sum of diameters of target lesions decreased by 50% compared with the last PET/CT results), tumor lesions and metabolism were significantly reduced, and the tumor activity was mostly inhibited, while a little tumor activity still left (Figure 3C). The treatment went on wheels according to the original plan. After four more courses of treatment, the patients were evaluated by PET/CT scan again. PET/CT reported that the metabolism of tumor was in a state of complete repression and no obvious tumor signs were observed (Figure 3D). The overall effect was almost complete response (CR).
During the treatment period, the overall patient's condition steadily improved without obvious side effects. The hemogram of outpatient reexamination revealed a temporary increase in the tumor markers in the early stage of immunotherapy, possibly due to the death and lysis of tumor cells, and a steady decline in the later stage (<PMC6757230_OTT-12-7691-g0004_A_1_2.webp><PMC6757230_OTT-12-7691-g0004_B_2_2.webp>). Moreover, the related immune indicators and immune cells in the peripheral blood changed greatly during immunotherapy. On the one hand, TNF-a and IL-6 remained at high levels during immunotherapy, and IL-2 kept a steady rise, while IL-10 showed an exponential decline (Figure 5A). On the other hand, CD3+T cell and CD8+T cell kept a slight decline, but were still at high levels; besides, the level of CD4+T cell consistently increased, which was the same as the rate of CD4+/CD8 (Figure 5B). These phenomena reflected enhancement of overall immune infiltration in tumours and inflammation of tumor microenvironment, which was the proof of the transition of "hot" tumor (Figure 5). Until now, the patient is undergoing systemic SOX chemotherapy and Nivolumab. He is still alive and in good condition for 11 months after the initial diagnosis, with PFS expected to be at least 11 months. The treatment is still going on.
image_captions: Pathologic findings of the gastroscopy biopsy. (A and B) The high-medium differentiated adenocarcinoma showed that some glands were well structured with obvious cell atypia; some glands were cribriform with cell atypia (hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification from left to right was x100, x200).

Pathologic findings of the gastroscopy biopsy. (A and B) The high-medium differentiated adenocarcinoma showed that some glands were well structured with obvious cell atypia; some glands were cribriform with cell atypia (hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification from left to right was x100, x200).
Pathologic findings of the gastroscopy biopsy. (C) Immunohistochemistry of HER2 demonstrated completely negative staining in tumor cells (immunohistochemistry, original magnification x200).

title: 28-year-old male presenting with headache and left-sided weakness, ultimately di
chief_complaint: 2-week history of headache and left-sided weakness.
history: This 28-year-old male had no previously known comorbidities. His past medical history was not significant for diabetes or any immunocompromised state.
exam_findings: General physical examination was unremarkable. Neurological examination revealed a GCS of 15, with the patient alert and oriented. Pupils were bilaterally equal and reactive, with no cranial nerve deficits. Motor and sensory systems were intact, showing normal bulk, tone, power of 5/5 in all limbs, and normal reflexes.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: MRI showed a large infiltrating heterogeneous mass involving the right parietal lobe, extending to the corpus callosum. DWI demonstrated homogenous diffusion restriction in the center of the lesion, indicating aggressive behavior.
diagnosis: Fungal abscess caused by Rhinocladiella mackenziei.
treatment: Neuronavigation-guided craniotomy and excision of the space-occupying lesion, followed by antifungal therapy and occupational physiotherapy.
key_learning_points: Fungal infections, even rare ones like Rhinocladiella mackenziei, can cause intracranial space-occupying lesions that mimic aggressive brain tumors like glioblastoma.
Advanced imaging sequences (e.g., DWI with homogenous diffusion restriction) and assessment of lesion behavior can help differentiate between fungal abscesses and neoplastic masses.
Definitive diagnosis of fungal CNS infections relies on histopathological examination of resected tissue and subsequent microbial culture.
description: 28-year-old male presenting with headache and left-sided weakness, ultimately diagnosed with a Rhinocladiella mackenziei fungal abscess after neurosurgical excision of a brain lesion initially suspected to be glioblastoma.
clinical_text:
A 28-year-old male presented to the neurosurgery clinic with complaints of headache and left-sided weakness for 2 weeks. He had no previously known comorbidities. His past medical history was not significant for diabetes or any immunocompromised state.
General physical examination was unremarkable. On neurological examination, Glasgow coma scale (GCS) score was 15. The patient was alert, awake, and oriented to time, place, and person. Pupils were bilaterally equal and reactive. No cranial nerve deficits were found. Motor examination revealed normal bulk and tone with power of 5/5 in upper and lower limbs bilaterally and the reflexes were normal. Sensory system was intact with no deficits.
The investigation done to arrive at a diagnosis included magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). The scan showed a large infiltrating heterogeneous mass involving the right parietal lobe. The mass was also seen to be extending to corpus callosum. Based on these features, a presumptive diagnosis of a neoplastic mass, most likely glioblastoma, was made. Images are shown in Figure 1.
On further reviewing of DWI, there was homogenous diffusion restriction in the center of lesion. In addition, its aggressive behavior as evident by conventional sequences confirmed it to be a fungal abscess as shown in Figure 2.
Subsequently, patient was planned for neuronavigation-guided craniotomy and excision of the space-occupying lesion. Intraoperatively, a firm-to-hard diffuse mass was noted in the right parietal lobe with mild-to-moderate vascularity. Postoperatively, patient recovered well and had no neurological deficits.
Microscopic examination of the resected lesion showed dense acute and chronic inflammation along with scattered granulomas and multinucleated giant cells. Rhinocladiella mackenziei was identified as the causative pathogen in the fungal culture as shown in <PMC6367948_SNI-10-13-g003_undivided_1_1.webp>.
Patient was started on antifungal therapy. The patient remained stable and afebrile. Occupational physiotherapy was done. Patient was discharged in a stable condition.
image_captions: Culture with arrows pointing toward the causative fungal pathogen, Rhinocladiella mackenziei.

title: A 40-year-old male presented with nephrotic syndrome and was diagnosed with Memb
chief_complaint: 40-year-old male presented with facial puffiness and edema of lower extremities of 7 months duration.
history: A 40-year-old male with no history of bony pain, oral ulcers, arthralgia, skin rashes, or any features suggestive of connective tissue disorder.
exam_findings: Patient had pitting edema of lower limbs with no pallor, icterus or skin rashes. Blood pressure was 110/70 mm Hg. Systemic examination was normal.
labs: Urine microscopic examination revealed 4 + proteinuria with no active sediments. Twenty-four hours urine protein was 6.9 g. Blood urea nitrogen was 25 and serum creatinine 2.06 mg/dl. Hemoglobin 138 g/L, total leucocyte count 11 x 10^9/L (normal differential), platelet count 3.4 lakhs/micro litre. Serum total protein 5.5 g/dl, albumin 2.5 g/dl. Liver function tests were normal. Negative for hepatitis B surface antigen, hepatitis C virus antibodies, HIV-I/II, antinuclear factor, rheumatoid factor, cryoglobulin, and antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies. Serum complement levels were normal (C3=110 mg/dl, C4=20 mg/dl). Serum total cholesterol 352 mg/dl, triglyceride 328 mg/dl. Urine and serum immunoelectrophoresis showed no monoclonal proteins. Serum kappa light chain 1088 mg/dl, lambda light chain 208 mg/dl, with a kappa/lambda ratio of 5.2. Bone marrow examination revealed 3% plasma cells. Post-treatment: proteinuria 3.1 g/day, serum creatinine 0.9 mg/dl, albumin 3.1 g/dl. Repeat serum free light assay revealed kappa 29 mg/dl and lambda 14 mg/dl (kappa/lambda ratio: 2.01).
imaging_description: Ultrasonography revealed normal sized kidneys. Skeletal survey did not reveal any abnormalities. Kidney biopsy light microscopy showed diffuse thickening of glomerular capillary walls with spikes on Jones silver stain. Immunofluorescence revealed granular polyclonal IgG, kappa light chain, and deposition of monoclonal IgG3 and C3 along glomerular capillary loops with intensity 3+.
diagnosis: Monoclonal gammopathy with Membranous Glomerulonephritis (MGN) and monoclonal IgG3-kappa deposition.
treatment: Patient was started on 6 monthly cycles of velcade-thalidomide-dexamethasone (VTD) regimen, consisting of bortezomib (1.3 mg/m2 on days 1, 4, 7, 11), thalidomide (200 mg/day), and dexamethasone (30 mg/kg on days 1-4 and 7-11 of month).
key_learning_points: Membranous Glomerulonephritis (MGN) can be secondary to monoclonal gammopathy, even in the absence of overt multiple myeloma.
Renal biopsy with detailed immunofluorescence is crucial for the diagnosis and classification of glomerulonephritis, especially when monoclonal immunoglobulin deposition is suspected.
Specific therapy targeting the underlying plasma cell dyscrasia, such as VTD regimen, can improve renal function and reduce proteinuria in monoclonal gammopathy-associated MGN.
description: A 40-year-old male presented with nephrotic syndrome and was diagnosed with Membranous Glomerulonephritis (MGN) due to monoclonal IgG3-kappa deposition from an underlying monoclonal gammopathy, successfully treated with VTD therapy.
clinical_text:
A 40-year-old male presented with facial puffiness and edema of lower extremities of 7 months duration. He had no history of bony pain, oral ulcers, arthralgia, skin rashes or any features suggestive of connective tissue disorder. On examination patient had pitting edema of lower limbs with no pallor, icterus or skin rashes. Blood pressure was 110/70 mm Hg. Systemic examination was normal. Urine microscopic examination revealed 4 + proteinuria with no active sediments. Twenty-four hours urine protein was 6.9 g. Renal function tests revealed blood urea nitrogen of 25 and serum creatinine of 2.06 mg/dl respectively. Patient had hemoglobin of 138 g/L, total leucocyte count of 11 x 109/L with normal differential counts and platelet count of 3.4 lakhs/micro litre. Serum total protein and albumin were 5.5 and 2.5 g/dl respectively. Liver function tests were normal. Patient's serum tested negative for hepatitis B surface antigen, antibodies for hepatitis C virus and human immunodeficiency virus-I/II. Antinuclear factor, rheumatoid factor, cryoglobulin and antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies were negative and serum complement levels were normal (C3 = 110 mg/dl and C4 = 20 mg/dl). Serum total cholesterol and triglyceride were 352 and 328 mg/dl. Ultrasonography revealed normal sized kidneys. With clinical diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome, ultrasound guided percutaneous kidney biopsy was performed.
Light microscopic examination showed eight glomeruli, all showed diffuse thickening of glomerular capillary walls with lifting up of podocytes. Jones silver stain revealed spikes [Figure 1]. No endocapillary or mesangial proliferative, tubulointerstitial and vascular alterations were noted. Immunofluorescence showed granular polyclonal IgG, kappa light chain and deposition of monoclonal IgG3 and C3 along glomerular capillary loops with intensity being 3 + on a scale of 0-3+ [Figure 2]. IgA, IgM, lambda light chain and complement (C1q) were negative. No deposition along tubular basement membranes was observed. Therefore, a diagnosis of MGN with monoclonal IgG3-kappa deposition was made on renal biopsy.
Urine and serum immunoelectrophoresis showed no monoclonal proteins. Serum kappa and lambda light chain concentrations were 1088 and 208 mg/dl respectively with kappa/lambda ratio of 5.2 (normal - 0.26-1.52). Skeletal survey did not reveal any abnormalities. Bone marrow examination revealed 3% plasma cells. With a diagnosis of monoclonal gammopathy with MGN, patient was started on treatment with 6 monthly cycles of velcade-thalidomide-dexamethasone (VTD) regimen (bortezomib - 1.3 mg/m2 on 1st, 4th, 7th and 11th days, thalidomide - 200 mg/day and dexamethasone - 30 mg/kg on 1st-4th and 7th-11th days of month). After 6 monthly cycles of VTD therapy, patient had reduction in proteinuria to 3.1 g/day with serum creatinine and albumin of 0.9 mg/dl and 3.1 g/dl respectively. Repeat serum free light assay revealed kappa and lambda light chain of 29 and 14 mg/dl respectively (kappa/lambda ratio: 2.01).

title: A man in his mid-70s with hypertension and smoking history presented with left l
chief_complaint: Gradually worsening numbness in his left leg for 2 weeks.
history: A man in his mid-70s with a history of 18 years of hypertension and 50 years of smoking.
exam_findings: Left foot appeared pale, dorsalis pedis pulse was not palpable, sensory loss in left toes, and no motor deficits were observed in the left foot.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: Preoperative computed tomography angiography (CTA) showed a left popliteal artery occlusion. Electrocardiography and echocardiography showed no major abnormalities. Further investigations identified no potential embolic sources such as thoracoabdominal aneurysms.
diagnosis: Acute limb ischemia (Rutherford category IIa) due to left popliteal artery occlusion.
treatment: Prompt revascularization.
key_learning_points: Acute limb ischemia often presents with symptoms like numbness, pallor, and absent pulses.
Risk factors such as hypertension and smoking are significant contributors to peripheral vascular disease.
Computed tomography angiography (CTA) is a critical diagnostic tool for identifying arterial occlusions.
Prompt revascularization is essential in managing acute limb ischemia to preserve limb viability.
description: A man in his mid-70s with hypertension and smoking history presented with left leg numbness and pallor, diagnosed with acute limb ischemia due to left popliteal artery occlusion, necessitating prompt revascularization.
clinical_text: A man in his mid-70s presented to the Emergency Department with gradually worsening numbness (Rutherford category IIa) in his left leg for 2 weeks. He had a history of 18 years of hypertension and 50 years of smoking. During a physical examination, the patient's left foot appeared pale and his dorsalis pedis pulse was not palpable. Although there was sensory loss in the left toes, no motor deficits were observed in the left foot. Preoperative computed tomography angiography (CTA) showed a left popliteal artery occlusion (Figure 1(a)). Cardiovascular assessments, including electrocardiography and echocardiography, showed no major abnormalities. Further investigations also identified no potential embolic sources, such as thoracoabdominal aneurysms. Based on the symptom onset within 2 weeks and the findings of the physical examination, there was a strong suspicion of acute limb ischemia, necessitating prompt revascularization.

title: 62-year-old woman with an unruptured PICA aneurysm develops central apnea and br
chief_complaint: Acute onset of vertigo after abrupt head turning.
history: A 62-year-old woman with no significant past medical history.
exam_findings: Postoperative examination revealed left eye ptosis and meiosis, subtle right gaze preference, and left-sided weakness and ataxia.
labs: Postoperatively during sleep, PaCO2 was 76 mmHg with acidosis; during wakefulness, PaCO2 was normal.
imaging_description: CT head and CTA head/neck revealed an unruptured 11.7-mm wide-necked left PICA aneurysm, confirmed by conventional cerebral angiography. Postoperative noncontrast MRI brain showed increased T1 signal in the left inferior cerebellum and medulla in the PICA distribution.
diagnosis: Unruptured 11.7-millimeter wide-necked left posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) aneurysm.
treatment: Surgical clipping of the left PICA aneurysm. Intraoperatively, the left vertebral artery was sacrificed due to profound bleeding. Postoperatively, managed with assisted ventilation and eventually continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP).
key_learning_points: Vertigo can be a presenting symptom of an unruptured PICA aneurysm.
Surgical intervention for posterior circulation aneurysms carries risks of brainstem injury, leading to deficits like central apnea and Horner's syndrome.
Brainstem lesions, particularly in the medulla, can impair central respiratory drive, necessitating ventilatory support, especially during sleep.
description: 62-year-old woman with an unruptured PICA aneurysm develops central apnea and brainstem deficits post-clipping after left vertebral artery sacrifice.
clinical_text:
A 62-year-old woman with no significant medical history experienced an acute onset of vertigo after abruptly turning her head to the left. The symptoms resolved within 24 hours. Computed tomography (CT) of the head and CT angiography of the head and neck revealed an unruptured 11.7-millimeter wide-necked left posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) aneurysm that was subsequently confirmed with conventional cerebral angiography. She was taken to the operating room where she subsequently had the aneurysm clipped. Intraoperatively, the patient developed profound bleeding due to loss of local hemostasis. As a result, the patient had an episode of pulseless electrical activity, followed by resuscitation and consequent sacrifice of the left vertebral artery.
Postoperatively, the patient remained intubated due to several episodes of prolonged apnea mainly during sleep, having often to be "reminded" to breathe. Initial physical examination was significant for left eye ptosis and meiosis, subtle right gaze preference, and left-sided weakness and ataxia. Noncontrast magnetic resonance imaging of the brain demonstrated increased T1 signal in the left inferior cerebellum and medulla in the PICA vascular distribution. It was noted that, during sleep when on the same ventilator settings as those during wakefulness, the patient became acidotic and was retaining carbon dioxide (CO2), with a partial pressure of CO2 (PaCO2) of 76 millimeters of mercury, while breathing only at the set rate and not initiating her own breaths. During wakefulness, the patient was able to maintain ventilation, evident by normal PaCO2. Over the course of stay in the intensive care unit, the patient was maintained on different modes of assisted ventilators and eventually continuous positive airway pressure. Consequently, the apneic episodes progressively became shorter until the patient recovered spontaneously before discharge to an acute rehabilitation facility.

title: A 35-day-old male infant presented with convulsions, fever, and congenital catar
chief_complaint: A 35-day-old male infant presented with convulsions, fever, and bilateral congenital cataracts.
history: A full-term 35-day-old male infant, born via spontaneous vaginal delivery, required oxygen therapy and resuscitation at birth, leading to NICU admission. His 33-year-old multigravida mother had no prenatal care or vaccinations and experienced skin rashes, headaches, and fever during early pregnancy. Parents are consanguineous with no inherited medical disorders, and the infant has been on phenobarbital since birth.
presenting_symptoms: Convulsions (clonic movement in right leg, facial twitching, abnormal body movements)
exam_findings: The infant appeared ill with generalized hypotonia and respiratory distress, but no signs of cyanosis. Vitals included HR 150 bpm, RR 60 bpm, T 37.6 OC, SPO2 94% in room air. Physical examination revealed pink conjunctiva, an anterior fontanel of 1.5x1.5 cm, bilateral cataractous lenses, involuntary rolling of the eyes, intercostal retractions with good air entry, a continuous machine-like murmur at the upper left sternal border, no abdominal distension or hepato-splenomegaly, and an imperfect Moro-reflex.
labs: Blood sugar 82 mg/dl. FBC showed WBCs 9x1000/mm3, HB 16.6 g/dl, and platelet count 181x1000/mm3 with no thrombocytopenia. Biochemical analysis revealed normal renal, liver, and thyroid functions, normal calcium, potassium, magnesium, and glucose levels, but a slight decrease in sodium (129 mmol/l) and albumin (2.7g/dl). CRP measured 29 mg/l. The rubella IgM antibody level was elevated at 50.2 AU/mL, while HSV, CMV, and toxoplasma serology were negative.
imaging_description: Chest X-ray showed cardiomegaly and mild bilateral lung infiltrates. An echocardiogram detected a low ejection fraction of 40% and a patent ductus arteriosus. A brain CT scan (non-contrast) revealed bilateral periventricular calcifications and hypodensity in the white and grey matter of both hemispheres with a loss of differentiation between them.
diagnosis: Suspected Congenital Rubella Syndrome, evidenced by elevated rubella IgM antibodies and a constellation of classic clinical and imaging findings including cataracts, patent ductus arteriosus, sensorineural hearing loss, and periventricular calcifications.
treatment: Empiric intravenous antibiotics (ampicillin and cefotaxim) were initiated. Enalapril and furosemide were given for low ejection fraction but discontinued upon improvement. Phenobarbital, prescribed since birth, was continued for convulsions. Referral to an upper level clinic for congenital cataract operation was recommended.
key_learning_points: Recognizing the classic triad of Congenital Rubella Syndrome (cataracts, congenital heart disease, sensorineural hearing loss) and other multisystemic manifestations.
Understanding the significance of maternal history of rash, fever, and lack of prenatal care in the diagnosis of congenital infections.
Interpreting serology (elevated IgM) and imaging findings (periventricular calcifications, PDA) in the context of TORCH infections in neonates.
description: A 35-day-old male infant presented with convulsions, fever, and congenital cataracts, ultimately diagnosed with suspected Congenital Rubella Syndrome based on elevated rubella IgM and multisystem findings.
clinical_text:
A full-term 35-day-old male infant was referred to us complaining of convulsions, fever, and bilateral congenital cataracts (Table 1).
Although not a high grade fever, the fever persisted and subsided after taking an antipyretic. In addition, he experiences episodes of clonic movement in his right leg, facial twitching, and abnormal body movements. Congenital cataracts and these complaints were since birth.
The baby was born by a 33 years old multigravida mother via a spontaneous vaginal delivery at a different hospital. The newborn was admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit after requiring oxygen therapy and resuscitation on delivery. On the thirty-fifth day, the patient was referred to us for an additional assessment and treatment.
No vaccinations or prenatal care were given to the mother during her pregnancy. The mother experienced skin rashes, headaches, and fever during the initial months of her pregnancy, but she did not seek medical attention at a hospital. She is the mother of three other healthy children. The mother's drug history was limited to analgesics. The baby's parents, who are consanguineous, had no record of inherited medical disorders. Upon examination, the baby appeared ill with generalized hypotonia, respiratory distress, and no signs of cyanosis.
The patient's vitals are: HR : 150 bpm, RR : 60 bpm, T : 37.6 OC, SPO2 : 94% in room air, blood sugar : 82 mg/dl, birth weight : 3.55 kg, height : 55 cm, and head circumference : 35.8 cm. The patient exhibited a pink conjunctiva, an anterior fontanel of 1.5x1.5 cm, bilateral cataractous lenses (Figure 1), and involuntary rolling of the eyes. His Chest or respiratory system: Intercostal retractions but has good air entry. Cardiovascular system: Continues machine like murmur at upper left sternal border. Abdomen: no abdominal distension and hepato-splenomegaly. Nervous system: baby was hypotonic but alert, had convulsions, and all of his reflexes were intact except the imperfect moro-reflex. According to the Investigations his full blood count (FBC) of the patient showed WBCs 9x1000/mm3, HB 16.6 g/dl and platelet count 181x1000/mm3, no thrombocytopenia was seen in all tests. The biochemical analysis revealed normal tests for the renal, liver, and thyroid functions, normal calcium, potassium, magnesium, and glucose levels but a slight decrease in sodium levels (129 mmol/l) and albumin (2.7g/dl). The C-reactive protein (CRP) measured 29 mg/l. The coagulation test results were unremarkable. The rubella IgM antibody level in the TORCH infections serology test was found to be elevated at 50.2 AU/mL (Table 1). The serology results were all negative for HSV, CMV, and toxoplasma. Unfortunately, we could not carry out PCR tests at our facility. The chest x-ray of the baby showed Cardiomegaly and mild bilateral lung infiltrates (<PMC11338173_IMCRJ-17-751-g0002_undivided_1_1.webp>). An echocardiogram detected a low ejection fraction of 40% and a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). The brain CT scan revealed periventricular calcifications (<PMC11338173_IMCRJ-17-751-g0003_undivided_1_1.webp>) that were properly symmetric on both sides. Additionally, there was hypodensity in the white and grey matter of both hemispheres, which was related to a loss of differentiation between them. There was no significant meningeal or parenchymal enhancement.   
The ophthalmoscope reveals bilateral congenital cataracts. There was also bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. Initially, we began empiric intravenous antibiotics (ampicillin and cefotaxim). For the low EF of the previous echocardiography, he was given an enalapril tab and furosemide; however, we stopped after the patient's ejection fraction (EF) improved. Since birth, he has been taking phenobarbital, which was prescribed at the time of discharge. The ophthalmology department suggested an upper level clinic for the operation of the congenital cataract.
After six days of clinical improvement and satisfactory oral intake, the patient was discharged home with surgical arrangements for treating congenital cataracts and Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).
image_captions: X-ray chest (posterior anterior view) showing cardiomegaly and bilateral lung infiltrates.
CT scan (non contrast) showing bilateral periventricular calcifications and hypodensity in the white and grey matter of both hemispheres, which was related to a loss of differentiation between them.

title: 37-year-old HIV-positive male with XDR-TB developed acute congestive heart failu
chief_complaint: Admitted to hospital after five months of treatment with acute congestive heart failure.
history: A 37-year-old HIV-positive male with XDR-TB, initiated on an individualized regimen of pyrazinamide, bedaquiline, delamanid, linezolid, clofazimine, and para-amino salicylic acid (PAS) in January 2017.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: Mild elevation in liver enzymes.
imaging_description: Not described in this case.
diagnosis: Acute congestive heart failure and QTcF-interval prolongation in an HIV-positive male with XDR-TB, likely due to treatment-related factors or CHF itself.
treatment: Initial individualized regimen included pyrazinamide-bedaquiline-delamanid-linezolid-clofazimine-PAS. Upon admission, bedaquiline, delamanid, pyrazinamide, and PAS were withheld. The patient received management for congestive heart failure. The MDR-TB regimen was modified to ethambutol-linezolid-clofazimine-delamanid for three months, after which bedaquiline was reintroduced. The patient completed 19 months of total treatment.
key_learning_points: Patients on complex XDR-TB regimens, especially those including bedaquiline and delamanid, require vigilant monitoring for QT interval prolongation and cardiac toxicity.
Congestive heart failure can independently cause QT interval prolongation, complicating the assessment of drug-induced cardiotoxicity.
Careful management and prompt regimen modification are critical when patients develop severe adverse drug reactions during treatment for extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis.
description: 37-year-old HIV-positive male with XDR-TB developed acute congestive heart failure and QT prolongation during treatment, leading to temporary drug withdrawal and regimen modification with successful cure.
clinical_text: The second patient is a 37-year-old HIV-positive male with XDR-TB. He was initiated on an individualized regimen of pyrazinamide (Z)-bedaquiline-delamanid-linezolid-clofazimine and para-amino salicylic acid (PAS) in January 2017. The baseline ECG was normal with QTcF-interval of 345 msec. He was admitted to hospital after five months of treatment with acute congestive heart failure (CHF). An ECG done on admission showed sinus rhythm with QTcF-interval of 488 msec. Bdq, Dlm, Z and PAS were all withheld because of the CHF, QTcF-interval prolongation, and mild elevation in liver enzymes on lab investigations. The patient responded well to CHF management and the QTcF-interval normalized within one week. The MDR-TB regimen was modified to ethambutol-linezolid-clofazimine-delamanid for the next three months after which bedaquiline was reintroduced. The patient took a Bdq and Dlm containing regimen for the next 11 consecutive months at which point he had completed 19 months of total duration of treatment and was discharged from treatment with an outcome of cure. As a result, the patient's QT-interval prolongation was likely to have resulted from the CHF, PAS or other factors.

title: Patient diagnosed with Lipoid congenital adrenal hyperplasia (LCAH) based on a d
chief_complaint: Genetic testing was performed due to concerns related to differences in sex development.
history: Not described in this case, other than the patient being a proband whose parents tested negative for the variant.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: Genetic testing included sequencing of exonic and flanking intronic regions for 69 genes associated with differences in sex development. Next-generation sequencing showed read depth of at least 20x. Results revealed a heterozygous novel variant in STAR at c.65-2A>C, confirmed by Sanger sequencing. Targeted variant testing was negative in both parents, confirming a de novo pathogenic variant in the proband.
imaging_description: Not described in this case.
diagnosis: Lipoid congenital adrenal hyperplasia (LCAH) confirmed by a de novo heterozygous novel variant in the STAR gene (c.65-2A>C).
treatment: Not described in this case.
key_learning_points: Understanding the role of genetic testing in diagnosing differences in sex development.
Interpretation of genetic variant nomenclature (e.g., c.65-2A>C) and concepts like 'de novo' and 'heterozygous'.
Recognition of Lipoid congenital adrenal hyperplasia (LCAH) as a genetic disorder linked to the STAR gene.
Familiarity with next-generation sequencing and Sanger sequencing for variant detection and confirmation.
description: Patient diagnosed with Lipoid congenital adrenal hyperplasia (LCAH) based on a de novo heterozygous novel variant in the STAR gene detected by genetic sequencing for differences in sex development.
clinical_text:
The patient underwent genetic testing at a commercial laboratory. The testing included sequencing of exonic regions and at least 10 bases of flanking intronic regions for 69 genes associated with differences in sex development. Initial sequencing and copy number variant detection was done using standard methods for next-generation (short read) sequencing. Read depth was at least 20x for all regions included on the panel. Potential pathogenic variants were confirmed using Sanger sequencing, also using standard methods.
Results revealed a heterozygous novel variant in STAR at c.65-2A>C, confirming a diagnosis of LCAH. Targeted variant testing was negative for the variant in both parents, confirming a de novo pathogenic variant in the proband. No other potential pathogenic variants were detected in genes associated with a difference of sex development.

title: A 22-year-old woman presented with progressive nasal conjunctival swelling in th
chief_complaint: Progressive nasal conjunctival swelling in the left eye of 2-years duration.
history: The patient had no history of systemic illness, ocular disease, or allergy. Family history was negative for any ocular and cranial vascular malformation.
presenting_symptoms: Progressive nasal conjunctival swelling in the left eye
exam_findings: Visual acuity was 20/20 in the right eye and 20/40 in the left eye. Intraocular pressures were 17 mmHg in both eyes. There was no relative afferent pupil defect or proptosis. Ocular motility was full, though the left eye was mildly displaced laterally. Anterior segment biomicroscopic examination of the left eye revealed a multicystic appearance of the plica semilunaris and inferonasal bulbar conjunctiva. A lesion similar to lymphatic malformation was noted on the patient's left hard palate.
labs: Thyroid function tests were within normal limits.
imaging_description: Anterior segment swept-source optical coherence tomography (AS-SSOCT) of the left eye showed elevation of the plica semilunaris and bulbar conjunctiva with variable-sized hyporeflective spaces separated by hyperreflective tissue. Orbital magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed an oval-shaped, intraconal mass located inferonasally in the left orbit, which was isointense on T1-weighted images, hyperintense on T2-weighted images, and demonstrated contrast enhancement. No vascular malformation was found affecting the brain and meninges.
diagnosis: Orbital vascular malformation (VM) and conjunctival lymphatic malformation (LM), confirmed by histopathology.
treatment: Subtotal excisional biopsy of the left conjunctival mass and complete removal of the orbital tumor via anterior orbitotomy using a cryoprobe.
key_learning_points: Progressive conjunctival swelling, especially if multicystic, should prompt investigation for underlying vascular or lymphatic malformations.
Orbital vascular malformations and conjunctival lymphatic malformations can coexist and require comprehensive imaging (e.g., AS-SSOCT, MRI) for diagnosis and surgical planning.
Histopathological examination is essential for the definitive diagnosis and differentiation of vascular malformation subtypes.
Surgical excision is a common and effective treatment for symptomatic orbital and conjunctival vascular/lymphatic malformations.
Successful surgical intervention can lead to improvement in visual acuity and resolution of ocular displacement.
description: A 22-year-old woman presented with progressive nasal conjunctival swelling in the left eye, diagnosed as coexisting orbital vascular malformation and conjunctival lymphatic malformation, successfully treated with surgical excision.
clinical_text:
A 22-year-old woman presented with progressive nasal conjunctival swelling in the left eye of 2-years duration. The patient had no history of systemic illness, ocular disease, or allergy. Thyroid function tests were within normal limits. Family history was negative for any ocular and cranial vascular malformation. Visual acuities at presentation were 20/20 in the right and 20/40 in the left eye. Intraocular pressures were 17 mmHg in both eyes. There was no relative afferent pupil defect bilaterally. Ocular motility was full, and there was no proptosis in either eye. The left eye was mildly displaced laterally although the patient did not complain of double vision (Figure 1(a)). Anterior segment biomicroscopic examination of the left eye revealed that the plica semilunaris and inferonasal bulbar conjunctiva had a multicystic appearance (Figure 1(b)). Anterior segment and fundus examination of the right eye were normal. There was a lesion similar to LM on the patient's left hard palate (Figure 1(c)). Anterior segment swept-source optical coherence tomography (AS-SSOCT) (DRI OCT Triton Plus, Topcon, Tokyo, Japan) showed there was elevation of the plica semilunaris and bulbar conjunctiva comprising variable-sized hyporeflective spaces separated by hyperreflective tissue in the left eye (Figure 2(a)). AS-SSOCT of the right eye revealed normal findings. The patient subsequently underwent orbital and brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) which revealed an oval-shaped, intraconal mass located inferonasally in the left orbit.The orbital mass was in the same quadrant as the conjunctival LM. The mass was isointense with respect to the extraocular muscles on T1-weighted images, hyperintense on T2-weighted images, and demonstrated contrast enhancement (Figures 2(b) and 2(c)). There was no vascular malformation affecting the brain and meninges.
Surgical intervention was planned to perform conjunctival biopsy and to remove the orbital tumor. Under general anesthesia, the patient first underwent subtotal excisional biopsy of the left conjunctival mass. Subsequently, an anterior orbitotomy was performed via the inferonasal transconjunctival approach and the orbital tumor was removed in toto with the help of a cryoprobe. The basal diameters of the excised reddish, smooth-edged, capsulated orbital mass were approximately 1.5 x 1.5 cm (Figure 3(a)). Histopathological examination of the orbital mass revealed enlarged vascular channels featuring thick walls with fibrosis, the lumens of which were filled with erythrocytes. The histopathological diagnosis of the orbital mass was established as VM (Figure 3(b)). Histopathological examination of the conjunctival lesion revealed a vascular structure containing lymphatic fluid surrounded by endothelium and conjunctival epithelial cells on the surface, consistent with LM (Figure 3(c)). At 3 months follow-up, visual acuity in the left eye improved to 20/30. The left eye was orthophoric and there was no proptosis. The conjunctiva looked devoid of any major lymphangioma cysts (Figure 4).

title: 87yo female with multiple comorbidities presented with altered mental status and
chief_complaint: Altered mental status and shortness of breath.
history: An 87-year-old female with a past medical history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, breast cancer (on letrozole), and diverticulosis.
exam_findings: Hypoxic with labored breathing.
labs: White blood cell count of 9.9 x 10^3/mcL, D-dimer of 2.23 mg/L, procalcitonin of 6.84 ng/mL.
imaging_description: Computed tomography of the chest showed diffuse bilateral patchy ground glass infiltrates.
diagnosis: COVID-19 positive and Streptococcus pneumoniae pneumonia.
treatment: Remdesivir and dexamethasone for COVID-19, ceftriaxone for Streptococcus pneumoniae. Required intubation, reintubation, tracheostomy, and feeding tube placement. Transferred to a rehabilitation facility.
key_learning_points: Elderly patients with multiple comorbidities are at high risk for severe COVID-19.
Bacterial superinfection, such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, can complicate severe viral pneumonia.
Prolonged respiratory failure may necessitate tracheostomy for mechanical ventilation weaning.
Altered mental status can be a presenting symptom of severe infection in the elderly.
description: 87yo female with multiple comorbidities presented with altered mental status and shortness of breath, diagnosed with severe COVID-19 and Streptococcus pneumoniae pneumonia, requiring prolonged critical care.
clinical_text: An 87-year-old female with a past medical history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, breast cancer (on letrozole), and diverticulosis was brought to the hospital with altered mental status and shortness of breath. In the emergency room, patient was hypoxic with labored breathing and was intubated. Her laboratory tests revealed white blood cell count of 9.9 x 103/mcL, D-dimer of 2.23 mg/L, and procalcitonin of 6.84 ng/mL. Computed tomography of the chest showed diffuse bilateral patchy ground glass infiltrates (see Figure 4). Patient was found to be COVID-19 positive, and her sputum cultures came back positive for Streptococcus pneumoniae. Patient was treated with remdesivir and dexamethasone for her COVID-19 infection. Patient was treated with ceftriaxone for her Streptococcus pneumonia. Patient was extubated 2 weeks later but went into respiratory failure requiring reintubation. Patient got a tracheostomy and feeding tube placement. She had a prolonged stay in the hospital for a month. She was weaned to tracheostomy collar and transferred to a rehabilitation facility.

title: 65yo male with subacute sensorimotor loss and bladder dysfunction due to combine
chief_complaint: A 65-year-old man presented with 1 day of sensorimotor loss in both legs and bladder dysfunction, preceded by 3 months of progressive weakness and numbness in his legs.
history: About 4 years prior, he was diagnosed with coronary atherosclerosis and unstable angina. He was on daily aspirin, atorvastatin, and isosorbide mononitrate to reduce thrombotic cardiac risk.
exam_findings: Neurological examination revealed hypoesthesia below the right L1 dermatome and sensation loss below left L1. Muscle strength was grade 0/0 between L1-L4 myotomes (left/right) and 1-2/0-1 between L5-S1.
labs: The laboratory tests were normal.
imaging_description: An MRI on May 2, 2019, showed an extradural protruding mass compressing the spinal cord dorsally at the T10-11 level, with intramedullary hypo-intense signals on T1WI and hyperintense signals on T2WI. A subsequent CT on May 6, 2019, revealed a calcified protruding mass not attached to the lamina. Post-operative CT on May 15, 2019, confirmed fenestration at the left T10-11 interlaminar space with complete removal of CLF. MR re-examination on December 26, 2019, showed complete expansion of the dura sac, though intramedullary hyperintensity on sagittal T2WI was still present.
diagnosis: Combined Calcified Ligamentum Flavum (CLF) and Subacute Spontaneous Epidural Hematoma (SSEH) compressing the spinal cord at T10-11.
treatment: Aspirin was replaced by low molecular weight heparin (3,000 iu subcutaneously daily). A single intravenous dose of 0.5g methylprednisolone succinic acid was administered. A decompression operation was performed 7 days later, involving bilateral decompression through a unilateral approach (PPES technique) using a high-speed diamond burr to remove portions of the lamina and articular process, followed by removal of bilateral CLF and evacuation of SSEH. Post-operatively, low molecular weight heparin was continued for 13 days; aspirin was not restored, but atorvastatin and isosorbide mononitrate were maintained.
key_learning_points: The importance of considering multiple etiologies, such as CLF and SSEH, for spinal cord compression, especially when imaging findings may overlap.
Careful management of antiplatelet therapy in patients with cardiac history requiring urgent spinal decompression surgery due to bleeding risk.
The utility of advanced surgical techniques and intraoperative findings for confirming diagnosis and achieving effective decompression in complex spinal pathologies.
description: 65yo male with subacute sensorimotor loss and bladder dysfunction due to combined T10-11 calcified ligamentum flavum and spontaneous epidural hematoma.
clinical_text:
A 65-year-old man visited our hospital on 6 May 2019 complaining of sensorimotor loss in two legs and bladder dysfunction for 1 day after experiencing progressive weakness and numbness in two legs for 3 months. About 4 years ago, he was diagnosed with coronary atherosclerosis and unstable angina and has taken aspirin, atorvastatin, and isosorbide mononitrate daily since to reduce thrombotic cardiac risk prophylactically.
A neurological examination found hypoesthesia below the right L1 dermatome and sensation loss below left L1. Muscle strength of left/right was grade 0/0 between L1 and L4 myotomes, 1-2/0-1 between L5 and S1. The laboratory tests were normal.
MR examination on 2 May 2019 detected extradural protruding mass compressing the spinal cord dorsally at the T10-11 level with intramedullary hypo-intense signals on T1-weighted images (T1WI) and hyperintense signals on T2-weighted images (T2WI) (Figure 1). The suspected diagnosis included ossification of LF (OLF), CLF, or subacute SSEH with incomplete paraplegia.
Subsequent computed tomography (CT) taken on 6 May 2019 found the calcified protruding mass did not attach to the lamina (Figure 1). CLF was diagnosed with the exclusion of SSEH or OLF.
Administration of aspirin was replaced by low molecular weight heparin 3,000 iu injected subcutaneously per day. An intravenous drip of 0.5 g of methylprednisolone succinic acid (MP) for a single time produced temporary neurological improvement.
The decompression operation was postponed and performed 7 days later, on May 13, fearing intraoperative bleeding from aspirin administration above. Bilateral decompression through a unilateral approach was performed using the PPES technique under local lidocaine anesthesia with conscious sedation. A high-speed flexible diamond burr (Chongqing Xishan Technology Co., Ltd., Chongqing, China) was used to remove the inferior portion of the left lamina, the base of the spinous process, and the medial aspect of the ipsilateral inferior articular process (IAP) from T10. Then, the posterior layer of LF with its normal white-yellow color was dissected. The deeper LF layer exhibited purple-red color indicating necrotic tissue appeared, meanwhile some dark-red blood clots squeezed out through the opened window of the deeper LF layer with intermittent stale blood fluid draining out. It confirmed intraoperatively that the spinal cord was compressed by SSEH deeply and CLF superficially together. Following removal of bilateral CLF and evacuation of SSEH, the dural sac expanded to its normal elliptical contour and free mobility of the dural sac was visualized endoscopically (Figure 2). No drainage tube was left as there was no obvious bleeding at the end of decompression.
Neurological function recovered quickly. CT re-examination on 15 May 2019 confirmed fenestration at left T10-11 interlaminar space with complete removal of CLF (Figure 3). After 1 week, the patient could walk a 10-m distance. Low molecular weight heparin doses of 3,000 iu injected subcutaneously per day were continued for another 13 days (about 2 weeks) until the discharge day. Aspirin was not restored in fear of SSEH recurrence after consultation of a cardiovascular specialist, left atorvastatin, and isosorbide mononitrate maintained. After 3 months, the patient gained complete recovery (Figure 4). MR re-examination on 26 December 2019 found complete expansion of the dura sac, while intramedullary hyperintensity on sagittal T2-weighted MR imaging sequences could still be detected (Figure 3E). A telephone follow-up on 26 November 2022 revealed normal neurological function without a cardiovascular event since.

title: 21yo male presenting with sudden chest and neck pain, diagnosed with spontaneous
chief_complaint: Sudden onset of chest and neck pain.
history: A 21-year-old male with a history of mild childhood asthma presented after self-administering salbutamol for perceived asthma, which had no effect. He denied trauma or infective symptoms, and had no cardiovascular risk factors or other past medical conditions, though he had engaged in weightlifting two days prior. He admitted to inhaling a small amount of cocaine and ingesting two ecstasy pills (MDMA) approximately 20 hours before symptom onset.
exam_findings: No signs of airway compromise, subcutaneous emphysema evident in bilateral subclavian regions, tachycardia, hyperthermia, and hyperreflexia.
labs: Mildly raised creatine kinase (CK) of 231 and leukocytes count of 14.
imaging_description: Chest X-ray showed significant pneumomediastinum and subcutaneous emphysema. Subsequent computed tomography (CT) showed retropharyngeal emphysema extending from the aortic arch to the base of the skull. There was no evidence of pneumothorax or pneumorrhachis. A gastrografin swallow study showed no contrast extravasation.
diagnosis: Spontaneous pneumomediastinum and subcutaneous emphysema, likely secondary to illicit drug use and strenuous activity.
treatment: Admitted to hospital for monitoring and conservative management. Discharged on day 3 after follow-up X-ray showed resolving pneumomediastinum and subcutaneous emphysema.
key_learning_points: Recognize spontaneous pneumomediastinum as a cause of acute chest and neck pain.
Understand that illicit drug use and strenuous activity (e.g., Valsalva maneuvers) are risk factors for spontaneous pneumomediastinum.
Appreciate that conservative management is often sufficient for uncomplicated spontaneous pneumomediastinum.
Consider substance use in patients presenting with acute symptoms, especially when initial treatments are ineffective.
description: 21yo male presenting with sudden chest and neck pain, diagnosed with spontaneous pneumomediastinum and subcutaneous emphysema following illicit drug use and weightlifting.
clinical_text:
A 21-year-old male with a background of mild childhood asthma presented to ED with sudden onset of chest and neck pain. He had self-administered salbutamol believing he was having an asthma attack, to no effect. The patient denied any trauma or infective symptoms and had no cardiovascular risk factors or past medical conditions. He had been to the gym two days prior where he partook in his usual weightlifting routine and had not engaged in any unusually strenuous activities. However, he did admit to inhaling a small amount of cocaine and ingesting two ecstasy pills (3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine, MDMA) approximately 20 hours prior to the onset of symptoms while out dancing with friends.
On examination, there were no signs of airway compromise, and subcutaneous emphysema was evident in bilateral subclavian regions. Tachycardia, hyperthermia, and hyperreflexia were present. Nasendoscopy showed normal anatomy and airway. Blood tests revealed a mildly raised creatine kinase (CK) of 231 and leukocytes count of 14. Chest X-ray showed significant pneumomediastinum and subcutaneous emphysema (Figure 1) with subsequent computed tomography (CT) showing retropharyngeal emphysema extending from the aortic arch to the base of skull (Figures 2 and 3). There was no evidence of pneumothorax or pneumorrhachis. A gastrografin swallow study showed no contrast extravasation.
He was admitted to hospital for monitoring and conservative management. Follow-up X-ray on day 3 of admission showed resolving pneumomediastinum and subcutaneous emphysema, and he was discharged that same day.

title: 39-year-old man with 6-month history of dyspnea ultimately diagnosed with metast
chief_complaint: 6-month history of dyspnea prior to hospital admission.
history: His past medical and family histories were unremarkable. No other relevant history, medications, or allergies were mentioned.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: Pleural effusion aspiration was bloody and confirmed to be an exudate.
imaging_description: Chest computed tomography (CT) revealed multiple diffuse pulmonary nodules and bilateral pleural effusion. Abdominal contrast CT revealed a 3 cm right renal mass.
diagnosis: Metastatic clear cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC) with pulmonary and pleural involvement.
treatment: Partial nephrectomy was performed to remove the right renal mass.
key_learning_points: Metastatic cancer can present with non-specific symptoms like dyspnea and an occult primary tumor, necessitating a comprehensive diagnostic approach.
Immunohistochemistry is a critical tool in pathology for identifying the tissue origin of metastatic tumors, guiding further diagnostic imaging to locate the primary site.
Pleural effusion, especially if bloody and exudative, can be a sign of malignancy, and pulmonary nodules warrant investigation for primary or metastatic causes.
description: 39-year-old man with 6-month history of dyspnea ultimately diagnosed with metastatic clear cell renal cell carcinoma presenting with pulmonary nodules and bilateral pleural effusion.
clinical_text:
A 39-year-old man presented with episodes of dyspnea 6 months prior to hospital admission. His past medical and family histories were unremarkable.
Chest computed tomography (CT) revealed multiple pulmonary nodules in a diffuse pattern, accompanied by bilateral pleural effusion. The aspiration of the pleural effusion was bloody, and analysis of the fluid confirmed that it was an exudate.
A consulting pulmonologist suggested pleural biopsy. On gross examination, the specimen consisted of 4 ir- regular pieces of cream-gray, soft and rubbery tissue measuring 1.5x1x0.3 cm together.
On microscopic examination, sections from the pleural biopsy showed portions of neoplastic tissue, as well as fragments of fibrous connective tissue with mesothelium lining infiltrated by a neoplasm. The mentioned neo- plasm was composed of large cells with round to oval nuclei and a moderate amount of clear cytoplasm. Mild nuclear pleomorphism and intercellular capillary-sized vessels were two noteworthy findings (Figure.1).
An immunohistochemistry study revealed the following results: tumor cells were strongly positive for CD10, Carbonic anhydrase IX, EMA, Pan CK and showed negative results for CK7, CK20, NapsinA, TTF1, Calretinin, WT1, CDX2, Inhibin and PSA (Figure.2).Based on histomorphologic findings and immunohistochemi- cal results, the tumor was diagnosed to be compatible with metastatic RCC, of the clear cell type. However we advised clinical/imaging correlation for the patient. Therefore, abdominal contrast computed tomography (CT) was performed, and showed a 3 cm right renal mass. Partial nephrectomy to remove the mass was performed. As suspected, the mass was of a clear cell RCC (Figure.3).

title: A 72-year-old woman developed severe chemotherapy-induced hand-foot syndrome and
chief_complaint: Three months after starting chemotherapy, the patient presented with palmoplantar redness, pain, onycholysis, a transparent serous exudate, and onychomadesis.
history: A 72-year-old woman with a history of hypertension for 3 years and coronary artery stenting in 2012 was diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast in April 2015, for which she underwent a modified radical mastectomy followed by chemotherapy with oral capecitabine and intravenous nab-paclitaxel. She denied being diabetic and reported taking aspirin and lovastatin.
exam_findings: Examination revealed toenail changes including subungual hyperkeratosis, onycholysis, onychomadesis, and a transparent serous exudate emanating from all nail beds. Her hands had desquamation and redness, and fingernail changes included dark pigmentations, Beau's lines, and subungual hyperkeratosis. Dorsalis pedis pulse was normal.
labs: A fungal microscopic exam was negative.
imaging_description: Not described in this case.
diagnosis: Severe chemotherapy-induced hand-foot syndrome (palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia) and onychotoxicity secondary to capecitabine and nab-paclitaxel.
treatment: Chemotherapy was discontinued. The patient was treated with oral vitamin B6, a polymyxin ointment, and high-energy red light therapy.
