key_learning_points: Recognition of severe dermatologic and nail toxicities, such as Hand-Foot Syndrome (palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia) and onychotoxicity, as common side effects of certain chemotherapeutic agents like capecitabine and nab-paclitaxel.
Understanding the diverse clinical manifestations of chemotherapy-induced onychotoxicity, including onycholysis, onychomadesis, subungual hyperkeratosis, dark pigmentations, and Beau's lines.

Importance of prompt identification and management of severe chemotherapy-induced toxicities, which may include discontinuation of the causative agent and supportive care with vitamin B6, topical treatments, and phototherapy.
description: A 72-year-old woman developed severe chemotherapy-induced hand-foot syndrome and onychotoxicity requiring treatment discontinuation during adjuvant therapy for breast cancer.
clinical_text:
A 72-year-old woman who was diagnosed with an invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast underwent a modified radical mastectomy in April 2015, followed by chemotherapy with 1,500 mg of oral capecitabine (Xeloda Roche, Shanghai, People's Republic of China) twice daily for 2 weeks at 3-week intervals and 300 mg of intravenous nab-paclitaxel every 3 weeks. The patient noticed dysesthesia and desquamation of her hands and feet, and thinning toenails after 1 month of chemotherapy. Three months later (1 week after the fourth round of chemotherapy), she visited our department while exhibiting palmoplantar redness, pain, onycholysis, a transparent serous exudate, and onychomadesis.
Examination of the patient revealed toenail changes including subungual hyperkeratosis, onycholysis, onychomadesis, and a transparent serous exudate emanating from all the nail beds (<PMC5565258_dddt-11-2373Fig1_A_1_2.webp><PMC5565258_dddt-11-2373Fig1_B_2_2.webp>). Her hands had desquamation and redness, and fingernail changes included dark pigmentations, Beau's lines, and subungual hyperkeratosis (<PMC5565258_dddt-11-2373Fig2_A_2_2.webp><PMC5565258_dddt-11-2373Fig2_B_1_2.webp>). The patient also complained of significant pain in the heels of her feet. In addition, numbness and dysesthesia of the hands and feet were noticed. Her dorsalis pedis pulse was normal, and a fungal microscopic exam was negative. The patient suffered from hypertension for 3 years, and she underwent coronary artery stenting in 2012. She was not diabetic, and she denied taking any drugs except aspirin and lovastatin.
The chemotherapy was discontinued. The patient was treated with oral vitamin B6 (Beijing Double Crane Pharmaceutical Company Limited, Beijing, People's Republic of China), a polymyxin ointment (Zhejiang Rishengchang Pharmaceutical Company Limited, Dongyang, People's Republic of China), and high-energy red light (126 J/cm2 at a wavelength of 633 nm for 20 min every day). The exudation in the nail bed disappeared after 6 days. The palmoplantar redness and pain were alleviated after 1 month. The dysesthesia symptoms remained, and all the toenails exhibited defects or deformities (Figure 3); however, her hands returned to normal and her fingernails improved at a 24-month follow-up (Figure 4).

title: 27-year-old woman with vertigo and vomiting, diagnosed with desmoplastic nodular
chief_complaint: A 27-year-old woman presented with a history of vertigo, malaise, and frequent vomiting.
history: The patient experienced vertigo, malaise, and frequent vomiting prior to presentation. No other past medical history, medications, allergies, or social/family history are described in this case report excerpt.
exam_findings: Neurological examination revealed abnormal cerebellar function tests.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: MRI axial and coronal T2 views revealed a solid mass in the posterior fossa, a left hemispheric lesion, and mild hydrocephalus.
diagnosis: Desmoplastic nodular medulloblastoma
treatment: Not described in this case.
key_learning_points: Posterior fossa masses can present with symptoms such as vertigo, vomiting, and cerebellar dysfunction.
MRI is critical for localizing and characterizing intracranial lesions and identifying associated conditions like hydrocephalus.
Histopathological examination is essential for the definitive diagnosis and subtyping of brain tumors, exemplified by desmoplastic nodular medulloblastoma.
description: 27-year-old woman with vertigo and vomiting, diagnosed with desmoplastic nodular medulloblastoma after MRI and histopathology.
clinical_text: A 27-year-old woman presented with a history of vertigo, malaise and frequent vomiting. On neurological examination, cerebellar function tests were abnormal. MRI investigations picked a solid mass in the posterior fossa and the left hemispheric lesion and mild hydrocephalus [<PMC4038867_AJNS-9-45-g003_a_1_3.webp><PMC4038867_AJNS-9-45-g003_b_2_3.webp>]. Histopathologic examination showed proliferation of large cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and scant cytoplasm, as well as nodular foci of tumor in less cellular areas, which is indicative of desmoplastic nodular medulloblastoma [<PMC4038867_AJNS-9-45-g003_c_3_3.webp>].
image_captions: Magnetic resonance imaging axial view T2.
Coronal view T2.
Histopathology showed hypocellular areas with nodular fashion (Pale islands).

title: A 35-year-old man presented with increasing abdominal discomfort and was diagnos
chief_complaint: Increasing abdominal discomfort.
history: A 35-year-old man presented from prison. No other significant medical history, medications, or allergies were reported.
exam_findings: Blood pressure 125/85 mmHg, heart rate 78/min, temperature 37 C. General physical examination was normal, external genitalia appeared normal. Rectal examination showed normal anal sphincter tone and a slightly enlarged prostate.
labs: PSA levels were normal. Hormonal profile, blood tests, and urinalysis were all within normal range.
imaging_description: Abdominal ultrasound revealed a right cystic prominence in the urinary bladder with a unique left urinary jet and a hypertrophied left kidney. 3D CT showed a defect in the urinary bladder due to a right seminal vesicle cystoma and a hypertrophied left kidney. Axial and Coronal IV contrast CT noted filling of the urinary bladder with contrast media and compression from a right seminal vesicle cystoma. MRI confirmed a well-differentiated right seminal vesicle cystoma separate from the urinary bladder and a hypertrophied left kidney.
diagnosis: Zinner syndrome
treatment: Surgical treatment was suggested along with close follow-up.
key_learning_points: Zinner syndrome is a rare congenital anomaly characterized by a triad of ipsilateral renal agenesis, seminal vesicle cyst, and ejaculatory duct obstruction.
Comprehensive imaging (ultrasound, CT, MRI) is essential for diagnosing Zinner syndrome and delineating the anatomy.
The presence of a seminal vesicle cyst and a hypertrophied contralateral kidney should raise suspicion for Zinner syndrome.
Surgical intervention is a common treatment approach for symptomatic Zinner syndrome.
description: A 35-year-old man presented with increasing abdominal discomfort and was diagnosed with Zinner syndrome based on comprehensive imaging findings.
clinical_text:
A 35-year-old man is brought from prison to the clinic with complaints of increasing abdominal discomfort. Blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg, heart rate 78/min, and temperature 37 C. Physical examination was normal. The external genitalia appear normal. There is no dysuria or hematuria. Rectal examination shows normal anal sphincter tone but a slightly enlarged prostate. PSA levels were normal. Hormonal profile and blood tests showed insignificant changes. Urinalysis was within normal range.
An abdominal ultrasound was ordered and a right cystic prominence in the urinary bladder with unique left urinary jet is revealed. Furthermore, a hypertrophied left kidney is noted.
Considering the ultrasound findings, Zinner syndrome was suspected. Further imaging examinations were ordered (Fig. 1).
3D CT: defect in the urinary bladder due to a right seminal vesicle cystoma and hypertrophied left kidney
Axial CT: notes filling of the urinary bladder with contrast media and compression from a right seminal vesicle cystoma
IV contrast CT in different modes revealed:
Coronal CT: notes filling of the urinary bladder with contrast media and compression from a right seminal vesicle cystoma.
The MRI findings confirmed well differentiated right seminal vesicle cystoma from the urinary bladder and a hypertrophied left kidney.
Considering the imaging results, a diagnosis of Zinner syndrome was made. Surgical treatment was suggested to the patient along with close follow-up.

title: 66-year-old man with pancreatic adenocarcinoma presenting with paraneoplastic my
chief_complaint: Acute worsening of weakness resulting in inability to walk up stairs, accompanied by severe bilateral thigh pain.
history: A 66-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia, was taking lisinopril, metformin, and atorvastatin. He is a retired teacher, lives with a roommate, consumes 3-10 alcoholic beverages weekly, and quit smoking 20 years prior after a one-half pack per day habit. His father had rheumatoid arthritis.
exam_findings: Vital signs were normal. Physical exam revealed a jaundiced appearance and three-fifths strength to hip flexion and extension bilaterally. The remainder of the exam was unremarkable.
labs: WBC 11.9 k/mm3, total bilirubin 24.6 mg/dL, direct bilirubin 13.0 mg/dL, ALT 1053 U/L, AST 2994 IU/L, alkaline phosphatase 2893 IU/L. CK was elevated to 38,000 U/L, later plateauing at 75,000 U/L. Lipase, creatinine, and GFR were within normal limits. Urine was tea-coloured, with urinalysis values unable to be assessed due to interfering color. Carbohydrate 19-9 antigens were 8,782 U/mL.
imaging_description: Abdominal CT scan showed a 3 cm obstructing pancreatic head mass with diffuse pancreatic, biliary, and gallbladder dilatation. MRI lumbar spine revealed diffuse edema within the paraspinal and bilateral psoas musculature with associated patchy enhancement, representing sequela of myositis, with no metastatic spinal cord compression.
diagnosis: Pancreatic adenocarcinoma (confirmed by duodenal biopsy) presenting with paraneoplastic myositis.
treatment: Statin held, aggressive fluid resuscitation, prednisone 80 mg/day, and chemotherapy (initially fluorouracil, oxaliplatin, and leucovorin, then gemcitabine and abraxane).
key_learning_points: Pancreatic adenocarcinoma can present with paraneoplastic syndromes, such as severe myositis, leading to profound weakness and elevated CK.
Jaundice, significantly elevated liver enzymes, and markedly high CA 19-9 are strong indicators of hepatobiliary obstruction and pancreatic cancer.
Severe rhabdomyolysis or myositis can cause tea-colored urine and requires aggressive fluid resuscitation to prevent renal complications, even if creatinine remains normal initially.
Paraneoplastic myositis may respond to corticosteroid therapy, even in the setting of advanced malignancy.
description: 66-year-old man with pancreatic adenocarcinoma presenting with paraneoplastic myositis, severe weakness, jaundice, and extremely elevated CK.
clinical_text:
A 66-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia, presented with severe, bilateral thigh pain. On further history, he reported 6 weeks of generalized fatigue, 4 weeks of progressively worsening weakness and loose stools in the setting of an 18-kg weight loss over the preceding 3 months. The patient had delayed seeking medical attention due to fear of contracting COVID-19 but ultimately presented after an acute worsening of his weakness, resulting in an inability to walk up the stairs in his home. His prior to admission medications included lisinopril, metformin, and atorvastatin, which he had been taking for several years. The patient was a retired teacher and lived with a roommate. He consumed 3-10 alcoholic beverages a week and had quit tobacco smoking 20 years prior. Previously, he had smoked one-half pack per day. His family history was notable for rheumatoid arthritis in his father.
On exam, the patient's vital signs were normal and physical exams revealed a jaundiced appearance and three-fifths strength to hip flexion and extension bilaterally. The remainder of the exam was unremarkable. On initial laboratory assessment, white blood cell count was 11.9 k/mm3 (normal 4-10), total bilirubin 24.6 mg/dL (normal 0.1-1.2), direct bilirubin 13.0 mg/dL (normal 0.1-0.3 mg/dL), ALT 1053 U/L (normal <41), AST 2994 IU/L (normal 5-40), alkaline phosphatase 2893 IU/L (normal 40-129). Lipase, creatinine, and GFR were within normal limits. CK was elevated to 38,000 U/L (normal 39-308). The patient's urine sample was tea-coloured on gross inspection. Urinalysis was performed although of limited utility as the pH, leukocyte esterase, nitrites, protein, glucose, ketone, bilirubin, and blood values were unable to be assessed due to interfering color. Regarding WBC and RBC counts, both returned at 0-2 (normal <2).
Given the elevation in CK, the patient's statin was held, and he was started on aggressive fluid resuscitation. An abdominal CT scan showed a 3 cm obstructing pancreatic head mass with diffuse pancreatic, biliary, and gallbladder dilatation. Carbohydrate 19-9 antigens returned elevated at 8,782 U/mL (reference range 0-37 u/mL). Duodenal biopsy confirmed pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Given his significant bilateral lower extremity weakness, MRI lumbar spine was done to rule out metastasis. MRI revealed diffuse edema within the paraspinal and bilateral psoas musculature with associated patchy enhancement that was thought to represent sequela of myositis. No metastatic spinal cord compression was appreciated.
Despite early initiation of aggressive fluid resuscitation, the patient's CK continued to rise. Given concern for inflammatory myositis, on hospital day 5 the patient was initiated on prednisone 80 mg/day. On hospital day 6, following initiation of steroids, his CK value plateaued at 75,000 U/L and began declining. Creatinine and GFR remained within normal limits despite elevated CK. On hospital day 12, the patient was seen by oncology and began chemotherapy with fluorouracil, oxaliplatin, and leucovorin in hopes of relieving his lower extremity weakness. He remained on prednisone therapy and his CK normalized on hospital day 14. His urine appearance improved from tea-coloured to clear yellow. The patient's hip weakness was still present objectively, but subjectively he felt increased strength. He was discharged in stable condition to a skilled nursing facility and, after 3 weeks, was able to ambulate with a walker and returned home. He continued outpatient palliative chemotherapy with five total cycles of fluorouracil, oxaliplatin, and leucovorin and then one cycle of gemcitabine and abraxane. He died about 1 month later.

title: A 4-month-old girl presented with severe hypercalcemia and nephrocalcinosis seco
chief_complaint: A 4-month-old girl presented with over a month of lethargy, decreased feeding, and constipation.
history: The patient had been receiving an excessive dose of an over-the-counter vitamin D supplement (5000 IU three times daily) for one month, instead of the intended 400 IU once daily. This medication error resulted from miscommunication with the pharmacist, despite parents being highly educated with excellent socioeconomic status.
exam_findings: Signs of moderate dehydration (dry skin, poor skin turgor, decreased urine output); initial vital signs were within normal limits (HR 122 bpm, RR 38 rpm, BP 90/60 mmHg).
labs: Corrected calcium level 5.60 mmol/L (normal 2.25-2.75) on admission, decreasing to 2.96 mmol/L at discharge. Serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D 350 nmol/L (critical >250 nmol/L). Serum creatinine 32 umol/L (normal 11-34 umol/L) and urea 5.9 mmol/L (normal 1.8-6.4 mmol/L) were normal. Urine calcium/creatinine ratio 6.17 (normal 0.08-0.57).
imaging_description: Abdominal ultrasound showed evidence of nephrocalcinosis.
diagnosis: Vitamin D intoxication with severe hypercalcemia and nephrocalcinosis.
treatment: Intravenous fluids (normal saline and dextrose), IV furosemide (initially, then replaced by thiazide), IV methylprednisolone, low calcium formula milk, oral potassium citrate, and bisphosphonate therapy (two doses). Follow-up with an endocrinologist and nephrologist was recommended, and the patient was discharged with low calcium milk and potassium citrate.
key_learning_points: Excessive vitamin D supplementation, often due to medication errors, can cause severe hypercalcemia and organ damage like nephrocalcinosis in infants.

The management of severe hypercalcemia from vitamin D intoxication requires a comprehensive approach including aggressive hydration, diuresis, corticosteroids, bisphosphonates, and dietary modifications.
Clear communication regarding medication dosages is paramount to prevent adverse drug events, even among highly educated individuals.
description: A 4-month-old girl presented with severe hypercalcemia and nephrocalcinosis secondary to vitamin D intoxication from an accidental overdose.
clinical_text:
A 4-month-old girl was brought to the emergency department with a history of lethargy, decreased feeding, and constipation for more than a month. On examination, the patient exhibited signs of moderate dehydration such as dry skin, poor skin turgor, and decreased urine output although initial vital signs were within normal limit (heart rate was 122 beats per minute, respiratory rate was 38 respiration per minute, and blood pressure was 90/60 mmHg). Routine investigations performed in the emergency department identified a high corrected calcium level (5.60 mmol/L; normal range: 2.25-2.75). Upon further questioning of the parents, it became apparent that the girl had been receiving an excessive dose of vitamin D supplementation. The patient had been receiving a full 1 mL dropper of an over-the-counter vitamin D supplement (1 mL dose equal to 5000 IU) three times a day on a daily basis, for a one-month period, instead of the intended dose of three drops once per day (three drops dose equals to 400 IU). Parents are highly educated with excellent socioeconomic status; however, miscommunication with the pharmacist regarding the dosage led to this mistake. This unfortunate event led the patient to present with vitamin D intoxication, with the blood test for vitamin 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25(OH)D) levels showing a level of 350 nmol/L (critical level: >250 nmol/L).
The infant was admitted to a general pediatric ward for further management of calcium and vitamin D levels. She was put on intravenous (IV) fluids containing normal saline and dextrose at rate of 28 ml/hour, which equals to 150 ml/kg/day. She also received 1 mg/kg furosemide IV divided into three doses per day along with the 3-day IV course of 0.3 mg/kg methylprednisolone once daily. Furthermore, the patient was fed with low calcium formula milk (Nutricia  Kindergen).
As part of the routine assessment of hypercalcemia and vitamin D toxicity, various laboratory and radiological investigations were performed to assess the extent of the toxicity on the patient's renal system. Both serum creatinine and urea were normal upon admission, 32 umol/L (normal range: 11-34 umol/L) and 5.9 mmol/L (normal range: 1.8-6.4 mmol/L), respectively. Urine analysis was performed as well and showed no abnormal parameters. However, urine calcium (mmol/L) to urine creatinine (mmol/L) ratio was significantly abnormal (6.17; normal range: 0.08-0.57). Additionally, an abdominal ultrasound was performed, showing evidence of nephrocalcinosis (Figure 1).
Furosemide (1 mg/kg/dose three times per day) was replaced with thiazide (1 mg/kg/dose twice per day) on day 3 of admission, and potassium citrate (1 mmol dose three times per day) was administered to reduce the risk of exacerbating the existing nephrocalcinosis.
The rate of reduction of the corrected calcium level was unsatisfactory, as on day 4 of admission, the level remained high at 4.17 mmol/L. At this point, bisphosphonate therapy was initiated, with two doses given (first dose of 0.5 mg/kg and second dose of 1 mg/kg).
On day 9 of admission, the corrected calcium level was 3.44 mmol/L, and the clinical condition of the patient had improved in terms of feeding and physical activity level. At the point of discharge after 10 days in the hospital, the patient's corrected calcium level had reduced to 2.96 mmol/L. The patient was discharged with a prescription of low calcium milk formula and potassium citrate (0.5 mmol three times per day). Furthermore, follow-up appointments with an endocrinologist and nephrologist were also given. Summary of daily laboratory results is gathered and presented in Table 1.

title: 20-year-old male with multiple gunshot wounds leading to a left axillo-subclavia
chief_complaint: The patient presented to the trauma bay after sustaining multiple gunshot wounds to the left upper and lower extremities.
history: The patient is a previously healthy 20-year-old male with no other significant past medical history, known allergies, or social history described.
presenting_symptoms: Multiple gunshot wounds to the left upper and lower extremities
exam_findings: Diminished left radial pulse.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: CT imaging revealed a left axillo-subclavian injury, lung contusion, and a nondisplaced humerus fracture. CT Angiography showed injury to the left subclavian artery with active contrast extravasation, a large pool of contrast in the axillary artery, an expanding hematoma, and subcutaneous emphysema, creating an asymmetrical enlargement with slight tracheal deviation to the right. No vascular injury to the lower extremity was noted.
diagnosis: Left axillo-subclavian artery injury secondary to multiple gunshot wounds, with associated active extravasation, expanding hematoma, lung contusion, and nondisplaced left humerus fracture.
treatment: Emergent endovascular repair of the left axillo-subclavian injury using three covered stents (one 6 mm x 5 cm stent to the distal left subclavian artery and two stents, 7 mm x 5 cm and 7 mm x 10 cm, to the proximal subclavian and axillary arteries) via common femoral artery access, with intraoperative heparinization. Non-operative management of the left open humerus fracture with 72 hours of intravenous cefazolin. Postoperatively, antiplatelet therapy with aspirin 325 mg and venous thromboembolism prophylaxis with enoxaparin were initiated.
key_learning_points: Evaluation and management of penetrating vascular trauma, specifically axillo-subclavian artery injuries.
Interpretation of CT Angiography findings including extravasation, hematoma, and associated injuries (e.g., lung contusion, subcutaneous emphysema).
Principles and techniques of endovascular repair using covered stents for arterial trauma.
Multidisciplinary approach to complex trauma management involving vascular and orthopedic services.
Post-operative management considerations including antiplatelet therapy and VTE prophylaxis following endovascular stent placement for trauma.
description: 20-year-old male with multiple gunshot wounds leading to a left axillo-subclavian artery injury, successfully managed with emergent endovascular stenting.
clinical_text:
The patient is a previously healthy 20-year-old male who presented to our trauma bay after sustaining multiple gunshot wounds of the left upper and lower extremities. On vascular examination, he had a diminished left radial pulse. Computed Tomography (CT) imaging revealed a left axillo-subclavian injury with an associated lung contusion and nondisplaced humerus fracture. CT Angiography revealed injury to the left subclavian artery, an active area of extravasation with a large pool of contrast in the axillary artery and an expanding hematoma (Fig. 1, Fig. 2, Fig. 3). Imaging did not reveal any vascular injury to the lower extremity.
The patient underwent emergent endovascular repair of this left axillo-subclavian injury. Intraoperatively, selective angiograms better characterized the injury (Fig. 4) and the decision was made to use a covered stent. Access was obtained via the common femoral artery. One 6 mm x 5 cm stent was deployed to the distal left subclavian artery and two stents, 7 mm x 5 cm and a 7 mm x 10 cm, were deployed to the proximal subclavian and axillary arteries. He received heparin throughout the procedure. Completion angiograms were performed to rule out an endoleak, and to confirm good distal runoff to the upper extremity (Fig. 5). The patient was taken to the ICU postoperatively. He had a palpable left brachial and radial pulse. Orthopedic surgery recommended non-operative management of the left open humerus fracture with 72 h of intravenous cefazolin. Antiplatelet therapy with aspirin 325 mg and venous thromboembolism prophylaxis with enoxaparin were initiated. He was transferred from the ICU to the surgical floor on POD#2 and was discharged to home on POD#5. On follow up the patient had a patent stent graft without endoleak.
image_captions: CT Angiography Chest. A. Coronal view: visualized above is a left subclavian/axillary artery injury with contrast extravasation at the site of injury along the course of the artery coursing out of the neck and in to the left shoulder.
CT Angiography Chest. B. Sagittal view: a large amount of extravasation is seen in the left shoulder area along with an expanding hematoma. Subcutaneous emphysema is also visualized.

CT Angiography Chest. A large, rapidly expanding hematoma creating an asymmetrical enlargement with slight deviation of the trachea to the right - away from the hematoma. Subcutaneous emphysema is noted in this image as well.

title: 70-year-old female with rheumatoid arthritis sustained a subtrochanteric helical
chief_complaint: Seventy-year-old female presented with a subtrochanteric helical fracture of the femur after an accidental fall downstairs.
history: The patient had a history of rheumatoid arthritis for over 10 years, controlled by self-medication. She was underweight with a BMI of 16.53. No other significant medical or family genetic history was reported.
presenting_symptoms: tenderness along longitudinal axis of right lower extremity
percussion pain along longitudinal axis of right lower extremity
flexion shortening and valgus deformity of the right lower extremity
limited functional activities of right lower extremity
exam_findings: Tenderness and percussion pain along the longitudinal axis of the right lower extremity, flexion shortening and valgus deformity of the right lower extremity, obvious pain and swelling of the right hip, and limited functional activities of the right lower extremity. The fractured part had a 'pseudo-joint' morphology.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: Anteroposterior and lateral radiographs of the femur showed a subtrochanteric spiral fracture with proximal posterior rotation, separation, displacement of the broken ends, and angular deformity.
diagnosis: Subtrochanteric helical (spiral) fracture of the femur.
treatment: Minimally invasive incision treatment using a femoral reconstruction intramedullary nail fixation. This involved combined spinal-epidural anesthesia, bed traction, manual reduction of the fracture, an approximately 5 cm incision, reaming of the medullary cavity, implantation of an intramedullary nail with two distal locking nails, and a proximal double half-threaded screw.
key_learning_points: Subtrochanteric helical femur fractures are complex fractures often requiring detailed imaging for characterization.
Minimally invasive intramedullary nailing is a common and effective surgical approach for subtrochanteric femur fractures.
Pre-existing conditions like rheumatoid arthritis and low BMI can be important considerations in fracture management and healing.
description: 70-year-old female with rheumatoid arthritis sustained a subtrochanteric helical femur fracture from a fall, treated with minimally invasive intramedullary nailing.
clinical_text:
The patient was a seventy-year-old female with a subtrochanteric helical fracture of the femur due to a sprain from an accidental fall downstairs (torsion violence), who had a history of rheumatoid arthritis for over 10 years, which was controlled by self-medication. The patient's BMI (Chinese standard) was 45/(1.65) 2 16.53 < 18.4, thin. No other basic diseases and family genetic history were recorded.
Anteroposterior and lateral radiographs of the femur showed a subtrochanteric spiral fracture of the femur with proximal posterior rotation, separation, and displacement of the broken ends and angulation (<PMC10213397_fsurg-10-1172971-g001_A_1_2.webp><PMC10213397_fsurg-10-1172971-g001_B_2_2.webp>). The patient presented with tenderness and percussion pain along the longitudinal axis of the right lower extremity, as well as flexion shortening and valgus deformity of the right lower extremity. The right hip was obviously painful and swollen, and the functional activities of the right lower extremity were limited. The fractured part was similar in morphology to a "pseudo-joint." The patient was positive for percussion pain on the longitudinal axis of the right lower limb. Subtrochanteric Seinsheimer type IIC fracture refers to a distal fracture of the small rotor. The two can be distinguished by x-ray and CT (Computed Tomography).
The patient was admitted to the hospital, and relevant examinations were conducted to exclude any contraindications of surgery. After reading the radiographic images, the surgeon decided to perform a minimally invasive incision treatment using a femoral reconstruction intramedullary nail with the consent of the patient and their family. After successful combined spinal-epidural anesthesia, the patient was placed in the supine position, bed traction of the affected limb was performed, the healthy limb was placed in the lithotomy position, the perineal blocking pad was placed in the groin of the unaffected side:with buttocks of the affected side being placed are as far away as possible:the bed traction was externally rotated under C-arm fluoroscopy, and abduction, manual squeezing, lifting, and pressing were also performed to reset the broken end (three points and one line: the midpoint of the groin-knee-ankle point was positioned on a straight line, and the toes were vertically upturned). After fluoroscopic observation of the alignment, the surgical area was routinely disinfected and covered with sterile towels and a brain surgical skin film. The anatomical projection of the apex of the greater trochanter was determined by hand touch, and an incision of approximately 5 cm was made obliquely from the proximal end to the distal end to the apex of the greater trochanter. Separation forceps were used to separate the surrounding tissues, the fascia was opened longitudinally, and the apex of the greater trochanter was touched. After the needle point was determined by fluoroscopy under the C-arm machine, with the aid of the sleeve, an opener was inserted obliquely at a 45  angle in the direction of the needle to the position of the minor trochanter. After completion, the long guide needle was inserted into the distal end, and the implantation and broken end of the guide needle was observed under the C-arm machine. An electric drill was used to expand the proximal medullary cavity, and then a 6.5-mm drill bit was used to expand the distal medullary cavity. According to the condition of the patient's medullary cavity, the distal medullary cavity was increased by 1 mm. Under the C-arm machine, the intramedullary needle implantation and broken ends were seen by fluoroscopy, and two locking nails were implanted along the distal end of the guide. The intramedullary needle was knocked back to shorten the separation between the broken ends, and the proximal double half-threaded screw was driven along the guide according to the perspective of the C-arm machine, which was satisfactory. After satisfactory surgery, rinse, suture, and bandage the wound. Remove the anesthesia tube and return to the ward.
After the operation, antibiotic treatment was given for 48 h, and intervention treatment for anti-osteoporosis and promoting fracture healing was performed. The patient could stay in bed for 14 days and perform simple standing activities with the aid of an auxiliary device. One month after surgery, simple walking activities could be performed with the aid of an auxiliary device. After three months of surgery, the patient could gradually disengage from the auxiliary tool for autonomous activities. During this period, the patient avoided sitting for a long time to prevent nail peeling during nail cutting. The patient was instructed to undergo a routine X-ray examination at two month after surgery to assess fracture healing, hip joint morphology, and implant status. The patient and their family members did not undergo routine medical examinations as instructed. After two months of surgery, the patient consciously contacted the foreign body in the hip to receive reexamination.
image_captions: (A) Anterior radiograph fracture with angular deformity.
(B) The fracture was significantly displaced, with proximal posterior rotation.

title: 25-year-old man with steroid-resistant Tolosa-Hunt syndrome successfully treated
chief_complaint: A 25-year-old man presented with a 6-month history of persistent, severe retro-orbital and left-sided hemicranial headache.
history: A 25-year-old man presented with a 6-month history of headaches and associated neurological symptoms. No other past medical history, medications, allergies, or social/family history are described.
presenting_symptoms: Persistent numbness of the left forehead
Decreased pinprick sensation over the left forehead
Partial ptosis of the left eye
Weakness of the left inferior oblique
Weakness of the left medial rectus
exam_findings: Partial left third cranial nerve palsy (partial ptosis of the left eye, weakness of left inferior oblique and medial rectus, diplopia on right lateral gaze), no proptosis, normal fundus examination, normal pupillary reflex. Other neurological examination findings were normal.
labs: Blood and CSF studies were normal, including erythrocyte sedimentation rate, CRP, and angiotensin-converting enzyme.
imaging_description: MRI of the brain and orbits revealed a discrete abnormally enhanced signal in the left cavernous sinus. Chest X-ray was normal.
diagnosis: Tolosa-Hunt syndrome (THS), characterized as steroid-resistant due to recurrence with dose reduction and development of side effects at maintenance dose.
treatment: Initial prednisone at 60 mg daily controlled symptoms, but reduction below 50 mg daily caused recurrence. Maintenance on 50 mg daily led to cushingoid features, acne, leg edema, and hyperglycemia. A single intravenous infusion of infliximab 300 mg over 2 hours resulted in resolution of pain and ophthalmoplegia, decreased forehead numbness, and allowed complete steroid taper without relapse for 8 months.
key_learning_points: Tolosa-Hunt syndrome (THS) is an idiopathic granulomatous inflammation of the cavernous sinus, typically presenting with unilateral headache and ipsilateral ophthalmoplegia, usually responsive to steroids.
Steroid-resistant THS can occur, necessitating alternative treatments due to symptom relapse or intolerable side effects from prolonged high-dose steroid therapy.

Infliximab, a TNF-alpha antibody, may be an effective treatment for steroid-resistant Tolosa-Hunt syndrome, potentially allowing complete steroid withdrawal with sustained symptom control after a single infusion.
description: 25-year-old man with steroid-resistant Tolosa-Hunt syndrome successfully treated with a single infusion of infliximab, achieving complete steroid withdrawal and sustained remission.
clinical_text:
We describe a 25-year-old man who presented with a 6-month history of persistent, daily, severe, retro-orbital and left-sided hemicranial headache that was associated with persistent numbness of the left forehead and decreased pinprick sensation over that region. He exhibited partial left-third nerve palsy expressed as partial ptosis of the left eye, weakness of the left inferior oblique and medial rectus, and diplopia on right lateral gaze. There was no proptosis, and a fundus examination produced normal findings. He had a normal pupillary reflex. The other findings of the neurological examination were normal.
MRI of the brain and orbits revealed a discrete abnormally enhanced signal in the left cavernous sinus. The findings of blood and CSF studies were normal, including for erythrocyte sedimentation rate, CRP, and angiotensin-converting enzyme. His chest X-ray was normal. The lesion was too small to perform a biopsy. The diagnosis of Tolosa-Hunt syndrome (THS) was based on the unilateral headache, preceding paresis of the ipsilateral cranial nerves, granulomatous enhanced lesion in the cavernous sinus on MRI imaging, and absence of other clinical or radiographic signs or symptoms fulfilling the International Classification of Headache Disorders.
The patient was started on prednisone at 60 mg daily, which controlled his symptoms. However, reducing the dose to below 50 mg resulted in the immediate recurrence of headache and diplopia. The patient was therefore maintained on 50 mg daily, but developed cushingoid features, acne, leg edema, and hyperglycemia. Tapering the dose by 10 mg per month resulted in symptom relapse after the second or third month. The patient was then infused with 300 mg of infliximab over 2 hours. The pain subsided the following day followed by resolution of the ophthalmoplegia. The numbness in the forehead decreased but did not subside completely. It was possible to taper the steroids completely without any relapse of his symptoms even at an 8-month follow-up. The patient did not experience any side effects of infliximab, and was asymptomatic on follow-up without requiring another dose.
THS is an idiopathic disorder characterized by subacute, severe, persistent, orbital and retro-orbital pain together with ophthalmoplegia. It is associated with the presence of granulation tissue in the anterior cavernous sinus or superior orbital fissure. It usually responds to steroid therapy with good control of the symptoms. Nevertheless, there are occasional cases of THS that do not respond adequately to steroids or that require prolonged, high-dose treatment that produces serious side effects. Other therapies that have been applied to control this condition include methotrexate, mycophenylate mofetil, and radiotherapy, but these interventions also have side effects.
Infliximab is a tumor necrosis factor-alpha antibody that induces proinflammatory cytokines and acute-phase reactants, enhances leukocyte migration, and activates neutrophils and eosinophils. It is used to treat inflammatory conditions including orbital inflammatory diseases, and was reported to successfully control the symptoms in a patient with THS resistant to steroid therapy. It is administered intravenously at a dose of 3-5 mg/kg per infusion.
In rare conditions infliximab can cause mild headache and fatigue, low-grade fever, myalgia, arthralgia, abdominal pain, and slight elevations in liver-function tests.
The dramatic and persistent improvement in the symptoms in the present case along with the patient being able to stop steroids completely raises the issue of whether infliximab should be added early when treating patients with steroid-resistant THS. Furthermore, our patient required only a single infusion to control his symptoms even with a prolonged follow-up, in contrast to the first case reported who received four infusions, which suggests that a controlled study should be performed to standardize the use of infliximab in THS, rather than copying the regimen used in other inflammatory disorders.

title: Male patient diagnosed with sigmoid perforation secondary to gallstone impaction
chief_complaint: Not described in this case.
history: Not described in this case.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: Figure 1 demonstrated sigmoid perforation secondary to gallstone impaction in the sigmoid colon.
diagnosis: Sigmoid perforation secondary to gallstone impaction in the sigmoid colon, leading to widespread feculent peritonitis.
treatment: Hartmann's procedure was performed.
key_learning_points: Gallstone impaction can cause sigmoid colon perforation, an uncommon form of gallstone ileus.
Feculent peritonitis secondary to sigmoid perforation is a surgical emergency requiring definitive intervention like Hartmann's procedure.
Postoperative hemodynamic instability is a serious complication that can lead to mortality in critically ill surgical patients.
description: Male patient diagnosed with sigmoid perforation secondary to gallstone impaction, who underwent Hartmann's procedure but passed away on the third postoperative day due to hemodynamic instability.
clinical_text: On February 2023, he was diagnosed with sigmoid perforation secondary to gallstone impaction in the sigmoid colon (Figure 1). The patient underwent Hartmann's procedure due to sigmoid perforation and widespread feculent peritonitis. Given concerns about haemodynamic instability demonstrated during the operation, he transferred after the operation to the intensive care unit. The patient passed away on the third postoperative day due to complications of haemodynamic instability.

title: 27-year-old male with progressive back pain, sciatica, and voiding difficulty du
chief_complaint: One year history of back pain, right sciatica, and voiding difficulty.
history: A 27-year-old vegan gentleman with no pets. He was evaluated in 2003 for back pain, when an MRI showed a small sacral cystic lesion, initially presumed to be a Tarlov's cyst, with no neurological deficits. He has no history of back injury.
exam_findings: Weakness of right foot, hypoesthesia of dermatomes below L5. No significant restriction of straight leg raise (SLR).
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: 2003 MRI T2W showed a small cystic lesion of the sacrum, presumed to be a Tarlov's cyst. 2007 MRI T2W showed significant enlargement of the previous sacral cystic lesion with heterogeneous intensity, inhomogeneous contents, and extension into the presacral space and spinal canal. Postoperatively, a myelo CT scan did not reveal any cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leak, and X-ray chest and ultrasound abdomen did not reveal any other cysts. Seven months post-surgery, an MRI T2W showed a collapsed cyst with no intracystic contents or epidural compression.
diagnosis: Spinal Hydatid Cyst (Echinococcosis) confirmed by surgical findings of multiple daughter cysts (initial working diagnosis was a cystic bone tumor).
treatment: L5 to S2 laminectomy and total excision of the cyst. The cyst cavity was irrigated by 1% formalin. Laparoscopic inspection was performed to rule out intrapelvic extension. A negative suction drain was placed and retained for 12 days. Postoperatively, the patient received albendazole 800 mg/day for two months.
key_learning_points: Spinal hydatid cysts are a rare but important differential diagnosis for progressive cystic lesions of the spine, especially when neurological deficits develop.
The presence of daughter cysts on surgical inspection is pathognomonic for hydatid disease.
Treatment for spinal hydatidosis typically involves radical surgical excision combined with anti-parasitic chemotherapy (e.g., albendazole) to prevent recurrence.
Initial imaging findings, like those of a Tarlov's cyst, can sometimes mask a more aggressive underlying pathology.
description: 27-year-old male with progressive back pain, sciatica, and voiding difficulty due to an enlarging sacral hydatid cyst, successfully treated with surgical excision and albendazole.
clinical_text:
A gentleman aged 27 years presented with back pain, right sciatica and voiding difficulty for last one year. In 2003 he was evaluated elsewhere for back pain when he did not have neurological deficits. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) at that time showed small cystic lesion in sacrum and no active treatment was offered [<PMC3137835_JNRP-1-43-g001_undivided_1_1.webp>]. He is a vegan, has no pets at home and never had back injury.
On presentation to our clinic his neurological examination revealed weakness of right foot and hypoesthesia of dermatomes below L5. There was no significant restriction of straight leg raise (SLR). A repeat MRI done in 2007 showed significant increase in size of cyst with inhomogeneous contents [<PMC3137835_JNRP-1-43-g002_undivided_1_1.webp>]. Our working diagnosis was a cystic bone tumor.
He underwent L5 to S2 laminectomy and excision of cyst. Cyst was lined by thin fibrous wall and had eroded laminae of S2. Inner lining of cyst was white with multiple daughter cysts within [<PMC3137835_JNRP-1-43-g003_undivided_1_1.webp>]. The fluid was clear. A few types of sediments were also present. The cyst cavity was irrigated by formalin 1%. No adverse reaction occurred during surgery. Cyst was totally excised and laparoscopic inspection was done to look for intrapelvic extension and confirm completion of excision. A negative suction drain was placed in the space left behind after excision of cyst.
Postoperatively, he had persistent watery discharge. A myelo computerized tomography (CT) scan of spine did not reveal any cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leak. The drain was retained for 12 days and leak subsided. X-ray chest and ultrasound examination of abdomen did not reveal any other cysts. He received albendazole 800 mg / day for two months. An MRI was done seven months after surgery showed collapsed cyst [<PMC3137835_JNRP-1-43-g004_undivided_1_1.webp>]. At the last follow-up after 16 months of surgery he was asymptomatic.
image_captions: MRI T2W, done in 2003 shows a small cystic lesion of sacrum, which was presumed to be Tarlov's cyst.
MRI T2W, done in 2007 shows enlargement of previous sacral cystic lesion with heterogeneous intensity and extension into presacral space and spinal canal.
MRI T2W done after seven months of surgery shows collapsed cyst. There are no intracystic contents. There is no epidural compression.

title: A 26-year-old male presented with a 2.5-year history of a painless frontal scalp
chief_complaint: A 26-year-old male presented with a 2.5-year history of headache and a raised, painless lesion on his left frontal region.
history: Not described in this case report. No relevant past medical history, medications, allergies, social or family history were provided.
presenting_symptoms: raised lesion on left frontal region
painless lesion on left frontal region
exam_findings: Physical examination revealed a single, skin-colored, firm nodule, 7 cm in diameter, with a fixated base, located on the left frontal region.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: A contrast head CT scan was performed, which revealed a mass measuring 7 x 6 x 5 cm.
diagnosis: Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP)
treatment: Wide local excision with a 2-cm margin of normal appearing scalp was performed.
key_learning_points: Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) is a rare, locally aggressive soft tissue tumor typically presenting as a raised, painless skin lesion.
Histopathological features of DFSP include a densely cellular, poorly circumscribed tumor with uniform spindle cells arranged in a 'storiform' or 'cartwheel' pattern.
Immunohistochemistry is crucial for DFSP diagnosis, with tumor cells typically showing positivity for vimentin and CD-34.
Wide local excision with adequate surgical margins is the primary treatment for DFSP to prevent local recurrence.
description: A 26-year-old male presented with a 2.5-year history of a painless frontal scalp lesion, ultimately diagnosed as Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) via wide excision and histopathology.
clinical_text:
We present a case of a 26-year-old male, who complained of headache with a raised, painless lesion on his left frontal region [<PMC4014828_SNI-5-45-g001_a_1_4.webp><PMC4014828_SNI-5-45-g001_b_2_4.webp><PMC4014828_SNI-5-45-g001_c_3_4.webp><PMC4014828_SNI-5-45-g001_d_4_4.webp>] since 2.5 years before admission. On physical examination, there was a single, skin colored, firm nodule, measuring 7 cm in diameter, with a fixated base. An excision biopsy was suggested to diagnose the tumor and to predict tumor behavior. A 2-cm margin of normal appearing scalp is incised down to the underlying periosteum, wide range of the incision was taken since the propensity of tumor spread along their facial planes; followed by undermining the defect with blunt-tipped scissors after removal of the specimen to minimize tension on the wound margin. Subsequently, an excision biopsy was performed, and final diagnosis of DFSP was made based on the histopathological findings. Hematoxylin and eosin stained sections showed a densely cellular and poorly circumscribed tumor in the dermis layer, comprising of interwoven bundles and fascicles of uniform spindle-shaped cells arranged in "storiform" or "cartwheel" pattern [<PMC4014828_SNI-5-45-g002_a_1_4.webp><PMC4014828_SNI-5-45-g002_b_2_4.webp>]. The tumor cells had monotonous appearance with oval nuclei, vesicular chromatin, inconspicuous nucleoli, and scanty to moderate cytoplasm [<PMC4014828_SNI-5-45-g002_b_2_4.webp>]. A panel of immunohistochemistry (IHC) comprising vimentin and CD-34 was applied. Tumor cells were positive for both vimentin and CD-34, respectively [<PMC4014828_SNI-5-45-g002_c_3_4.webp><PMC4014828_SNI-5-45-g002_d_4_4.webp>].
He was discharged from our hospital uneventfully, and no recurrence of the mass was detected at 1-year follow-up.
image_captions: (b) Contrast head CT scan.
(d) Mass size 7 x 6 x 5 cm.
(a) Section showing spindle cells arranged in short fascicles and storiform pattern (Hematoxylin and eosin, x10).

title: Four older patients (70-81 years) with severe CKD stage 3 or 4 and comorbidities
chief_complaint: Management of severe chronic kidney disease (CKD) accompanied by comorbidities.
history: Four patients aged 70-81 years with CKD stage 3 or 4, accompanied by several comorbidities, most notably diabetes and hypertension. One patient had severe CKD stage 4 with a baseline eGFR <20 ml/min/1.73 m2. Treatment and follow-up durations were 6-7 years.
exam_findings: Not described in this case.
labs: Baseline eGFR (as low as <20 ml/min/1.73 m2 for one patient) and follow-up eGFR, serum creatinine, and other renal chemistry parameters were monitored.
imaging_description: Figures 1 and 2 are mentioned but their content is not described in the text or available captions.
diagnosis: Severe chronic kidney disease (CKD) stage 3 or 4, accompanied by diabetes and hypertension.
treatment: Multifactorial treatment approach for severe CKD, with specific regimens detailed in Table 2 (not provided).
key_learning_points: Successful management of severe chronic kidney disease (CKD) is achievable with a multifactorial treatment approach, even in elderly patients.
The importance of addressing comorbidities like diabetes and hypertension in the comprehensive management of CKD.
Monitoring eGFR, serum creatinine, and other renal chemistry parameters is crucial for assessing CKD progression and treatment efficacy.
description: Four older patients (70-81 years) with severe CKD stage 3 or 4 and comorbidities (diabetes, hypertension) underwent successful long-term management with a multifactorial approach.
clinical_text: The 4 cases presented herein were selected retrospectively to illustrate the author's experience of successful management of severe CKD using a multifactorial treatment approach. The 4 patients described were 70-81 years old with CKD stage 3 or 4, accompanied by several comorbidities, most notably diabetes and hypertension. One patient had severe CKD stage 4 with a baseline eGFR <20 ml/min/1.73 m2. Treatment and follow-up durations were 6-7 years. Clinical characteristics and comorbidities are presented along with treatment regimens and final outcomes with respect to CKD progression (eGFR and/or serum creatinine plus other on-treatment renal chemistry parameters) in table 2 and figure 1 and figure 2. The patients provided written informed consent for the anonymous publication of their clinical data.

title: A 54-year-old female presented with rapidly progressing acute myelopathy, initia
chief_complaint: A 54-year-old female presented with acute paresthesias and mild weakness of the left leg that rapidly progressed to severe weakness and loss of bladder function.
history: The patient is a 54-year-old Caucasian female without relevant medical history.
exam_findings: Clinical exam revealed an atactic paresis of the left leg graded 4/5 on the MRC scale, pathologically increased tendon reflexes in the lower limbs, and an absent Babinski's response. There was a loss of superficial sensation below the T6 dermatome, most pronounced on the left side, and diminished sense of vibration, touch, and position in the left leg. Sphincter pressure was decreased with 150 mL residue after micturition.
labs: Laboratory exams including ESR, CRP, vitamin B12, ACE, TSH, and serology for CMV, EBV, Lyme, Treponema pallidum, thyroperoxidase, thyroglobulin, antinuclear, anti-extractable nuclear antigen, anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic, lupus anticoagulant, AQP4, MOG, and paraneoplastic antibodies were within normal limits or negative. Visual evoked potentials showed delayed latencies (p100: left 120 ms, right 122 ms). CSF analysis showed normal cell count, mild elevation of protein levels, and no oligoclonal bands.
imaging_description: Initial spinal MRI showed a calcified Th8-9 disc herniation slightly indenting the anterior cord without cord abnormalities. Repeat MRI the day after surgery demonstrated multiple hyperintense intramedullary lesions. Repeat MRI 10 days after symptom onset revealed a clearly demarcated T2 hyperintense lesion in the posterior cord extending from T5 to T10, with partial contrast enhancement. Cranial MRI was normal. MRI after three months showed a marked decrease in cord abnormalities with no contrast enhancement.
diagnosis: Spinal cord ischemia.
treatment: Emergency laminectomy of the eighth thoracic vertebra was performed with transpedicular removal of the partly calcified disc. The patient received high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone followed by an oral maintenance dose, and azathioprine which was later discontinued. The patient underwent rehabilitation.
key_learning_points: Acute myelopathy requires a broad differential diagnosis, including compressive, inflammatory, and ischemic etiologies.
Initial imaging findings may be misleading, and repeat imaging is crucial in evolving neurological deficits.
Spinal cord ischemia should be considered in cases of acute myelopathy, even when other findings (like disc herniation) are present.
Careful interpretation of ancillary tests (e.g., VEPs, CSF) is essential to avoid misdiagnosis and guide management.
description: A 54-year-old female presented with rapidly progressing acute myelopathy, initially attributed to a calcified disc herniation but later diagnosed as spinal cord ischemia after extensive workup.
clinical_text:
A 54-year-old Caucasian female without relevant medical history noticed acute paresthesias and mild weakness of the left leg in the evening before admission. When she awakened at night she noticed that the weakness had progressed and that she had lost control of bladder function. On admission, she also complained of acute severe pain on the thorax, paresthesias and weakness of the right leg, and she reported diffuse pain in the left leg. In the weeks previous to presentation she had been experiencing a different sensation on the left side of her thorax. Clinical exam revealed an atactic paresis of the left leg graded 4/5 on the MRC scale. Tendon reflexes were pathologically increased in the lower limbs, and Babinski's response was absent. There was a loss of superficial sensation below the T6 dermatome, most pronounced on the left side, and there was diminished sense of vibration, touch and position in the left leg. Her sphincter pressure was decreased, and there was 150 mL residue after micturition.
Spinal MRI showed a calcified Th8-9disc herniation which slightly indented the anterior cord without cord abnormalities (Figure 1). The paresis progressed to grade 1 of the left leg and grade 2 of the right leg within two hours. Emergency laminectomy of the eighth thoracic vertebra was performed that same night. Due to rapid deterioration no further (time-consuming) diagnostic procedures (eg additional imaging) were carried out prior to surgery. The partly calcified disc was removed through a transpedicular approach until there was no more spinal cord compression. Surgery was uneventful. Of note, because of the emergency setting, intra-operative neuromonitoring was not available. The day after surgery the paresis improved slightly, and there was no further deterioration of neurological function. Repeat MRI performed the day after surgery demonstrated multiple hyperintense intramedullary lesions (Figure 1). Therefore, acute myelitis (possibly neuromyelitis optica spectrum disease, NMOSD) was considered as a differential diagnosis, and treatment with high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone was initiated, followed by oral maintenance dose. Repeat MRI 10 days after symptom onset revealed a clearly demarcated T2 hyperintense lesion in the posterior cord extending from the fifth to the tenth thoracic vertebrae, with partial contrast enhancement (Figure 1). Cranial MRI was normal.
The results of additional laboratory exams including erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein, vitamin B12, angiotensin-converting enzyme, and thyroid-stimulating hormone. Serology for CMV, EBV, Lyme, and Treponema pallidum and thyroperoxidase, thyroglobulin, antinuclear, anti-extractable nuclear antigen, anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic, lupus anticoagulant, aquaporin-4 (AQP4), myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (MOG) and paraneoplastic antibodies were within normal limits or negative. Visual evoked potentials showed delayed latencies (p100: left 120 ms, right 122 ms). The last-mentioned finding led to a possible diagnosis of neuromyelitis optica (NMO), and the patient was started on azathioprine for long-term immunosuppression. However, repeat ophthalmologic exam revealed no abnormalities, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis showed normal cell count, mild elevation of protein levels and no oligoclonal bands. Therefore the azathioprine was discontinued. At this point, the patient was referred for a second opinion, and spinal cord ischemia was established as the most likely diagnosis.
The patient was transferred to the division of rehabilitation. After three months the patient was able to walk short distances with a walker. MRI showed a marked decrease in cord abnormalities, and contrast enhancement was no longer present (Figure 1). Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report. Institutional approval was not required to publish the case details.

title: A 66-year-old male presented with sudden right hemiplegia and dysarthria due to
chief_complaint: A sudden onset of right hemiplegia and dysarthria.
history: A 66-year-old male with a significant smoking history of 30 cigarettes/day for 45 years. No other significant past medical history, medications, allergies, or family history were reported.
presenting_symptoms: right upper and lower extremity paresthesia
exam_findings: Right facial paralysis, dysarthria, right upper extremity paralysis, right upper and lower extremity paresthesia, and a National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score of 6/42.
labs: Not described in this case.
imaging_description: MRI DWI showed slightly high signal areas in the left putamen, corona radiata, and middle cerebral artery region. MRA revealed an occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery, with T2-weighted images showing no obvious thrombi in the occluded area. Subsequent internal carotid arteriography confirmed distal left MCA occlusion, with collateral blood flow from the anterior to the middle cerebral arteries via pial anastomosis in the delayed phase. Post-thrombectomy imaging showed immediate flow restoration but persistent arterial stenosis (proximal 2.6 mm, distal 2.1 mm). Angioplasty initially achieved temporary recanalization, followed by restenosis, and then successful peripheral perfusion with a specialized coronary perfusion balloon.
diagnosis: Acute ischemic stroke due to left middle cerebral artery occlusion caused by Intracranial Atherosclerotic Disease (ICAD).
treatment: Intravenous alteplase therapy was administered after managing hypotension with nicardipine. This was followed by endovascular recanalization (mechanical thrombectomy) using a Trevo XP ProVue Retriever. Post-thrombectomy, the patient received crushed aspirin and clopidogrel. Angioplasty was performed using a Gateway balloon catheter, and due to restenosis, a prolonged angioplasty was subsequently attempted with a Ryusei coronary perfusion balloon.
key_learning_points: Understanding the acute management of large vessel occlusion stroke, including IV thrombolysis and mechanical thrombectomy.
Recognizing and managing acute ischemic stroke complicated by underlying Intracranial Atherosclerotic Disease (ICAD), which can lead to persistent stenosis despite initial recanalization.
Applying advanced endovascular techniques, such as angioplasty with specialized perfusion balloons, for complex intracranial stenosis in the acute setting.
Appreciating the role and significance of collateral circulation in maintaining cerebral perfusion during acute stroke.
description: A 66-year-old male presented with sudden right hemiplegia and dysarthria due to acute left middle cerebral artery occlusion from Intracranial Atherosclerotic Disease, managed with IV thrombolysis, mechanical thrombectomy, and complex angioplasty for persistent stenosis.
clinical_text:
66-years-old male.
A sudden onset of the right hemiplegia and dysarthria.
Nothing significant.
Smoked 30 cigarettes/day for 45 years.
At 7:30 a.m. while driving, the patient suddenly experienced right hemiplegia and dysarthria and was rushed to our hospital.
Right facial paralysis, dysarthria, right upper extremity paralysis, right upper and lower extremity paresthesia, and National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score 6/42.
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) showed slightly high signal areas in the left putamen, corona radiata, and part of the middle cerebral artery region. Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) showed an occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery [<PMC10629293_SNI-14-365-g001_a_1_4.webp><PMC10629293_SNI-14-365-g001_b_2_4.webp>]. The T2-weighted images showed no obvious thrombi in the occluded area.
The patient was admitted to the hospital at 8:25 a.m. Based on the MRI findings, we determined that there was a mismatch between the perfusion area of the left middle cerebral artery and the high signal DWI lesion. An intravenous alteplase therapy was deemed appropriate without any cautionary or contraindicated items as per the guidelines. Alteplase was administered at 9:27 a.m. following the management of hypotension with nicardipine. The primary strategy was to pursue an endovascular recanalization.
A 9 Fr sheath was placed in the right femoral artery, and a 9 Fr OPTIMO (Tokai Medical Products, Aichi, Japan) was guided into the left internal carotid artery. Internal carotid arteriography revealed that the left middle cerebral artery was distally occluded [<PMC10629293_SNI-14-365-g001_c_3_4.webp>]. In the delayed phase, an anastomosis of the cerebral pia mater provided the collateral blood flow from the anterior to the middle cerebral arteries [<PMC10629293_SNI-14-365-g001_d_4_4.webp>]. The rebar (Medtronic, Minneapolis, MN, USA) was guided distal to the occlusion with a CHIKAI 14 200 cm (Asahi Intec, Aichi, Japan) to secure the distal vessel, and a Trevo XP ProVue Retriever 4.0 x 30 mm (Stryker, Kalamazoo, MI, USA) was deployed. The post deployment imaging showed an immediate flow restoration but poor stent dilation in the occluded area, suggestive of arterial stenosis [<PMC10629293_SNI-14-365-g002_a_1_3.webp>].
The proximal and distal diameters of the stenosis were 2.6 mm and 2.1 mm, respectively [<PMC10629293_SNI-14-365-g002_b_2_3.webp>]. After retrieving the Trevo, a 1-min amount of thrombus was retrieved. Although reperfusion was achieved, a significant degree of stenosis persisted [<PMC10629293_SNI-14-365-g002_c_3_3.webp>]. A diagnosis of ICAD was established, and an angioplasty using a balloon catheter was proposed.
Crushed aspirin and clopidogrel (300 mg each) were administered orally. A 6 Fr Cerulean catheter DD6 113 cm (Medikit, Tokyo, Japan) was guided to the pyramidal segment of the internal carotid artery as a distal access catheter. Subsequently, a Gateway 2.0 x 12 mm monorail (Stryker, Kalamazoo, Michigan, USA) was placed at the stenosis region using a CHIKAI. A gradual dilatation and retraction were performed under nominal pressure [<PMC10629293_SNI-14-365-g003_a_1_3.webp>]. Subsequent imaging revealed a temporary recanalization [<PMC10629293_SNI-14-365-g003_b_2_3.webp>]; however, restenosis was observed after 7 min [<PMC10629293_SNI-14-365-g003_c_3_3.webp>].
The strategy was to use a coronary perfusion balloon for prolonged angioplasty while maintaining the peripheral perfusion. Ryusei 2.5 x 20 mm monorail (Kaneka Medix, Osaka, Japan) was navigated toward the stenotic lesion. After dilating to 2 atm, the wire was drawn anterior to the proximal perfusion hole, and the perfusion lumen was subsequently unsealed [<PMC10629293_SNI-14-365-g004_a_1_4.webp>].
The angiography performed in this state showed that peripheral perfusion was achieved using balloon dilation [<PMC10629293_SNI-14-365-g004_b_2_4.webp><PMC10629293_SNI-14-365-g004_c_3_4.webp>]. The patient was maintained in this state for 15 min, during which intermittent angiography was performed to monitor the patency of the perfusion lumen. Ozagrel sodium 80 mg was administered intravenously. The Ryusei was then deflated and adequate vascular dilation was observed [<PMC10629293_SNI-14-365-g004_d_4_4.webp>]. After an additional waiting period of 20 min, we confirmed the absence of restenosis and concluded the procedure.
Heparin was administered while monitoring activated clotting time (ACT) during the procedure, with a minimum ACT value of 200. The total dose was 6,000 units.
The patient's symptoms resolved to an NIHSS score of 0 on the day after the procedure. Postoperative echocardiography and electrocardiography revealed no evidence of cardiogenic cerebral embolism. Based on the intraoperative findings, the patient was diagnosed with ICAD. Postoperatively, aspirin 100 mg and clopidogrel 75 mg prescriptions were continued, and cilostazol 200 mg and atorvastatin 10 mg were added. Postoperative MRI showed a clearly defined high signal DWI without significant enlargement of the infarcted area [<PMC10629293_SNI-14-365-g005_a_1_3.webp>] and although a mild stenosis remained, the MRA also showed a satisfactory peripheral perfusion [<PMC10629293_SNI-14-365-g005_b_2_3.webp>].
The patient was discharged without a neurological deficit on the 7th day.
Clopidogrel medication was discontinued at discharge. Three months later, the MRA indicated an improvement in the stenosis [<PMC10629293_SNI-14-365-g005_c_3_3.webp>], and the patient was prescribed antithrombotic therapy with cilostazol as a single agent. No specific events were observed for more than 1 year after the procedure.
An application for an unapproved new medical device was submitted to the hospital's committee for the evaluation of highly difficult new medical technology, and approval was obtained. Furthermore, during patient consultations regarding surgical procedures, we explicitly conveyed that we may employ nonconforming medical devices if adequate substitutions proved arduous and secured informed consent accordingly.
image_captions: (a) Magnetic resonance imaging diffusion weighted imaging at initial onset. Diffuse high-intensity signals are observed in the left corona radiata and middle cerebral artery.
(b) Magnetic resonance angiography, left middle cerebral artery occlusion.
Digital subtraction angiography, left internal carotid angiography,. Is the early phase.

title: A 22-year-old G0P0 woman presented with amenorrhea and vaginal bleeding, initial
chief_complaint: Cessation of menstruation for 73 days and slight vaginal bleeding for 4 days.
history: A 22-year-old married woman, gravida 0, para 0. She did not comply with weekly beta-hCG assessments for surveillance after initial molar evacuations. No other relevant PMH, medications, allergies, social or family history described.
exam_findings: Initially, a small amount of blood in the vagina and an abnormally enlarged, soft uterus. During an acute event, blood pressure was 76/48 mmHg and pulse rate 116 bpm.
labs: Initial serum beta-hCG: 582,621 mIU/ml. One week after 1st S&C: beta-hCG 8,407 mIU/ml. After 2nd S&C: beta-hCG 5,718 mIU/ml. 21 days after 2nd S&C: beta-hCG 183,309 mIU/ml. 39 days after 2nd S&C: beta-hCG 489,190 mIU/ml. Hemoglobin concentration: 7.9 g/dL (during acute bleeding). Day after MTX & UAE: serum beta-hCG 83,530 mIU/ml, hemoglobin 8.2 g/dL. After 1st EMACO cycle: serum beta-hCG 894.2 mIU/ml. Normalized after 5th EMACO cycle.
imaging_description: Transabdominal ultrasound showed a uterus 10.4 x 11.0 x 7.7 cm with an uneven echo area of 8.7 x 6.6 cm in the uterine cavity, described as 'falling snow'. Subsequent ultrasound showed a residual uterine lesion (2 x 1.5 cm). Later ultrasound showed the uterus 9.2 x 8.9 x 7.8 cm, an uneven echo area of 6.9 x 5.2 cm near the fundus, loss of normal muscle layer in the convex anterior wall, and outer margin 0.24 cm from the serosa. Pelvic MRI showed an enlarged uterus with multiple cystic mixed abnormal signals (7.1 x 6.1 x 8.2 cm) in the left anterior wall, extending from muscular to serosal layer. Chest and cranial CT scans detected no metastatic lesions. Emergency abdominal ultrasound showed acute intra-abdominal bleeding (approximately 2,000 ml).
diagnosis: Complete hydatidiform mole, which progressed to an invasive mole (FIGO stage I, WHO score 6, low-risk GTN), complicated by acute intra-abdominal bleeding due to uterine rupture.
treatment: Two suction and curettage procedures. Subsequently, due to acute hemorrhage, uterine artery embolization was performed, and 35 mg of methotrexate was administered bilaterally through the uterine arteries. Four units of packed red blood cells were transfused twice. Followed by EMACO chemotherapy (etoposide, methotrexate, dactinomycin, cyclophosphamide, and vincristine).
key_learning_points: Diagnosis and initial management of complete hydatidiform mole, including post-evacuation beta-hCG surveillance.
Importance of patient compliance with follow-up to detect gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) progression.
Recognition and management of invasive mole, including FIGO staging and WHO scoring.
Management of acute, life-threatening complications like uterine rupture and hemorrhage in GTN.
Multimodal treatment strategies for GTN, combining chemotherapy, uterine artery embolization, and blood transfusion.
Consideration of fertility preservation in young patients with GTN.
description: A 22-year-old G0P0 woman presented with amenorrhea and vaginal bleeding, initially diagnosed with a complete hydatidiform mole that progressed to an invasive mole, complicated by acute uterine rupture and hemorrhage, requiring multi-modal treatment including chemotherapy and uterine artery embolization.
clinical_text:
A 22-year-old woman (married, gravida 0, para 0) presented to our department with cessation of menstruation for 73 days and slight vaginal bleeding for 4 days. She reported no nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, or bloating. Physical examination revealed a small amount of blood in the vagina and an abnormally enlarged, soft uterus. The serum beta-hCG was 582,621 mIU/ml. Transabdominal ultrasound showed the uterus was 10.4 x 11.0 x 7.7 cm, with an uneven echo area of 8.7 x 6.6 cm in the uterine cavity, which looked like falling snow. The patient underwent suction and curettage, and a pathological examination revealed a complete hydatidiform mole. A week later, an ultrasound examination suggested a residual lesion in the uterine cavity (2 x 1.5 cm), and the beta-hCG was 8,407 mIU/ml. Subsequently, she underwent a second suction and curettage, and the beta-hCG level further decreased to 5,718 mIU/ml ( Figure 1 ). The results of the second pathological examination were consistent with those of the first ( Figure 2 ).
The patient was then recommended weekly beta-hCG assessments for surveillance. However, she did not comply with the follow-up schedule. Within 21 days after the second molar evacuation, her serum beta-hCG level was elevated to 183,309 mIU/ml, despite an unremarkable ultrasonography examination. She didn't take the high hCG level seriously so that she forgot to consult doctor in time. After that, the beta-hCG level continued to rise, reaching 489,190 mIU/ml on day 39 after the second procedure. An ultrasonography examination showed that the uterus was 9.2 x 8.9 x 7.8 cm in size, an uneven echo area of 6.9 x 5.2 cm was near the fundus of the uterine cavity, the convex anterior wall had lost its normal muscle layer, and the outer margin was about 0.24 cm from the serosal layer ( Figure 3A ). Pelvic magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed an enlarged uterus with multiple cystic mixed abnormal signals in the left anterior wall. The lesion was about 7.1 x 6.1 x 8.2 cm, extending from the muscular layer to the serosal layer ( Figure 4 ). The patient was diagnosed with an invasive mole. Chest and cranial CT scans were performed, and no metastatic lesions were detected. These findings indicated an invasive mole at stage I according to the FIGO 2000, with a World Health Organization (WHO) score of 6, and belonged to the low-risk GTN.
The patient was very young and had the willing to perserve her fertility, and we proposed methotrexate (MTX) chemotherapy. The day before the planned chemotherapy, she experienced sudden abdominal pain accompanied by shortness of breath, blood pressure of 76/48 mmHg, and a pulse rate of 116 bpm. An emergency abdominal ultrasound scan showed acute intra-abdominal bleeding (approximately 2,000 ml) ( Figures 3B-D ), and blood tests showed a hemoglobin concentration of 7.9 g/dL. We recommended emergency surgery, but she rejected. Given she was experiencing an acute intra-abdominal bleeding which risked her life, then we chose to perform the MTX chemical therapy and uterine artery embolization simultaneously which can suppress the tumor and stop bleeding at the same time, and is a relative conventional way to stop bleeding in a short time. So uterine artery embolization was performed, and 35 mg of MTX was administered bilaterally through the uterine arteries. Simultaneously, four units of packed red blood cells (RBCs) were transfused. The next day, the serum beta-hCG decreased to 83,530 mIU/ml, and the hemoglobin concentration was 8.2 g/dL. Four units of packed RBCs were transfused again. There were no signs of persistent intraperitoneal bleeding, and the patient was stable. Seven days later, chemotherapy with etoposide, methotrexate, dactinomycin, cyclophosphamide, and vincristine (EMACO) was administered. After the first cycle, the serum beta-hCG dropped to 894.2 mIU/ml and was normalized after cycle five. Consider the cost and the severe side effects such as myelosuppression, vomiting, hair loss and so on. We decided to use the MTX regimen with 1mg/kg/day intramuscularly on days 1, 3, 5, 7, with folinic acid 0.1 mg/kg/day orally 24 hours after MTX on days 2,4,6,8); repeat every 2 weeks. The patient received two additional courses of chemotherapy with MTX to reduce the risk of relapse. At the 13-month follow-up after therapy completion, the patient was disease free with negative beta-hCG.
Invasive mole is a form of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) that most commonly occurs after the evacuation of a molar pregnancy. Most cases are clinically rather than histologically diagnosed.
Diagnostic methods: The diagnostic criteria for GTN after hydatidiform mole were as follows: The elevated blood beta-hCG level reached a plateau ( +- 10%) for 4 times (day 1, 7, 14, 21), lasting for 3 weeks or longer; The serum beta-hCG level increased (>10%) for 3 consecutive times (day 1, 7, 14) for 2 weeks or longer; The histological diagnosis was invasive hydatidiform mole.
Diagnostic challenges: It is necessary to exclude residual pregnancy (any retained molar tissue/products of conception after suction and curettage) and repeat pregnancy during diagnosis. If it cannot be excluded, it is recommended to repeat suction and curettage, and if necessary, hysteroscopy can be performed.
Diagnosis (including other diagnoses considered): The patient was diagnosed with an invasive mole. Chest and cranial CT scans were performed, and no metastatic lesions were detected. These findings indicated an invasive mole at stage I according to the FIGO 2000, with a World Health Organization (WHO) score of 6.
Prognostic characteristics when applicable: beta-hCG is a reliable indicator of tumor activity. At the 13-month follow-up after therapy completion, the patient was disease free with negative beta-hCG.

title: A 56-year-old Asian woman presented with respiratory distress caused by separate
chief_complaint: A 56-year-old Asian woman presented with respiratory distress and episodes of apnea at night.
history: The patient had a history of hypertension; no other significant medical or family history was noted. Ophthalmologic and dermatologic tests were negative.
exam_findings: Laryngoscopy revealed a 1.5x2.0cm tumor in the left arytenoids area, obscuring the laryngeal inlet, with a protruding parapharynx wall of the left vocal cord and fixed left vocal cord. No enlarged lymph nodes were found in the neck during palpation. Postoperatively, left vocal cord palsy was present.
labs: Histological stain positive for S-100.
imaging_description: Computed tomography (CT) revealed a non-enhancing mass originating from the left arytenoid cartilage and parapharynx, extending to the carotid artery. Axial views showed two separate masses without linkage at the second cervical section.
diagnosis: Plexiform neurofibroma (parapharyngeal mass) and simple neurofibroma (arytenoid mass).
treatment: Surgical removal of the parapharyngeal mass (3.5x5.0cm) via lateral pharyngotomy, and excision of the arytenoid mass (2.0x1.3cm) using a carbon dioxide (CO2) laser. Postoperative injection laryngoplasty was performed for persistent vocal disorder and airway aspiration.
key_learning_points: Neurofibromas, including plexiform and simple types, can manifest as obstructive masses in the head and neck region.
Diagnosis of neurofibromas is supported by S-100 positivity on histology, showing nerve fascicles and bipolar cells.
Surgical management of complex head and neck neurofibromas may require different approaches for separate lesions (e.g., lateral pharyngotomy for parapharyngeal, CO2 laser for laryngeal).
